D., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Harrow; writer, India office, 29th Sept., 1869; geographical department clerk, July, 1873; detached in 1880 to be assistant private secretary, and subsequently, from May, 1884, principal private secretary to H.M.'s, secretary of state, home department (Rt. Hon. Sir William V. Harcourt); secretary to the royal commission on the blind, the deaf and dumb, &c., July, 1885; clerk for geographical records, India office, Sept., 1885; author of the 'Abstracts of the Reports of the Surveys, and of other Geographical Operations in India' from 1873 to 1878.

BLACK, Samuel, Major-General, C.S.I., Bengal S.C.—First commission as ensign, Bengal N.I., Dec., 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49 (medal); from May, 1854, served in the public works department, Lower Provinces, embankment circle; staff officer, Punjab irregular force, Jan., 1857; medal for service in the mutiny; executive engineer, public works department, Punjab, Jan., 1860; military secretary to government, Punjab, March 1862-83.

BLANC, Henri Jules, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 7th Aug., 1859, and served in the military department and also as acting civil surgeon in various stations, and as superintendent of vaccination; served in the China War, 1860-62; was a member of the Abyssinian mission, 1864, and was confined in chains during 21 months by the Emperor Theodore; subsequently joined the expeditionary force, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); superintendent of Yerrowda central jail, April, 1875; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibho Hospital, Bombay, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical College, May, 1876, to Aug., 1882; also acted as professor of anatomy, and curator of the museum, May-June, 1879; physician, European General Hospital from Aug., 1882.

BLANFORD, Henry Francis, Meteorological Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, and was appointed assistant in the geological survey, 1st Oct., 1855; in charge of geological museum, Sept., 1856, to May, 1857; in charge of geological survey party, Madras, May, 1857 to 1860; was subsequently engaged in the Calcutta museum, and in surveying in the Sonthal country; resigned the service, Dec., 1861; appointed professor in the Presidency college, Calcutta, Dec., 1862; 2nd grade, educational department, Jan., 1866; meteorological reporter to
government of Bengal, April, 1867; meteorological reporter to the government of India for the purpose of organising the meteorological department, Jan., 1875; author of numerous reports and monographs, and contributions to scientific journals and societies, including reports on the geology of the Nilgiri Hills, and the cretaceous rocks of the Trichinopoly district ('Memoirs of Geological Survey'), on the Calcutta cyclone of 5th Oct., 1867 (in conjunction with Colonel Gastrell), on the winds of Northern India ('Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society'), and official reports on the meteorology of India, 1875, 1876, 1878 to 1884; is also author of a monograph of the Belemnitidae and Nautilidae of the cretaceous rocks of Southern India, of 'The Rudiments of Physical Geography for the use of Indian Schools,' 'The Indian Meteorologist's Vade Mecum,' and a chart of the average rainfall of India; edited and contributed to the Indian Meteorological Memoirs (2 vols. and 2 parts).

BLATHWAYT, CHARLES GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kanara, Oct., 1882; senior collector, March, 1886.

BLENNERHASSETT, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district judge, 3rd grade, March, 1883.

BLISS, HENRY WILLIAM, B.A., Madras C.S.—Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Feb., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served as commissioner of salt revenue, and of abkari revenue, and was appointed customs collector throughout the Madras Presidency under the Sea Customs Act of 1878, Aug., 1882; on duty to Bombay, Oct., 1879, and to Calcutta and N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, to examine the working of the salt department; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; on duty to Orissa to report on the system of salt administration, Jan., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with the abkari committee, March, 1884; additional member of the board of revenue in addition to his duties as commissioner of salt revenue, Feb., 1886; member of the finance committee under the government of India, April, 1886.

BLISSETT, T., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st March, 1850; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Arracan division, Aug., 1869; personal assistant to director-general, 1873-75; served subsequently in the Dacca and Scinde divisions, and in the store department, and from 1882 in Bombay; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1883.

BLOOMFIELD, ALFRED, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission as ensign, March, 1856; served in the Central Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1867; deputy commissioner, July, 1870; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1876; deputy commissioner, and class, Aug., 1881; author of 'Notes on the Baigas of the Central Provinces,' 1885.

BLYTH, Ven., GEORGE FRANCIS POPHAM, M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Archdeacon of Rangoon, Oct., 1879; retired, 1887.

BLYTH, WILLIAM DUNBAR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1880; officiating under-secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments in 1881 and 1882; under-secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; officiating chief secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1886; officiating inspector-general of registration, July, 1886; 1st inspector of registration offices, Oct., 1886.

BODDAM, WELBY WROUGHTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 12th Dec., 1851; arrived in India, and July, 1852; served with the military police 1857-61; district superintendent of Lahore police, Feb., 1861; deputy inspector-general March, 1878; promoted to 1st grade, May, 1888; officiating inspector-general, Punjab, March, 1883, and again, February, 1885.

BOILEAU, HENRY, Major, B.S.C.—Served under the military department from May, 1865, to April, 1873, when he was appointed officiating assistant commissioner, Burma; on special duty to Mandalay, May, 1873; assistant commissioner, 4th grade, and superintendent of immigration, Sept., 1874; also sub-registrar of deeds, Rangoon, Aug., 1875; on special duty in connection with the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Nov., 1876; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Jan., 1877; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, and small cause court judge, July, 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1885, continuing to be employed as cantonment magistrate; deputy commissioner, Singhbhum, March, 1887.

BOLSTER, J. A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 22nd Feb., 1872.

BOLTON, CHARLES WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, Royal College, Mauritius, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Oct., 1872; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, April, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1879; officiating under secretary, govern-
ment of India, home, revenue, and agricultural department, Feb., 1880; on deputation as under secretary in the judicial, political, and appointments departments, government of Bengal, Feb., 1883; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, in addition to his own duties, March, 1884; officiating magistrate and collector, April, 1884; officiating inspector-general of registration, Oct., 1884; senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Nov., 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1885.

BONAVIA, Emanuel, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th August, 1857; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1857; served under the military department up to Dec., 1861, and was present at the capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, and in the Trans-Gogra campaign; assistant civil surgeon, Lucknow, Dec., 1861; on special duty, May, 1866; health officer, Lucknow, and superintendent of museum, observatory, and horticultural society's garden, April, 1867; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1869; was engaged for some time in 1872 under the military department in analysing drinking water; principal of medical school at Balrampur, in addition to other duties, Jan., 1873; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Sept. to Nov., 1874, and again Jan. to March, 1877, also officiating as inspector-general of prisons, Oudh; officiating civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1877; civil surgeon, Etawah, Dec., 1881; has published works on date culture in India, and "The Villagers' Domestic Medicine," 1885.

BONUS, Joseph, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and storming of Jhansi, the capture of Calpec and Gwalior, and various other operations and engagements (medal and clasp); joined the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer, June, 1859, and was employed on the Bombay harbour defences, Oct., 1860; from Sept., 1867, served as deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind; officiating deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, railway branch, March, 1870; from Nov., 1871, served as superintending engineer on Indus Valley state railway, and officiated as engineer-in-chief, Aug., 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, July, 1873; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, Sept., 1876; transferred to Punjab northern state railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, July-Oct., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Pindi-Peshawur section, Oct., 1879; medal for services in the Afghan War, 1879-80; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1881; acting consulting engineer for railways, and joint secretary to government, Bombay, with temporary rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, May, 1882; and again Aug., 1883, to April, 1886; senior deputy consulting engineer and under secretary to government, railway branch, from Nov., 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885.

BOUGHEY, George Fletcher Ottley, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, June, 1862; arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1863; served in the Bhotan expedition, 1863-66 (medal and clasp); joined the public works department, Nov., 1860, as assistant engineer, railway branch, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Rajputana railway, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, May, 1877; officiating assistant director, state railways, central system, 1878; assistant secretary, railway branch, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1879; served in the Afghan War, 1878-79-80 (medal); personal assistant to chief engineer, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1880; officiating manager, Nizam's state railway, Jan., 1881; manager, Indus Valley and Kandahar railway, Jan., 1882; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Oct., 1882; manager, Eastern Bengal State Railway, Nov., 1885.

BOULTON, Charles Frederick, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—Arrived in India, 6th Aug., 1852; on military duty up to Sept., 1856, when he was appointed acting assistant collector and magistrate, Satara; from 1860 served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate; superintendent, Bombay, Baroda, and C.I. railway police, Jan.-Aug., 1866; served subsequently in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting judge and sessions judge; manager of encumbered estates in the Karachi, Hyderabad, and Shikarpur collectorates, March, 1877; collector and magistrate Dec., 1879; acting commissioner in Sind, March-June, 1884.

BOURDILLON, James Austin, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; officiating under secretary, government of India, financial department, Sept., 1874, and subsequently in the home department, March, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Dec., 1875; from Aug., 1876, served in the registration department as inspector of registration offices, and officiating inspector-general; deputy superintendent of census, Dec., 1880; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1887.

BOUTFLOWER, W. N., B.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department from 6th Aug., 1869, as professor in the Agra College, and officiated as principal, July-Dec., 1872; 3rd professor in the Muir Central College, Allahabad, Oct., 1874; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1875, to May, 1876; professor of mathematics, Muir College, March, 1876; 3rd grade of educational officers, April, 1878; officiating meteorological reporter to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April-June, 1881.

BOWEN, Charles, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1858; arrived in India, April, 1863; joined the Madras P.W. department, Nov., 1863, and, from June, 1864, served under the Mysore Government; executive engineer, March, 1867; assistant to chief engineer, Mysore, June, 1869; officiating engineer in chief and joint secretary to government, Feb. to June, 1880; served in the Madras P.W. department, April, 1883, to September, 1889, as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government; served again under the Mysore Govern-
ment from Sept., 1885; superintending engineer, April, 1886.

BOWER, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Caistor Grammar School, Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th December, 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

BOWIE, MATHEW MORTON, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Central Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th June, 1858; from June, 1863, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Delhi assemblage, Nov., 1876; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, June, 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Sept., 1880; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, April, 1882.

BOWRING, LEWIN BENTHAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mount Radford School, Exeter, and at Leipzig; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1843; assistant magistrate and collector, 1845; assistant to treasurer, Calcutta, 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847-49; deputy commissioner, Punjab, 1849-54; private secretary to Lord Canning, 1858-62; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1862-70; retired 1870; has published 'Eastern Experiences,' and contributed papers to the Asiatic Society of Bengal.

BOXWELL, JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1883; also served as inspector of schools, July, 1885, and settlement officer, Midnapore, March, 1877; officiating commissioner, Patna, Sept., 1884; and again July, 1886.

BOYS, HENRY SCOTT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from Dec., 1864, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed superintendent of the encumbered estates of Sitapur and Kheri, June, 1872; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, and grade, Nov., 1884; acted as commissioner in the Fyzabad division in 1883, and in the Lucknow division in March, 1886.

BRACKENBURY, MAULE CAMPBELL, Major, R.E., Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1865; arrived in India, June, 1875; joined the P.W. department, June, 1875; executive engineer, March, 1877; served in the Perak expedition, 1875-76 (medal and clasp), and the Afghan War, 1879-80 (medal and two clasps and bronze star); officiating deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1881; assistant manager, Punjab northern state railway, Feb., 1883; officiating manager and traffic superintendent, Mysore railway, April, 1883; acting deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, Oct., 1884; deputy manager, North Western State Railway, Sind Section, Dec., 1885; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; manager, Sind Section, March, 1887.

BRADBURY, JAMES FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; also served as officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Sept., 1876, and officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, and grade, Aug., 1885.

BRADFORD, SIR EDWARD RIDLEY COLBORNE, Colonel, K.C.S.I., M.S.C.—Cornet, 6th light cavalry, Madras, Feb., 1854; proceeded to Persia under General Jacob in 1856; political assistant in Western Malwa, and in command of 1st Regiment Central India Horse, Nov., 1860; political agent, Bhagelcund, 1871; political agent, Bhurtpur, Jan., 1873; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, May, 1874; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Dec., 1878; also chief commissioner of Ajmere; secretary, political and secret department, India office, Feb., 1887.

BRADLEY, HERBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in South Canara as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting head assistant, and was in charge of the South Canara forests, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner, salt revenue, April, 1885, and on special duty with the commissioner, July, 1885.

BRADLEY, J. A., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state.

BRADSHAW, JOHN, M.A., LL.D. (Trinity College, Dublin), Madras Education Department.—Head master, Mangalore College, 31st Dec., 1870; member of conference of inspectors of schools, Jan., 1873; professor of history, Presidency College, April, 1875; fellow of University of Madras, July, 1875; from Nov., 1877, has served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 3rd class of the department, March, 1884; member of committee for preparing a scheme for examination for the degree of licentiate of teaching, Oct.-Nov., 1883; board of examiners, Oct., 1884; member of committee for revision of the grant-in-aid code, 1885; president of committee for preparation of the pre-matriculation text, 1886; edited Milton's poetical works with notes, and published an English Anthology, 1886.

BRAJENDRANATH DE, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Hare School, Calcutta, Canning College, Lucknow, Calcutta University, and St. Mary's Hall, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th September, 1875; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Oct., 1886.

BRANDIS, SIR DIETRICH, PH.D., K.C.I.E.—Served in the forest department of the govern-
ment of India from 16th Jan., 1856, and was appointed inspector-general of forests, April, 1864; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; retired 1883; appointed a member of the board of visitors of the Royal Indian Engineering College, 1886; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

BRANDRETH, ASHTON MILNES, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1857; served in the public works department from 8th Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, assistant principal, Thomason College, and executive engineer; transferred to the Punjab, Sept., 1861; served on the Western Jumna Canal; assistant secretary, government of India, May to Dec., 1863; assistant secretary, public works department, Punjab, May, 1867; officiating assistant to chief engineer and secretary to Government, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; officiating superintending engineer, Western Jumna Canal, April, 1871; principal, Thomason College, Feb., 1879.

BRANDT, FRANCIS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, and in the departments under the chief secretary, acting sub-secretary to board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty, board of revenue, 1872; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, April, 1874; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1877, and afterwards in the Nilgiris, 1883; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, June, 1878; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

BRANFOOT, ARTHUR MUDGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1872, and served under the military department till March, 1873, and subsequently as civil surgeon at Cocanada, and Madras, and as resident surgeon at the general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology in the Medical College, April-July, 1878; assistant physician, general hospital, and professor of hygiene, Medical College, July, 1878; superintendent of the lying-in-hospital, and professor of midwifery, Medical College, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

BRANSON, JAMES CHARLES EMERTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1882, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, officiating deputy-commissioner, and officiating city magistrate of Lucknow; transferred to Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; officiating assistant accountant-general Madras, March, 1886.

BRASHER, ALFRED, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed traffic manager, Persian Gulf telegraphs, 1863; superintendent, London office, 1867; director of traffic 1880; had charge of London training school in autumn, 1865; had executive charge of examinations for Indian telegraph department from 1867 to the opening of Cooper's Hill College; projected mean tariff between India and Europe, which replaced rates to different countries; has been on special duty to Constantinople, Vienna, Berlin, and Berne; has made public translations of the international telegraph conventions of Rome, St. Petersburg, London, and Berlin.

BRERETON, ASHLEY F., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School; supernumerary writer, 13th Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Jan., 1860; junior clerk, financial department, April, 1874; senior clerk, Nov., 1885; transferred to revenue statistics and commerce department, 1886.

BRERETON, REGINALD HUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

BRETT, ALFRED CORBYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from May, 1878, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

BRETT, CECIL MICHAEL WILFORD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, April, 1885; member central examination committee, April, 1886; registrar, high court (appellate side), April, 1886.

BRIDGES, JAMES EMILE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Royal College, Tournai, and University of Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, land revenue, and agricultural department, and officiating director of agriculture, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886.

BRIGHT, WILLIAM ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

BRIND, CHARLES BROWNLOW, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1884; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1887.

BROADFOOT, RAMSAY DOUGLAS (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Kensington School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878;
arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate.

BROCKMAN, WILLIAM DRAKE, A.M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the Punjab as sub-assistant revenue surveyor, 1852-55; joined Thomason College at Roorkee, and from there was appointed to the public works department, April, 1858, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer; transferred temporarily to railway department, Nov., 1859, to Dec., 1860; employed on famine relief works on Ganges Canal in 1861, and again in 1877-78 in the Rae Bareli division; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1874; on special duty in the public works secretariat, Nov., 1878; superintendent of works, Agra, Oct., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886.

BRODHURST, MAYNARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1850; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1850; from Oct., 1851, to Sept., 1858, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; received the mutiny medal for his services during the disturbances of 1857-58, while acting as magistrate of Shahabad; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1858, and appointed magistrate and collector, Ghazipur, May, 1862; from Feb., 1870, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge, Benares, and was temporarily additional judge of the high court in 1874; on special duty to Singapur, April to Aug., 1876; also served as president of the commissions appointed in 1872 and 1879 respectively, to inquire into the charges brought against the sub-judges of Mirzapore and Farkhabad; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1881.

BRODIE, VERNOR ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India 6th Jan., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; senior assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885.

BROJENDRO COOMAR SEAL, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 23rd Oct., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1880, and district judge, Bankura, and assistant session judge, Burdwan, April, 1881.

BROOKE, THOMAS HENRY BARSTOW, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, April, 1855; arrived in India, 15th May, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service in the China expedition, 1857-59; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, and as judge of the small cause court, Jubbulpore, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Nov., 1874; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1883.

BROOKE, W. R., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 13th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Bombay, Jan., 1866; served in the Punjab, 1869-1871; 1st grade superintendent Aug., 1877, officiating as director of traffic; director, construction branch, June, 1883; officiating deputy director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887.

BROOKE, WILLIAM SAURIN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1858; arrived in India 3rd January, 1859; served in the Central Provinces from Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; acting assistant settlement officer, Chanda, Oct., 1865; acting registrar-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, May, 1869; acting inspector-general of police and jails, Aug.-Nov., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, May, 1886.

BROUGHTON, U., Railway Department, Government of India.—Traffic superintendent, North-Western State Railway, Oct., 1885.

BROWN, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and cantonment magistrate.

BROWN, SIR JOHN CAMPBELL, Surgeon-General, K.C.B.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1836; surgeon, 66th N.I., Feb., 1850; surgeon, 3rd brigade artillery, Jan., 1855; C.B., March, 1858; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Sirhind, Dec., 1859; inspector-general of hospitals, Nov., 1870; surgeon-general, 1873; retired, Feb., 1876; hon. surgeon to the Queen.

BROWN, JOHN CROMMELIN, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India 24th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; was employed in the public works department, Nov., 1879, to April, 1880; on special duty, Dec., 1880.

BROWN, THOMAS EDWIN BURTON, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1858; arrived in India, 11th Feb., 1859; from Nov., 1860, served as professor of chemistry and chemical examiner, medical school, Lahore; principal, medical school, March, 1872; professor of surgery and midwifery in addition to his other duties, April-Dec., 1876; also officiated as civil surgeon of Lahore on several occasions, and as meteorological reporter, July-Aug., 1879; author of a work on the symptoms and treatment of the poisons used in the Punjab.

BROWNE, CLEMENT METCALFE, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, 1854; joined the public works department, June, 1856, as assistant engineer; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, Punjab, and assistant secretary, public works department, Oct., 1868; assistant to chief engineer, military works, Murree, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, Aug., 1873; superintending engineer, Punjab (provincial), Feb., 1877; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; rank of chief engineer,
March, 1886; chief engineer and secretary, public works department, Burma, Oct., 1886; chief engineer, and class, Nov., 1886; officiating chief engineer and secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1887.

BROWNE, LORD HENRY Ulick, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, Dec., 1850; arrived 1st Sept., 1851; served in the revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; also served as private secretary to the president of the governor-general's council, Feb., 1853, under secretary to the government of Bengal, July, 1859, officiating under secretary to the government of India, home and financial department, April, 1860, registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, April, 1861, superintendent of stamps and stationery, Oct., 1865, and officiating additional judge, Jessore and Nuddea, Feb., 1867; commissioner, Chittagong division, Dec., 1869, and subsequently of the Presidency, and Rajshahye and Cooch Behar divisions; chairman of the justices of the peace, Calcutta, Feb., 1872, and officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1878; retired Oct., 1886.

BROWNE, JAMES, Colonel, C.B., C.S.I., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, June, 1860, as assistant engineer in the Punjab; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1873, and subsequently to the railway branch, Oct., 1874; superintendent of works, Indus Bridge, Indus Valley state railway, Jan., 1875; during 1878-79 served in the Afghan war as superintending engineer with the Quetta field force (medal); C.S.I., July, 1879; assistant secretary to government, buildings and road branch, Punjab, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1882, military works; served in the Egyptian expedition as commanding engineer, 1882 (medal and clasp, bronze star, 3rd class Osmanieh, C.B.); transferred temporarily to railway branch for employment on the Hurnai road, Biluchistan, 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind-Pishin state railway, 1884; superintending engineer, and class, Jan., 1884.

BROWNE, Ven., JAMES FRANCIS, B.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Divinity College, London; junior chaplain, Madras, 20th July, 1870; senior chaplain, July, 1880; archdeacon of the diocese of Madras and commissary to the Lord Bishop, Feb., 1884; senior joint chaplain of St. George's Cathedral, Feb., 1884; in charge of the diocese, May to Oct., 1884; fellow of Madras university, March, 1886.

BROWNE, WILLIS, A.I.A., Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 15th Oct., 1867; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878; actuarial clerk, Feb., 1882.

BROWNING, COLIN ARROTT ROBERTSON, M.A., C.I.E., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Senior inspector of schools, N.W. Provinces, 26th June, 1862; acted as director of public instruction, Central Provinces, May, 1864, to March, 1865, and as inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, April-Oct., 1865, and again March, 1869, to July, 1870; director of public instruction in Oudh, July, 1870; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Oct., 1873; on special duty at Calcutta in connection with education conference in 1884; C.I.E., Jan., 1886; author of 'The Indian Official Thesaurus,' 'The Annals of the Indian Empire,' 'Mahomedan Education in Oude,' 'A List of Sanscrit Manuscripts existing in Oudh,' and various reports on education in the Central Provinces; has edited several school and text books, and was joint editor of the 1st edition of the Central Provinces' Gazetteer.

BROWNLOW, HENRY ALEXANDER, Major-General, R.E.—and lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; deputy superintendent, Ganges Canal, Feb., 1852; and afterwards on the Eastern and Western Jumna Canals; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekeserai, the siege of Delhi, and in the Rohilkund campaign (medal and clasp); superintendent, Eastern Jumna Canals, 1853; superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, March, 1865; 1st grade superintending engineer, Sept., 1870; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1872; superintending engineer, Bari Doab, Punjab, April, 1874; acted as chief engineer and joint secretary, Punjab, Feb.-May, 1876, and as chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, June, 1876; officiating inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, irrigation, July, 1878, and afterwards in the buildings and roads branch; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882; retired, 1886.

BROWNRIGG, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rossall, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

BRUCE, HENRY ALEXANDER, Principal Inspector-General, Her Majesty's Forces, M.D.—Educated at the University of St. Andrew's and the University of Edinburgh, where he graduated M.D. in 1829; diploma of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh, 1828; assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 1830; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1831; was employed on regimental duty, and served through the Cabul campaign, 1838 to 1841; was present at the storming of Ghuznee, 1839 (medal), and with the garrison of Cabul, 1839-40; in medical charge of the force sent to oppose Dost Mahomed in the Hindoo Koosh, Sept., 1840; surgeon to the envoy of Herat, Jan., 1841; was posted to the Sirmoor rifle battalion, Feb., 1841; principal medical storekeeper to the army of reserve, Nov., 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1846, and was present at the battles of Aliwal (medal) and Sobraon (clasp); rank of surgeon, June, 1847; medical storekeeper, Cawnpore, and staff surgeon, Dec., 1852; superintending surgeon, Sirhind circle, May, 1859; inspector-general of hospitals, Upper Provinces, April, 1864; principal inspector-general, medical department, November, 1865; retired, Sept., 1866; Fellow of the University of Calcutta, Jan., 1865.

BRUCE, RICHARD ISAAC, C.I.E., Political Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab as extra assistant-commissioner, 1863-1868; assistant commissioner, Dec., 1868; prepared a gazetteer of the Dhena Ghazi Khan district, and a manual of the Bituch language; on special duty in connection with Major Sandeman's 2nd
Kalat mission, 1876; 1st assistant to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, Feb., 1877; compiled a history of the Marri-Biluchi tribe; acted as agent, Biluchistan in 1878 and 1885; political agent at Thal-Chotiali from 1882.

BUCK, SIR EDWARD CHARLES, K.T., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from May, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and officiating secretary, board of revenue; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1875; commissioner for the government of India at the Melbourne International Exhibition of 1880; officiated as secretary to the Government of India in the revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881, and was confirmed in that appointment, April, 1882.

BUCKINGHAM AND CHANDOS (Duke of), RIGHT HON. RICHARD PLANTAGENET CAMPBELL TEMPLE NUGENT BRYDGES CHANDOS GRENVILLE, G.C.S.I.—Born 10th Sept., 1823; educated at Eton and Christchurch; represented Buckingham, 1846 to 1857; junior lord of the treasury, 1852; keeper of the Prince of Wales' privy seal, and deputy warden of the stannaries, 1852; chairman of the London and North Western Railway Company, 1853-1861; lord president of the council in Lord Derby's third administration, July, 1866; secretary of state for the colonies, March, 1867, to Dec., 1868; governor of Madras, Nov., 1875, to 1880; chairman of committees, and deputy speaker of House of Lords, 1886.

BUCKLAND, CHARLES EDWARD (Barrister-at-Law), B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; attache, foreign department, Nov., 1871; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore, Jan., 1874; on special duty in Behar, Jan., 1874; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1875; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, April, 1874, to Jan., 1877; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1876; private secretary to Sir Richard Temple during his mission to Madras and Bombay, Jan., 1877; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, May, 1878; private secretary to president of governor-general's council, Nov., 1878; officiating press commissioner with government of India, Feb., 1879; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bengal, May, 1880; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1882, and again in 1883, 1884, and 1886; edited "Excise Manual," 1884.

BUCKLE, HENRY, Burma.—Served in the Burma commission from 7th Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, and was in charge of the town magistrate's office, Akyab, Sept., 1871, to Nov., 1874, and of the Hill Tracts of Northern Arakan, Dec., 1874, to Jan., 1876; in command of an expedition beyond the frontier against the Shandus, Nov., 1876; from June, 1878, served as deputy commissioner in various districts, and was promoted to 1st grade, April, 1882; president, Henzada municipal committee, Dec., 1884.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK D'OLBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, St. Aubin's Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judge small cause court, Delhi, Jan., 1873; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1882; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Oct., 1885.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK SHORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating cantonment magistrate, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, small cause court judge, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1885.

BULLOCK, ROBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Madras army (infantry), 11th Dec., 1858; from July, 1862, served in the Berar commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, officiating small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (March, 1880); boundary commissioner for demarcation of the Dhans frontier, Feb. to June, 1886.

BULMAN, ALBERT ROBINSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Richmond Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Aug., 1884; 1st grade deputy commissioner, March, 1886; officiating commissioner, Umballa, Jan., 1887.

BURGESS, GEORGE DOUGLAS, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1870, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant collector of customs, and deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officer in charge of state prisoners, Jan., 1879; secretary to chief commissioner, July, 1881; officiating commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1884, and subsequently in the Irrawaddy division; commissioner, Arakan, April, 1886.

BURGESS, JAMES, C.I.E., LL.D., F.R.G.S., M.R.A.S., M. Soc. As., Paris, Archaeological Survey of India.—Was educated at Dumfries, Glasgow, and Edinburgh; archaeological surveyor and reporter for Western India, 15th Jan., 1874; also archaeological surveyor for Southern India, Nov., 1881; director general of the archaeological survey of India, March, 1886; is a fellow of the University of Bombay; author of scientific papers in the Philosophical Magazine, 'The Indian Antiquary,' 'Views of Architecture and Scenery in Gujarat and Rajputana,' 'Reports of the Archaeological Survey of Western and Southern India,' and, conjointly with the late J.
Ferguson, LL.D., C.I.E., 'The Rock Temples of India.'

BURKE, J., Telegraph Department.—Joined the department, 2 June, 1864; superintendent, and grade, Aug., 1883; officiating director of traffic, Feb., 1886.

BURKITT, WILLIAM ROBERT, M.A., (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Middle Temple, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880.

BURLS, E. GRANT, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 20th Oct., 1863; junior clerk, store department, Dec., 1865; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

BURLTON, HENRY MONTGOMERY BARTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 5th Native Infantry, Bengal, Aug., 1855; served in the Indian Mutiny, 1858-59, and was present at the capture of Gwalior, the actions of Jaora and Alipore, and other operations (medal and clasp); served subsequently in the Bhutan campaign, 1862, and the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68 (medal); assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1870; cantonment magistrate, Mhow, 1881; cantonment magistrate, Morar, Dec., 1884, and at Umballa, Nov., 1886.

BURNE, HENRY KNIGHTLEY, Lieut.-General, C.B., Bengal S.C.—Ensign, Dec., 1843; arrived in India, 25th May, 1844; served throughout the Sutlej campaign, 1845-46, including battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshah, and with the expedition against Kota Kangra (medal and clasp); during the Burmese war of 1852-53, was military secretary to General Godwin, commander of the force, and was present at the capture of Prome and Pegu (medal and clasp and brevet rank of major); acted as deputy assistant quartermaster-general, May-Oct., 1849; and as cantonment joint magistrate, Umballa, Nov., 1849; acting brigade major, Umballa, 1849-51, and as deputy assistant adjutant-general, Sirhind division, 1851-52; deputy judge advocate general, April, 1852; and assistant secretary to government of India, military department, July, 1856; 1st assistant secretary, Jan., 1858; deputy secretary, March, 1862; secretary to government of India, military department, June, 1870 to Dec., 1881; C.B., May, 1875.

BURNE, KNIGHTLEY GREY, Burma Commission.—Served in the Bengal police as assistant superintendent and acting district superintendent, from 26th Oct., 1865 to May 1872, and from the latter date in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and acted as town magistrate and superintendent of jail at Moulmein, 1872-75; officiating director of public instruction, Aug.-Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

BURNE, SIR OWEN TUDOR, Colonel, K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Ensign, 20th foot, 15th April, 1855; served in the Crimea; also in the Indian Mutiny of 1858-59, and was present in fifteen actions (including the siege and capture of Lucknow); promoted for gallantry at Lucknow to captaincy and brevet majority. After serving in the field as adjutant of regiment, and brigade-major to a field-column, was appointed military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (the late field marshal, Lord Strathnairn), 1861-62, and afterwards A.D.C., and at times officiating military secretary to that general officer when commander of the forces in Ireland, 1865-68; private secretary to viceroy of India (Earl of Mayo), 1869-72; political A.D.C. to secretary of state for India, 1872; assistant secretary in political and secret department, India Office, 1873; secretary in that department, 1874; on special duty in India as private secretary to the viceroy (Earl of Lytton), 1876-78; member of the council of India, 1887; was a royal commissioner of the Health, the Colonial and Indian exhibitions of 1882 and 1886, and is member of special committee appointed by Prince of Wales for organising new Imperial Institute.

BURNEY, RICHARD THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; superintendent, Chamba State, April, 1877; officiating additional sessions judge, Jan., 1880; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawal Pindi divisions, Dec., 1880; additional judge, chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Lahore; confirmed as judge of the chief court, Oct., 1885.

BURROWS, LEONARD ROBERT, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Lincoln Diocesan School, St. Nicholas College, Lancing, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1865; president of municipal commission, Madras, 1875-1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1882; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Sept., 1883; collector and magistrate and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Sept., 1884.

BUSTEED, HENRY ELMSLEY, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., C.I.E., late Mint Department, Calcutta.—First commission, Indian medical service (Madras establishment), Aug., 1855; arrived in India, March, 1856; civil surgeon, Cuddalore, Jan., 1861; assistant assay master, Madras mint, Feb., 1865; acted as assay master for various periods, and also as mint master and commissioner of paper currency; deputy assay master, Bombay, April, 1868; from Feb., 1869, served in the Calcutta mint as officiating assay master, and was appointed deputy assay master, Nov., 1870, and confirmed as assay master, Sept., 1872; also acted as mint master in 1873 and 1875; retired June, 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1887.

BUTLER, JAMES, Major, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 10th foot, Feb., 1866; arrived in Madras, 24th May, 1866; served in the Burma commission from Oct., 1868, as assistant commissioner and town magistrate; appointed a deputy commissioner, July, 1881; president of the Henzada Municipal Committee, Oct., 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886; author of 'Mergui Gazetteer'.

BUTLER, WILLIAM G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Bradfield and Eton;
junior clerk, store department, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to secretary of state, 1874-78.

BUTTERWORTH, ALAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived 15th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate.

BUTTS, HENRY HILL (Barrister-at-Law), Oudh Commission.—Extra assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, 3rd June, 1863; from Nov., 1865, to Oct., 1873, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer, and from the latter date as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882; author of the 'Lucknow Settlement Report.'

BYATT, J., Store Department, India Office.—Assistant clerk, education department, May, 1860, to May, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, May, 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, Nov., 1880.

BYRNE, EDWARD SIMPSON, Financial Department, Government of India.—Head assistant to auditor-general of India, June, 1862; served in Hyderabad from Jan., 1865, to March, 1871, as deputy auditor and accountant-general, and was ordered on special duty to Calcutta in connection with Berar finance, Dec., 1867; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1874, served in the Punjab as deputy accountant-general and acting accountant-general, and trustee, Punjab University; served subsequently as deputy accountant-general in Assam, Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1879, and in Bombay 1879 to July, 1882, and acted as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, in 1879; from July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as deputy accountant-general, and acted as accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Allahabad, Sept.-Oct., 1882; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated deputy auditor-general) in 1st class of the financial department, July, 1883.

CADELL, ALAN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Guetersloh Gymnasium, Westphalia, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from April, 1867, to March, 1881, served in the settlement department in Allahabad, Mozaffarnagar, and Banda, and was placed on special duty, June, 1867, and again in March, 1869, to conduct the prosecution of the Munsifof Deoband; promoted to settlement officer, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, and grade, May, 1880; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1885; officiating civil and sessions judge, April, 1886.

CADELL, ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1845; joined the public works department, April, 1848; executive engineer, Rawul Pindi, 1850; executive engineer, Nagpore, April, 1856; executive engineer in Oude road department, Dec., 1858; superintendent of works, northern road, and Saugor division, 1863; superintending engineer, Punjab, 1864; from 1867 to 1878 served in Indore, first as superintending engineer, and then as chief engineer, and secretary to the governor-general's agent for Central India; also officiated as chief engineer and secretary to government N.W. Provinces, 1874-75; chief engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, 1879-80; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1881; inspector-general, military works, 1881-82; retired 13th March, 1882.

CADELL, THOMAS, Colonel, V.C., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, July, 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi (medal, clasp, and Victoria cross); and subsequently in the operations in Oudh and Bundelcund; and in command, Malwa Bheel corps, deputy Bheel agent, and political assistant, April, 1861; officiating commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, and Bheel agent, March, 1869; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1870; political agent, Ulwar, Nov., 1870; political agent, Marwar, Nov., 1877, and in Meywar, April, 1878; commandant, Erinpoora force, and political agent, Western Rajputana, Oct., 1879; chief commissioner and superintendent, Port Blair and the Nicobars, from Dec., 1879.

CALL, C. F., Major, R.E., Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal engineers, 16th July, 1866; served on the Indian establishment with the Bengal sappers and miners, and afterwards in the public works department, buildings and roads and railway branches, Feb., 1869, to Sept., 1881; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, including the march from Kabul to Kandahar (medal and 2 clasps, bronze star, and brevet of major); assistant superintendent, India store depot, Jan., 1883.

CALLAGHAN, T., Registry Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, 27th March, 1885.

CAMERON, ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, April, 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1868, and served as civil medical officer at various stations in Oudh; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1870; served subsequently in the same capacity at Bara Banki, Lucknow, Sultanpur, and other places; surgeon-major, April, 1880; in medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, Nov., 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1886.

CAMERON, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces and Oudh.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department 1860-66, and served in the Bhootan campaign (medal); from April, 1866, served in the civil department in Oudh, as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Baraiach and Rae Bareli; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, Sept., 1875; served also as civil surgeon at Bara Banki and at Gonda.

CAMERON, DUNCAN, M.A., Bengal, C.S.—Aberdeen University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal,
as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CAMERON, Lewis, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1866; from Feb. 1873, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in Bengal; surgeon major, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Backergunge with charge of the jail, Dec. 1879; transferred to Champarun, Feb. 1883, and to Rajshahye Dec., 1885.

CAMPBELL, Archibald Colin, Assam Commission.—Served in Assam from 27th April, 1861, as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to chief commissioner; was personal assistant to the chief civil officer, Bhutan field force, 1865 (medal and clasp); superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Dhubri, Sept., 1875; promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1878; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

CAMPBELL, Archibald Edwardes, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Jan., 1851; served the Sonthal campaign 1855-56, and in Central India, 1857-58 (medal and clasp); from May, 1862 served in the Assam commission and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1866; inspector of labourers, Sibsagar, Feb., 1882; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Aug., 1883.

CAMPBELL, Colin G., India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; junior clerk, military department, 13th Jan., 1876; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state from 1877.

CAMPBELL, Duncan John Alfred, Bengal C.S. Burma).—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1877, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, boundary officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, in 1883; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Feb., 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1886.

CAMPBELL, Sir George, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at New Academy, Edinburgh, and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1842; served in Rohilkund, 1843 to 1846, in usual grades of the revenue and judicial departments, and was in charge of several districts and political divisions of cis-Sutlej states, 1846-51; on furlough 1851 to 1854, during which he was associate of the Court of Queen's Bench, and published 'Modern India,' and 'India as it may be'; magistrate and collector, Azimgurh, 1854; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, 1855; commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, 1855-1857; took an active part in the events following the mutiny, and was present at several engagements; personal assistant to governor-general, Lord Canning, 1857-58; judicial and financial commissioner of Oude 1858; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1862-66; president of the commission to enquire into the famine in Orissa, 1866-67; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1867-68; while on furlough, 1868-70, published a work on Irish land tenure; D.C.L., University of Oxford; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1871-74; retired 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1874-75; resigned on election as M.P. for Kirkcaldy burghs in 1875; presided over economy and trade department at the Social Science Congress at Glasgow, 1874; re-elected for the Kirkcaldy burghs in 1880, and again in 1885; is the author of numerous statistical, ethnological, and linguistic works on India, also of 'A Handy Book of the Eastern Question,' 1876, and of various publications on different countries visited by him.

CAMPBELL, Francis Johnstone Graham, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 20th January, 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1875, and district and sessions judge, and grade, April, 1880; 1st grade, April, 1887.

CAMPBELL, Gerald Edward Lyon, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1884.

CAMPBELL, James McNabb, M.A., C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Glasgow Academy and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant conservator of forests, acting under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and compiler of the 'Gazetteer' and 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency'; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, April, 1880; acting under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1880; acted as collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery in 1881; 1st assistant collector, Bombay presidency, May, 1885.

CAMPBELL, John McLeod, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Glasgow; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as deputy registrar of the high court, Bombay, and assistant collector and magistrate; from July, 1871, to Aug., 1876, served in the forest department as deputy conservator and conservator in Sind; forest settlement officer, June, 1879; acting collector of customs, Bombay, Jan., 1882; junior collector and collector of salt revenue, March, 1883; collector of customs, Bombay, Oct., 1885.

CAMPBELL, John Scarlett, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grange, Sunderland; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; arrived in India, Jan., 1848, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate, Moradabad, 1856; during the mutiny was present at the siege of Delhi, and subsequently took charge of the Rohtuk district as deputy commissioner, 1st class; commissioner, Saugor division, Central Provinces, Jan., 1862; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1864; officiating chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1871; on assassination of Lord Mayo in 1872, was deputed
to enquire into and report on the administration of the convict settlement in the Andaman Islands; retired, 1878; author of a 'Memo. on proposed changes in the mode of selection and training of candidates for the Indian Civil Service.'

CAMPBELL, JOHN STRATHEDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; senior assistant commissioner, Garhwal, Dec., 1886.

CAMPBELL, LORNE AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Jan., 1875, to Feb., 1881, and acted on several occasions as secretary to Government, and as sub-secretary, board of revenue; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Oct., 1882; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Oct., 1884.

CAMPBELL, RICHARD HAMILTON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 18th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

CAMPBELL-WALKER, INCHES, Lieut.-Col., Madras S.C., Forest Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1859; from May, 1865, served in the Madras forest department as assistant conservator and deputy conservator; appointed by the secretary of state a commissioner for the Vienna Exhibition, April, 1873; knight commander of the order of Francis Joseph of Austria for services at the Vienna Exhibition; officiating inspector of forests, Feb., 1874, to Sept., 1875; on duty at the forest conference, Simla, Sept., 1875; member of the forest bill committee, Madras, Jan., 1876, and again, March, 1882; on special duty to New Zealand, March, 1876, to Nov., 1877, and in Nilgiris, S. Coimbatore, and Tinnevelly, Dec., 1877; member of forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; conservator of forests, 1st grade, Dec., 1884; author of reports on forest management in Germany, Austria, and Great Britain (1872), and on the forests of New Zealand.

CANDY, EDWARD TOWNSHEND (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; on special duty, Poonah, March, 1869; from Oct., 1873, acted as judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1878; acting judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, May, 1883; 2nd grade, judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Aug., 1883; 1st grade judge, Surat, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, July-Nov., 1885; judge and sessions judge, Belgaum, Aug., 1885.

CANDY, RICHARD EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting educational inspector; acting director of public instruction, Berar, June, 1872, to Dec., 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1877; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1885.

CAPPEL, SIR ALBERT JAMES LEPPOC, K.C.I.E., Indian Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the telegraph department, 10th Feb., 1857; 1st grade superintendent and personal assistant to director general, Dec., 1866; director of traffic, May, 1869; deputy director-general, Feb., 1879; director-general of telegraphs, June, 1883; K.C.I.E., Feb. 1887.

CAPPEL, EDWARD LOUIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from May, 1882, served under the government of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

CARD, H. C., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

CARDEW, ALEXANDER GORDON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somerseshire College, Bath, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar high court, and acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments (July, 1885); on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1884, and again in 1885; on special duty as secretary to the Malabar land tenures committee, Dec., 1885; acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Oct., 1886.

CARDOZO, HENRY O'CONNELL, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 21st March, 1859, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 1st class, March, 1883.

CAREY, ARTHUR DOUGLAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the City of London School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the salt department from May, 1872, to March, 1877, and from May, 1877 to Feb., 1882, as assistant collector of salt revenue, and acting deputy collector, and was appointed collector of salt revenue, Bombay, April, 1881; on special duty to Sambhar, Oct., 1881; from Feb., 1882, served under the government of India as officiating commissioner, inland customs; commissioner, salt revenue, Northern India, Dec., 1882.

CAREY, LIONEL SLADE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting district superintendent of police, July, 1883; acting inspector of schools, May-July, 1884; acting
deputy commissioner, 1884; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, June to Dec., 1885; settlement officer, Bilaspur, Oct., 1886.

CARLYLE, ROBERT WARRAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CARMICHAEL, CHARLES PAGET, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and subsequently at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; arrived in India, March, 1849; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1854; officiating registrar of Sudder Dewany and Nizamat Adawlut, April, 1854; officiating civil auditor, Aug., 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1856; deputed as civil officer with the relieving force to Shahjahánpur, April, 1858; magistrate and collector, Budaun, Feb., 1862; officiating commissioner, Kumaun, May, 1867, to Jan., 1868; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1870; from April, 1873, acted as commissioner and agent to governor-general, Benares, and was confirmed in these appointments, March, 1877; also held the substantive appointment of district and sessions judge, Jan., 1877; officiated as member of the board of revenue in 1877-78-79, and was appointed permanently to the board in 1882; retired March, 1884.

CARMICHAEL, DAVID FREMANTLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury, 1851; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1851; head assistant registrar, court of Sudder and Foujdaree Adawlut, Feb., 1855; deputy secretary to government, Oct., 1856; secretary to board of examiners, Oct., 1856; private secretary to governor of Madras, March, 1859; fellow of Madras University, Oct., 1859; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1863, to April, 1867, and afterwards at Ganjam; acting judge, high court, Madras, April to July, 1869; employed in preparation of Vizagapatam district manual; acting member, board of revenue, Aug., 1871; president of committee for examination of assistants, July, 1871; Inam commissioner, Aug., 1871; on special duty as president of the committee for inquiring into the action of government officials during cyclone in 1872, May, 1872; secretary to government, revenue department, Nov., 1872; additional member of council for making laws and regulations Feb., 1874; on special duty with government at imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; chief secretary to government, June, 1877; ordinary member of council, Madras, Dec., 1878; on tour as special commissioner through Hill tracts of Ganjam, Vizagapatam, and Godavari, Feb., 1881; retired, 1886.

CARNDUFF, HERBERT WILLIAM CAMERON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1883.

CARR, REGINALD CHILDERS CULLING, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Cheam school, the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

CARSTAIRS, ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Edinburgh Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, April, 1886.

CARTER, ALBERT M., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 4th Nov., 1861; junior clerk, March, 1866; senior clerk, Aug., 1882.

CARTER, HENRY VANDYKE, Brigade Surgeon, M.D. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 27th Jan., 1858; arrived in India, 29th March, 1858, and served on military duty and as professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital; also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara; on special duty in England, May, 1874, and in Bombay and Kathiawar, 1875; appointed surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejal Hospital, Bombay, Nov., 1879; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1882; principal and professor of medicine and clinical medicine, Grant Medical College, and acting first physician Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, 1886.

CARTER, THOMAS TUPPER, Major, R.E. (Bengal), Survey of India.—First commission, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Dec., 1859; served with the Sikkim Field Force, 1860-61, as survey officer; from May, 1861, to April, 1862, served as assistant engineer in the public works department, Punjab; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862, and served as assistant in the Kashmir and Kumaon and Garhwal surveys; served in the Umbeyla Campaign, 1863 (medal and clasp); surveyor, 3rd grade, April, 1866; in charge of the survey party with the Abyssinian expedition, Dec., 1867, to March, 1869; was subsequently in charge of survey parties on the Brahmaputra, in Madras, Guzerat, Kumaon, Gwalior, and Central India; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, March, 1886.

CASEY, ARTHUR EDWIN COMERFORD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, and Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Kumaon, May, 1882.
