CASPERSZ, CHARLES PETER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and London University.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CASSELS, ANDREW.—Member of the council of the secretary of state for India from April, 1874, to April, 1884.
CAVE-BROWNE, E. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the College School, Taunton; junior clerk in the treasury, East India House, 12th April, 1854, and from 1858 in the India Office; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant in the accounts branch of the financial department, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax 1872; deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

CAYLEY, H., Brigade Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1857; from April, 1872, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of royal botanical gardens, ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta (from Jan., 1876), superintendent of the eye infirmary, and marine surgeon; rank of brigade surgeon, April, 1884; medical board, India office, 1885.

CENTER, WILLIAM, M.B., M.A., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1865; arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from March, 1871, served under the government of the Punjab as chemical examiner and professor of chemistry and surgery in the Lahore medical school; officiating meteorological reporter in addition to his other duties, May, 1872; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; served under the government of India, Aug.-Nov., 1882, as statistical officer in sanitary department; officiated as principal of the Lahore medical school in 1878, 1882, and 1883; civil surgeon, Lahore, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Aug., 1885.

CHAMBERLAIN, Sir Neville Bowles, General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, 1837; served through the Afghan campaigns of 1839-42 (medal); present with the governor-general's body-guard at the battle of Maharajpore, Dec., 1843 (bronze star); deputy assistant quartermaster-general to the army, 1843; hon. aide-de-camp to Lord Dalhousie, 1848; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the actions of Chillianwallah and Goojerat (medal and two clasps); military secretary to the chief commissioner for affairs of the Punjab, March, 1853; commandant, Punjab irregular force, Dec., 1854; adjutant-general of the Bengal army, July, 1857; C.B., 1857; aide-de-camp to the Queen for services in the mutiny; commanded the force on the N.W. frontier of India in various expeditions against the hill tribes (medal and clasp); commander in chief, Madras, and member of the governor's council, Feb., 1876 to 1881; was appointed head of the special mission to Kabul, Aug., 1883, which, however, was not allowed to enter the Ameer's territory.

CHAMIER, Francis Edward Archibald, Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 7th April, 1850; aide-de-camp to General Outram throughout the Oudh campaign; commanded the Kapurthala contingent during its service in Oudh, in 1858 (medal and two clasps); from March, 1858, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, officiating settlement officer, and officiating commissioner in various divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Bara Banki, April, 1873; district judge, 1st grade, Rae Bareli, Feb., 1882, and afterwards at Fyzabad.

CHANNING, Francis Chorley, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; settlement secretary to financial commissioner Jan., 1878; senior secretary to the financial commissioner, March, 1882; officiated as divisional judge, Nov., 1885; and again April, 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1886.

CHAPMAN, Charles, Oudh Commission.—Assistant in the opium department, Bengal, 27th May, 1862; assistant conservator of Oudh forests, Sept., 1865; from Sept., 1866, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; superintendent of encumbered estates, Gonda and Fyzabad, 1875-76; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Rae Bareli, Oct., 1883.

CHAPMAN, Charles, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 6th Aug., 1884.

CHAPMAN, Francis Steuart, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1849; served as assistant collector and magistrate, Belgaum, up to 1852, when he was appointed assistant to Inam commissioner, and was employed on special duty in connection with the settlement of claims to compensation on account of the abolition of transit and town duties; 1st assistant to collector and magistrate, Ahmednuggur, 1855; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1862, and subsequently of Sattara; chief secretary to government of Bombay, and secretary in revenue and finance departments, 1865; additional member of council, Bombay, 1869, and again in 1871; retired 1877.

CHAPMAN, Robert Barclay, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived 6th March, 1850; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary to government of India, home, financial, and foreign departments, April, 1856, to April, 1860; called to the bar (Inner Temple) Jan., 1863; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, June, 1863; acting commissioner, Nuddea division, Nov., 1866, to Jan., 1866; served subsequently as secretary to government of India, financial department, and government director of Bank of Bengal; retired, 1881.

CHARLES, Fendall Lewis, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Repton School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty, demarcation of forests in Nasik, July, 1875; forest settlement officer, Dharwar, Nov., 1881; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Oct., 1886.

CHARLES, John George, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 15th Dec., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1866; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1870; on special duty (member of cattle plague commission) June, 1870; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1871; offici-
ating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, March, 1876; officiating presidency magistrate, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; officiating chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1877, also judge of the court for the trial of pilots; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; district and sessions judge, and grade, Jan., 1885; additional district judge, 24-Pergunnahs, Jan., 1885, to March, 1887; member, central examination committee, April, 1886.

CHARLTON, A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 8th April, 1882.

CHATFIELD, KYRLE MITFORD, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th March, 1866, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as educational inspector and as director of public instruction, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1874.

CHATTERTON, FRANK WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry.—Arrived in India as ensign 4th Nov., 1859; employed under the military department till Feb., 1869, from which date he served in Jhansi and Kumaon as officiating assistant commissioner; from May, 1873, served as cantonment magistrate of Roorkee; also appointed a small cause court judge, Roorkee, March, 1879; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Agra, Dec., 1880.

CHESNEY, GEORGE TOMKYNNS, Major-General, R.E., C.B., C.S.I.—Joined the service, 1848; served in the public works department from 1851 as executive engineer in the Lower Provinces, N.W. Provinces, and Punjab; assistant to principal of Thomason College, 1855; controller and examiner of accounts, public works department, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1860; inspector-general of public works accounts, Bengal, Jan., 1860; also ex-officio under secretary to government of India; accountant-general, public works department, May, 1864; on the institution of the Royal Indian Engineering College at Cooper's Hill in 1870, was appointed president of the college, and continued in that post till 1880, when he was appointed military secretary to the government of India; military member of governor-general's council, May, 1886.

CHIPPERFIELD, E., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Finchley; matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, and class, India office, 3rd Dec., 1875.

CHIPPERFIELD, A. E., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 27th June, 1881; retired, Jan., 1886.

CHISHOLM, JAMES WRIGHT, Central Provinces.—Served in the Central Provinces from 24th Oct., 1856, as deputy collector, assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1871; inspector-general of police and jails, Oct., 1875; secretary to the chief commissioner, June, 1880; commissioner of the Chattisgarh division, March, 1883.

CHITPAL SINGH, RAJA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a covenanted civilian under native civil service rules without probation, 12th Dec., 1881; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

CHOLMELEY, NORMAN GOODFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884.

CHRISTIE, ARCHIBALD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating district judge; on special duty, Kurram field force, Oct., 1878; under secretary to government of Punjab, Aug. to Dec., 1884.

CHRISTIE, CHARLES HOWARD PEREGRINE, Major, R.E., Public Works Department.—First commission as lieutenant, April, 1866; joined the Madras public works department, March, 1869; served as assistant engineer, assistant consulting engineer for railways, acting examiner of railway accounts, and acting deputy consulting engineer; deputy controller, public works accounts, Madras, irrigation branch, Jan., 1873; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Central India, Sept., 1880; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1881; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, Madras, March, 1887.

CHUNDER MADHUB GHOSE.—Member of the legislative council of Bengal, 1883 to 1885; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885.

CHURCH, WILLIAM THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintendent, Dehra Dün, Jan., 1882; magistrate and collector, and grade, July, 1885.

CHURCHILL, LORD RANDOLPH HENRY SPENCER.—Born 1849; educated at Merton College, Oxford, and graduated B.A., 1871; represented Woodstock in the House of Commons from Feb., 1874, until Nov., 1885, when he was returned for South Paddington; secretary of state for India, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; chancellor of the exchequer and leader of the House of Commons, in the Marquis of Salisbury's second ministry, Aug., 1886, but resigned after a few months' tenure of office.

CLARK, WILLIAM OVENS, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Portora School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty, Bengal, Feb., 1874; on special duty in the public works department March, 1882; officiating cantonment magistrate, Multan, April, 1883.

CLARKE, SIR ANDREW, Major-General, G.C.M.G., C.B., C.I.E.—and Lieutenant, Royal
Engineers, June, 1834; in 1848 was employed on special service in New Zealand, and was aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor, Tasmania, June, 1849, to June, 1853; governor and commander-in-chief, Straits Settlements, Aug., 1873, to May, 1875; member of council of governor-general of India in charge of public works June, 1875 to 1880; commandant, school of military engineering, Chatham, April, 1881, to June, 1882; inspector-general of fortifications and director of works, ordnance department, War Office, June, 1882, to June, 1886.

CLARKE, C.B., M.A., Educational Service, Assam.—Appointed to the Bengal educational department, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor at the Presidency College, and as inspector of schools; officiating superintendent of the Calcutta botanical garden, May, 1869; 1st class of the education department, March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1879, to April, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, December, 1884; transferred to Assam as inspector of schools, March, 1885.

CLARKE, HERVEY MORRIS STANLEY, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, Madras Native Infantry, 13th March, 1854; served with the Central India Horse, during 1858-60; from Sept., 1861, served in the N.W. Province police department; district superintendent, April, 1863; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Dec., 1871; acted at various times as assistant inspector-general, government railway police; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1885; inspector-general of prisons, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886.

CLARKE, ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant, and was in charge of the Jhelum settlement, Aug., 1878; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, May, 1881.

CLARKE, TREDWAY GEORGE, Colonel, M.S.C.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, 1833; served in the Mysore commission from Oct., 1857; deputy superintendent, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner, Mysore, 1873; from 1875 acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, and was confirmed in this appointment, 1877; commissioner, Nagar division, May, 1879; commissioner of Coorg, 1881; officiating resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885.

CLARKE, WILLOUGHBY CHARLES STANLEY, Colonel, B.S.C.—Commission as ensign, June, 1851; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1851; was employed on military duty till 1862, including service in the Sonthal Expedition, 1855, and in the China Expedition, 1860-61; also served as superintendent of police and magistrate, governor-general's camp, Sept., 1859, to Jan., 1860; from June, 1862, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, July, 1867; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885.

CLAY, ARTHUR LLOYD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cholmeley Grammar School, Highgate, at Cologne, and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 29th Nov., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1874; from Sept., 1874, to June, 1877, served in Assam as deputy commissioner, 1st grade, and district and sessions judge of Sylhet; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, July, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Manbhum, Aug., 1879; officiating commissioner of Chota Nagpore, Sept., 1884; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Backergunge, March, 1886.

CLAY, WILLIAM McKINLEY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner (wards' estate, Patna); on famine relief duty, 1873-74; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1887.

CLEGG, ROBERT BAILEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

CLEGHORN, JAMES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; served in Bengal, and held various military medical charges, and officiated as civil surgeon of Howrah and Moorshedabad, 1867, and of Mooltan and Cawnpore, 1868-69; from Feb., 1870, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, Azimgarh, June, 1870; junior civil surgeon and superintendent, district jail, Allahabad, April, 1873; held medical charge of the camp of the lieutenant-governor on several occasions, including Imperial assemblage at Delhi, 1876; civil surgeon of Naini Tal, March, 1876, and subsequently at Mirzapur, Cawnpore, and Allahabad; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; on special duty to Calcutta, Dec., 1880; officiating surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, Calcutta, June, 1885 to March, 1886, when he was appointed civil surgeon of Lucknow.

CLERK, SIR GEORGE RUSSELL, G.C.S.I., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1816; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and judge, and was appointed 1st assistant to the secretary in the secret and political department in 1820; assistant resident, Rajputana, and officiating assistant superintendent, Ajmere, 1821; assistant resident, Nagpur, and afterwards at Delhi, and assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1827; officiated as political agent at Jeypoor and in other districts, 1828-31; political agent, Umballah, 1831, and at Loodianah, 1839; agent to governor-general in the Punjab, 1840; envoy to the court of Maharajah Shere Singh at Lahore, 1842; provisional member of council of governor-general, 1845; member of governor-general's council, 1846; governor of Bombay, 23rd Jan., 1847; retired from the civil service, May, 1847; appointed one of the secretaries to the board of control, 1856, and on the transfer of Indian affairs to the crown was made under secretary of state
for India, 1859; again governor of Bombay, May, 1860, to April, 1862; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1864-76.

CLINTON (Baron), CHARLES HENRY ROLLE HEPBURN STUART TREFUSIS.—Under secretary of State for India, July, 1867 to Dec., 1868; appointed a charity commissioner for England and Wales, 1874.

CLOETE, HENRY DANIEL, Colonel, M.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Army, Dec., 1849; arrived, 27th April, 1850; served in the Madras police department from June, 1860, as superintendent, deputy inspector-general, acting commissioner and acting chief magistrate of police for the town of Madras; inspector-general of police, Madras, from Dec., 1881 to 1885.

CLOETE, JOSIAS GORDON, Colonel, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Feb., 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; served in the Madras police as assistant superintendent, June, 1861, to June, 1863, and from the latter date in the revenue survey; deputy superintendent, Jan., 1872; on special duty preparing code of rules for survey department, July, 1873 to March, 1874.

CLOGSTOUN, HERBERT FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting assistant superintendent of police, April, 1867, to April, 1868; acting deputy director of revenue settlement March, 1872; on special duty in connection with state relief works, Kurnool, Dec., 1876; acting principal assistant collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Vizagapatam, Jan., 1880; joint sessions judge in Rumpa cases, Jan., 1880; from March, 1880, served in the financial department as officiating accountant-general, Bengal, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; member of board of examiners, Madras, June, 1882; accountant-general and commissioner of issue of state paper currency, Madras, July, 1882.

COATES, JOHN MARTIN, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Bengal Medical Department.—First commission, 1855; in medical charge of 1st Bengal military police battalion, Dec., 1856; civil assistant surgeon, April, 1859; superintendent of jails, Hazaribagh, Nov., 1866; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; civil surgeon, Moorsheadabad, Dec., 1871; in joint medical charge, Simla, and in charge of commander-in-chief's staff, 1873; sanitary commissioner for Bengal, May, 1874; principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex officio 1st physician to the college hospital, April, 1880; also officiated as inspector-general of jails, Aug., 1879; brigade surgeon, May, 1881; officiating surgeon-general, Bengal, in addition to other duties, June, 1884; president of a committee of enquiry on sanitary matters in connection with Kidderpore docks, March, 1885; has published a vocabulary of the dialects of Chota Nagpur.

COBB, WILLIAM HEY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1884; served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant-magistrate and collector, and assistant-commissioner.

COCKERELL, FRANCIS RICHARD, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1850; arrived, 15th April, 1850; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments; appointed magistrate, 1857, and served in that capacity, and also as collector in various districts; temporarily inspector-general of jails in Bengal; judge of the special courts for the adjudication of rent suits in Nuddea and Jessore, 1863; temporarily secretary to the government of Bengal; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1864; legislative council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal; on special duty conducting an inquiry into the causes of the distress in the Patna and Bhagulpore divisions; additional member of the governor-general's council, Jan., 1868, and again in 1870, 1872, and 1876-79; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Dacca division, Jan., 1874, and subsequently of Rajshahye; deputed in 1873-74 as special commissioner to inquire into certain cases of mal-administration in the province of Assam; retired, 1879.

COCKERELL, HORACE ABEL, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1853; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of survey, Sept., 1859, and as officiating chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, and commissioner of police, March, 1866, and Dec., 1872; commissioner of the Chittagong division, June, 1872, and subsequently of the Dacca and Burdwan divisions; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, April, 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, April, 1878, and again, March, 1880 and 1882; board of revenue, March, 1883; officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Aug., 1885.

COCKS, WALTER CAREW, Auditor, India Office.—Appointed 1st Aug., 1874.

CODDINGTON, FITZHERBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 12th June, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857; was employed under the military department, including service during the mutiny (medal and clasp for Lucknow), till Jan., 1862, when he was appointed assistant surveyor in survey department; deputy superintendent of survey, July, 1867; was employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, 1867, and in the Deccan, 1871; 2nd grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; Hissar and Pirozepore district survey, March, 1884.

CODRINGTON, GEORGE HENRY FORBES, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th May, 1857; served on military duty till Dec., 1865, and subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, April, 1883.

COGHLAN, ROBERT NESBIT, Customs Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd April, 1871; from March, 1872, served as general manager of the customs' bonded warehouses, Bombay, and as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, in charge of the tobacco department, Bombay; from March, 1874, served as assistant collector of salt revenue; collector of sea customs, Karachi, and assistant commissioner of salt revenue in Sind, Sept., 1882.
COLDSTREAM, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; officiating commissioner and sessions judge, Lahore, April, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1883; deputed to Calcutta to act as one of the representatives of the Punjab in the committee on museum and exhibition held there, Dec., 1883; officiating commissioner, Lahore, Feb., 1887.

COLE, WILLIAM HAMMOND, M.A. Cantab., F.R.A.S., F.R.G.S.—Served in the education department, N.W. Provinces, April, 1862, to March, 1864, as professor of mathematics at the Government College, Agra; from Jan., 1867, served in the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor attached to the computing office, Dehra; assistant superintendent of surveys, Sept., 1869; deputy superintendent July, 1882; appointed to charge of head quarters office, Dehra Dun, and survey detachment in Kashmir, Jan., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; author of various contributions to the 'Account of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India,' and to the 'Synopsis of the Results of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey,' also of various translations relating to geodesy.

COLLEN, E. H. H., Lieut-Col., B.S.C.—First commission, royal artillery, July, 1863; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, May, 1873; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, March, 1875; and assistant secretary April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, Dec., 1876; deputy secretary, military department, April, 1884; accountant general, military department, government of India, July, 1886.

COLLETT, CHARLES, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; subordinate judge of Calicut, 1862; judge of court of small causes, Cuddalore, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1866; retired in 1871.

COLLIER, FRANK ROBERT STANLEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, May, 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; published an annotated edition of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1884.

COLLIER, GEORGE H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Uppingham School; junior clerk, India office, 17th Feb., 1876.

COLLIN, EDWARD WOODFIELD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; private secretary to financial member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1880; served under the government of India, foreign department, Jan. to July, 1881, and, in the financial department, March-Sept., 1885; settlement officer, Mozafferpore, Jan., 1886.

COLLINGWOOD, WILLIAM, Lieutenant, Accounts Department, India Office.—Served in the Indian navy from 1st June, 1846 to 1862, in the course of which period he was employed in the survey of Mesopotamia, and as transport agent during the Persian war; from 26th June, 1867, served as a writer in the India office, and was employed in the financial department till 1877, and subsequently in the accountant-general's department; junior clerk, Dec., 1870; senior clerk, May, 1876.

COLLINS, ARTHUR HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1879; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

COLLINS, SIR ARTHUR JOHN HAMMOND, Knt., Q.C.—Chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, 28th Nov., 1885.

COLLINS, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Dec., 1885.

COLOUHOUN, ARCHIBALD ROSS, A.M.I.C.E., F.R.G.S., Burma Commission.—Entered the public works department in Oct., 1871, as apprentice engineer; served in the grades of assistant and executive engineer in various divisions of Burma; on special duty as personal assistant to Major Street on his mission to Siam, Jan.-May, 1879; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; was posted to special duty in Upper Burma as civil officer, and appointed a deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Feb., 1886; author of 'Across Chruse,' 'Among the Shans,' 'The Truth about Tonquin,' 'The Opening of China,' 'Burma and the Burmans.'

COLVIN, SIR AUCKLAND, K.C.M.G., C.I.E., Bengal C.S., (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton; appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating under secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1864, and in the foreign department, Jan. to Nov. 1865; settlement officer, 2nd grade, July, 1866; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1870; on special duty to Naini Tal, in connection with the revision of settlement in the Allahabad district, June, 1870; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, April, 1873, and again in 1875; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, June, 1873; member of commission for investigating disturbances in Poona and Ahmednagar, Aug., 1875; magistrate and collector, Basti, Feb., 1877, and afterwards at Bijoor; officiating commissioner of inland customs under the government of India, Nov., 1877; transferred for employment in Egypt,
Jan., 1879, and served as controller of Egyptian finance, and subsequently as finance minister to the Egyptian government; acted as consul-general in Sir E. Malet's absence; financial member of council of the governor-general of India, 11th Oct., 1883.

COLVIN, Bazett Wetenhall, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; arrived in India, 29th June, 1850; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector till Jan., 1854; and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1855; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, July, 1865, and civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, July, 1873; officiated as commissioner of the Jhansi division, April, 1873, and of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1873; on special duty at Agra during the visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Feb., 1876; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1876; commissioner, Meerut division, Jan., 1877; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1877, to May, 1881; board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; retired, April, 1885.

COLVIN, Clement S., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, and by private tuition in England and on the Continent; temporary clerk, 1863; junior clerk, military department, 1864; funds department, 1867; private secretary to secretary of state (the Duke of Argyll), 1873-74; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state, 1874-77; and accompanied Sir Louis Mallet on his deputation to India in 1875-76; senior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, 1877; resident clerk, 1877 to 1885; public works department, 1877; government director of Madras irrigation and canal company, 1880-82; assistant secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph department, Sept., 1882; assistant government director of Indian railway companies, 1882.

COLVIN, Elliot Graham, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1883; transferred to Assam as personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1884; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1884; officiating assistant political agent, Rajputana, Dec., 1884.

CONDER, James, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Sept., 1870; executive engineer, Neemuch railway, Oct., 1873; Punjab northern state railway, 1874; personal assistant to engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, June, 1875; provisional assistant director of state railways, western system, 1877; traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, May, 1878; officiating manager, southern section, Western Rajputana railway, Aug., 1879; manager, Holkar, Sindia-Neemuch, and Neemuch-Nusseerabad railways, Feb., 1881; officiating manager, Nagpur-Chhattisgarh and Wardha coal railways, Nov., 1883; traffic superintendent, Rajputana-Malwa railways, Sept., 1884.

CONDON, James Hunt, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 25th July, 1859; served under the military department till Oct., 1861, when he was appointed civil assistant surgeon in Oudh; from April, 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to surgeon, Feb., 1871, and surgeon-major, July, 1873; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cawnpore, March, 1871; brigade surgeon, Oct., 1886.

CONINGHAM, Henry Evelyn, Major-General, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 18th March, 1855; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1861, as assistant superintendent and superintendent, and acted as deputy inspector-general, Sept., 1883, to May, 1884; 1st grade superintendent, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

CONNAUGHT and STRATHAERN, Duke of, H.R.H. Arthur William Patrick Albert, K.G., K.T., K.P., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., C.B.—Commander-in-chief, and 2nd member of council, Bombay, 14th December, 1886.

CONNELL, Charles James, M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner; from May, 1874, to Feb., 1878, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Gonda and Fyzabad; first assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1878; from Nov., 1879, served as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1882, and acted on various occasions as secretary; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884, and acted as secretary to government in 1884 and 1885; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1886.

CONNEMARA (Baron), Right Hon. Robert Bourke, G.C.I.E.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, Nov., 1852; M.P. for Lynn Regis from Dec., 1868; parliamentary under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Feb., 1874, to April, 1880; a royal commissioner on the laws relating to copyright, Oct., 1875; privy councillor, April, 1880; again parliamentary under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; governor of Madras, Sept., 1886.

CONOLLY, Edward Robert, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th April, 1883; from Sept., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; on special duty as assistant to Major Cavagnari, Feb., 1879, and again at Khyber, Feb., 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Bannu, Nov., 1884; also district judge.

CONSTABLE, Edwin T., M.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as mathematical professor, Bareilly College, 25th Feb., 1865; inspector of public instruction, 1st circle, Aug., 1870; inspector of schools, Meerut division, Dec., 1877; Benares division, Dec., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1883; 1st grade of education officers, April, 1883; inspector of schools, Meerut, and inspector of European schools, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Sept., 1884.
CONWAY-GORDON, Lewis, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, India.—1st commission, 1857; joined the public works department, May, 1862, and served in the Punjab; assistant principal, Roorkee College, 1865; assistant consulting engineer, railway department, and examiner of accounts, Punjab, Oct., 1866; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary, railway branch, Punjab, Oct., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, Punjab, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer to government of India for guaranteed railways 1871; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, March, 1874; controller of accounts, Madras, 1875 to 1879; 1st class examiner, Jan., 1879; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, April, 1881; deputy accountant-general, public works department, and ex officio under secretary to government of India, Sept., 1881; acted as accountant-general and deputy-secretary, May to Aug., 1883; deputed on special duty to England in 1884, to give evidence before the select committee of the House of Commons on railways in India; temporarily manager, Eastern Bengal state railway, 1884; manager, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; director, North-Western railway, March, 1887.

CONYBEARE, Henry Crawford Arthur, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Westminster School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; on special duty for preparation of provincial gazetteer, July, 1877; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1884; author of 'An Account of Pargana Dudhi, in South Mirzapur.'

COOK, Henry, Surgeon-Major, M.D. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 31st Aug., 1865, and served as civil surgeon at various stations, superintendent of vaccination, and superintendent of jail; acted as second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, 1879-80, and as senior surgeon and professor of surgery 1881-82; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Dec., 1881; civil surgeon, Poona, with medical charge of the Deccan College and College of Science, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, April, 1883, also superintendent and teacher of medicine and therapeutics at the medical school; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, Oct., 1884.

COOK, Henry, Deputy-Surgeon General, M.D., F.R.C.P. (Lon.), F.G.S., F.M.S., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 24th Jan., 1855; arrived in India, 28th July, 1855, and served under the military department up to 1859, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Karachi in 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force in 1857 (medal); appointed medical officer to political agency, Khelat, April, 1859; and accompanied H.H. the Khan of Khelat and Sir H. Green on a military expedition into Makran; from April, 1861, served as civil surgeon in Ahmednagar and Satara, and as superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, and assistant collector and magistrate at that station; scientific officer, Abyssinian field force, Dec., 1867 (medal); from June, 1871, served in Bombay as acting and physician, Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and acting professor of physiology and of hygiene at the Grant Medical College, and was confirmed in these appointments, May, 1873; 1st physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, principal and professor of medicine and hygiene, Grant Medical College, Sept., 1876; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, June, 1884; author of various papers published in the transactions of the Medical and Physical Society of Bombay, on the geology, topography, and meteorology of different portions of Biluchistan, and on other scientific and medical subjects, also of various reports on similar subjects published by order of government, and of a paper read before the British Association, on the registration of atmospheric ozone in Bombay, with reference to epidemic cholera, 1869.

COOKE, Crawford Boyd, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission assigned, March, 1864; served under the military department up to Dec., 1868, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Burma; acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1871 to Feb., 1874; from Feb., 1874, to May, 1877, served as political agent at Bhamo, Upper Burma, and from May, 1879, to Jan., 1884, as cantonment magistrate in Nowgong, Bundelcund; from Jan., 1884, served as deputy commissioner in Burma, and was appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1886; author of the 'British Burma Manual.'

COOKE, Henry Giraud, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, June, 1886.

COOKE, Henry Reade, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of General Administration Report of Bombay Presidency for 1879-80; first assistant collector, June, 1885.

COOKE, John Edward, Financial Department, government of India.—From Oct., 1863, to April, 1868, served as assistant secretary to the government of India in the financial department; officiated as deputy accountant-general, first in Bengal and then in Hyderabad, and as accountant-general in Bengal, 1868-69; deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, Aug., 1870, and in Madras, Jan., 1874; officiating accountant-general, Madras, Aug.-Oct., 1874; assistant comptroller-general, May, 1875; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878, to July, 1883, and officiated as accountant-general in 1880, 1882, and 1883; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1883; acted as accountant general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, in 1884; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1886.

COOKE, Samuel, M.A., F.I.C., F.G.S. A.M.I.C.E., Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of chemistry and geology at
the Engineering College, Poona, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, June, 1875.

COOKE, THEODORE, M.A., M.I., LL.D. (Dub.), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, Nov., 1860; from June, 1865, served in the Bombay educational department as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Poona, and also officiated as lecturer on chemistry and geology; 1st grade of the educational department, March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Feb.–May, 1884.

COOKSON, HUGH CECIL, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Dec., 1883, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1886.

COOPER, CHARLES PHILIP (Barrister-at-Law), Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1863; served from June, 1864, as examiner of the insolvent debtors' court, Bombay; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer in the high court; police magistrate, Bombay, from Oct., 1871; acting first judge of the small cause court, Sept., 1873; senior magistrate of police and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1874.

COOPER, H. A., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, accountant-general's department, 3rd June, 1880; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1881.

COPESTON, FREDERICK SELWYN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd October, 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Sept., 1874; on special duty in Rangoon, Nov., 1879; on forest demarcation duty, Toungoo, Jan., 1880; deputy superintendent of census, Sept., 1880; judge under the Land Acquisition Act, March, 1881; officiating deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1885; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim and Pegu, March, 1886; deputy commissioner, 1887.

CORBYN, EDWIN COLNETT, Lieut.-Col., B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; from Nov., 1861, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, 1st class, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; 1st grade deputy commissioner, Dec., 1884; also district judge, Ferozepur.

CORDERY, JOHN GRAHAM, M.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1856; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; from Oct., 1864, to Sept., 1868, served in the Hyderabad Assigned Districts as deputy commissioner and assistant resident; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, Jan., 1872, to May, 1873; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1877; officiating secretary to government of Punjab, April–Aug., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Multan, April, 1879; also acted as political agent and superintendent, Bahawalpur State, May–Nov., 1879; commissioner, Peshawur, April, 1881; resident, Hyderabad, April, 1883; C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

CORNISH, ROBERT, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Lancing College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine relief duty, May–Dec., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884.

CORNISH, WILLIAM ROBERT, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., C.I.E., late Madras Medical Service.—Studied at St. George's Hospital (scholar and prizeman); appointed to the Madras medical service, April, 1854; arrived in India, 2nd July, 1854; served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon of Coimbatore, 1857–58; secretary to the director general of the medical department, Oct., 1858, to Feb., 1870; consulting physician to the Irrigation Canal Company, April, 1860; on special duty at Calcutta as Madras member and secretary to the commission for the reorganization of medical establishments, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866; secretary of Madras medical fund, 1864–70; on special duty for revision of medical code of regulations, 1869–70; sanitary commissioner, Madras, March, 1870, to April, 1880; member of committee for review of general hospital establishments, 1873–74; on special duty as member of the cinchona alkaloid commission in 1874 and 1875; during the famine of 1876–78, was specially engaged in organising a system of sanitary and medical inspection; surgeon-major, April, 1874; was superintendent of Madras census, and proceeded on special duty to Calcutta as member of census committee, Jan., Feb., 1878; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; appointed C.I.E., Jan., 1880; deputy surgeon-general, April, 1880; surgeon-general with the government of Madras, April, 1880–85; was member of a commission to draw up a code for famine relief, and member and president of a committee on local government; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1883; retired from the service, April, 1885; was appointed fellow of Madras University, Feb., 1867, and president of the medical faculty, 1880–85; hon. physician to the Queen; author of various contributions to the medical press, of sanitary reports to government, and the Madras census report, 1873; was for some time editor of the 'Madras Quarterly Journal of Medical Science.'

CORNWALL, WILLIAM WOLFRAN GARDNER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Fatehpur, March, 1881; and afterwards at Farukhabad.

COSSINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to
the Bengal C.S., after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1886; assistant commissioner in Assam, Jan., 1886.

COTTON, Sir Arthur Thomas, General, Kt., K.C.S.I., R.E.—Joined Addiscombe, 1818; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1821, as 2nd lieutenant of engineers; assistant to superintending engineer, tank department, May, 1822; served with the Burmese expedition, 1824-26; from June, 1826, served as superintending engineer in the tank department, and in 1828 was appointed to the charge of the Cauvery irrigation, being also employed in the survey and improvement of the Paumber pass; in 1844 was appointed to the northern division of the tank department, and was employed in carrying out the systematic irrigation of the Godavari delta; promoted to chief engineer, 1852; in 1858 was ordered to Cuttack, and planned works for the irrigation of the Mahanadi delta, and was afterwards employed under the government of Bengal, reporting upon the water communication between the Ganges and Calcutta; resigned government service in 1862; in 1863, was employed under the Madras irrigation company, reporting on their works, and also inspecting the Ganges canal works, and proposed additional works, which were afterwards carried out as the Lower Ganges Canal; also projected works for the Sone irrigation, which have since been partially executed; general, 1876; retired from the army in 1877.

COTTON, Henry John Stedman, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College School, Brighton College, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 29th Oct., 1867; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed officiating small cause court judge, Sealdah, March, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1873; officiating registrar, high court, Dec., 1873; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1875; junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1876; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1878; officiating commissioner, Chittagong, Sept., 1879, and again, April, 1884; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1882; author of a 'Memorandum on the Revenue History of Chittagong,' 1880, 'Memorandum on the Land Tenures of Bengal,' 1884, and 'England and India—New India, or India in transition.'

COUCH, Right Hon. Sir Richard, Knt.—Recorder of Bedford, 1838 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature at Bombay, 1869-66; chief justice, Bombay, 1866-70; chief justice of Bengal, March, 1870, to April, 1875, and was president of the commission appointed to inquire into the charges made against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Feb., 1875; made a privy councillor, and sworn in, 27th Nov., 1875; a member of the judicial committee, Jan., 1881.

COUCHE, T. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

COUPER, Sir George E. W., Bart., K.C.S.I., C.B., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sandhurst, and served in H.M.'s 15th regiment for two years before joining the East India College, Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1846; served in Bengal and the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary, government of India, home and finance department, 1853; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, 1854; secretary to chief commissioner of Oudh, 1855; served through the siege of Lucknow, and was present at several engagements during the mutiny as aide-de-camp to Sir H. Lawrence and Sir John Inglis, and afterwards to Sir James Outram; commissioner in Oudh, 1858; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; judicial commissioner of Oudh, 1863; chief commissioner of Oudh, 1874; lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces, 1876, as well as chief commissioner of Oudh; retired 1882.

COURT, Major Henry, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; compiled 'Statistical Report and History of the Budaon District'; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, 1853, and subsequently at Allahabad; president of special commission on the police of India, 1860; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, 1861 to 1866; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1866, and subsequently of the Meerut division, 1869; retired 1872.

COURTENAY, Robert, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of the 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency for 1883-84'; from March, 1885, acted as assistant judge.

COWIE, Alexander John, Deputy Surgeon-General, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1854; served under the military department with various regiments, and also held several civil surgeoncies in Burma; sanitary commissioner, British Burma, 1868-72; served subsequently with the 37th N.I.; garrison staff surgeon, Fort William, Nov., 1872; principal medical storekeeper in 1873-75, and again in 1876-84; examiner of medical accounts (military), Jan., 1875; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Presidency district, April, 1884; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Bengal, March, 1885.

COWIE, Henry George, B.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—From Nov., 1863, to April, 1876, served in the grades of assistant accountant-general and assistant comptroller-general, and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, in the N.W. Provinces, and at Calcutta; from April, 1876, to March, 1883, served in the Central Provinces as deputy accountant-general and deputy commissioner paper currency; comptroller, Assam, March, 1883; class 3 of the financial department, Sept., 1883.

COWIE, Thomas Renny, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 12th Aug., 1860; employed under the military department till Aug., 1869, from which date he served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating sub-judge; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1881, and subsequently at Cawnpore, 1886.

COWLEY, Francis William Rice, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Uni-
versity; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived and Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at the disposal of the public works department, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, June, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and was promoted to the 1st grade, Aug., 1885; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpore, May, 1886.

COX, ARTHUR FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled 'The North Arcot District Manual'; on special duty in connection with visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; from Sept., 1882, served in the financial department, and was appointed officiating assistant accountant-general, first in Madras and afterwards in Bombay; assistant comptroller-general, 3rd class, July, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of state paper currency, May, 1886.

COX, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

COX, HENRY WILLIAM HOLMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Nov., 1857; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; served in the Madras police from April, 1861, and was promoted to superintendent, April, 1873; assistant inspector-general, Dec., 1881; acting commissioner of police, Madras city, September, 1883; presidency magistrate, Oct., 1883; political officer in charge of ex-King Theebaw of Burma, Dec., 1885, to April, 1886; deputy inspector-general of police, Madras, Aug., 1886.

COX, JOHN HANDS MORRELL, Revenue Settlement Department, Madras.—Served from 18th March, 1861, in the revenue settlement department, Madras, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collectors of Cuddapah and Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, May, 1867, to April, 1871, and again in North Arcot, May, 1882; acting special deputy collector for state relief works, Jan., 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883.

COXE, HENRY REYNAL HOLLED, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagulpore, Nov., 1884.

COXHEAD, THOMAS EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 8th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on famine duty, Tirhoot, April, 1874; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1876; magistrate and collector, and grade, Aug., 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, Sept., 1886.

CRADDOCK, REGINALD HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1884; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1884.

CRANBROOK, (Viscount), Rt. Hon. GATHORNE GATHORNE-HARDY, G.C.S.I.—Born 1st Oct., 1814; educated at Shrewsbury School, and at Oriel College, Oxford (B.A. in 1836, 2nd class in classics); called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1840, and practised as a barrister for several years; contested Bradford unsuccessfully 1847; sat in the House of Commons for Leominster from 1856 to 1865, when he was returned for Oxford; under secretary of state for the home department, 1858; president of the poor law board, July, 1860; secretary of state for the home department, May, 1867, to Dec., 1868; secretary of state for war, Feb., 1874; raised to the house of peers as Viscount Cranbrook, May, 1878; secretary of state for India, March, 1878, to May, 1880; lord president of council, June, 1880, to Feb., 1886, and again, Aug., 1886.

CRASTER, GEORGE AVTON, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th Dec., 1849; served under the military department till 1853; from Nov., 1853, served as assistant and executive engineer in Assam, Oudh, and the Punjab; promoted to executive engineer 1st grade, April, 1865; transferred to N.W. Provinces as officiating superintending engineer, March, 1866; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, public works department, April, 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; promoted to 1st class, March, 1881; retired, 1886.

CRAWFORD, ARTHUR TRAVERS, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1855, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and special income tax officer; from Feb., 1862, to June, 1864, served as assistant judge and session judge, and acting judge and session judge; registrar-general of assurances, Jan., 1865; acting collector of Bombay, special income tax commissioner, collector of income tax, president of the income tax commission, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1865; municipal commissioner for Bombay, June, 1865, to Oct., 1871; member of the architecture improvement committee, Bombay, Sept., 1866; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1875; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Kolaba, Feb., 1876, and afterwards at Ratnagiri, 1876-79; on special duty at Kolaba, June-July, 1876; on special duty as president of the G.T.P. railway commission in connection with the railway robberies, March-Aug., 1878; from May, 1879, acted as commissioner, southern division, and was confirmed as commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; British delegate for the
Portuguese treaty, Goa, Sept., 1879, and was on special duty under the government of India in connection with customs arrangements with native states in Bombay, Nov., 1880, to March, 1881; also on special duty, Oct.–Nov., 1882, at Simla, and Jan.–Feb., 1884, and in Europe, Feb. to Aug., 1884; commissioner, central division, March, 1886.

CRAWFORD, CHARLES EDWARD GORDON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Jan., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, railway magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; also acted as district superintendent of police, Aug.–Oct., 1875; from Jan., 1879, acted in the judicial department as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; and grade assistant judge, Aug., 1883; also acted as judge and sessions judge in various districts, and as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Feb.–May, 1885; registrar, high court, Bombay, September, 1885.

CRAWFORD, JAMES ADAIR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1881, served in the political department, and acted as assistant to the governor-general's agent for Rajputana, boundary settlement officer in Meywar, and assistant to the resident at Hyderabad (June, 1881); attache, foreign department of government of India, May, 1882; in charge of office of press commissioner, June, 1882, to Nov., 1883; acting political agent, 3rd class, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1884; assistant secretary, foreign department, Jan., 1885; political agent, Quetta and Pishin, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886.

CRAWFORD, JOHN THOMSON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Perth Academy, Edinburgh University, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1864; from Feb., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; from Nov., 1880, served as district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, and from Jan., 1882, as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Unao, March, 1885.

CRAWFORD, RICHMOND IRVINE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1857; served in the pursuit of the Gwalior rebels in 1858 (medal and clasp for Central India); from September, 1864, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and (from April, 1867) as superintendent of police; from May, 1873, acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1875; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, Shikarpur, June, 1885; and subsequently at Karachi.

CRAWFORD, JAMES, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Glasgow, and Dublin University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector, Rajshahye, Jan., 1869; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1875; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1876; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1877; registrar, high court, Nov., 1878; district and sessions judge, and grade, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, Nuddea, Dec., 1885.

CRAWLEY-BOEVEY, ARTHUR WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special assistant to political agent, and acting political agent in Rewa Kantha; from May, 1873, to Dec., 1874, served in Baroda as acting assistant resident, and performed the duties of the cantonment and railway magistrate, and small cause court judge, May–Nov., 1873; in special charge of Sachin state, Dec., 1874; on special duty at Baroda, Feb., 1875; on famine duty at Kaladgi, Aug., 1877; Talukdari settlement officer, Gujerat, June, 1879; pro tem, special officer for the settlement of claims to giras and watans in Baroda territory, April, 1883, and again April, 1885.

CREEGEN, ARCHIBALD CRELLIN, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1859, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; transferred to Punjab, Feb., 1861; executive engineer, April, 1866; railway department, Central India, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1870; engineer-in-chief, provincial light railway survey extensions, Lucknow, June, 1878; Neemuch-Naseerabad survey, Nov., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Western Rajputana state railway, Aug., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Vizagapatam-Raipur railway survey, Oct., 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of public works department, Sept., 1883; engineer-in-chief, construction establishment, Nagpur-Bengal railway, Oct., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; agent and chief engineer, Indian Midland railway, Feb., 1886.

CRESSWELL, CHARLES ARTHUR, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1866; arrived in Madras, 12th Jan., 1867; joined the Burma commission, Feb., 1871, as officiating assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate at Toungoo; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Dec., 1875; boundary officer, Sandoway, March, 1881; president, Sandoway Town committee, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, March, 1885.

CROFT, SIR ALFRED WOODLEY, K.C.I.E., M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, 21st Dec., 1865; served as professor, Presidency College, officiating principal, Dacca College, and Presidency College, inspector of schools, and officiating registrar, Calcutta University, and was promoted to 2nd class of the educational service, Feb., 1877; director of public instruction, Aug., 1878; president of the commission to draw up a code for European schools, Oct., 1881; on special duty with the government of India, as member of the education commission, Jan., 1883; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

CROFTON, JAMES, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—and lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 9th Dec., 1844; joined the public works department, Nov., 1847; assistant engineer, Punjab circle, Dec.,
1849; superintendent, 1st division, Bari Doab canal, July, 1854; executive engineer, Punjab irrigation, 1858; superintendent engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1862; superintendent, Sutlej canal surveys; officiating superintendent, Eastern Jumna canals, 1863; chief engineer, irrigation, and under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1864; chief engineer, 1st class, April, 1872; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1874, to Jan., 1882, when he resigned the service.

CROLE, CHARLES STEWART, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh High School and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as sub-secretary, board of revenue, July—Sept., 1869, and as collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants in 1870-80; compiled Chingleput district manual; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, Jan.—March, 1880; district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1881; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882, in the district of Kistna, and afterwards in the districts of Madura and Anantapur; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Aug., 1886.

CROMBIE, ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1872; officiating resident surgeon, Calcutta Medical College Hospital, 25th Jan., 1873; professor of surgery, Medical College, in addition to his own duties, Oct., 1873; professor of materia medica, Sept., 1874; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1875, and appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and health officer to the port; from April, 1877, served in Bengal as civil surgeon, also at Simla as joint medical officer, March, 1880, to Feb., 1882; civil surgeon, Dacca, with charge of the jail, March, 1882; also superintendent of the lunatic asylum, medical school and Mitford Hospital; surgeon-major, March, 1884; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, Calcutta, March, 1886.

CROOKE, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's Grammar School, Tipperary, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1886; author of a rural and agricultural glossary for the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.

CROOKSHANK, ARTHUR CHICHESTER WILLIAM, Colonel, C.B., B.S.C.—1st commission, Jan., 1859, 65th Foot; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1862; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, April, 1884; deputy secretary, 1886.

CROSS (Viscount), Rt. Hon. Richard Asheton Cross, G.C.B.—Born 30th May, 1823; educated at Rugby School, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1846; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849, and for several years went the northern circuit; represented Preston in the House of Commons, March, 1857, to March, 1862, and S.W. Lancashire from Dec., 1868; secretary of state for the home department, Feb., 1874, to 1880; bencher of the Inner Temple, 1876; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, Oct., 1878; G.C.B. in 1880; again secretary of state for the home department, June, 1885; in Lord Salisbury's second administration, Aug., 1886, was appointed secretary of state for India, and raised to the peerage under the title of Viscount Cross; author of two legal works—'The Acts relating to the Settlement and Removal of the Poor, with Notices of Cases, Indices, and Forms,' 1853; and 'The General and Quarter Sessions of the Peace; their Jurisdiction and Practice in other than Criminal Matters' (written in conjunction with Mr. H. Leaming), 1858, and edition, 1876.

CROSTHWAITE, CHARLES HAUKES TODD, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; from Nov., 1858, to March, 1877, served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and settlement officer, and acted as secretary to the board of revenue for two years from March, 1875; from April, 1877, served in the Central Provinces as commissioner of the Nagpur and Jubbulpur divisions, and was appointed judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881, and additional member of the governor-general's council for the purpose of making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881; acting chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1883, to April, 1884; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1885; member of the public service commission, Nov., 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; chief commissioner of Burma, March, 1887.

CROSTHWAITE, ROBERT JOSEPH, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty on the revenue committee at Naini Tal, July, 1872; assistant superintendent, sub-judge, and registrar of Dehra Dun, Dec., 1873; small cause court judge, Allahabad, March, 1875; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1878, to Feb., 1881; acting secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March to May, 1881; district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1881; additional secretary to government of India, legislative department, Jan., 1883; acted as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1882 and 1883, and was confirmed in the appointment, Jan., 1885.

CROW, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, 23rd Oct., 1883.

CROWDY, JOHN HENRY, Lieut-Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; posted to Indian establishment, Sept., 1870; from Dec., 1870, served as executive engineer in the Punjab; transferred to military works, 1872, and served in the Punjab, the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; superintending engineer, 3d class, March, 1886.

CROWE, WILLIAM HENRY (Barrister-at-
Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of mental and moral philosophy and logic at the Deccan College, Poona, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and assistant judge and sessions judge; editor of the 'Bombay Gazetteer' Oct., 1868; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, March, 1882; on special duty at Kathiawar, Nov., 1882; appointed 2nd grade judge and session judge, Thana, Aug., 1883, and afterwards at Satara; 1st grade judge, Sept., 1885.

CROZIER, ROBERT G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; temporary clerk, India Office, 30th Nov., 1865; junior clerk, Jan., 1867.
