FANSHAWE, ARTHUR UPTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July, 1880, and acted as secretary in 1880 and 1881; in charge of model farm, Nagpur, July, 1880, to Jan., 1881; from April, 1881, served in the postal department as officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1882; also officiated as director-general of the post office in India, Aug., 1884.

FANSHAWE, HERBERT CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bedford, Tonbridge, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1873, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab; served temporarily in Bengal on famine duty Feb.–Nov., 1874; officiating settlement officer, Rohtak, Aug., 1875, to Feb., 1876, and again in 1877; under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, March, 1879; assistant to the officer on special duty in Kashmir, June, 1879; officiating junior secretary to government, Oct. to Dec., 1882, and again in 1883 and 1884; officiating secretary to government, Jan., to April, 1884; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1885.

FARMER, HENRY RICHARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Loughborough, Bromsgrove, and Uppingham Grammar Schools; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acted as Tamil translator to government, Feb., 1880, to Sept., 1881; on special duty completing treatise on Madras Act viii. of 1865, July, 1882; acting district and sessions judge, Kurnool, Oct., 1886.

FARQUHAR, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 28th May, 1858; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, and served under the military department in Madras, Burma, and the Straits Settlements; also held civil medical charge, Toungoo, in 1859; medical officer, Ootacamund, from Nov., 1882; promoted to brigade surgeon, April, 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Belgaum and Western Districts, July, 1885.

FARRAN, C. F., B.A. (Dublin), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served as reporter, high court, Bombay, 1868–1874, also as acting government professor of law, April, 1868, to June, 1870, and Perry professor of jurisprudence, June, 1870, to Jan., 1872; acted as clerk of the crown, Sept., 1874, to Sept., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1880; acting advocate general, Bombay, May–Dec., 1884; additional judge of the high court, Bombay, Nov., 1886.

FARRAN, G. H., M.A. (Dublin), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 17th May, 1866, as head assistant in the prothonotary's office, high court, Bombay, acting prothonotary, ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, acting official assignee of the insolvent debtors' court, and acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court; deputy registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits, and judge's clerk, Nov., 1873; assistant commissioner for taking accounts and assistant taxing master, July, 1876; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer.

FARRER, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Heversham Grammar School, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served
in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; postmaster-general, Madras, June, 1886.

Fasson, Herbert John Hamilton, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School, Quebec, and Bray College, Wicklow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty at Dinajepore, March, 1874; assistant settlement officer, Chittagong, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1885.

Faulder, Cecil Joseph Salkeld, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector.

Fawcett, George William, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, deputy commissioner of salt revenue, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector and magistrate, Malabar, July, 1883.

Fayrer, Sir Joseph, Surgeon-General, K.C.S.I., LL.D., M.D., F.R.S.S. (London and Edinburgh), F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., Medical Board, India Office.—Acting assistant surgeon, R.N., Aug., 1847; assistant surgeon, royal artillery, 1849; joined the East India Company's service April, 1850, and served under the military department, also holding civil surgeoncy of Cheera Poonjee, Nov., 1850; served in the Burma campaign, and officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, Feb., 1853; appointed residency surgeon, Lucknow, by Lord Dalhousie, for services during war in Burma; honorary assistant resident at Lucknow, Sept., 1854; civil surgeon, Lucknow, March, 1856; brevet rank of surgeon for services in defence of Lucknow residency during the siege, Sept., 1858; officiating professor of surgery and ex-officio 1st surgeon of Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, May, 1859; confirmed in these appointments, June, 1860; medical charge of Mysore princes, June, 1860; fellow of University of Calcutta and member of the senate, March, 1861; served for two years as president of the medical faculty, and received the public thanks of the faculty; surgeon, July, 1864; consulting surgeon to Howrah General Hospital Nov., 1865; president of the Asiatic Society; Bengal, 1867; J.P. for Calcutta, Feb., 1868; government trustee for India Museum, 1869; officiating surgeon to viceroy, Jan.-Feb., 1869; accompanied H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh on his tour through India, Jan.-March, 1870; surgeon-major, June, 1870; honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1871; accompanied H.R.H. the Prince of Wales to India, 1875-76, in medical charge of his party; retired, 1874; president of medical board, India Office, Dec., 1874; member of army sanitary commission; member of senate of Army Medical School at Netley; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital; author of 'Clinical Surgery in India,' 'Clinical and Pathological Observations in India,' 'Thanatophidia of India' (presented to the Indian government, by whom it was published in 1872), and other works; has also published numerous papers, monographs, and addresses, on medical and scientific subjects.

Fenton, Michael William, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1883, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov.-Dec., 1885; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, revenue department, April, 1887.

Fenton, T. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd May, 1873; attached to the store department till Aug., 1879, and subsequently to the registry department.

Ferard, Henry Cecil, Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1885, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

Feret, C. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

Ferguson, Henry Tanner, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined public works department as locomotive superintendent, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley Railway, Oct., 1879; Punjab Northern State Railway, Aug., 1881; class 1, state railway, revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, North-Western Railway, Jan., 1886.

Fergusson, Rt. Hon. Sir James Bart., G.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E., M.P.—Born in 1832; educated at Rugby, and University College, Oxford; entered the Grenadier Guards, and served in the Crimean campaign, 1854-55 (medal and three clasps); retired from the army in 1855; represented the county of Ayr in parliament in the Conservative interest from Dec., 1854, to April, 1857, and from Oct., 1859 to 1868; under secretary of state for India, June, 1866, to July, 1867; under secretary for the home department, July, 1867, to Aug., 1868; governor of South Australia, Aug., 1868; governor of New Zealand, March, 1873-1874; governor of Bombay, April, 1880, to March, 1885; parliamentary under secretary of state, foreign office, Aug., 1886; royal commissioner for the Adelaide Exhibition of 1887.

Ferrar, Michael Lloyd, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Belfast Academical Institution, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, to Sept., 1865, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Sept., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner; from July, 1868, to April, 1875, served in the settlement department, and was appointed to take up lands for railway purposes in Lucknow, Aug., 1870; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, in 1882 and 1883; deputy
commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1883; magistrate and collector, Etah, March, 1884.

FFINCH, B. T., Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, 5th Nov., 1857; deputy director of the Persian Gulf section, from April, 1875; director Persian Gulf, March, 1884; also acted as assistant political agent, Gwadar, Aug., 1879, and as political agent, Aug., 1884.

FIDDIAN, JAMES PAULL, Madras C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Bellary, Dec., 1884.

FIDDIAN, WILLIAM, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Huddersfield College, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine duty, May, 1874; officiating commissioner, Soonderbunds, Jan. 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1886.

FIELD, CHARLES DICKENSON, M.A., LL.D. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating judge of the principal court of small causes, Kishnaghrur and Jessore, officiating magistrate and collector, and registrar, high court (July, 1867); from Dec., 1870, served in the judicial department, and was placed on special duty in connection with a commission to consider the question of amending the rent law of Bengal, May, 1879; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1879; judge, high court, Oct., 1880; retired, Sept., 1886; author of 'Rent Law Procedure in Bengal,' 'Essays on Indian Topics,' 'Chronological Table of, and Index to, the Indian Statute Book,' 'The Law of Evidence in British India,' 'The Law relating to Protestant Curates,' 'The Regulations of the Bengal Code,' 'A Digest of the Law of Landlord and Tenant in Bengal,' and 'Landholding and the Relation of Landlord and Tenant in various Countries.'

FIELD, GEORGE A., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; supernumerary writer, 30th May, 1859; copying clerk, Sept., 1860; assistant to registrar, March, 1882.

FILGATE, ALEXANDER JEROME, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—First commission, 1857; served in the China war, 1860 (medal and clasps); joined the Madras public works department, Oct., 1863, as assistant engineer, South Canara; deputy controller, public works accounts, July, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, and examiner of accounts, Feb., 1866; from March, 1867, served in the public works department of the government of India, as assistant accountant-general; deputy accountant-general, and ex-officio under secretary to government, March, 1872; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1879, to Nov. 1880; confirmed as accountant-general, and deputy secretary, Sept., 1881; member of finance committee, April, 1886, to March, 1887.

FILGATE, TOWNLEY P. H. MACARTNEY, Registration Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 1st March, 1867, and served as military secretary to governor of Bombay, and registrar-general of assurances, Bombay Presidency (from Aug., 1870); from July, 1871, served as inspector-general of registration; on special duty, Nov.-Dec., 1876, engaged in selecting prisoners for release from the jails of the Bombay Presidency on the occasion of the proclamation of the Empress of India, 1st Jan., 1877; on special duty, Dec., 1879, as member of the committee on the registration law, at Calcutta; acting inspector-general of prisons, Dec., 1886.

FINCH, C. T., Accounts Department, India Office, Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

PINK, W. R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Assistant to the taxing officer and registrar, high court Calcutta, 1878; chief clerk, high court of judicature, 1885.

FINLAY, JAMES FAIRBAIRN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty in the public works department, Oct., 1880; transferred to finance department of government of India, May, 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as officiating assistant accountant-general and officiating deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general in 4th class of financial department, July, 1882; officiating under secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, Aug., 1883; officiating secretary to government of India, financial department, Aug.-Nov., 1885.

FINLAY, HERBERT BLAKEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, Dec., 1865; from May, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Oct., 1873, to April, 1880, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, July, 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, July, 1885; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1885.

FINUCANE, MICHAEL, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Munchin's College, Limerick, Limerick Collegiate Academy, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1872; manager, Raj Darbhunga, Sept., 1879; settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Jan., 1882; on special duty, Midnapore, May, 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, and director of the agricultural depart-
ment in Bengal, Dec., 1884; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; edited Bengal Tenancy Act viii. of 1885.

FIREBRACE, Frederick, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1861; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1862; assistant principal Roorkee College, 1865-68; officiating assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, May, 1868; manager, Calcutta and S.E. Railway, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, Sept., 1870; Neemuch railway survey, Feb., 1871; assistant director of state railways, March, 1875; manager, Rajputana state railway, Nov., 1876; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, April, 1877; on duty at the Royal Engineering College, Cooper's Hall, Sept., 1878, to Nov., 1879; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, July, 1885; consulting engineer and joint secretary, Bombay, Feb., 1887.

FISHER, Frederick Henry, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Boston Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause judge of Dehra Dün, March, 1879; officiating civil and sessions judge, Saharanpur, Oct., 1881; on special duty in connection with the preparation of the Provincial Gazetteer, Dec., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1885; retired, Aug., 1885.

FISHER, John Hadden, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1861; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Jan., 1872, to April, 1879, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner; from April, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade; magistrate and collector, April, 1880.

FITZMAURICE, John Day Stokes, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Jan., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, May, 1886.

FITZGERALD, Edward Ambrose, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1850; arrived in India 27th Jan., 1860, and was employed under the military department, 1860-68; from Feb., 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Jaunpur; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1873; served subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.

FITZGERALD, James, Colonel, B.S.C., Berar Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; arrived in India, Sept., 1856; was employed under the military department up to 1862, including service in the mutiny, 1857-59, and was present at the siege and capture of Delhi (medal and clasp); served in the China war, 1860, and was present at the capture of Pekin (medal and two clasps); from Aug., 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, railway magistrate, and deputy commissioner.

FITZGERALD, James Richard, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1875, served under the foreign department, government of India, as assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, and assistant to resident, Hyderabad; on special duty in connection with control of Moghias, Jan., 1878; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1878; officiating 1st assistant and secretary for Berar to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1882; held charge of the office of resident, May, 1882; from July, 1882, served in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner, and acted as commissioner, Aug.-Oct., 1882; magistrate of the district of Ajmere, Oct., 1882; first assistant, governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, May, 1883; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1883; held charge of the agent's office in 1883-84, and of the Kalat Political Agency, Nov.-Dec., 1884; from April, 1885, acted as 1st assistant and secretary for Berar, Hyderabad.

FITZGERALD, Sir W. G. S. V., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., India Office.—Educated at Harrow, and Oriel College, Oxford; political aide-de-camp to the secretary of state for India, 14th Aug., 1874; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; K.C.I.E., Aug., 1887.

FITZPATRICK, Dennis, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge, and was placed on special duty in England in connection with Begum Sumroo's case, March, 1869, and at Calcutta in the legislative department of government of India, May, 1873; deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department, 1874; secretary in the legislative department from 1877; is also secretary to the governor-general's council; acted as judge of the chief court, Punjab, in 1876-77, and as secretary to government of India, home department, Jan.-April, 1885; acting chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

FLEET, John Faithfull, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector, Dec., 1878; on special duty in England, Jan.-May, 1879, and again in 1884 and 1885; epigraphist to the government of India, Jan., 1883; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Sholapur, June, 1886.

FLEMING, Allan Stopford, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Harrow, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination
of 1880; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1882, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

FLETCHER, WILLIAM MORRIS, Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India 2nd June, 1865, and served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, acting assistant settlement officer, and acting deputy superintendent of survey; on special duty in connection with the famine, Nov., 1876; superintendent of survey, Sept., 1879.

FOORD, EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Lieutenant-General, R.E.—Second lieutenant, Madras Engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; arrived in India, July, 1844; assistant civil engineer, Oct., 1846; adjutant of engineers, 1850-52; assistant to secretary board of revenue, public works department, Madras, Aug., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in South Arcot and Tanjore, Dec., 1856, to May, 1863; superintending engineer, Tanjore and Trichinopoly, May, 1863; inspecting engineer for civil and military buildings, Madras, Dec., 1872; superintending engineer, Kista and Nellore, June, 1874; deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1875; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, buildings and roads branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, April, 1877; resigned the public works department and retired from the army, 31st Dec., 1878.

FOOTE, ROBERT BRUCE, F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined 28th Sept., 1883; served in various districts of the Madras Presidency, the Nizam's territory, and Bombay; deputed to Vienna Exhibition in joint charge of the survey collections, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1876; deputy superintendent, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University and member of the faculty of engineering, 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; author of contributions to the survey publications.

FORBES, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1867; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Sept., 1873; also secretary to the central relief committee, Jan., 1874; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1874, to May, 1876; on special duty at Sibsaugor, Jan., 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882.

FORBES, GEORGE FOREST GREENLAW, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

FORBES, GEORGE STUART, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue; from Sept., 1880, to Jan., 1883, was employed in the Madras secretariat as acting under secretary in the revenue department, assistant secretary, judicial and legislative department, and under secretary in the departments under the chief secretary, and also served on the board of examiners from Jan., 1882; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of India in the home department as officiating under secretary, also in the foreign department, on special duty, Dec., 1884, and as junior under secretary, Jan., 1885; also in charge of duties of press commissioner, March, 1885.

FORBES, JOHN GREENLAW, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 9th Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; during the mutiny, 1857-58, served at the siege of Delhi, the relief of Lucknow, the siege and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and three clasps); served in the public works department, Punjab, from 21st June, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and from July, 1863, in the N.W. Provinces; on special duty in the Madras Presidency, Feb., 1867, reporting on the Kaveri, Krishna, and Godavari canals; superintendent of irrigation works, Oudh, Dec., 1867; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, July to Nov., 1872; from Nov., 1872, served as superintending engineer in the irrigation branch in the N.W. Provinces, in the Punjab (Bari Doab Canal), and in Bengal (Sone circle), and officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Bengal, May to July, 1877; on special duty under the government of India to prepare a revised scheme for the Sardah canal, June, 1878; on special duty on the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi, and Indus valley railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, buildings and roads branch, April, 1881, and in the irrigation branch from Nov., 1881; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886.

FORBES, WILLIAM A., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1847; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Oude; served as political officer throughout the mutiny; medal with clasp for Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Jaunpore, 1862; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1872; officiated as member board of revenue, N.W. Provinces; retired, 1875.

FORBES, WALTER ERNEST, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 13th April, 1859; served from Oct., 1860, in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1876; commissioner, Lucknow division, July, 1883; Fyzabad division, Oct., 1883; author of report of the Partabgarh Settlement.

FORD, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1842; arrived in India, 7th July, 1842; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty in the Sikh states, April, 1846; assistant to the
governor-general's agent, N.W. Frontier, May, 1846; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and superintendent, cis-Sutlej territory, and officiating deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Goorgaon, 1856; deputy commissioner, 1st class, 1858; deputed on special duty to Cashmeer, March-Nov., 1860; commissioner and superintendent, Hissar division, Oct., 1864; Mooltan division, March, 1865; placed in charge of the state of Bhawalpoor, 1866; retired 1869; author of a report on native government as contrasted with the English system.

FORDHAM, JOHN WILLIAM, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department as assistant accountant, July, 1850; assistant controller, July, 1860; deputy controller, Holkar and Neemuch State Railways, Dec., 1871; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880.

FORTEY, HENRY, M.A. (Cambridge), late Education Department, Madras.—Head master, Government School, Kumbakonam, 9th Sept., 1854; professor and acting principal, Presidency College, March, 1856; from Dec., 1857, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 2nd class of education department, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, Feb., 1872; retired, Aug., 1885.

FOSTER, CHARLES J., Genera C.B.—Served with the 16th Lancers during the campaign in Afghanistan under Lord Keane, including the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); served also at the battle of Maharajapore, 9th Dec., 1843 (bronze star); and in the campaign on the Sutlej in 1846, including the battles of Buddiwal, Aliwal (as aide-de-camp to Brigadier Creton), and Sobraon (medal and clasp); appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, July, 1878.

FOSTER, HERBERT WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate.

FOSTER, WILLIAM SHRUBSOLE, M.A., late Madras C.S.—St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras from Nov., 1861, as assistant magistrate and collector, and sub-collector; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1873; collector and magistrate and political agent, Godaveri, April, 1875; retired, 1885.

FOSTER, W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Sept., 1882.

FOWLER, JAMES TOWNSHEND, F.R.G.S., F.S.A., Education Department, Madras.—Principal, Government Normal School, Madras, and Dec., 1855; fellow of Madras University, Sept., 1857; on special duty superintending formation of normal schools, May, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 1st class of educational department April, 1880; on special duty to Calcutta as member of the educational committee, Feb., 1882, and again, Aug., 1882, to March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Madras, April-June, 1883.

FOX, CHARLES EDWARD, M.A. (Cantab), (Barister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 9th Jan., 1866, as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts and local investigations, and taxing officer, high court, Bombay.

FOX, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Independent College, Taunton, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the Central Provinces, and from March, 1877, in Burma, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of central jail, Moulinmein, in 1877 and 1878; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, May, 1885.

FOX, G. J. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1877.

FOX-STRANGWAYS, MAURICE WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1882; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nagpur, Nov., 1882.

FOXTON, WILLIAM, B.A. (Oxon), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Aug., 1857; from Oct., 1857, served in the educational department as acting professor at the Poona and Elphinstone College, and head master of the English school, Ahmednagar, and was appointed tutor to ex-Ameers of Hyderabad, Sind, July, 1860; from Oct., 1860, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, deputy collector of income tax, acting judge and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; appointed judge of the court of small causes, cantonment magistrate, and superintendent of jail, Karachi, also Sindi translator to government, May 1876; acting collector of customs and shipping master, Karachi, and assistant collector of salt revenue in Sind, April, 1886.

FRANCIS, EDWARD BELCHAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, Feb. to Nov., 1874; officiating superintendent of Chamba, April-Aug., 1879; officiating secretary to financial commissioner Aug., 1879, and again in 1883-84; officiating judicial assistant in various districts, 1880-83.

FRANKS, CHARLES N. B., Public Works Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 19th Nov., 1856; junior clerk, railway department, India office, 1860; senior clerk, Feb., 1875.

FRANKS, EDWARD, Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1853; junior clerk, financial department, India office, Dec., 1866; funds department, 1867; senior clerk, military department, Aug., 1881.

FRASER, ALEXANDER, General, C.B., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 8th Dec., 1843; joined the public works department Sept., 1850, as executive engineer, Lower Provinces; executive engineer, Arracan, 1853, and subsequently at Rangoon; garrison engineer, presidency, Feb., 1856; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1859; superintendent, Alguada Reef and
other lighthouses, 1860; chief engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1862; officiating secretary to government of Bengal, and chief engineer, 1862; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Aug., 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1873; chief engineer and secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, to Jan., 1879; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Jan., 1879, to Feb., 1882.

FRASER, ANDREW HENDERSON LEITH, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1871; served in Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, Jan., 1877; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1877; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881; junior secretary to the chief commissioner, and director of agriculture, Feb., 1882; acting secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1882, and again in 1883–84; acting deputy commissioner, Wardha, March, 1884.

FRASER, HENRY, Colonel, Police Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Madras cavalry, 1854; arrived in India, 14th March, 1854; assistant to general superintendent, Thuggee and Dacoity department, Nagpur, July, 1860; joint magistrate, Nagpur and Berars, Aug., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the police department, Central Provinces; acted as inspector general, July-Aug., 1868; 1st class, district superintendent, Nov., 1885.

FRASER, HUGH, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1885.

FRASER, STUART MITFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

FRAZER, ROBERT WATSON, B.A., LL.B., M.R.I.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, engineer and manager of the Parla Kemedi estate (Jan.-Feb., 1882), acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy director of revenue settlement; retired, 1886.

FRENCH, Right Rev. T. LOUIS VALPY, D.D., Bishop of Lahore, 8th Feb., 1878.

FRIZELLE, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Punjab, May, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, Ferozepore, April, 1877; divisional judge, and grade, Nov., 1884.

FROST, CHARLES EVITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and foreign schools; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate and political agent, acting railway magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1884.

FRY, HENRY J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 18th Aug., 1873.

FRYER, FREDERICK WILLIAM RICHARD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at foreign schools, and at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1875; on special duty with the Quetta field force, Oct., 1878, and again, Feb., 1879; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1882; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, May, 1883; deputy commissioner, and grade, Dec., 1884; commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; author of a report on the settlement of the Dera Ghazi Khan district.

FRYER, GEORGE EDWARD, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853; assistant superintendent of police in Madras presidency, June, 1861; officiating assistant engineer, Madras public works department, May, 1862; from Jan., 1864, served in Burma as officiating assistant superintendent of police, and from Jan., 1865, as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner; cantonment magistrate, Thayetmyo, Nov., 1883.

FULLER, JOSEPH BAMPFYLDE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875; from Nov., 1875, to July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty as assistant director of agriculture and commerce, Feb., 1878; transferred to Central Provinces, July, 1882, and appointed acting director of agriculture and commerce, and junior secretary to the chief commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1882; commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Oct., 1885; author of 'A Primer of Agriculture,' and 'Field and Garden Crops of the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.'

FULTON, EDMUND McGILDDOWN HOPE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind, acting judge and session judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed registrar of the high court,
Bombay, Feb., 1881; and grade judge and sessions judge, Ratnagiri, Feb., 1886.

FURLONG, MALCOLM, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 10th Feb., 1857; served at the capture of Copul, 1853, and with the Bellary movable column, 1859 (medal); personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Burma, June, 1865; served in the Burma commission from Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1869, to Feb., 1871), and town magistrate of Prome; from Jan., 1880, acted as deputy commissioner of Mouline, also officiating as judge in 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1884; president, Mouline municipal committee, Jan., 1885.

FUNNELL, MICHAEL CUDMORE, Surgeon-General, C.I.E., M.D., M.R.C.S., F.A.S.L., F.R.C.S., late Medical Department, Madras.—Joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 7th Feb., 1855; arrived in India, 28th April, 1855, and served under the military department till Dec., 1865; served subsequently as civil surgeon in various districts, and also as professor at the Medical College, and ophthalmic surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; surgeon to H.E. the governor, March, 1871, to Dec., 1873; fellow of Madras University, April, 1872; acting superintendent, government central museum, June, 1874; surgeon-major, Feb., 1875; senior physician, General Hospital, and principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, March, 1875; sanitary commissioner, April, 1880; brigade surgeon, May, 1880; deputy surgeon-general Feb., 1881; surgeon-general, Madras, April, 1885; C.I.E., May, 1886; retired, Oct., 1886.

FURNIVALL, W. C., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, May, 1869, as superintending engineer on the Delhi and Rewari railway; 1st grade superintending engineer, Rajputana railway, March, 1874; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873, in charge of Rajputana railway as engineer-in-chief; officiating director of railways, central system, and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1877; joint secretary and officiating chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1879; director of construction for state railways, March, 1880; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Oct., 1880; services lent to the Bengal Central, and Bengal and N.W. railway companies, May, 1883; Nizam's guaranteed railway company, March, 1884; chief engineer, 2nd class (supernumerary), March, 1882; retired from public works department, 1886.

FYTCHE, ALBERT, General, B.S.C., C.S.I., F.R.G.S.—Educated at Rugby and Addiscombe; ensign in 70th regiment, Bengal army, Dec., 1838; was employed on the Arracan frontier in 1841-2, and captured the Walling Hill stockade; from July, 1845, served in the Arracan commission, as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Sandoway, July, 1846; took part in the second Sikh war, 1848-49, and was present at the actions of Chilianwallah and Goojerat (medal and two clasps); in Dec., 1852, was appointed deputy commissioner of Bassein, and took part in various military operations in that district, 1853-54 (medal and clasp, and brevet of major), and also in the operations against the Karen tribes, 1857; commissioner of Tenasserim and Martaban, April, 1857; chief commissioner of British Burma, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1867 to 1871; major-general in the army, Nov., 1868, and a companion of the order of the Star of India; general, 1881.

GAFNEY, JOHN BURKE, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1866, having previously served as assistant surgeon, Her Majesty's home service, 1864-65; arrived in India, 27th April, 1867; was employed under the military department, including service in the Nicobar expedition, 1867; house surgeon, medical college hospital, Calcutta, March, 1868; from June, 1868, served in the Central Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and assistant to the deputy commissioner, Upper Godavary district; from June, 1878, served as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Raipur, and afterwards at Seoni and Saugor.

GAIT, EDWARD ALBERT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884, and served as assistant commissioner in Assam.

GALBRAITH, EDGAR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1885.

GALTON, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley, Magdalen Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Aug., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), acting under secretary to government in the revenue department (March, 1872, to March, 1873), secretary to the board of revenue (Oct., 1879, to March, 1881, and in 1881-82), and acting collector of sea customs at Madras, and protector of emigrants; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Nov., 1885; acting commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, April, 1886; also acting additional member, board of revenue.

GAMBLE, JAMES SYKES, M.A., F.L.S., Madras Forest Department.—Educated at Magdalen college, Oxford; appointed assistant conservator of forests, Oct., 1871; arrived in India 27th Dec., 1871, and served in British Burma; transferred to Bengal, Aug., 1872; served under the government of India as assistant to the inspector-general of forests, April, 1877, to Jan., 1879; deputy conservator, Bengal, July, 1880; conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; transferred to Madras, Dec., 1882; conservator, and grade, Dec., 1884.

GAMBLE, REGINALD ARTHUR, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1885.

GANPATRAO BHASKAR, RAO BAHADUR,
Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from Aug., 1874, as 4th judge of the court of small causes, Bombay.

GANPATRAO DAMODHAR PANSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant collector and magistrate, 13th Dec., 1881; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1884.

GARBETT, COLIN HUBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 27th June, 1859; from 4th Dec., 1866, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1886.

GARBETT, Hubert, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department Nov., 1854; executive engineer, Bari Doab canal, Feb., 1860; Western Jumna canal, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, on the inundation canals, Punjab, Feb., 1870; superintendent of works, Derajet circle, Punjab, 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1878; superintending engineer, Bari Doab circle, Jan., 1880; and in the Derajet circle, April, 1882; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1881.

GARDEN, ALEXANDER, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1855; arrived in India, June, 1855, and was employed under the military department up to 1859, including service during the mutiny, 1857-58, with the Goorha brigade, and the Bengal yeoman cavalry, and was present at numerous engagements (medal and clasp); from Sept., 1859, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon of Ghazipur, Oct., 1859, and was subsequently in medical charge of Saharanpur and Mussooree; rank of surgeon, March, 1867; officiating sanitary commissioner and inspector-general of jails, Oudh, Feb., 1876; transferred to Assam, and officiated as civil surgeon of Tezpur, Feb., 1877; from March, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed a civil surgeon, 2nd class, April, 1882; posted to Ghazipur, March, 1883, and Saharanpur, Dec., 1883; surgeon-major, July, 1873; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879.

GARDINER, JOHN WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Lycée Imperial Bonaparte, Paris; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty under financial department of government of India, Sept.-Nov., 1873; again on special duty, Nov., 1880; promoted to judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1880, and to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1885.

GARRETT, CHARLES BAZETT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating registrar of assurances, district and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector; judge of the principal court of small causes in Nudda and Jessore, Dec., 1882; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, 26th Nov., 1884.

GARRETT, H. W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the King's School, Ely; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 12th April, 1882.

GARSTIN, JOHN HENRY, C.S.I., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed private secretary to H.E. Lord Napier, March, 1866, acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Jan., 1871, and collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent, Pondicherry, May, 1871; served as acting secretary, and additional secretary to government, revenue department, 1876-80; wrote the review of the Madras famine of 1876-78; C.S.I., May, 1878; compiled South Arcot district manual; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, March, 1880, to April, 1881; board of revenue, July, 1882; appointed to revise the establishments of collectors and divisional officers in Madras Presidency, Feb., 1883; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

GARTH, SIR RICHARD, Knight, M.A., Q.C.—Educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford; called to the bar in Lincoln's Inn in 1847, and went the home circuit; represented Guildford in Parliament, 1866-68; nominated chief justice of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, March, 1875; retired, March, 1886.

GARTHWAITE, LISTON, B.A. (London), Education Department, Madras.—Served from 8th April, 1857, as head master of the Zillah School, Cuddalore, of the Provincial School, Calicut, and of the normal school, Cannanore, and as deputy inspector of schools; also acted as Malayan translator, and Canarese translator to government; from Sept., 1869, served as inspector of schools; compiled Canarese and Malayan Arzis for the secretary of state, and also various text-books; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; 2nd class, education department, May, 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of a scheme for development of technical and scientific education, in 1884-85, and again in 1885-86.

GATES, FRANK CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; from Aug., 1884, served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

GAY, EDWARD, M.A. (Oxon), Financial Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state as assistant in the finance department, Sept., 1865; assistant comptroller-general of accounts and acting assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, June, 1867; acting deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1868; deputy comptroller-general, Calcutta, Sept., 1869; 1st class of the financial department, Jan., 1871; on special duty in England, March, 1872, to Dec., 1873; acting accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1874, to Jan., 1875; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of paper currency, April, 1879; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, April, 1885.

GEIDT, BERNARD GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed
to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, Oct., 1877, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, Jan., 1882; officiating deputy commissioner, Lakhimpur.

GELL, Right Rev. Frederick, D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Fellow of Christ College, Cambridge; nominated lord bishop of Madras, 16th May, 1861; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1861; acting metropolitan bishop, Calcutta, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877.

GEOGHEGAN, Henry Thomas, B.A., M.I.C.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab Northern state railway; superintending engineer, Indus valley railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer to government of India for state railways, Feb., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bhopal railway, June, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Madras state railway surveys, Feb., 1885; superintending engineer, 1st class, May, 1886.

GIBB, Malcolm Couper, LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883.

GIBSON, Edward, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Alban's Grammar School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in Madras revenue and judicial department from Feb., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and was on special duty, Jan., 1868, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot, and on famine duty in Kurnool, Nov., 1876, to March, 1878; acting under secretary to government, chief secretary's department, Feb., 1880; private secretary to governor of Madras, Dec., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1882; secretary to the board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector, district magistrate, and government agent, Tanjore, July, 1886.

GIBSON, Frederick Edward, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, London University, and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1883.

GIBSON, Henry William (Barrister-at-Law), Oudh Commission.—Volunteer in the Meerut light horse, 1857-58; served subsequently in the military police, 1858-61; assistant district superintendent of police, Oudh, June, 1861; district superintendent, 4th grade, April, 1863; from July, 1864, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and officiated as settlement officer, Feb.-Dec., 1865; acted as superintendent of encumbered estates, Sitapur, July to Oct., 1874; deputy commissioner, Sultanpur, Nov., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1883.

GILES, Arthur Henry, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 14th Feb., 1863; district superintendent, Jan., 1866; officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, March, 1869; officiating deputy commissioner of police and justice of the peace for the town of Calcutta, May, 1870; 1st grade district superintendent, April, 1885; officiating deputy inspector-general, June, 1886.

GILES, Edward, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 14th May, 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of history and political economy, Elphinstone College, Bombay; from May, 1875, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of the department, March, 1883.

GILES, Frank, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary to Government, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886.

GILES, Robert, M.A., Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1868; assistant settlement officer, Indus survey, March, 1869; served from Jan., 1870, as deputy collector, superintendent of police, and educational inspector in Sind; 2nd assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1885.

GILL, John Edward, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; author of 'Gazetteer of the Ghazipur District.'

GILLAN, G. G., Rev., M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Assistant chaplain of the Church of Scotland, 4th Jan., 1866; served under the military department with the 91st Highlanders at Dum Dum, 1866, and with the 72nd Highlanders at Umballa, 1871; chaplain, Jan., 1876; senior chaplain of the church of Scotland in Bengal, and of St. Andrew's Church, March, 1880.

GIRDLESTONE, Charles Edward Ridgway, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse School and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 29th Jan., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; acted as under secretary in the foreign department in 1867 and 1868; on special duty compiling a report on past famines in N.W. Provinces, Jan.-June, 1868; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, June-Aug., 1868; deputy commissioner, Central Provinces, 1871; deputed to Kashmir on special duty, April, 1871; resident in Nipal, 1873; on special duty with Maharaja Sir Jung Bahadur, 1874; officiating resident in Mysore, and chief commissioner of Coorg, June, 1885, to May, 1886; graded as resident, and class.

GIRINDRA NARAIN DEB, Kumar, Bengal C.S.—Officiating deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Burdwan, Aug., 1878; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil
service rules, and served as probationary assistant magistrate and collector from Dec., 1880; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Feb., 1886.

GLADSTONE, CECIL ERNEST, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Delhi in the Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876, and again, in the foreign department of the government of India, Feb., 1877; from Sept., 1885, acted as district judge, Rawul Pindi; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, and grade, Sept., 1886.

GLAZIER, EDWARD GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; from April, 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; author of 'Report on the district of Rungpore,' 'Further Notes on the Rungpore Records,' 'Report on the Famine in Rungpore.'

GLENNY, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry Collegiate School, Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, Jan., 1868, enquiring into the condition of the poorer classes, South Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, April, 1880; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Oct., 1885; in charge of the Inam department, Oct., 1885; collector and magistrate, North Arcot, May, 1886.

GODFREY, CHARLES WILLIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1858, and served in the Bombay artillery; from Aug., 1864, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and acting deputy superintendent, and was promoted to superintendent of survey, Jan., 1885.

GODFREY, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Oct., 1873; on famine duty, May, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July to Oct., 1877; from Jan., 1880, served in Bengal as officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; again transferred to Assam, Oct., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Lakhimpur; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1886.

GODLEY, JOHN A., C.B., Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; Hertford scholar, 1868; Ireland scholar, 1870; Eldon law scholar, 1874; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 1876; private secretary to the first lord of the treasury, 1872-74; and again, 1880-82; commissioner of inland revenue, 1882-83; permanent under secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1883.

GODELL, WILLIAM, Audit Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 30th Sept., 1860; senior examiner, June, 1863; junior inspector Dec., 1868.

GOLDINGHAM, JOHN DALRYMPLE, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from July, 1862, to July, 1865, served as judge of the court of small causes, Madura, and from Oct., 1868, to Oct., 1872, as civil and sessions judge at the same place; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Nov., 1872, to Feb., 1881, and afterwards at Bellary.

GOLDSMITH, SEPTIMUS JESSE, Surgeon-Major.—Joined the Bombay medical service, April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; served as civil surgeon in North Canara and Guzerat; agency surgeon, Baghelkhand, Sept., 1875; also tutor to Maharaja of Rewah from Oct., 1883.

GONNE, CHARLES, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; arrived in India 10th March, 1854; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, May, 1861; joint judge and sessions judge, Thana, March, 1863, and acted as judge and sessions judge June, 1863, to March, 1864; acting judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, April-June, 1864; acting registrar, high court, Bombay, June-Oct., 1864; from Oct., 1864, served as secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial and political departments; chief secretary to government in the political, secret, judicial, and separate departments, April, 1870; temporary member of council, Bombay, March-April, 1884; retired in 1885.

GOODFELLOW, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Colonel, R.E., V.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, July, 1853; and lieutenant, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; served with the Central India field force, 1857-58 (medal and clasp, V.C.), and with the Okhmandal and Kattiarwar field force, 1859; joined the public works department as special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, April, 1860; executive engineer, Feb., 1862; joined the Abyssinian Expedition, Dec., 1867, as brigade major of Royal Engineers (medal); executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1877; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1884.

GOODFELLOW, GEORGE RISTO, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, Oct., 1854, and was employed on military duty till Jan., 1863, also serving as personal assistant to inspector-general of prisons, Poona, Oct., 1859, to March, 1860; from Jan., 1863, to April, 1870, served in the political department, at Aden, as Arabic interpreter to the resident, and as assistant resident, and acted for various periods as resident; acting special assistant political agent in charge of Rajkot and Gondal states, Kathiawar, April, 1870; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1872, served in Central India as officiating
political agent, Baghelkhand; from May, 1872, served under the government of Bombay as acting political agent, Cutch, acting political superintendent, Akalkot, and assistant resident and acting resident at Aden; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1880; political agent and collector of stamp revenue, Cutch, Sept., 1881; and grade political agent, Feb., 1885.

GOODFELLOW, WILLIAM WEST, Major-General, C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, Oct., 1853; joined the public works department, July, 1854; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-7 (medal and clasp), and with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867 (C.B. and medal); executive engineer, Bombay defences, Jan., 1869, to May, 1870; acting controller of public works accounts, June - July, 1870; served subsequently as executive engineer at Aden and in the Poona districts; from June, 1876, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, March, 1882; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1885.

GOODRICH, HARRY ST. AUBYN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from July, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy director of revenue settlement, acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, Nellore, Feb.-Sept., 1881; appointed collector and magistrate, March, 1882, in South Canara, and subsequently in the districts of Ganjam and Vizagapatam; on duty to Calcutta as additional member of governor-general's legislative council, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, and again, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886; on special duty at Madras conferring upon proposals for legislating on relation of landlord and tenant in Malabar, March, 1885; member of the draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885; collector and magistrate, Bellary, Nov., 1885.

GOODRICKE, G. M., Bengal Customs Department.—Served from 30th Nov., 1859, as preventive officer and appraiser, Calcutta custom house, and was appointed assistant collector of customs, 24th July, 1871, and deputy collector of Calcutta, March, 1880; is also superintendent of excise revenue, collector of stamp revenue, and a collector under the Licence Tax Act.

GOODRIDGE, JOHN PERCH, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1869; served as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces, and held acting appointments at various dates as district superintendent of police, inspector of schools, cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and was deputed on famine duty to Madras, Sept., 1877; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884.

GOPALLAL MITTER.—Vice-chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, Sept., 1884.

GOPENDRA KRISHNA, KUMAR, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S.—Served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, from Jan., 1877, and officiated as registrar of Calcutta and second inspector of registration offices; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, Nov., 1882, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GORDON, ALEXANDER EVANS, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, 18th April, 1865; from May, 1872, served in the Bengal non-regulation commission as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Maharajah of Johore, Dec., 1875; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Dum-Dum, March, 1876; tutor to the Maharajah of Durbhunga, June, 1877; on special duty in Calcutta, Jan., 1880, and in the foreign department, Nov., 1880; on deputation to Cooch Behar, Dec., 1883.

GORDON, D. C., Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined the public works department in 1868, as assistant controller of accounts, N.W. Provinces; served subsequently as deputy controller in the Punjab; controller, 3rd class, on the Indus Valley state railway, July, 1874, and afterwards on the Punjab northern railway; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1877-79, and afterwards in Madras; examiner, P. W. accounts, Madras, May, 1881; examiner, 1st class, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1887.

GORDON, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Radley College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Assam, Dec., 1885.

GORDON, HAMILTON WINKUP, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1866, officiating inspector of schools, July, 1872, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1881.

GORDON, HUNTLY PRYSE, Madras C.S.—Educated at New College, London, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), and acting district and sessions judge; appointed collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Dec., 1878, and afterwards at Bellary, April, 1880; and in South Arcot, Nov., 1885.

GORDON, SIR JAMES DAVIDSON, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and at Trinity College, Glen Almond, Perthshire; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1854; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed junior secretary to government of Bengal, April, 1861, and magistrate and collector of Maldah, Jan., 1863, and subsequently at Monghyr; mutiny medal; officiating civil and sessions judge of Purneah, April, 1865, and subsequently of Dinapore, and Moorsheadabad; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1865; private secretary to the governor-general of India, Jan., 1866; judicial commissioner, Mysore, Dec., 1868; president of the famine relief
committee, 1874; chief commissioner, Mysore and Coorg, and guardian to H.H. the Maharaja, 1878; resident, Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, April, 1881; retired 1883.

GORST, Sir John Eldon, Q.C., M.P.—Graduated at St. John's College, Cambridge; 3rd wrangler, 1857; M.A., 1860; fellow of his college; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1865; Q.C., 1875; civil commissioner of Waikats, New Zealand, 1861 to 1862; represented Cambridge (borough) in the House of Commons, April, 1866, to Nov., 1868, and Chatham from Feb., 1875, to 1885; solicitor-general in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885; vacated his seat on elevation to the bench of judges in Dec., 1885, but was subsequently re-elected for Chatham, and was appointed under secretary of state for India, Aug., 1886; author of 'The Maori King.'

GOUGH, Archibald Edward, M.A., Educational Service, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the department, and Nov., 1868, and served as Anglo-Sanskrit professor, Benares College, and as professor of English literature and professor of history and philosophy at the Muir College, Allahabad, and also officiated for various periods between 1872 and 1878 as principal, Benares College, and held charge of the meteorological observatory; served in Bengal, 1878-1886, as professor in the Hooghly and Presidency Colleges, and principal of the Calcutta Madrassa; education officer, and grade, and principal, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1886; author of 'Papers relating to the Collection and Preservation of the Records of Ancient Sanskrit Literature in India,' 1878.

GOVAN, George Moncrieff, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P.E., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1852, and served under the military department up to 1883, in Bengal, Burma, and Assam, and throughout the Bhootan campaign, 1864-1866 (medal and clasp for Burma); rank of surgeon, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Dec., 1871; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, and class, Fatehgarh, and posted to Azamgarh; officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, Aug., 1883; superintendent of Pilgrim Hospitals in Kumaun and Garhwal in addition to other duties, Aug., 1883; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Budauli and at Almora.

GRACE, Charles Hallyburton, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, as ensign, Madras infantry, March, 1854; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1883, at Jubbulpore; acted as commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, May-June, 1882.

GRAHAM, James, Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay artillery and ordnance department, 1834 to 1864; during which he served four years as chief clerk in the adjutant-general's office, also in auditor-general's office, and in charge of Mulligama depot, and in grand arsenal, Bombay; examiner of stores, India store depot, London, 25th May, 1866; sub-inspector of stores, Dec., 1866; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877.

GRAHAME, William Francis, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, and was placed on special duty in July, 1868, with Dr. Janssen in connection with the solar eclipse; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, June, 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1882, in North Tanjore, and afterwards in the districts of Kurnool and Cudapah.

GRANT, Sir Charles, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity College, Cambridge, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the revenue and settlement departments; transferred to Central Provinces, Nov., 1863, and served as settlement officer and acting deputy commissioner; in charge of settlement commissioner's office, Jubbulpore, Jan., 1868; secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1861; compiled the 'Provincial Gazetteer'; commissioner of Chattisgarh division, Nov., 1870, and subsequently of the Jubbulpore and Narbada divisions; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; acting chief commissioner, April to Nov., 1879; additional member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1879; acting secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural departments, May, 1880; foreign secretary, government of India, Sept., 1881; retired, Feb., 1885.
