GRANT, Charles, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 4th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Feb., 1857; served with the Guzerat Horse, and subsequently with the Mahtratta Horse; special officer in charge, Káthiawár local battalion, and extra assistant political agent, Dec., 1867; in charge state prison, Asirgarh, March 1870; assistant resident, Persian Gulf, June, 1871, and acted as resident in 1877; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1878; political agent, Muscat, Feb., 1880; superintendent Rajputana railway police, Dec., 1880; from Feb., 1881, served as cantonment magistrate, Nimach.

GRANT, George, Surgeon-Major, M.B., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 11th July, 1859, and served under the military department till 1860; from June, 1860, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Bijnoor, and was in medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp, Nov., 1861; civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Farakhabad, March, 1862; on special deputation to Calcutta to give evidence in a criminal case at the high court, Jan., 1864; officiating superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, and chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces, Oudh and Central Provinces, Aug., 1866; superintendent of new central prison, Farakhabad, Dec., 1866; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; representative of N.W. Provinces at the prison committee, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; officiating inspector-general of prisons and civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces, in 1877, 1879, and 1882; superintendent, central and district jails, Bareilly, Dec., 1877; deputy sanitary commissioner, 1st circle, Dec., 1883; retired, Oct., 1885.
GRANT, GEORGE FRANCIS MYTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Brighton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch registrar-general, education inspector in Sind, and acting talukdari settlement officer; in charge of the Sachim state, May, 1879; acted as collector, magistrate, and agent at Surat, 1879-80, and subsequently in the Panch Mahals, and at Broach, Kaira, and Kaladgi; junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Nov., 1883; acting collector of customs, Bombay, May, 1884; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Thana, March, 1885.

GRANT, GREGORY COLQUHOUN, Brevet-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1853; on military duty till Nov., 1860, including service with the Okhamandal field force, in Oct., 1859; served subsequently as deputy collector and magistrate in Sind; judge and sessions judge, March, 1865; also acted as judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sadar court.

GRANT, J. G. GARROW, Dr., Emigration Department, Bengal.—Served in the emigration department from 22nd May, 1863, as medical inspector and protector of labourers, Kooshtea; on special duty at the Presidency, Oct., 1870; protector of emigrants and superintendent of labour transports, Calcutta, Feb., 1871; superintendent of emigration, Calcutta, Jan., 1874.

GRANT, JOHN ANDREW, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; served under the foreign department, government of India, at Kurram, May-Aug., 1880; transferred to Umballa-Karnal settlement as assistant settlement officer, Dec., 1883; officiating settlement officer, Aug., 1884; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept., 1884; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1885.

GRANT, JOHN HAY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 6th Feb., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, assistant revenue and police commissioner, acting collector and magistrate, and acting commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; junior collector, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1877 to Feb., 1881; collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Aug., 1883; special commissioner for Bombay for purpose of international exhibition at Calcutta, Nov.-Dec., 1883; president of a commission to make certain enquiries in connection with Abkari act, July, 1885; commissioner of income tax for town and island of Bombay, in addition to his other duties, April, 1886.

GRANT, SIR JOHN PETER, G.C.M.G., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1826; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; deputy collector of Sarun, 1833; officiated as secretary, Sudder board of revenue, Calcutta, and as assistant secretary and deputy secretary to government, 1834; deputy accountant and civil auditor, Agra; deputy secretary to governments of India and Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, and officiating superintendent of the botanical gardens, 1835; junior member and secretary, prison discipline committee, 1836; officiating secretary, Indian law committee, 1837; officiating secretary to government of India, legislative, judicial, and revenue departments, 1838; private secretary to governor-general, and deputy secretary, general and financial departments, 1839; deputy accountant-general, ex-officio director of bank of Bengal, and junior secretary, financial branch, 1840; commissioner for payment of Mysore debts 1844-47; commissioner for enquiry into proceedings regarding Meriah sacrifices in Ganjam, 1847; secretary to Indian law commission, 1848; secretary to government of Bengal, 1849; secretary to government of India, home department, and foreign department, 1852-54; governor-general's council, 1854 to 1857; temporarily lieutenant-governor of Central Provinces during mutiny, 1857-58; governor-general's council, 1858-59; lieutenant-governor of Bengal 1859 to 1862, when he resigned the service; governor of Jamaica, 1866 to 1874.

GRANT, JOHN PETER, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Jessore, June, 1857; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Sept., 1862; officiating comptroller of government salt chowkeys, Nov., 1862; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1863; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1863; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1867; small cause court judge, Kishnahgur, April, 1874; district and sessions judge, and grade, March, 1875; 1st grade, district judge, Jan., 1878; officiating judge, high court, April, 1885.

GRANT, JOHN PYNE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey of Mysore.—First commission as ensign, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1856; joined the revenue survey, 1860; superintendent of revenue survey, Mysore, Jan., 1868.

GRANT, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was promoted to magistrate and collector, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1878.

GRANT, T., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk 2nd class, India office, 28th May, 1875.

GRANT-DUFF, Rt. Hon. Sir MOUNTSTUART ELPHINSTONE, P.C., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., F.R.S.—Born, 1829; educated at Edinburgh, and at Balliol College, Oxford; M.A., in 1853; called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1854; represented the Elgin burghs in parliament from Dec., 1857, to July, 1881; under secretary of state for India, Dec., 1863, to Feb., 1874; under secretary of state for the Colonies, April, 1880, to Aug., 1881; governor of Madras, Nov., 1881, to 1886; was lord rector of the university of Aberdeen, 1866, to 1872; author of 'Studies in European Politics,' 'Elgin Speeches,' 'A Political Survey,' &c.
GRAY, EVELYN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Nasik, March, 1884.

GRAY, PERCY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 30th December, 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Roorkee, Oct., 1883; junior secretary, board of revenue, April-July, 1885.

GRAY, R., Surgeon-Major, M.B., Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 11th March, 1860; civil assistant surgeon, Gujranwala, Feb., 1863; superintendent, central jail, Jan., 1864; civil surgeon, Mooltan, May, 1868; officiated as inspector-general of prisons, March, 1869, to March, 1871, and again in 1877; surgeon-major, July, 1873; in medical charge of lieutenant governor's camp, Nov., 1877; served afterwards as civil surgeon of Murree, Mooltan, and Lahore; inspector-general of prisons, Punjab, Sept., 1884.

GRAY, WELLINGTON, Surgeon-Major, L.M., L.Ch. (Dub.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866, and was appointed professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and 2nd surgeon at the Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Bombay; curator of Victoria and Albert Museum, and professor of botany, Grant Medical College, June, 1871; also acted as professor of chemistry and medical jurisprudence, and chemical analyser to government; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department, June, 1878; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical Hospital, May, 1883.

GREAVES, RICHARD HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884.

GREENE, WALTER JAMES, Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st July, 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; attached to the financial department; clerk for examination of army non-effective accounts, March, 1885.

GREENSHIELDS, ROBERT SCOTT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Birkenhead School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, March, 1882, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Assam, March, 1886; officiated as director of agriculture, Assam.

GREENSTREET, WILLIAM LEES, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission as lieutenant, Oct., 1864; arrived in India, Jan., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works branch, 1872; executive engineer, Nov., 1874; superintending engineer, July, 1885.

GREER, RICHARD TOWNSEND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Erasmus College, Drogheda, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty Oct., 1878; forest settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating deputy commissioner Sept., 1881; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1884.

GREIG, G., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1857, as a lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland Highlanders; retired from the army, June, 1865; joined the forest department, Dec., 1868, and was appointed assistant conservator, Aug., 1869, deputy conservator, March, 1871, and conservator, Nov., 1876; promoted to 1st grade of conservators, April, 1883.

GREIG, IRWIN MONTGOMERY, Major-General, R.E., A.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1855; served in the Bombay public works department from Oct., 1855, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; deputy consulting engineer for railways, B.B. and C.I. railway, April, 1863; served subsequently as executive engineer in Ahmedabad, Khandesh, Kanara, Lower and Central Sind, and Dharwar, and with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867; from April, 1879, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, Oct., 1882; retired, 1886.

GREY, CHARLES, Political Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1864; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, April-July, 1866; financial department, 1866; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1872; accompanied Sir Bartle Frere on his mission to Zanzibar, 1872-1873; political department, 1874; reading clerk to council from 1875; senior clerk, April, 1877.

GREY, LEOPOLD JOHN HERBERT, Colonel, C.S.I., B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; assistant commissioner in Assam, Feb., 1865; officiating civil officer with Bhootan Dovar field force, Dec., 1865; from April, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, but was employed under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1868, to June, 1869; on special duty, Oct., 1869, to March, 1870; political agent, Bahawalpur State, March, 1871, to Jan., 1873, and again in 1877; judicial assistant, 1st grade, July, 1876; on special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage, Sept., 1876, to Jan., 1877; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1876; officiating civil and session judge, Pesha-wur, Aug., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; secretary to board of examiners (under government of India), March, 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi division, March, 1886.

GREY, WILLIAM FRANCIS HUNGERFORD, Captain, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 2-19th regiment, Aug., 1868; served in the Burma commission from April, 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June-Oct., 1876; boundary officer, Paungde, Aug., 1881; cantonment
magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, Sept., 1882; was elected president of the Kyaukpyu town committee, March, 1884; and of the Akyab municipal committee, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

GRIERSON, GEORGE ABRAHAM, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Bees, Shrewsbury, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1873; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating inspector of schools Oct., 1880; on special duty in the revenue department, Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; has published various works in connection with the Behari language and its dialects, translations, collections of folk songs, &c., also 'Behar Peasant Life,' 1885; 'Report on Colonial Emigration from the Lower Provinces of Bengal,' 1883; 'Curiosities of Indian Literature,' 1885; 'Vidyapati and his Contemporaries,' 1885.

GRIERSON, JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Public Works Department.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1858; joined the P.W. department, Feb., 1864; executive engineer, Jan., 1871; from May, 1872, served as deputy controller of accounts, Bombay; deputy examiner, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1875; examiner of accounts, Dec., 1876; transferred to Burma, July, 1880, and subsequently to Bombay (Sept., 1884), and to N.W. Provinces; examiner of telegraph accounts, Aug., 1885; 2nd class, examiner, May, 1886.

GRIFFIN, HENRY DALY, B.A., Bengal, C.S. (North West Provinces).—Educated at French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, and Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces.

GRIFFIN, SIR LEPFEL HENRY, K.C.S.I., B.C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty compiling the 'Punjab Chiefs,' Oct., 1867; under secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1870; on special duty to frame track rules between Punjab and Rajputana states, Feb., 1873; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1875; deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; acted as secretary to government, Punjab, from Feb., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1878; on special duty at the Paris exhibition, July, 1878; during the occupation of Afghanistan, held the special appointment of chief political officer in north and west districts of that country (Afghanistan medal); resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Central India, Feb., 1881; K.C.S.I., May, 1881; royal commissioner, Indian and colonial exhibition, 1886.

GRIFFITH, HUGH, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department (Madras establishment), 1859; served under the military department from 1869 to 1871, and also held civil surgeoncies of Thayetmyo and Hoshungabad during that period; civil surgeon and health officer, Rangoon, April, 1871; also superintendent of lunatic asylum, and in charge of state prisons and lock hospital, June, 1871; in medical charge of Rangoon jail, Nov., 1871, to March, 1885; also superintendent of vaccination, May, 1875; in medical charge, Burma state railway, Nov., 1885; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886.

GRIFFITH, RALPH THOMAS HOTCHKIN, M.A., C.I.E., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1853, and served as professor and head master, Benares College, also as officiating inspector of public instruction, 3rd circle; principal, Benares College, Jan., 1861; superintendent of observatory, Benares, May, 1866; promoted to 1st grade April, 1873; on special committee under government of India, for selection of text-books, May, 1877; inspector-general of schools, N.W. Provinces, March, 1878; director of public instruction, Feb., 1879.

GRIFFITHS, W., M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed to the education department, 1st July, 1869; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1870, and served as assistant professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College; professor, Presidency College, Feb., 1876; principal, Hooghly College, April, 1880; and class, education department, July, 1883.

GRIGG, EDWARD EVANS, Major, Bengal Infantry, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Dec., 1861; served under the military department till Jan., 1864, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Assam up to March, 1867, when he was transferred to the Oudh commission, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner in various districts; officiating cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, May–June, 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Sultanpur, May, 1885.

GRIGG, HENRY BIDWELL, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1866; acting inspector of schools Feb., 1867; from March, 1872, to Feb., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and acting commissioner, Nilgiris; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Feb., 1876, and acting secretary, March, 1877; on special duty, preparing Annual Administration Report, Oct., 1877; under secretary, public department, Oct., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1880; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1880; director of public instruction and commissioner for the uncov. civil service examinations, July, 1880; compiled the 'Nilgiri District Manual'; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882.

GRIMES, HENRY ROBERT, Jail Department, Madras.—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency, Vizagapatam, 29th Nov., 1864; from April, 1866, served as superintendent of the central jail, Coimbatore; inspector-general of jails, Madras, July, 1884.

GRIMLEY, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India 12th Dec., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue
and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiated as superintendent of surveys, Feb., 1869, and as inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; on special duty in connection with the examination of candidates for the native civil service, Jan., 1874; officiated as secretary to the board of revenue, 1874 to 1877, and again in 1879 and 1883-84; junior secretary to the board of revenue, 1877-79; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1879; officiating collector of customs and ex-officio shipping master, Calcutta, April, 1881; served under the financial department from April, 1885; commissioner of income tax in Bengal, March, 1886; author of 'The Sea Customs Law,' 1878, and 'Tariff Act, with notes.'

GRIMWOOD, FRANK ST. CLAIR, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, inspector of labourers, and officiating deputy commissioner.

GRINDLAY, WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GROSE, JAMES, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, secretary to commissioner for uncov. civil service examinations, secretary to the central committee for the examination of assistants, sub-secretary board of revenue (Aug., 1867), and receiver of the Carnatic property fellow of the Madras University, May, 1868; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, March, 1870; secretary to board of revenue, 1870 to 1877; collector and magistrate, Nellore, March, 1877; acting member, board of revenue, April, 1886; acting director of revenue settlement, Nov., 1886.

GROVES, FREDERICK W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; M.A. and LL.B., University of London; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; temporary clerk, India Office, 1st Aug., 1863; junior clerk May, 1864; senior clerk, Aug., 1879.

GROWSE, EDWARD FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GROWSE, FREDERICK SALMON, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oriel and Queen's Colleges, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; from Dec., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, Jan., 1870; has published a translation of Tulsi Dass's 'Ramayaná,' also 'Mathura: a District Memoir,' 'Bulandshahr: Sketches of an Indian District,' and 'Indian Architecture of To-day.'

GUBBINS, FREDERICK BEBB, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1835; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, Delhi division; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Moradabad, 1842, and subsequently in Rohtuk and Banda; magistrate and collector of Benares, 1852; civil and sessions judge, Benares, 1857; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Benares, agent to governor-general, and superintendent of ex-rajah of Coorg, 1858; retired 1863.

GUN, WILLIAM HENRY MAFFETT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Greenock Academy, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions' judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884.

GUPTA KRISHNA GOVINDA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mymensing Zilla School, and Pogose School, Dacca, and matriculated at Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1886.

GURBACHAN SINGH, SIRDAR SINDHAWALLA, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra assistant commissioner, 27th Jan., 1880; probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1882; assistant commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1884.

GURDIAL SINGH, SIRDAR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 26th Jan., 1880; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1882.

GURDON, EVELYN PULTENEY, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India and April, 1852; from Aug., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1851; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsar divisions, Nov.-Dec., 1881, and subsequently in the Lahore and Rawul Pindi divisions; promoted to commissioner and superintendent, Aug., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1885.

GUTERSLOH, F. N., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1874, as assistant engineer on the Indus Valley state railway; in charge of locomotive and carriage department, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1875; officiating manager and locomotive superintendent, Holkar state railway, 1877; manager, Wardha Valley Railway, Dec., 1878; locomotive superintendent, Rajputana railways, March, 1880; 1st class, and grade, locomotive department, state railways, Jan., 1886.

GUTHRIE, THOMAS KEY, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, March, 1855; arrived in India, 11th July, 1855; served with the Madras Rifles in
Bengal, N.W. Provinces, and Central India, Oct., 1857, to Jan., 1860, and was present at several engagements (medal and clasp); served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; deputy inspector-general, Dec., 1881; commissioner of police, Madras, July, 1883; inspector-general of police, Madras, Dec., 1885.

GUTHRIE, WILLIAM JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Glasgow Academy, University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner.

HACKETT, ARTHUR LUKE, Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, April 1, 1867; arrived in India, Oct. 26, 1867; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; surgeon, April, 1873; from June, 1874, acted as presidency surgeon, also as ophthalmic surgeon at the General Hospital, Sept., 1874; garrison assistant surgeon, Bangalore, and superintendent of jail, 1877-78; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Bellary, 1878-81; surgeon-major, April, 1879; surgeon, 3rd district, Madras, Feb., 1881, and acted as superintendent of prisons, in 1881 and 1883; was subsequently appointed civil surgeon at Cannanore, April, 1883, at Salem, July, 1883, and at Negapatam; principal medical storekeeper, Madras, 1885; surgeon, 2nd district, Madras, health officer, and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Oct., 1885.

HAIG, CHARLES THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Obtained his first commission from Addiscombe, June, 1854; lieutenant, Bombay engineers, May, 1856; arrived at Bombay July, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp), and with the Rajputana field force, 1857 (medal and clasp); assistant executive engineer at Nee-much, May, 1858; appointed as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, Sept., 1859; served with the Okhamandal field force in 1859, and was subsequently variously employed in the survey department in Cutch, Kattywar, Guzerat, Meywar, Malwa, the Deccan, and Kanara; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; on deputation as commissioner, Venice geographical exhibition, April-Nov., 1881; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; officiating deputy surveyor-general in charge of trigonometrical survey branch, Oct., 1884.

HAINES, HERMANN A., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; junior clerk, financial department, India Office, 15th Nov., 1881; political department, 1886.

HALL, CHARLES FREDERICK, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of jail, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Bareilly, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Budaun, Feb., 1883; retired, Dec., 1886.

HALL, M. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 21st Jan., 1875; clerk, 2nd class, Oct., 1873.

HALL, WILLIAM THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Rossall, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner.

HALLETT, HENRY HONYWOOD HUGHES, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Jail Department, Central Provinces.—First commission as ensign July, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Aug., 1858; was employed under the military department up to 1868, including service with the Bundelcund field force, 1859; from Dec., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and was appointed superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1878; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, 1883.

HALLETT, JOHN REVANS, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 17th Oct., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, May, 1865; inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; officiating judge of the small cause courts, Bhagulpore and Monghyr, March, 1876; second inspector of registration offices, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1880.

HALLIDAY, SIR FREDERICK JAMES, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1824; arrived in India, 8th June, 1825; served in Bengal as junior assistant to the agent in the Saugor division and assistant registrar of the Sudder court; joint magistrate and deputy collector in Bundelcund, and afterwards in Noacoily and Bullooh, 1831-35; magistrate and collector of the Zillah Court at Dacca, Feb., 1835; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, Feb., 1836; secretary to the Sudder board of revenue, April, 1836; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, May, 1838; member of the general committee of public instruction, June, 1838; junior secretary to the government of India, revenue, judicial, and legislative departments, in addition to his other duties, March, 1840, to 1843; secretary to the government of India, home department, 1849; member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1853; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1st May, 1854; retired in 1859; member of council of secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1868, to Dec., 1886.

HALLIDAY, FREDERICK MYTON, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived, 30th Oct., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating civil and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, May, 1871); officiated as opium agent, Benares, in 1876 and 1877; commissioner, Presidency division, April, 1878, and Patna division, June, 1878; officiating member, board of revenue, Sept., 1884, to April, 1885.
HAMBLIN, RICHARD EBB, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Christ College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAMILTON, FRANK SUMNER, Bengal, C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, December, 1885.

HAMILTON, RIGHT HON. LORD GEORGE FRANCIS, M.P.—Born Dec., 1845; educated at Harrow; ensign, Rifle Brigade, 1864; transferred to the Coldstream Guards, 1868; was elected member for Middlesex, Dec., 1868, and represented that county in parliament, until the election which followed the Reform Bill of 1885, when he was returned for the Ealing Division; under secretary of state for India, Feb., 1874; vice-president of the committee of council on education, April, 1878; first lord of the admiralty in the Marquis of Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, and again, Aug., 1886.

HAMILTON, RICHARD ERRIS, Financial Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the financial department, 1st Aug., 1868; served as assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1869, also in British Burma, May, 1870; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1872; from July, 1873, to March, 1876, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, and subsequently in Calcutta, March, 1876, to Dec., 1877; reposted to Bombay, March, 1878; officiated as deputy accountant-general in Bombay, the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, the Punjab, and Madras, 1879-81; officiating assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, March, 1882; controller and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; 3rd class of the financial department, Feb., 1884.

HAMILTON, THOMAS SHARP, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, the College, Chester, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and sessions judge; promoted to 2nd assistant collector, Feb., 1883.

HAMMICK, MURRAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from Jan. to June, 1882, served in Coorg as acting 1st assistant commissioner and district magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, and acting under secretary in the revenue department; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Canara, April, 1885; acting postmaster-general, Madras, Jan.-May, 1886; acting secretary, board of revenue, May, 1886.

HAMMICK, STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant educational inspector, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; assistant political agent, and tutor to the Maháraja of Kolhapur, Feb., 1873; on famine duty, Kaládgí, Sept., 1877; judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, Aug., 1883; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1885; 2nd grade judge, Surat, Sept., 1885.

HAMNETT, FREDERICK HARPER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and was on special duty, Sept., 1882, preparing the Madras administration report; from March, 1885, to March, 1886; served in the financial department as assistant accountant-general, Madras, and acting deputy-accountant-general.

HAMNETT, GEORGE, C.I.E., Registration Department, Madras.—Served from 11th March, 1843, in the public works and revenue departments as writer, head clerk, and manager and surveyor in office of consulting engineer for railways; unconvenanted assistant to the consulting engineer, Jan., 1859; receiver of the Carnatic property, Feb., 1875; marriage registrar for town of Madras, Jan., 1866; first uncov. assistant, chief secretary's office, Feb., 1867; inspector-general of registration, Nov., 1880; C.I.E., June, 1885.

HANCOCK, GEORGE EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1859, and served under the military department till Nov., 1863; from Nov., 1863, to March, 1868, served as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, and assessment, Gujárát; from March, 1868, acted as political and personal assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar; acting superintendent of the Rajkot and Limbdi states, Aug., 1866; acting assistant resident at Aden, May, 1870, and at Baroda, May, 1871; assistant general superintendent for thuggee and dacoity, Oct., 1871; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, Oct., 1871; assistant political agent, Mahí Kántha, July, 1872; from Oct., 1873, served as superintendent of surveys under Rájastháník court, Káthiáwar, and acted on various occasions as president of the court; on special duty at Delhi, Nov., 1876, to Jan., 1877; acting joint administrator of Gondal state, Nov., 1880, to Feb., 1881; on special duty with the Thákór Sáheb of Gondal on tour in Europe, April, 1883; on special duty to inquire into administration of Rajpipla state, Nov., 1883; third assistant political agent, Káthiáwar, Feb., 1885, continuing to be superintendent of surveys; president of the Rájastháník court, Kathiawar, Jan., 1886.

HANDLEY, FRANCIS FREDERICK (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sydenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating in-
spectator-general of registration, and senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Dec., 1880; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, June, 1884; inspector-general of registration, April, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885.

HANDLEY, JAMES WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in Madras as government pleader from 29th Oct., 1868, to July, 1881; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, July, 1881; officiating judge of the high court, July to Nov., 1885.

HANKEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; served in the Punjab till 1862, and subsequently in the Lower Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Maldah, 1867, and subsequently at Chittagong; superintendent of transport during famine of 1874; inspector-general of police, Lower Provinces, 1876; retired, 1878.

HANKIN, EDWARD LEWIS, Colonel, M.S.C. Ensign Indian army, Dec., 1847; arrived in India 16th June, 1848; served in the public works department, Madras, from Aug., 1853, to July, 1859; served subsequently in the police department as superintendent of police and acting deputy inspector-general, and temporarily in the department of the deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Jan.–June, 1861; acting magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1870; joint magistrate, Ootacamund, Nov., 1870, to Sept., 1876; superintendent of family payments and pensions, Oct., 1876; secretary to government, military department, Madras, Dec., 1882.

HANNYNGTON, JOHN CHILD, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, small cause court judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Salem, Nov., 1873; on special duty, Dec., 1880, as arbitrator of boundary disputes between states of Travancore and Cochin; on tour with H.H. the Maharajah of Travancore to Benares, Jan., 1882; resident of Travancore and Cochin, April, 1882.

HAPPELL, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Crosshill School, Maybole, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Sept.–Nov., 1879; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1880; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, April to Nov., 1881; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, and government agent, Godavari, Dec., 1885.

HARCOURT, ALFRED FREDERICK POLLOCK, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1855; from Sept., 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating small cause court judge; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1877; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1885; author of 'Down by the Drawl,' 'The Royal Umbrella,' and 'Kulu Lahoul and Spitti.'

HARDIE, R., Council of India.—Appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India in 1887; was previously engaged in the profession of banking, and held the office of secretary and treasurer of the Bank of Bengal for 15 years; in 1886 was a member of the finance committee appointed by the government of India for the reduction of expenditure.

HARDING, FRANCIS HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885.

HARDING, HERBERT W., Audit Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; writer, India office, 27th April, 1868; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1873.

HARDINGE, HON. ARTHUR EDWARD, Lieut.-General, C.B.—Equerry to the Queen; commander-in-chief and member of council, Bombay, 30th March, 1881.

HARDY, RICHARD GILLIES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Witney Grammar School, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1885.

HARE, LANCELOT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Hurstpierpoint, and City of London School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; on famine duty, July, 1874; assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1879, and officiating secretary March, 1880; officiating inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, Assam, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Purneah, Nov., 1884.

HARINGTON, ARTHUR HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; served in Oudh from Aug., 1863, as assistant commissioner and junior secretary to chief commissioner; from Dec., 1866, to Jan., 1868, served under the government of India as officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, and officiating under secretary, home department; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Oudh, July, 1868; appointed to take up lands for railway purposes, Nov., 1868; officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, March, 1869; officiating settlement officer, Hardoi, March, 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Fyzabad and Gonda, 1872-75; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Oct., 1883; acted as commissioner in the Lucknow, Sitapur, and Rae Bareli divisions, 1886; author of 'Hardoi Settlement Report,' and 'Economic Reforms in Rural India.'

HARINGTON, HERBERT BARING, M.A.—
—Arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1857, as assistant in telegraph department; for services during the mutiny at the relief of Lucknow received medal and clasp; from Feb., 1860, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, 1869-73; also officiating director of public instruction, April-July, 1870; deputy commissioner, July, 1875; district judge, and grade, Lucknow, Aug., 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sultanpur, Dec., 1881; officiated as commissioner of the Sitapur division in 1876, and of the Rae Bareli division in 1881, 1884, and 1885.

HARMAN, C., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 19th Aug., 1878.

HARRIDANCE, H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 8th March, 1878.

HARRIS, EDWARD BRANSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Commercial School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

HARRIS, (BARON), Rt. Hon. GEORGE ROBERT CANNING HARRIS.—Educated at Eton, and at Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1874; is J. P. and D. L. for Kent, and deputy chairman of the East Kent Quarter Sessions; under secretary for India in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; under secretary of state for war, Aug., 1886.

HARRIS, ROBERT LISTON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating district judge; deputed to settlement department, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating divisional judge, April, 1886; officiating deputy commissioner, April, 1887.

HARRISON, CHARLES WILLIAM INGLEBY, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, irrigation branch, North-Western Provinces, from 10th April, 1863, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and assistant to chief engineer, and was employed on the Eastern Jamna, Rohilkund, and Ganges canals; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1881; deputed to Bengal as member of commission to enquire into system of canal administration in Orissa, Dec., 1884, to April, 1885; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1886; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government, Bengal, July, 1886.

HARRISON, FRANCIS CAPEL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Dec., 1884.

HARRISON, HENRY ANTHONY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1855; arrived in India, 3rd April, 1855; served from May, 1856, to Sept., 1858, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, Cuttack, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1862; assistant, settlement department, Feb., 1864; magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, March, 1872; magistrate and collector, Farukhabad, 1873-1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi division, Sept., 1875; civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, March, 1878, and subsequently at Mirzapur, Farukhabad, and Meerut; 1st grade judge, March, 1884.

HARRISON, Sir Henry Leland, Knt., B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments in the usual grades, and as inspector of schools (1864-1866); junior secretary, government of Bengal, 1867-71; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1868, and again in 1871; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1871; also superintendent of survey, Oct., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1878, and again in March, 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1879; on special duty in connection with the rent commission, Nov., 1879; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, Jan., 1882; member of the Bengal legislative council, Feb., 1886; author of 'Embankment Manual'; knighted, Feb., 1887.

HARRISON, John Henry, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's School, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, Nov., 1876; officiating assistant director of department of agriculture and commerce, Nov., 1880; acting junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, and grade, Aug., 1883.

HARRISON, Richard Prvce, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1834; arrived in India, 19th Sept., 1835; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and officiating collector, Moorshedabad, 1849; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Bograh, 1850; officiating abkari commissioner, Dacca division, 1851; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1853-56; civil and sessions judge, 1856; accountant-general, government of Madras, and a government director of the Madras bank, 1859; accountant-general and auditor-general to government of India, and a government director of the bank of Bengal, 1860; also first member and president of the board of audit; comptroller-general, 1863-67; resigned, April, 1867.

HARRISON, William Pringle, Major, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign 10th Feb., 1861; employed under the military department till Oct., 1867, from which date he served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and acted as district superintendent of police in 1873-74, and as superintendent of encumbered estates in Sultanpur in 1874; sub-judge, Patialgurh, Aug., 1879; cantonment magistrate of
Fyzabad, July, 1881, and subsequently of Lucknow, April, 1883; also acted as district judge in 1884-85.

HART, G. H. R., Financial Department, Government of India.—Probationer in financial department, 20th July, 1869; from Dec., 1870, served as assistant to comptroller-general; on special duty in Behar, Jan.-March, 1874; assistant to private secretary to viceroy, April, 1874, to April, 1876; assistant to accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1877; from Feb., 1878, acted as private secretary to governor of Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1880.

HART, JOHN HENRY EUSTACE, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854; joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1855, and served as civil engineer at Satara, Nasik, and Dhawar; acting executive engineer for reclamations, Bombay, May, 1860; architectural executive engineer and surveyor, Bombay, May, 1871; acting superintendent, harbour works, Karachi, Nov., 1874; acting superintending engineer in Sind, April, 1876; acting chief engineer for irrigation, Sept., 1877; superintending engineer 1st class, March, 1880; joint secretary to government of Bombay for irrigation, March, 1880; chief engineer, and class, Dec., 1885.

HART, WILLIAM, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; commissioner for enquiring into claims, &c., South Mahratta country, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay, in the general and ecclesiastical departments, 1855, also in the public works department, and railway branch, 1856; puisne judge of the court of Sudder Dewani, 1860; revenue and police commissioner, Southern division, 1862; additional member of Bombay council for making laws and regulations, 1864; retired in 1865.

HART, WILLIAM ELLERKER, B.A. (Cantab.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acting professor of English literature, Elphinstone College, Bombay, March, 1872, to Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court, and reporter to the high court; first judge of the small cause court, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as judge of the high court, July to Oct., 1884, and again, Dec., 1886.

HART-DAVIES, THOMAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1876, served in Sind as educational inspector, acting judge and session judge, and acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, Oct., 1879, to Sept., 1885.

HARTINGTON (MARQUIS OF), RIGHT HON. SPENCER COMPTON CAVENDISH, D.C.L., M.P.—Born 23rd July, 1833; educated at Trinity College, Cambridge (graduated B.A. in 1854, LL.D. in 1862); attached to Earl Granville's special mission to Russia in 1856; sat in the House of Commons for North Lancashire, from March, 1857, to Dec., 1868, when he was returned for the Radnor boroughs; D.C.L., Cambridge, 1862, appointed a lord of the admiralty, March, 1862; under secretary for war, April, 1863; secretary of state for war, Feb.-July, 1866; postmaster-general, Dec., 1868, to Jan., 1871; chief secretary for Ireland, Jan., 1871, to Feb., 1874; received the freedom of the city of Glasgow, Nov., 1877; lord rector of the university of Edinburgh, Jan., 1879; was returned for N.E. Lancashire in April, 1880, and became secretary of state for India; secretary of state for war, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885; was a royal commissioner for the Exhibition of 1886.

HARTNOLL, HENRY SULLIVAN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant commissioner, Burma, Dec., 1883.

HARVEY, ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission 1865; officiating civil surgeon, Sept. to Dec., 1865; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1878; member of committee to report on management of the medical institutions, and on medical expenditure in Bengal, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Bankoora, May, 1878; officiating professor of midwifery, Medical College, Calcutta, and superintendent-general of vaccination, Aug., 1878; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Nov., 1878; also in medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, May, 1879; also superintendent of emigration, July, 1879; officiating professor of midwifery, medical college, and obstetric physician to the college hospital, Sept., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1882; also officiating principal of the college, May to July, 1883; honorary surgeon on personal staff of H.E. the Viceroy, May, 1883.

HARVEY, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884.

HARWARD, ALFRED EDGAR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1885.

HASHMAT-ULLA, MAULVI, M.A., Bengal, C.S. (North-West Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, March, 1886.

HASTED, JOHN ORD, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India 2nd Dec., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from 30th Jan., 1856, as assistant engineer, and was promoted to executive engineer, April, 1865, and superintending engineer, Feb., 1877; officiated as chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government for various periods between 1875 and 1884; and was confirmed in this appointment and promoted to chief engineer, 2nd class, April, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept. 1886.

HASTINGS, F. T. C., Political and Secret Department, India Office.—Educated at Haileybury College; admiralty writer, 8th Oct., 1868;
to Jan., 1874; civil service copyist from Jan., 1874, to Feb., 1877; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, India office, 7th March, 1877.

HATCHELL, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 30th Sept., 1858; served in N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon from Dec., 1859, to Oct., 1864, and was subsequently employed under the military department, and served in the Bhootan expedition; served again under government of N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1866, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Bulandshahr; rank of surgeon, July, 1870; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Bulandshahr, Jaunpur, Muzaffarnagar, Aligurh, and Farukhabad; senior surgeon-major, July, 1878.

HATHORTHWAITE, J. T., M.A. (Cantab.) Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1872, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of mathematics at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, Dec., 1877.

HAWES, ARTHUR B., Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; ensign, Bengal army, 12th Dec., 1849; chief executive officer of telegraph from Bagdad to Constantinople, 1857-58; captain, May, 1858; retired, Oct., 1858; assistant auditor, India office, March, 1859; member of committee for valuation of military equipments, April, 1863; author of a work on small arms ammunition.

HAWKINS, CESAR RICHARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow School, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862; served in Bengal as assistant collector and magistrate, and from Feb., 1865, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Peshawur, March, 1870; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, 1876; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1885; officiating commissioner and superintendent, April, 1887.

HEATON, JOSEPH JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bradford Grammar School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge.

HEAVISIDE, WILLIAM JAMES, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1857; lieutenant, Bengal Engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served in the public works department as assistant engineer from Sept., 1862, to Feb., 1865; assistant field engineer with the Bhutan force, 1865-66 (medal and clasp); joined the great trigonometrical survey, as and grade assistant, Jan., 1866; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1872; served with the Southern Afghanistan field force in 1878-79, on special survey duty (medal, brevet of major); served subsequently in Khandeish and Bombay native states, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

HEBBERT, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1832; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1833; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed deputy secretary to government in the Persian department, Jan., 1835; deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1849; collector and magistrate of Broach, March, 1852; from March, 1853, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, July, 1853; judge and sessions judge, and agent for the governor, Surat, March, 1856; judge of the court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, 1857; and again in 1860; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, June, 1862; retired, May, 1863.

HENDERSON, EDWARD PIERCY (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; from Feb., 1878, has served as government advocate, Punjab.

HENDERSON, GEORGE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 20th November, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Shahpur, May, 1862; officiating professor of medicine and surgery, April, 1865, to Jan., 1867; superintendent of Lahore central jail, April, 1868; officiating superintendent, botanical gardens in Bengal, Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Gujranwala, Dec., 1875, and subsequently at other stations in the Punjab.

HENDERSON, PHILIP DURHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, Feb., 1857; attaché, foreign department, May, 1871; under secretary to the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1872, to July, 1874; resident, 3rd class, on special duty in Cashmere, 1874; political officer on staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Sept., 1875; C.S.I., March, 1876; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity from March, 1878; graded as resident, and class.

HENRY, CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885.

HENRY, EDWARD RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1882; on famine duty, Tirhoot, Dec., 1873; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July, 1879, to 1882.

HENSLOWE, CECIL WILLIAM EDWARD, Railway Department.—Joined the Public Works Department, June, 1866, as assistant engineer,
and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and in the Central Provinces (1870-71); transferred to railway establishment, Jan., 1880; engineer-in-chief and manager, Cawnpur-Farukhabad and Muttra-Hathras Railways, Dec., 1880; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, May, 1881; manager, Cawnpur-Achneyra state railway, 1884; transferred to Burma state railway, Dec., 1886.

HENVEY, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, officiating secretary to board of revenue, and officiating junior secretary to government, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; placed on special duty for purpose of compiling a narrative of the famine of 1869-70, April, 1871; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, July, 1874; officiating resident, Nipal, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; on special duty, Kashmir, April, 1878; resident, and class, and commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, Jan., 1883; resident, Eastern Rajputana, states, Dec., 1885.

HERALD, JOHN LUMGAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

HERBERT, PATRICK C. H., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; junior clerk, accounts branch, India Office, 11th March, 1872; judicial and public departments, 1877; resident clerk, 1885.

HERSCHEL, JOHN, Colonel, F.R.S., R.E., late Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1855; first commission, Dec., 1856; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1859; served in the great trigonometrical survey from Nov., 1859, in the grades of assistant surveyor and deputy superintendent; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Jan., 1884; retired, March, 1886.

HEWAT, RICHARD A., Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 13th Aug., 1858; junior clerk, military department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

HEWETSON, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in Burma, from March, 1886, as assistant commissioner; judge, civil court, Mandalay, May, 1886.

HEWETT, JOHN PRESCOTT, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; in charge of provincial gazetteer, Aug., 1883; acted as assistant accountant-general, Jan., 1884; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1884; officiating under secretary to Government of India, home department, Oct., 1886; author of contributions to Provincial Gazetteer.

HEWISH, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 1st Feb., 1869; senior clerk (supernumerary) Sept., 1883.

HEWITT, JAMES FRANCIS KATHERINUS, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived, 12th Feb., 1859; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1860; officiating deputy commissioner, Lohardugga, July, 1863; settlement officer, Chuttergurh, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, wards' estate in Behar, Feb., 1873; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, March, 1879; retired, July, 1885.

HEWLETT, THOMAS GILHAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., M.R.C.S., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 20th Jan., 1854; arrived in India, 21st Feb., 1854, and served in the military department, and as civil surgeon and superintendent of vaccination; served in the Indian navy, in the Red Sea, in 1856, in defence of the Turkish ports, and with the Rajputana field force, in 1858 (medal); acting deputy assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1863, to June, 1865; sanitary officer, Bombay, May, 1863, to June, 1865; coroner of Bombay, Oct., 1865; health officer, Bombay, Aug., 1865, to Oct., 1873; municipal commissioner, Oct.-Dec., 1872; sheriff of Bombay, and superintendent of common jail, Dec., 1872; member of municipal corporation of the city of Bombay and member of the town council, March, 1874; from April, 1874, served as surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejal native general hospital, and was appointed a member of the standing medical committee, Nov., 1874; deputy surgeon-general (in Sind) Nov., 1879; sanitary commissioner for the government of Bombay, May, 1883.

HEYWOOD, JOHN MAGEE, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; 1st commission, Bengal Engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, April, 1858; served in the Bengal public works department from April, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; on special duty, Oct., 1866; deputed to examine reservoirs in France and Spain while on leave in 1867; ordered to report on arrangements connected with towing in inland rivers in Belgium; special survey duty, Sept., 1870; deputed on special duty to the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, and class, May, 1881; officiating chief engineer, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, April, 1883, to Feb., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1884; chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Nov., 1886.

HIGGINS, ALFRED WILLIAM BUCKLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; on special duty as secretary to the draft forest bill
committee, April-Nov., 1883; deputy conservator of forests, 1st grade, Cuddapah, Dec., 1882; also forest settlement officer, July, 1886.

HIGGINS, JOHN JAMES, Police Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed acting adjutant military police, Narsinghpur, for services rendered during the mutiny under Sir Henry Havelock, Dec., 1858; from March, 1861, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st class, June, 1879; on special duty at Kalahandi, June, to Aug., 1882.

HIGHAM, THOMAS, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, July, 1867; arrived in India, Oct., 1867; served in the irrigation department, Punjab, and was promoted to executive engineer, Sept., 1873; assistant secretary to government, irrigation branch, Nov., 1882; superintendent of works, Derajat, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Aug., 1886.

HILDEBRAND, ARTHUR HEDDING, Burma Commission.—From Feb., 1868, to March, 1872, served in the Burma police department as assistant superintendent and acting superintendent; from March, 1872, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner, and was sent on special mission to Chiangmai, March, 1875, and in charge of expedition to Western Karenni, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885; superintendent of the Shan States, Jan., 1886.

HILDEBRAND, GODFREY, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Oct., 1864; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; joined the P.W. department, March, 1869, and served in Bengal and the N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works, May, 1872; secretary to defence committee, 1881; superintending engineer, March, 1886.

HILL, F. G., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1882; attached to the funds department.

HILL, HENRY, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh University; India office writer, old establishment, 1859; junior clerk, financial department, 1860; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1867-74; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1874; assistant secretary in the revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Sept., 1877; compiled the Annual Official Reports on Sanitary Measures in India from 1873-74 to 1877-78; and the Moral and Material Progress Reports from 1873-74 to 1875-76.

HILL, JOHN, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, June, 1862; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1865; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1866, and was employed in Kumaon and Garhwal, and afterwards in Bombay, and on the eastern frontier; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1870; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884; in charge of Konkan topographical survey, Oct., 1884.

HILL, T. C., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Aug., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1867; superintendent, British Burma, Feb., 1879; 1st grade superintendent, March, 1885.

HILL, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Aug., 1853; served in the Mysore commission from July, 1859, as junior assistant; deputy superintendent, 3rd class, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner in Mysore, April, 1873; acted for various periods as commissioner in the Nandigram and Nagar Divisions; acting commissioner of Coorg, 1881; from March, 1885, served as civil and sessions judge of the civil and military station of Bangalore.

HILSON, ARCHIBALD HAMILTON, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the army medical department from Dec., 1855, to Oct., 1856; appointed assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 29th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857, and served under the military department in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, including service in the Mutiny (medal), and in the Bhootan campaign (medal and clasp), also temporarily holding the civil surgeonies of Moradabad, 1860, and Aligarh, 1863, and serving as civil assistant surgeon, Gorakhpur, 1864; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; from April, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Naini Tal, and officiating civil surgeon at Bijnor and Moradabad; also held charge of the jails at Bijnor and Moradabad, and of the lock hospital at the latter place; civil surgeon, Naini Tal, Oct., 1874; civil surgeon, 1st class, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, and principal, medical school, Agra, March, 1876; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1884; author of various professional papers on snake-bite, leprosy, and diseases of the eye, of a 'Memorandum on the Medical Education of the Native Women in India,' 1872, and of the annual reports of the Agra medical school, 1875 to 1886.

HOBART, ROBERT THOMPSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; deputy inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1873; inspector-general of prisons, Oct., 1882; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886.

HOBHOUSE, ARTHUR F., late Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Royal College, Boulogne; junior clerk, India board, political and secret department, 30th Oct., 1849; private secretary to the president, 1849-52; public department, 1852; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, India Office (Sir George R. Clerk, K.C.B.), 1858-60; senior clerk, public department, 1860; assistant secretary in the public department, June, 1867; retired, June, 1887.

HOBHOUSE, SIR CHARLES P., Bart., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1844; arrived in India, 22nd July, 1844, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and in the financial department, government of India, as assistant to the sub-treasurer, and assistant to accountant-general; collector of
