(Assam).—Educated at the Catholic University of Ireland; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1869; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1882; transferred to Assam as district and sessions judge of Sylhet, March, 1884.

KELLEY, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 9th Oct., 1879.

KELLNER, EDWIN WELSH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department as assistant comptroller-general, 29th April, 1870; served as deputy accountant-general, and, for a short period, as accountant-general, Bengal, 1874-76; deputy comptroller-general, Jan., 1877; assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Aug., 1878; acted as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1883 and 1886.

KELLY, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1868; also served as assistant-superintendent of survey, 1863-64, and officiating inspector of schools, 1869; appointed small cause court judge, Bhagulpore, Jan., 1876, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, and grade, Jan., 1879.

KELSALL, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; from March, 1865, to Jan., 1867, served as probationary assistant-superintendent of police, and subsequently, in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled the Bellary 'District Manual'; appointed district and sessions judge, Aug., 1880, in the Godavari district, and afterwards in South Malabar and Vizagapatam.

KEMBALL, SIR ARNOLD BURROWES, General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I.—Educated at Addiscombe; lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1837; served in the Afghan war, 1838-39, and was present at the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); appointed assistant to the resident at Bushire, Feb., 1842; political resident, Persian Gulf; May, 1852; consul general, Bagdad, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, April, 1855, to 1873; served in the Persian expedition of 1857, and was present at the capture of Mohumrah (medal and clasp, C.B., and brevet of major); during the Russo-Turkish war, 1876-77, was British military attache at the headquarters of the Turkish army.

KEMBALL, CHARLES GURDON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1850; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, judicial assistant commissioner (in Sind), and deputy magistrate; collector and magistrate, Karachi, Nov., 1861; served as judge and sessions judge, Surat, from Jan., 1866, to June, 1870, and from the latter date acted as judge of the high court, Bombay, in which appointment he was con-
firmed in Aug., 1871; acted as member of council, Bombay, in 1880, and again in 1881; retired in 1885.

KEMBLE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 8th April, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; inspector-general of jails, July, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; officiating opium agent, Benares, April, 1881; opium agent, Behar, May, 1884.

KEMP, FRANCIS BARING, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at foreign schools, and at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1831; served in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Bengal; collector, Tirhoot, 1851; civil and sessions judge, Backergunge and Jessore, 1855 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1862 to 1878; retired, 1878.

KENNEDY, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1879; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, March, 1884.

KENNEDY, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty, Madras, July, 1878; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1883, as assistant commissioner, 1st class; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

KENNEDY, SIR MICHAEL KAVANAGH, General, K.C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th June, 1841; arrived in India, Nov., 1842; assistant engineer, roads and tanks, June, 1843; executive engineer at Surat, Aden, and Satara, 1848-60; on special duty, Ceylon, Madras, and Calcutta, Oct., 1860, to April, 1861; superintending engineer, Southern division, April, 1862; secretary to government of Bombay, public works and railway departments, July, 1863; resigned the public works department in 1880; controller-general of supply, Kabul expedition; additional secretary to government of India for supply and transport, 1880.

KENNEDY, ROBERT MUIRHEAD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1877; and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate.

KENNEDY, THOMAS JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, Balliol College, Oxford, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1880, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; settlement officer, Raipur, Oct., 1885.

KENNEY—HERBERT, ARTHUR ROBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Cavalry.—Cornet, Sept. 20, 1859; arrived in India, Oct. 31, 1859; served on regimental duty with various cavalry regiments; adjutant, Governor's body guard, Sept., 1865; deputy assistant quarter-master general, 1873-76; major, Sept., 1879; military secretary to the governor of Madras, May, 1881, to April, 1884; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, military department, Dec., 1881; from April, 1884, acted as secretary to the government of Madras, military department, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, September, 1885.

KENSINGTON, ALFRED, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; on special duty in civil secretariat, Oct., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1882; promoted to settlement officer, April, 1884.

KERNAN, JAMES, M.A., Q.C., Judicial Department, Madras.—Judge of the high court, Madras, 3rd May, 1870; fellow of the Madras University, Feb., 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, June, 1885; officiating chief justice, July to Nov., 1885.

KERR, T. COULTER, Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Surveyor of shipping, 1st April, 1881.

KETTLEWELL, G., B.A., Inspecting Veterinary Surgeon, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till Dec., 1881, when he was appointed principal, Veterinary School, Lahore.

KEYS, ARTHUR INNES, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed clerk, London office, 1880.

KEYSER, ALFRED, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Royal Academy, Gosport; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant-collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Surat, Dec., 1884.

KHARSEDJI MANEKJI KHARSEDJI, KHAN BAHDUR, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th May, 1874, as judge of the court of small causes, Ahmednagar, and subsequently at Ahmedabad (Sept., 1879).

KHARSEDJI RATANJI BAMANJI, BOMBAY C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882; confirmed as member of the Bombay Civil Service, Jan., 1885.

KIERNANDER, CHARLES ROBERT CAMPBELL, Financial Department, Government of India.—Assistant accountant-general, British Burma, 5th Aug., 1864; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, April, 1870; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1870; from Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1876, served as
deputy accountant-general in the Punjab, and subsequently in Bombay, N.W. Provinces, British Burma, and Bengal; officiated as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1878 and 1879; inspector of local offices of account, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, Nov., 1884, to Jan., 1885; deputy auditor-general, Jan., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1885; deputy comptroller-general, April, 1886.

KILBY, G. C. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Deputy superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 28th Feb., 1876.

KILBY, SANDFORD JAMES, Bengal Preventive Service.—Assistant collector of customs, Chittagong, 30th June, 1865; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1866; from Aug., 1868, to Dec., 1876, served in the police department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 1st grade, May, 1874; on famine relief duty, Dec., 1873, and March, 1876; on special duty in Chumparam, April, 1874; from Dec., 1876, served in the customs' preventive service, and was appointed superintendent, Jan., 1877; also in charge of the Sulkea salt golahs, April, 1880; served in Madras, Sept.-Nov., 1885, as deputy commissioner, abkari and salt department.

KIMBERLEY (Earl of), Right Hon. John Wodehouse, K.G.—Born Jan. 7, 1826; educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1847, with 1st class in classics; succeeded to title of Baron Wodehouse, May, 1846; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Dec., 1852, to 1856; ambassador at St. Petersburg, 1856-58; under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1859, to Aug., 1861; on a special mission to the North of Europe, in connection with the Schleswig-Holstein question, 1863; under secretary of state for India, April-Nov., 1864; Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Nov., 1864, to July, 1866; raised to earldom of Kimberley, May, 1866; elected governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, April, 1868; lord privy seal, Dec., 1868, to July, 1870; secretary of state for the colonies from July, 1870, to Feb., 1874; member of the royal commission to enquire into the working of the Penal Servitude Acts, Feb., 1878; secretary of state for the colonies, May, 1880; held provisionally the office of chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, on Mr. Bright's resignation, June, 1882; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885, and again Feb. to Aug., 1886; was a royal commissioner for the exhibition of 1886.

KINCAID, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Madras Army, March, 1849; appointed to adjust boundaries disputes, Bhopal agency, March, 1864; assistant political agent, Bundelcund, small cause court judge and cantonment magistrate, Nowgong, 1866; second in command, Malwa Bheel corps, Nov., 1870; political agent, Bhopal, Aug., 1876; political agent, Bhopawur, and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, Oct., 1879, political agent, Bhopal, June, 1881.

KINDERSLEY, JOHN ROBERT, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1847; served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector till 1857, when he was appointed assistant judge of Mangalore; subordinate judge, Bellary, 1859; civil and sessions judge, Rajahmundry, March, 1865, and subsequently at Bellary; officiating judicial commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1866, and again 1868; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, June, 1877; retired in 1884.

KING, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; house surgeon, Medical College Hospital, from 9th May to 25th Aug., 1866, when his services were placed at disposal of government of India, military department; superintendent of Royal Botanical Gardens, ex-officio professor of botany in Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio superintendent of cinchona plantation in British Sikkhim, from July, 1871; surgeon-major, Oct. 1877; also officiating quinologist, Dec., 1879; author of 'Manual of Cinchona Cultivation in India.'

KING, JOSHUA, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 26th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and session judge; in charge of the small cause court, Ahmedabad, April-May, 1864; acting under secretary to Government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1866; acting collector and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bombay, July, 1869, to Jan., 1870; talukdari settlement officer, Dec., 1874, to Feb., 1876, and again, Feb., 1876, to Nov., 1877, for carrying Bombay Act VI of 1862 into effect, and manager under Act XV of 1871; on special duty, Baroda, Nov., 1877, to June, 1879; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, May, 1879; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, May, 1884; retired, 1886.

KING, LUCAS BLACKER BURNET, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 11th Oct., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue, survey, and judicial departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, Aug., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1880; retired, Aug., 1885.

KING, LUCAS WHITE, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Ennis College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Sept., 1882; revenue officer, Swat River Canal, Feb.-May, 1885; transferred to foreign department as officiating political agent, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, June, 1885.

KING, WILLIAM, D.Sc., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined the service, 4th March, 1857; served in various districts of the Madras presidency, and was appointed deputy superintendent for Madras, Nov., 1868; served subsequently in the Godavari district and the Nizam's territories, and discovered the Singareni coal-field, 1871-72; deputed to Vienna in joint charge of the survey collections at the Exhibition, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1875; fellow of the Madras University and member of
the Faculty of Engineering, 1884; officiated as superintendent of the geological survey, May-Nov., 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; author of contributions to the survey publications.

KIPLING, JOHN LOCKWOOD, Education Department, Punjab.—Joined the government service as architectural sculptor, Bombay, May, 1865; from April, 1875, served in the Punjab as principal of Mayo School of Industrial Art, and curator, Lahore Museum.

KIRKHAM, T. B., Barrister-at-Law, Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational department, 1st Jan., 1862; arrived in India, 21st June, 1862, and served as headmaster of the Poona High School, principal of the Elphinstone High School, Bombay, and professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College; was also a member of the first municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug., 1873; from April, 1878, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, April, 1885.

KIRKWOOD, TOWNSEND MOLLOY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, and Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1876, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1880; served temporarily under the public works department, Oct., 1869, to Oct., 1871, and was employed on famine duty, Bhagulpore, March, 1874; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1886.

KISCH, HERMANN MICHAEL, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Nov., 1873; on famine duty, Patna, March, 1874, and at Bellary, Feb., 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, May, 1878; under secretary, judicial and political departments, Jan., 1880; officiating secretary in the financial department, June, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1883; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885.

KITTS, EUSTACE JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Berar, Aug., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner and also as small cause court judge of Akola; on special (famine) duty, in Madras, 1877-78; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, May to Nov., 1883; from April, 1884, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1885.

KNIGHT, RAYMONT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's College, Stony Stratford, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1883; assistant collector, April, 1885.

KNOWLYS, HENRY BOLD, Berar Commission.—Served as a writer in the Ceylon civil service, 15th Feb., 1859, to Aug., 1866; from Sept., 1866, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1873; deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

KNOX, GEORGE, Punjab Administration.—Assistant engineer, May, 1854; from June, 1856, served in the Punjab commission, and was appointed personal assistant to commissioner of Jullundur, April, 1864, assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1864, and deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Rawul Pindi, Nov., 1878, to April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

KNOX, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from June, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed small cause court judge, Allahabad, Aug., 1877; judge, 3rd grade, March, 1884; officiating legal remembrancer, Feb., 1885; member of the lieutenant-governor's council for making laws and regulations.

KNOX, HUBERT THOMAS, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, acting principal assistant, joint sessions judge for trying Rumpa cases, and assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); acted as district and sessions judge, Ganjam, April-Sept., 1884, and afterwards in North Arcot; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Oct., 1884.

KNYVETT, WILLIAM LEYCESTER NATHANIEL, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th June, 1854; served in the Bengal police department from June, 1863, as district superintendent (1st grade, April, 1875); officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, July, 1875; deputy inspector-general, April, 1885.

KOUGH, CHARLES, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1867, and served in various districts of Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, head assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate in the districts of Madura, Cuddapah, and North Arcot.

KRISHNA CHUNDER CHATTERJEE, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 19th Dec., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1877; small cause court judge, Backergunge, Dec., 1877; subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

KRISHNA MOHUN MOOKERJI, B.L.,
Judicial Department, Bengal.—Served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, from 28th March, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1884.

KUNWAR BHARAT SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

KUNWAR SHIAM SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 12th Jan., 1881.

KUNWAR JWÁLA PRASÁD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1884; probationary assistant magistrate, Gorakhpur.

LAFFAN, EDWARD SIDNEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimbledon School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, 1877-78; from June, 1882, served in the Madras secretariat, and was appointed assistant secretary in judicial and legislative departments, July, 1884; has also acted for various periods as under-secretary and as secretary in the revenue department, and as under-secretary in the chief secretary's departments; on special duty, preparing Madras administration report, Nov., 1882; Canarese translator to government, Sept., 1885; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1885, to March, 1886; acting secretary, board of revenue, Nov.-Dec., 1885.

LAIDMAN, GEORGE JOHN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dün, and officiating magistrate and collector; small cause court judge, Dehra Dün, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Nov., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1883.

LAING, JAMES ANDERSON, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1870, and served in the Madras medical department as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acting resident surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; deputy sanitary commissioner and inspector of vaccination, Feb., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; officiating sanitary commissioner, April, 1886.

LAKSHMAN GOPAL DESHMUKH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

LAL BEHARI DE, Rev., Bengal Education Department.—Served from 3rd Sept., 1867, first as head master, and afterwards as assistant professor, in the Berhampore College; assistant professor in the Hooghly College, Jan., 1872; 3rd class of the education department, May, 1885; author of 'Govinda Samanta, or Bengal Peasant Life,' 'Folk Tales of Bengal,' 'Recollections of Alexander Duff.'

LAMB, RICHARD AMPHLETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Khandesh, March, 1883; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

LAMBE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1886.

LAMBERT, JOHN, C.I.E., Police Department, Bengal.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1863, as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and officiating personal assistant to the inspector-general; on special duty, March, 1872; visitor of the presidency jail, and of the lunatic asylums, July, 1872; deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, Feb., 1874; served under the government of India, foreign department, from March, 1882, to March, 1884, as officiating political resident, 2nd class, and general superintendent of the operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; acted as commissioner, Calcutta, and president of the boiler commission, 1885-86.

LAMBERT, PARRY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1857; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, 8th Jan., 1858, and served in Oudh, and the Punjab; executive engineer, Dec., 1863; officiating controller of Punjab northern state railway accounts, Sept., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, May, 1876; examiner, 3rd class, Oct., 1878; transferred to the office of examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1879; transferred to Bombay, as officiating examiner, public works accounts, Dec., 1879; from Dec., 1881, served in the N.W. Provinces as examiner, public works accounts, and officiated in Bengal, Feb.-Dec., 1882; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; transferred to Bombay, May, 1884; and to the Punjab, Sept., 1886.

LANE, CLAYTON TURNER, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign Bengal army, 11th Dec., 1858; from March, 1863, served in the Punjab as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent of police; transferred to Berar police, Sept., 1865; inspector-general of police and jails, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; is also inspector-general of jails, and registration and stamps, and registrar of joint stock companies.

LANE, J. H., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Feb., 1857; superintendent, 1st grade, Bombay, Aug., 1870; officiating deputy director-general, March, 1872, and again Feb.-April, 1886; director of traffic, Feb., 1879.

LANE, J. M., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian tele-
graph department, 22nd Sept., 1862; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Bengal, Oct., 1869; served subsequently in the Malabar Coast and Nagpur divisions; 1st grade superintendent, British Burma, Sept., 1883, and afterwards in Bombay.

LANE, WILLIAM MOORE, Colonel, M.S.C., Postal Department, Punjab.—Ensign in the Madras Army, 20th Jan., 1851; arrived in India, and March, 1851; from July, 1856, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, March, 1866; postmaster-general, Punjab, Feb., 1869; officiating director-general, post office of India, Nov., 1879, to Feb., 1880.

LANE, WILMOT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 13th January, 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Aug., 1863 to March, 1866, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Moradabad, Aug., 1877; commissioner, Rae Bareli Division, Sept., 1880, and subsequently of the Agra and Meerut divisions; officiating as member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct.-Dec., 1883.

LANG, ARTHUR MOFFATT, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, N.W.P.—1st commission, June, 1852; arrived in India, July, 1854; assistant engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1855; superintendent, civil buildings, Lahore, Aug., 1856; executive engineer, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and clasps); assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; assistant secretary, public works department, to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1865; principal, Thomason Engineering College, March, 1871, to May, 1877; superintending engineer, 1st grade, deputy inspector-general military works, and secretary, defence committee, Feb., 1879; secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, public works department, Feb., 1881; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, public works department, Jan., 1883; chief engineer and joint secretary, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, March, 1886.

LANG, GEORGE LUKIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, March, 1858; from Nov., 1858, to Nov., 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; from Nov., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; appointed magistrate and collector, Aligarh, April, 1877, and was subsequently posted to Bulandshar; officiating district and sessions judge, July-Sept., 1880; has acted for various periods as commissioner in the Agra and Rohilkund Divisions.

LANG, RICHARD TICKELL MONTGOMERY, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, Mooltan, April, 1877; officiating additional civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, April-Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, March, 1881, and subsequently in the Rawal Pindi Division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

LANGLEY, EDWARD HARTLEY RAYNSFORD, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. (Dub.), M.R.C.S. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1858; was employed under the military department, and as acting civil surgeon in various stations; served with 5th regiment, N.L.I., in China in 1860-62; appointed presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay, Oct., 1876; also in medical charge of the European General Hospital, May-June, 1882; brigade-surgeon, March, 1885.

LANSOWNE (Marquess of), Rt. Hon. HENRY CHARLES KEITH FITZMAURICE.—Born, 1845; educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; succeeded to the marquisate in 1866; a lord of the treasury, 1868 to 1872; under secretary for war, 1872 to 1874; under secretary for India, April to July, 1880; governor-general of Canada, May, 1883.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 2nd Aug., 1873.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM REA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 28th Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Orissa division, and superintendent of Tributary Mehalas, Cuttack, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Dacca, April, 1885; commissioner, Dacca division, Oct., 1886.

LARPENT, FREDERIC DE HOCHEPIED, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 19th Feb., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant accountant-general, officiating deputy accountant-general, and assistant comptroller-general; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nov., 1875; served in Madras, Nov., 1876, to April, 1878, as assistant accountant-general; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1878; examiner of local accounts in Bengal, March, 1880; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, in 4th class of financial department, Nov., 1884; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1885.

LATHAM, F. L., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Service, Bombay.—Served as acting remembrancer of legal affairs, 23rd May, 1872, to 1st Jan., 1873; also acted as advocate-general, and as judge of the high court, Bombay, for various periods between 1st Jan., 1880, and 5th March, 1884; advocate-general, Bombay, 6th March, 1884.

LA TOUCHE, CECIL D'URBAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Ensign, 29th July, 1850; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1850, and served on military duty up to Nov., 1883, and subsequently as cantonment, magistrate, Poona.
LA TOUCHE, HENRY CHRISTOPHER DIGGES, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab northern state railway; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, construction division, Nov., 1879; Bundelcund railway surveys, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Jhansi-Manikpur state railway, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Bellary-Kistna and Cuddapah-Nellore railways, March, 1886.

LATOUCHE, JAMES JOHN DIGGES, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, till Dec., 1871, when he was transferred as settlement officer to Ajmere; also served as officiating assistant commissioner of Bewar and officiating deputy commissioner, Ajmere; returned to N.W. Provinces, 1875, and was appointed district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1875; served subsequently in various districts in officiating appointments as settlement officer, magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge, and was promoted to joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1882; settlement officer, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Nov., 1883; from Aug., 1886, served in Burma as commissioner of the Southern division.

LATOUCHE, WILLIAM PAGET, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Salt Department, Bombay.—1st commission, Bombay army, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1855; was employed on military duty, and served in the Persian war, 1856, and the mutiny campaign, and was also appointed assistant magistrate, Dec., 1859 and assistant district superintendent of police, Jan., 1865; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, June-Nov., 1867; from Dec., 1867, served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent (1st grade, May, 1882), and also acted as superintendent of the Bombay, Baroda, and C. I. railway company's police, Nov., 1868, to Nov., 1869; on special duty, June, 1879, to Feb., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as deputy collector of salt revenue.

LAUDERDALE (Earl of), Rt. Hon. FREDERICK HENRY MATTLAND, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Hussars, Feb., 1861; served in Central India on civil employ from 1869 as boundary officer, and political assistant; and assistant agent, Indore, 1877; 1st assistant agent, Indore, 1878; additional political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, 1880; retired, Jan., 1886.

LAUGHTON, DANIEL WILSON, Major-General, M.S.C., late Berar Commission.—First commission in the army, Jan., 1854; arrived in Madras, April, 1854; from Jan., 1865, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate; acted as inspector-general of registration, Jan., 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Feb., 1885; retired, May, 1886.

LAURIE, LEWIS KOSSUTH, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting district superintendent of police; acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1880, to March, 1883, and as small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1881 and 1882; acting assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, 1883-85; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, July-Oct., 1883, and again, March, 1885; acting director of agriculture, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1884; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1885.

LAW, VICTOR EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, April, 1859; acted as government agent at Chepak, paymaster of Carnatic stipendiaries, and Persian and Hindustani translator to government, July, 1866; attaché, foreign department, July, 1872; served in Rajputana as superintendent of railway police, 1872 to 1877; political agent, Jeypoor, 1877, and afterwards in Ulwar, 1877-1883; officiating political agent, Charkhari, 1883; assistant at Sujangarhi to governor general's agent in Rajputana, Feb., 1884; agent to governor general with king of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1884; appointed to the political charge of ex-Amir Muhammad Yakub Khan of Kabul, Aug. 1884; graded as political agent, 3rd class.

LAWRENCE, ALEXANDER JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1856; served from March, 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1864, served in the Central Provinces as settlement officer of Bhandara; re-attached to N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1869, and served as settlement officer and officiating magistrate and collector; member of the commission under the military department on the Lawrence asylums, June to Nov., 1872; on special duty with the government of India, home department, Dec., 1872; officiating civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, June, 1874; magistrate and collector, Etawah, Oct., 1874, and subsequently of Agra; officiated for various periods as commissioner, Agra division; commissioner of the Allahabad division, April, 1886.

LAWRENCE, EDWARD, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as assistant to the political resident at Aden, March, 1882, and as under secretary to Government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, April, 1885; compiler of general administration report for 1884-85.

LAWRENCE, HENRY JOHN, Major, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th February, 1862; from Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commis-
sioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884, Amritsar; additional divisional judge, Amritsar, Jan., 1885.

LAWRENCE, RICHARD CHARLES, Lieut.-General, C.B., Bengal S.C.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; served in the Sutlej campaign in 1846, and was present at the battle of Soobraon (medal); second in command, Loodianah regiment, Dec., 1847; assistant commissioner, Punjab, April, 1849; captain of police, Lahore division, Jan., 1853; served in the Indian mutiny as political officer in charge of the Cashmere contingent, under General Wilson, in 1857, and was present at the assault and capture of Delhi (brevet of major, C.B., medal with clasp); military secretary to lieutenant governor of the Punjab, 1860; deputy commissioner, Simla, April, 1862; resident, Nepaul, 1867 to 1872.

LAWRENCE, WALTER ROPER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 5th December, 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Sept., 1881, to April, 1884, served in Ajmere and Merwara as officiating political assistant and assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; in charge Ajmere treasury and office of registrar of assurances, May, 1882; under-secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1886; under secretary to government of India, revenue department, Sept., 1886.

LAWRIE, EDWARD, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Indian Medical Department.—First commission, Bengal medical service, 1872; surgeon-major, March, 1884; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, April, 1885; is also superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of medical school, and surgeon to the Afzalganj hospital.

LEARY, A.S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the Moravian colleges of Fulneck in Yorkshire, and Neuwinden on the Rhine; temporary clerk, India Office, 15th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LEBRETON, WILLIAM INGLIS, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined the royal artillery, Dec., 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; joined the public works department, Nov., 1866, and served as assistant engineer in the Bombay presidency till Nov., 1869, and subsequently as assistant controller and deputy controller of accounts in the Punjab, N.W. Provinces, and Bombay; controller, 3rd class, and examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, Sept., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; from Dec., 1879, served as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, and was promoted to 2nd class, May, 1886; also officiated as examiner of public works accounts, Sept.-Dec., 1883, and port storekeeper, state railways, March-June, 1884; examiner, public works accounts, Bombay, Feb., 1887.

LEE, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Yarmouth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1885.

LEE, J., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Caius School, Cambridge; writer, India Office, 24th Aug., 1868; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LEEDS, ROBERT JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1867; served from Aug., 1862, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharája of Benares, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1879, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge.

LEEDS, WILLIAM HENRY ARTHUR ST. JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

LEE-WARNER, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in various districts of Madras from April, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting cantonment magistrate; on special duty, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot and Salem, Jan., 1868; boundary arbitrator between the Kalastari Zemindari and Madras district, Sept., 1868; special assistant collector, Madura, for the management of the Ramnad estate, Dec., 1871, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1882; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1884; district and sessions judge, Kinsta, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, Dec., 1884.

LEE-WARNER, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th November, 1869; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1870; officiating director of public instruction, Berar, Feb., 1872; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1872, to Nov., 1874, and Jan.-Dec., 1876; on special duty in the secretariat, Nov., 1874; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and acting secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, Nov., 1874; from Dec., 1876, to Aug., 1878, served in Sind as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, acting educational inspector, and acting commissioner; acting junior collector and magistrate, Satara, March, 1881; on special duty as member of the education commission, Calcutta, 1882; on special duty at the Nira canal, April, 1882; from Jan.-Oct., 1884, acted as junior under secretary to government of India, foreign department, and as private secretary to the president in council of the governor-general (Jan.-Feb.), and was on special duty in the foreign department, March-June, 1884; acting press commissioner, Sept., 1884; acting under-secretary to government of India, foreign department, Oct., 1884; first assistant collector and acting director of public instruction, Bombay, March, 1885; on special duty in the Hyderabad
State, Nov., 1885; acting political agent, Kolhapur, and Southern Mahratta country, Jan., 1886; also president of the Regency Council, Kolhapur, May, 1886; acting secretary to Government of Bombay, Nov., 1886.

LE FANU, WILLIAM JOSEPH HENRY, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Tipperary Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Salem district manual; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1885; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1886.

LEGEYET, PHILIP HARRISON, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th March, 1851; was employed under the military department, including service with the Persian expeditionary force (medal and clasp); served subsequently with the Gujarat Irregular Horse, and also acted as assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha (April, 1858); from May, 1863, served in the political department as assistant political agent, Káthiáwar and Cutch, and magistrate of the district of Bhávnagar; political agent, Mahi Kántha, 1872-1880; political superintendent, Palanpur, Sept., 1880; 1st grade, political agent, Feb., 1885.

LEGGATT, EDWARD OWEN EVERY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, and Dec., 1885; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LEITNER, GOTTLIEB WILLIAM, Dr., M.A., Ph.D., LL.D., D.C.L., Barrister-at-Law, late Education Department, Punjab.—Served in education department as principal of the Lahore College from 12th Nov., 1864, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, Nov., 1880; in July, 1867, was deputed to Kashmir for a philological examination of the Kashmiri and Chilasi dialects; on special duty in connection with the school text-book committee at Simla, May, 1877; attended the congress of Orientalists at Florence, Oct., 1878; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, July, 1879; on special duty with education commission, May, 1882; retired in 1886.

LELY, FREDERIC STYLES PHILPIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th December, 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting city survey and inquiry officer at Ahmedabad, acting Tálukdári settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; in charge of the Sachin state, Oct., 1881; first assistant collector, Surat, Dec., 1884; administrator of the Porbandar State in Káthiáwar.

LEMAN, GEORGE DOWNTON, Madras C.S., appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed principal assistant to the collector and magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Guntoor, July, 1867, and afterwards at Tellicherry; acted as collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, in 1868, and again in 1875 and 1881-82, and as Inam commissioner in 1869; from Feb., 1872, to Nov., 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Kistna, and subsequently in Ganjam and Coimbatore.

LE MESSURIER, AUGUSTUS, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st Commission, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1856; served in the Indian Mutiny at the sieges of Forts Beyt and Dwaraka; joined the Bombay public works department, as assistant engineer, May, 1860; was employed on the Karáchi harbour works, on irrigation in Sind, on the Bombay harbour defences, &c.; executive engineer, March, 1863; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, Aug., 1864; served in the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal); deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind, Aug., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lahore, April-July, 1875; acted as secretary to the railway transport committee at Delhi, in 1875-76, and to a similar committee at Agra, 1876-77; deputed to Brussels exhibition to report on continental system of transport by railways, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, May, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, May, 1877, to Nov., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80, (medal and brevet of lieutenant-colonel); engineer-in-chief, Mysore State railway, Nov., 1879; joint secretary to chief commissioner, Mysore, 1880; on special duty reporting on timber-cutting operations in east of France, April, 1880; manager, Mysore State railway, Feb., 1881; consulting engineer to Mysore Government, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, March, 1882; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Bangalore-Harihar railway.

LE MESURIER, HAVILLAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Assam, Nov., 1886.

LE MESURIER, JOHN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; second lieutenant, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1855; served in the public works department in Sind from June, 1856, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Nara works and the Rohri canal, Hyderabad; served with the Persian expedition, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); on special duty, Karáchi, Jan., 1867; acting superintending engineer for irrigation in Sind, April, 1871, to Dec. 1873, and for various periods between 1875 and 1880; superintendent of works, Western Indus, Karáchi, Dec., 1873; superintending engineer, Jan., 1879; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, June-Aug., 1883; (temporary) chief engineer, 3rd class, and chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, public works department (irrigation), March, 1884; superintending engineer in Sind, Jan., 1886.

LETHBRIDGE, ALFRED SWAINE, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1867; served from March, 1872, as superintendent of central jail and officiating civil surgeon, Bhagulpore; officiating inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner, and superintendent of vaccination, British Burma,
July, 1876; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, May, 1877; inspector-general of jails, Bengal, Jan., 1878; rank of surgeon-major, Sept., 1879.

LETHEREN, S. K., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

LEUPOLT, JOHN CUNNINGHAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Aug., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Aug., 1882, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge.

LEWIS, E. M.—Superintendent, Bengal secretariat press, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Bengal, Sept., 1877.

LIARDET, CHARLES AYLMER, Colonel, M.S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Oct., 1855; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1855; Madras staff corps, Sept., 1866; served in the Madras revenue survey department from Oct., 1868; on famine relief works, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884.

LIDDERDALE, ROBERT, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; superintendent of vaccination, 8th November, 1869; in medical charge, Julipigoree, in addition to his own duties, June, 1872; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, April, 1880; professor of hygiene, Medical College; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; deputy surgeon-general (local rank), Bengal, Jan., 1884.

LIGHTFOOT, J., Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed from the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as deputy manager, North-Western state railway, Jan., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, state railways, July, 1886; manager, Punjab section, March, 1887.

LILLINGSTON, EDWARD GORDON, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 30th Aug., 1859; from 5th Feb., 1864, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1867, officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1874, superintendent of the central jail, and the European penitentiary at Hazaribagh, May, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886.

LIMOND, DAVID, Major-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1850; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Feb., 1853; during the mutiny, served at relief and defence of Lucknow (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Cawnpore, 1858; officiating superintending engineer, Allahabad, April, 1867, and in Bengal, western circle, from March, 1868; transferred to Rawal Pindee, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, military works, Rawal Pindee, April, 1872; in 1879-80 served as commanding engineer, Peshawur Valley field force (medal, C.B.); chief engineer, 3rd class, military works, April, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1884; retired, 1886.

LINCOLN, FREDERICK, Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—From Oct., 1846, to March, 1860, served in various capacities in the offices of the commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, the Punjab board of administration, the judicial commissioners of the Punjab and Oudh, and the secretariat at Allahabad; appointed, for special services during siege of Lucknow, extra assistant commissioner in Oudh, March, 1860; assistant civil judge, Lucknow, Jan., 1861; small cause court judge, Lucknow, March, 1866; civil judge, Lucknow, Aug., 1869; district judge, 3rd grade, Sitapur, Aug., 1879.

LINDSAY, CHARLES ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Woolwich, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1844; arrived in India, 1845; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1858; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, 1862; extra judge of the Sudder court, Agra, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Mynpoorie, 1865, and subsequently of Goruckpore and Moradabad; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1869; retired, 1880.

LINDSAY, JAMES GAVIN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Aug., 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Dec., 1857; during the mutiny served at the battle of Banda (medal and clasp), served subsequently as executive engineer in Banda and Orissa; deputy consulting engineer for railways, 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, railway survey, Mysore, April, 1870; officiating superintending engineer, and engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal railway, 1872; acted as director of state railways, N.E. system, and joint secretary to Bengal government, Nov., 1878, to March, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Harnai and Gulistan-Karez sections of Kandahar railway, Feb., 1880; served in the Afghan Campaign, 1879-80, (medal); superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Southern Mahratta railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class (supernumerary), April, 1881; services lent to Southern Mahratta railway company, from May, 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, April-June, 1885.

LINDSAY, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; junior clerk, India Office, 31st Jan., 1867; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1877-81; senior clerk, Jan., 1882.

LISTER, ALLEN LINDSAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in the grades of assistant and sub-collector, and was placed on special duty in connection with the relief of the poorer classes, South Arcot, Jan., 1868; on famine duty, Sept. to Dec., 1877; on special duty, Irrigation and Canal Company, Jan., 1878; collector and magistrate, South Canara, July, 1882; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1882, in Vizagapatam, and afterwards in the Godavari district.

LISTON, JOHN, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 29th May, 1856; served with the Bundelcund field force in the campaign of 1859; from Aug., 1863, served in Jhansi, Kumaon, and Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Lalitpur, Dec., 1879; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, Aug. to Nov., 1882.
LITTLE, Charles, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.C., L.R.C.S., L.M., Madras Medical Service.—Arrived in Madras, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department; civil surgeon, Akola, Jan., 1877; sanitary commissioner, inspector-general of dispensaries, superintendent of vaccination, and administrative medical officer of the Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884.

LITTLE, F. A., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acted as government solicitor and public prosecutor, Bombay, Oct.–Nov., 1879, and May to Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1884.

LIVESAY, John James, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1878; employed on famine relief duty, March to Oct., 1874.

LLOYD, Ernest Thomas, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Shrewsbury, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, and Feb., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1882; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1885, and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Dec., 1886.

LLOYD, Francis, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the College School, Gloucester; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and session judge; judicial assistant to magistrate, Satara, 1860; judge and session judge, Dharwar, 1861; judge and session judge, Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1869; retired in 1873.

LLOYD, R. A., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department, from 1st May, 1864, as professor and officiating principal, Agra College; from Oct., 1867, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1870; acted as principal of the Bareilly College, 1875–76.

LOCH, Francis Adam Ellis, Lieutenant-General, C.B., Bombay S.C.—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and Rochester School; 1st commission as cornet, Bombay cavalry, 7th April, 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848–49, and was present at the siege and capture of Mooltan (medal and clasp); served subsequently as adjutant of the Southern Maharatta horse, 1850, and of the 1st regiment Bombay light cavalry, 1850–57; in the mutiny of 1857–58 was wounded at the outbreak of the Bengal troops at Nusseerabad, May, 1857; was present at the siege and capture of Awah and Cotah, the recapture of Chandaree, the action at Kotah-ke-Serai, the capture of Gwalior, the siege of Pourie, the pursuit of rebels under Maun Sing, and the action of Koondrye (brevet of major, medal and clasp), served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867–68, and was present at the battle of Arogce, and the capture of Magdala (brevet of colonel, medal and clasp); C.B., May, 1875; political superintendent and commandant, Upper Sind frontier, 1873 to 1876; commanded Hyderabad contingent, 1876, and the station at Ahmednugger, 1876–77; political resident, Aden, and commanding Aden brigade, May, 1877, to March, 1882.

LOCH, James Henry, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; served under the military department till Aug., 1859, including service with the Oudh field force in 1855, and at the relief of Azamgarh, 1858 (medal), and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in various stations, and superintendent of jail, and held medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp in 1860–70, and again, 1872 and 1873; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1884.

LOCH, William, Captain, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, March, 1866; served in the 104th Foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, May, 1868, and served subsequently in the Sind horse; assistant political superintendent, Sawantwari, May, 1877; assistant to general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, 1878; and assistant to governor-general's agent, Indore, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, 1880; during the Afghan war was on political duty with Major-General Sir R. Phayre's force, marching to the relief of Kandahar (medal); and assistant agent, Beloochistan, in charge of Pishin valley, Nov., 1880; assistant resident, Western Rajputana, and boundary settlement officer in Marwar, Dec., 1881; graded as additional political agent, 3rd class.

LOCH, Willie Walker, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, April–Nov., 1880; first assistant collector and railway magistrate, Thana, Oct., 1882.

LOGAN, Alexander Cochrane, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, and Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

LOGAN, Robert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, and University College, London; matriculated at the London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1869; served in the Central Provinces from 1860 to 1881, in the grade of assistant commissioner, and officiated as district superintendent of police, March, 1872; inspector of schools, Dec., 1873, to March, 1874; and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, April, 1874, to Dec., 1876; from April to Nov., 1881, served in the financial department in Bengal as deputy accountant-general and officiating accountant-general; appointed assistant comptroller-general in Class III of the financial
department, Sept., 1881; acted as under-secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, from Nov., 1881, and was confirmed in this appointment, July, 1883; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Aug.-Oct., 1883, and as deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1884, and again in 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1885.

LOGAN, WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at Musselburgh Grammar School, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate of Malabar, March, 1876; on special duty, Feb., 1881, as commissioner for inquiring into certain important matters in the Moplah districts; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1881; member of Forest Draft Bill Committee, March, 1882; acting member, board of revenue, Nov., 1882; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, May, 1883 to Feb., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with Report on Land Tenures of Malabar, Feb., 1884, and again in connection with the Attipadi Valley suit, July, 1884; has published a collection of treaties, engagements, &c., relating to British affairs in Malabar, 1879; and edited Mr. Graeme's glossary of Malayalam words and phrases, 1882.

LORD, WALTER FREWEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

LOVE, HENRY DAVISON, Captain, R.E., Madras Education Department.—Educated at University College, Bath, and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; Lieutenant, R.E., 12th September, 1872; acted as inspector of schools for science and art department, 1875-76; admitted to Madras establishment, Oct., 1876; arrived in India, 5th December, 1876; first assistant master civil engineering college, July, 1877; on special duty in connection with Madras harbour works, Dec., 1877; served subsequently in the P.W. Department, and acted as deputy consulting engineer for railways in 1878 and 1879, and as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, irrigation branch, June-Nov., 1879; assistant examiner of accounts, Nov., 1879; principal, civil engineering college, Jan., 1880; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885.

LOVETT, BERESFORD, Colonel, C.S.I., R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, Sept., 1860; joined the public works department, April, 1861, and served in the Punjab till Sept., 1866, when he was transferred to the Persian telegraph department; assistant commissioner, Seistan boundary commission, Sept., 1870; rejoined P.W. department as executive engineer, Sept., 1872; C.S.I., Feb., 1873; attached to Bori Valley field force, Nov., 1877 to Jan., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1878-79; transferred to Bengal, Feb., 1881; British consul at Astrabad, Sept., 1880 to Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, Bengal, 1885; transferred to military works, Rawal Pindi command, April, 1886.

LOVETT, SACKVILLE HALTON HARRINGTON VERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LOWIS, EDMOND ELLIOT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1863; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1864; deputy commissioner, Western Dooras, Oct., 1867; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Oct., 1867; magistrate and collector, Maladah, Dec., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1868; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1872; commissioner, Chittagong division, March, 1875; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1879; officiating opium agent, Behar, Jan. to Nov., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Dec., 1885, and in the Rajshahiye division, Oct., 1886.

LOWNDES, THOMAS, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Burma.—Joined the Madras army, and arrived in India, Dec., 1854; served in the Burma police department from March, 1861, as superintendent; on special mission to Chiengme, March-May, 1871; political agent, Bhamo, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; 1st grade, superintendent, May, 1875; inspector-general of police, British Burma, Jan., 1876; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885.

LUARD, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1857; deputy superintendent, Western Jamna canal, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1859; assistant principal, Thomason College, 1863; assistant secretary, government of India, public works department, officiating as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, March, 1865; deputy superintendent, Ganges canal, 1865; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bengal, Oct., 1867; officiating under secretary, government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873 to 1875; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1874; officiating mint master, Calcutta, July to Oct., 1876; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1884, and subsequently at Calcutta, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, and class, May, 1886.

LUCAS, ARTHUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1886.

LUDLAM, JOSEPH T., Registry Department, India Office.—Served under the India Board from 1858; registrar at India Board, 1859, and continued in charge of the records till 1867, when he was transferred to the registry department, India Office, as extra assistant to registrar.
LUFKIN, GEORGE, India Office.—Clerk to the clerk of the works, India office, 21st June, 1860; clerk of the works, Aug., 1874; surveyor and clerk of the works, April, 1882.

LUGARD, HENRY IBBETSON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; was employed under the military department till 1864, also serving in the Madras police in 1857 and 1860-61; from Jan., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry, Jubbulpore, May to Sept., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, March 1873; deputy commissioner, and class, Dec., 1885.

LUMSDEN, JOHN JAMES FOOTE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, July, 1874; on special duty to Naini Tal, July-Sept., 1875; commissioner, Fyzabad division, Dec., 1879, and subsequently of the Benares division, and agent to the governor-general.

LUMSDEN, SIR PETER S., Major-General, G.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal army, Dec., 1847; assistant executive engineer, 1849; deputy assistant quartermaster-general, April, 1853; assistant political agent, Afghanistan, Jan., 1857, to June, 1858; assistant quartermaster-general, Sept., 1858; deputy quartermaster-general, April, 1863; quartermaster-general, May, 1868; officiating resident, Hyderabad, 1872; adjutant-general, Sept., 1874; chief of the staff, 1879; member of council of secretary of state for India, Dec., 1883; Afghan boundary commissioner, 1884.

LUSHINGTON, EDWARD HARBORD, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1841; arrived in India, 22nd June, 1841; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate of Chittagong in 1847, and afterwards of Patna; deputy collector of government sea customs, Calcutta, 1855; collector, Nuddea, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, 1857; acting commissioner of the Burdwan, Manbhoon, and Singhbhoon district, 1857-58; Mutiny medal; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Nuddea, 1861; secretary to government of Bengal, 1861; secretary to government of India in the financial department, government director of Bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1863; retired, 1871.

LUSON, HEWLING, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's, Southwark, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Nuddea, Jan., 1885.

LUTTMAN-JOHNSON, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1872; acting under secretary, government of Bengal, department of scarcity and relief, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1874; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1874, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, and secretary to chief commissioner, July, 1879; judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, May, 1886.

LYALL, SIR ALFRED COMYN, K.C.B., K.C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, and Jan., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Central Provinces, April, 1864, and served as deputy commissioner, officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating commissioner of the Nagpur division; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1867, and appointed commissioner, West Berar, Aug., 1867; secretary to the government of India, home department, March, 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere; on special duty in England, Aug., 1876; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1878; on special political duty in Kabul, March, 1880, and again in Sept., 1880; K.C.B., May, 1881; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, 17th April, 1882; C.I.E., May, 1882; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

LYALL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., LL.D., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's College School, King's College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated at various times as under secretary to government, and as junior secretary, Oct., 1872; assistant under secretary to government of India, foreign department, April-June, 1872; from April, 1873, served under the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed under secretary to government, Sept., 1873, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1878; transferred to Assam as officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, 1883; secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1883; officiating secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Feb.-Nov., 1886; author of 'Article on Hindustani literature in Encyclopaedia Britannica,' 1880; 'Sketch of the Hindustani language,' 1880; 'Translations of ancient Arabic Poetry,' 1885; and 'Guide to the transliteration of Hindu and Muhammadan names in the Bengal army,' 1885.
