LYALL, DAVID ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, March, 1878, and Presidency division, Feb., 1882; inspector-general of police, March, 1883; officiating commissioner of Chittagong, Oct., 1884.
LYALL, JAMES BROADWOOD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1858; arrived, April 8, 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and deputy commissioner; settlement commissioner, Mooltan and Derajat, March, 1874; financial commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1883; also judicial commissioner of Coorg; graded in the political department as resident, 1st class; lieut.-governor of the Punjab, April, 1887.

LYNCH, SIDNEY S., Medical Department, Bengal.—From 16th Nov., 1858, served in Assam as civil medical officer, and inspector of landing of native labourers, and from Jan., 1866, in Bengal, as superintendent, presidency jail; superintendent of the Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1871; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, May, 1879; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1882.

LYON, GEORGE KENNETH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1885.

LYON, ISIDORE BERNADETTE, Surgeon-Major, F.C.S., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., F.I.C., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 1st March, 1866; acting professor of anatomy and curator of museum, Grant Medical College, March, 1866; professor of chemistry, Grant Medical College, and chemical analyster to government, Jan., 1867; in addition to these appointments was also third physician at the Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, July, 1867, to Oct., 1872; professor of medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, from July, 1868, and professor of chemistry at the Elphinstone College from Dec., 1875; on special duty conducting petroleum experiments, Oct.–Nov., 1882.

LYON, PERCY COMYN, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's School, Bruton, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1881; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to the chief commissioner.

LYTTELTON, Hon. N. G., Colonel, Rifle Brigade.—Military secretary on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. D. J. M. Lord Reay), 31st March, 1885.

LYTTON (Earl of), RIGHT HON. EDWARD ROBERT BULWER-LYTTON, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Born Nov. 8, 1831; educated at Harrow, and afterwards at Bonn; entered the diplomatic service in 1849, and served as attache successively at Washington, Florence, Paris, the Hague, St. Petersburg, and Constantinople; from Jan., 1859, to Jan., 1863, he was attached to the Vienna embassy, during which period he acted as consul-general at Belgrade (Feb.–March, 1860), and was employed on a special mission to prevent the renewal of hostilities between the Turks and Servians; and secretary in the diplomatic service, Oct., 1866; secretary of legation at Copenhagen, Jan., 1863, at Athens, May, 1864, and at Lisbon, April, 1865; successfully concluded the negotiation of a commercial treaty with Austria; transferred to Madrid, Feb., 1868; secretary of embassy at Vienna, Oct., 1868, and at Paris, Oct., 1872; during the periods of his service at Copenhagen, Lisbon, Vienna, and Paris he acted on several occasions as chargé-d' affaires, and during the absence of the ambassador at Paris, was accredited there as minister plenipotentiary; ambassador at Lisbon, Nov., 1874; viceroy and governor-general of India, April 12, 1876, to April, 1880; during his tenure of office as governor-general he presided at the Delhi assembly, on the proclamation of Her Majesty the Queen as Empress of India, Jan. 1, 1877, and was the object of an attempt at assassination, Dec., 1879; G.C.B., Dec., 1877; created an earl, April, 1880; his published literary works include: 'Clytemnestra, the Earl's Return, the Artist and other Poems, 1855; 'The Wanderer; a Collection of Poems in Many Lands,' 1859; 'Lucile,' 1860; 'Tannhauser, or the Battle of the Bards' (written in collaboration with the Hon. Julian Fane), 1861; 'Serbski Pesme, a collection of the national songs of Servia, 1861; 'The Ring of Amaisin, 1863; 'Poetical Works of Owen Meredith,' 1867; 'Chronicles and Characters,' 1868; 'Orval, or the Fool of Time,' 1869; 'Julian Fane, a Memoir,' 1871; 'Fables in Song, 1874; and 'The Speeches of Edward, Lord Lytton, &c.,' 1874.

MACAULAY, COLMAN PATRICK LOUIS, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ratcliffe College, Loughborough, Queen's College, Galway, and at Liège; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1870; district superintendent of police, June, 1873; on famine duty at Bankoora, July, 1874; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1875; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Oct., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1875, and July, 1876; officiating under secretary, government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, April, 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, Feb., 1879; junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1879; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Aug., 1879; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1882; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department, 1885.

MACAULIFFE, MICHAEL, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Newcastle School (Limerick), Springfield College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1882; divisional judge, Nov., 1884 (and grade, Jan., 1887); author of 'Life of Baba Nanak,' and of articles on the Sikh religion in the 'Calcutta Review,' 1880-81.

MACARTIE, CHARLES FALKNER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the
Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served in Bombay till Nov., 1872, and subsequently in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting principal assistant, additional sessions judge, and acting collector, magistrate, and agent, and was placed on special settlement duty, Nov., 1882; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Jan., 1882; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, April-Dec., 1883; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, May, 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1885, to May, 1886.

MACDONALD, DONALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Oct., 1853; arrived in India, Dec., 1853; appointed to the survey department, revenue branch, Dec., 1860; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1866; promoted to 2nd grade, Jan., 1878; in charge of the N.W. frontier survey, 1879-1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general, March, 1886.

MACDONALD, JOHN CRAWFORD, Kumaun Commission, North-Western Provinces.—Previous to employment in India, was engaged in the railway survey department at Melbourne, 1855 to 1858; from 5th Sept., 1858, served in Kumaun as assistant to the superintendent of Khedas, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Tarai, April, 1861; superintendent, Tarai, May, 1871.

MACDONALD, R. G., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the subordinate accounts establishment, Oct., 1863, to Dec., 1867; examiner of railway accounts, Oudh, Dec., 1867; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkund railway accounts, Jan., 1870; examiner, railway accounts, Madras, 1875; W. Rajputana railway, 1876; assistant accountant-general, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; examiner of accounts, Punjab, 1881; N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1882; examiner of military works accounts, 1883; inspector of public works accounts, 1884; officiated as deputy accountant general, and under secretary to government, Nov., 1885, to Feb., 1886, and April, 1886, to March, 1887; examiner, 2nd class, in the accounts establishment, May, 1886.

MACDONNELL, ANTHONY PATRICK, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1874; officiating magistrate and collector, 1875; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1881, and again, Jan.-April, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Sept., 1881, and again, April, 1882; confirmed as secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, July, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, March, 1886; confirmed in this appointment, March, 1887; author of 'Food Grain Supply and Famine Relief in Behar and Bengal,' 1876.

MACDOUGALL, JAMES WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1858; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted at various times as cantonment magistrate of Kamptee, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur, April, 1871, to March, 1873; held charge of the model farm, Nagpur, in addition to other duties, 1873-79; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1883.

MACEWEN, ROBERT SUTHERLAND TAYLOR (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Sub-assistant commissioner, Sonthal commission, Sept., 1862; officiating assistant commissioner, May, 1863; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1866; served from Dec., 1870, as judge, Calcutta court of small causes, and was promoted to 2nd judge, Oct., 1884; served temporarily as recorder of Rangoon, April-Oct., 1884, and again in 1885-86; published 'The Practice of the Presidency Courts of Small Causes under Act XV. of 1882,' June, 1883.

MACFARLAN, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1857; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, Satara, till 1860; deputy collector and magistrate, in Sind, 1860-61; second assistant collector and magistrate at Poona and Dharwar, 1862 to 1864; acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, April, 1866; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, 1870-72, and from Feb., 1873, and was appointed postmaster-general, Madras, in 1875; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, April, 1877, to Dec., 1878; retired, Dec., 1878.

MACGEORGE, HENRY JOHN, Central Provinces.—Joined the service as deputy superintendent of Jhansi, 10th June, 1854; deputy collector, Betul, Nov., 1856; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Dec., 1860; in charge of settlement duties, Wardha and Chanda, Dec., 1862, to April, 1863; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877.

MACGREGOR, JAMES LISTOR LAIRD, Forest Department, Bombay.—Appointed an assistant conservator of forests, Punjab, Dec., 1871; arrived, 16th Jan., 1872; transferred to Bombay, June, 1873; deputy conservator, Aug., 1879; conservator, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886.

MACIVOR, IVAR, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 18th Hussars, Oct., 1872; arrived in India, March, 1873; 1st regiment, Central India Horse, Aug., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, Oct., 1878; assistant to political resident, Persian Gulf, Feb., 1880; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, Jan., 1885.

MACKAY, DUNCAN LACHLAN MACPHERSON, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Madras College, and University, St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1875, and was appointed assistant commissioner at Jubbulpore; transferred to Burma, July, 1876; 1st grade assistant commissioner, Aug., 1886.

MACKENZIE, ALEXANDER, B.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward VI.'s Grammar School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; assistant magistrate and
collector, Shahabad, Sept., 1863; from Feb., 1866, to Dec., 1873, served as under secretary, junior secretary, and officiating secretary to government of Bengal; on famine duty, Dec., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1875, and again in 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Moorsheadabad, July, 1876; also in charge of office of agent to governor-general; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, July, 1877; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Oct., 1877; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1879; secretary, government of India, home department, April, 1882; C.S.I., May, 1886; author of 'History of the Relations of the Government with the Hill Tribes of the N.E. Frontier of Bengal.'

MACKENZIE, Gordon Thomson, Madras C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner, Nilgiris, Aug., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Kista, Sept., 1881; head assistant collector, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; acting registrar, high court, July, 1883; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883, and acting secretary, Nov., 1884; president of the municipal commission, Jan., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1886.

MACKENZIE, John, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon Madras.—Assistant surgeon, army medical department, 5th Aug., 1858; served through the campaign in North of China in 1860; surgeon, March, 1873; surgeon-major, April, 1873; medical officer to His Grace the Duke of Buckingham and Chandos, governor of Madras, April, 1877, and to the Right Hon. M. E. Grant-Duff, Nov., 1881; brigade-surgeon, Sept., 1884.

MACKENZIE, Kenneth James Loch, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—Joined Madras artillery from Addiscombe, 11th June, 1858; from April, 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts, as assistant commissioner, assistant conservator of forests, and deputy commissioner (2nd class, Feb., 1885).

MACKENZIE, Stephen Coull, M.D.—Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served from 15th Oct., 1869, as professor of hygiene, Calcutta Medical College, also officiating as assistant surgeon at the Presidency General Hospital; superintendent, presidency jail, in addition to his own duties, Jan., 1871; junior surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, Dec., 1873; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, Feb., 1877; superintendent of Campbell Medical School and Hospital, Sealdah, professor of medical jurisprudence, Calcutta Medical College, and police surgeon, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; also appointed, in addition to his other duties, superintendent of lock hospitals in Calcutta and its suburbs, Nov., 1879, and of lunatic asylums, Dec., 1880, and coroner's surgeon; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1878.

MACKENZIE, Thomas Duncan, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate; secretary, Baroda Inquiry commission, Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1875, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1877; member of civil and military examination committee, April-Oct., 1879; from Nov., 1879, served as acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty at Baroda, March-Aug., 1880, in connection with the settlement of the affairs of Mir Zulfikar Ali; acting junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, May, 1884; collector, magistrate and political agent, Khandeish, Feb., 1886; acting chief secretary to government, Bombay, May, 1886.

MACKENZIE, Sir William, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., K.C.B., C.S.I., late Madras Medical Service.—A.M. of King's College, Aberdeen, 1830; M.R.C.S., London, 1832; M.D., University of Aberdeen, 1836; assistant surgeon in the Madras medical service, 1835; served with the 8th light cavalry, Madras, 1837-1839, and with the army of His Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad, 1839-1862; was superintendent of the Bolarum Medical School, 1842-44; served with the Ellicpoor field force, against the insurgent Rohillas in 1841, and again in Nov., 1851, with the cavalry field force, under Brigadier W. Mayne; staff-surgeon with the Central India field force, 1857-58, and with the Berar field force, Nov., 1858, to March, 1859, and was present at numerous engagements; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Mysore Division, March, 1863; inspector-general, Aug., 1866; inspector-general and head of the medical department, March, 1867; retired, Aug., 1871; appointed honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1867; author of a treatise on the medical topography of Ellicpoor, and papers on the Indian Materia Medica, and has translated into Hindustani, 'Gregory's Practice of Physic,' and 'Thomson's Conspectus of the British Pharmacopoea.'

MACKIE, Andrew Wallace, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Universities of Edinburgh and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874, and again, in Nellore, March, 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1887.

MACKINTOSH, James Simon, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, Edinburgh University, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary, and officiating under secretary to government; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb.-April, 1874; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Aug.-Nov., 1875; junior secretary to government, July, 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1877; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

MACLEAN, Alexander Thomas, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1856; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy
collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Pooree, Oct., 1866; from July, 1869, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge and district judge in various districts of Bengal, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs in 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1880; retired, 1885.

MACLEANE, CHARLES DONALD, Mus. Doc., M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; acting inspector of schools, Oct., 1866; assistant collector, Dec., 1867; acting cantonment magistrate, Sept., 1868; acted for various periods as under secretary to Government of Madras, and sub-secretary to the Board of revenue; on special duty in preparing annual administration report, Nov., 1876, and again, Sept., 1878; on special duty revising standing orders of the board of revenue, Oct., 1877, and again in June, 1886; under secretary to government in chief secretary's department, July, 1880; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1881; Canarese translator to government, April, 1881; member of board of examiners, Jan., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1883; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of 'Manual of Administration,' Nov., 1883, and again, Aug., 1884 and 1886; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Feb., 1884; on special duty as president of the committee on Muhamadan Educational Endowment, Aug., 1885; Tamil translator to government, Sept., 1885; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Feb., 1886; on special duty in the general record department, Feb., 1886, and also to collect information for the finance committee, June, 1886.

MACLEOD, BANNATYNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, Edinburgh University, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector; also forest settlement officer, May, 1886.

MACLEOD, DONALD GRANT, M.A., LL.M. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma.—Trinity College, Cambridge, and Inner Temple; judge of the court of small causes, Rangoon, Sept., 1869; judge of Moulmein, March, 1876.

MACLEOD, Roderick Henry, Bengal C.S. (North-West Provinces).—Educated at University College, London, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate.

MACMILLAN, ALEXANDER, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Aldenham grammar school, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating assistant secretary to government, Aug., 1874; under secretary to government, March, 1876; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883; from April, 1884, served as officiating district and sessions judge and small cause court judge.

MACNABB, Sir Donald C., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Peshawur, 1865; commissioner, Hisar division, 1872, and subsequently in the Lahore, Rawal Pindi, and Peshawur divisions; retired, 1881; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

MACNABB, James William, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1852, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Aug., 1861; commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Nov., 1875, and afterwards in the Hissar and Delhi divisions; retired, March, 1886.

MACNAGHTEN, Chester, M.A. (Cantab.), Educational Department, Bombay.—From July, 1866, to Dec., 1870, held the appointment of tutor to the minor Mahárájah of Durbhunga under the court of wards, Bengal; joined the Bombay educational service, 19th Dec., 1870, and served from that date as principal of the Rajkumar College, Kathiawár.

MACONACHIE, GEORGE ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; was employed under the military department till Jan., 1872, including service in the Abyssinian campaign (medal), and subsequently as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and comparative anatomy at the Grant Medical College, Bombay; also presidency surgeon from June, 1880.

MACONACHIE, James Robert, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1880; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, July, 1884; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department, Sept.-Oct., 1885; officiating deputy commissioner, Gurgaon; author of report on the settlement of the Delhi District.

MACONOCHIE, Alexander Francis, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; acting joint administrator, Rajpipla, Oct., 1886.

MACPHERSON, ARTHUR G., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at University and King's College, Aberdeen, and University of Edinburgh; called to the bar, 1852; 1st judge of Calcutta small cause court, 1859; secretary to the government of Bengal, legislative department, 1862; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India in the home department (legislative), 1863; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1865; acted as chief justice, Calcutta, in 1875; retired, 1877;
legal adviser to the secretary of state, Nov., 1879; secretary in the judicial and public department, India Office, Feb., 1882; author of 'Law of Mortgage in Bengal,' and joint author, with Mr. W. Morgan, of 'The Indian Penal Code (Act xlv. of 1860).'

MACPHERSON, ANDREW KENNEDY, Major B.S.C.—First commission, 19th Dec., 1865; arrived in India, 9th March, 1866; from April, 1871, served as cantonment magistrate at various stations in the Punjab, and was promoted to the 1st class, Dec., 1879; officiating in the judge advocate-general's department since May, 1886.

MACPHERSON, CHARLES GORDON WELAND, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and superintendent of police; supernumerary under secretary to government of Bombay in the public works department for relief purposes, Nov., 1876; on famine relief duty in Madras, as secretary to personal assistant to the governor, Sept., 1877, to Jan., 1879; from April, 1879, acted as under secretary to government of Bombay, political and judicial departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; acting private secretary to governor of Bombay, Dec., 1880, to March, 1881; acted as secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, in 1884 and 1885; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, April-July, 1885, and again in 1886; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Nov., 1885; on special duty in the political department of the secretariat, Dec., 1885.

MACPHERSON, DUNCAN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882.

MACPHERSON, GEORGE MORISON, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, small cause court judge, and judge and sessions judge in various districts; 1st grade judge, Jan., 1881; judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sadar court, Feb., 1885.

MACPHERSON, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; on special duty under board of revenue, July, 1875; joint magistrate, and grade, May, 1884; superintendent of Dehra Dun, Aug., 1886.

MACPHERSON, J. M. (Barrister-at-Law), Legislative Department, Government of India.—Educated at Westminster School; advocate of the high court, Calcutta; served from Dec., 1877, as deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department; joint editor with Mr. H. Hyde of 7th edition of 'Macpherson's Law of Mortgage in Bengal.'

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating civil and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 10th Jan., 1885.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Dec., 1877; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating inspector of schools; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1884; under secretary to government of Bengal, Nov., 1885.

MACRAE, JOHN KENNETH, Burma Commission.—Joined the Burma commission as officiating assistant commissioner, 20th July, 1860; registrar to the court of the recorder, and judge of the court of small causes, Moulmein, May, 1864; deputy commissioner, July, 1869; town magistrate, Akyab, Nov., 1874; boundary officer, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883; president, Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1885; acted as commissioner of Arakan, Nov.-Dec., 1885.

MADDEN, JOHN MELLISH, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay Infantry.—Ensign, Bombay army, Sept., 1859; employed on military duty, including service in Abyssinia in 1868, up to 1876; served subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate, Poona; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmadabad, January, 1880.

MAGUIRE, HUGH FITZJOHN TYRREL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; member, central examination committee, April, 1886.

MAHADEV GOVIND RAJADE, RAO BAHURDUR, C.I.E., M.A., LL.B. (Bombay), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 28th May, 1866, in the educational department, and was appointed assistant professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, Oct., 1868; also served in the judicial department as assistant reporter to the high court, Bombay, acting magistrate of police, acting small cause court judge, and subordinate judge (June, 1872) acting presidency magistrate, Bombay, Jan.-March, 1881; appointed under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act to inspect and supervise the lower courts in districts of Poona and Satara, Aug., 1881; judge of the court of small causes, Poona, Feb., 1884, and was in charge of duties of law lecturer, Deccan College, Jan.-April, 1885; member of a committee on public expenditure; C.I.E., Feb., 1887.
MAHESH CHUNDER NYARATNA, Pundit, C.I.E., Bengal Education Department.—Served in the education department from 10th January, 1864, as assistant professor, and professor in the Sanskrit College, and was appointed principal of the college, June, 1885; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1884.

MAINE, Sir Henry James Sumner, K.C.S.I., LL.D., D.C.L., F.R.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Cambridge; Craven scholar; graduated B.A. in 1844 (senior classic and senior chancellor's classical medallist); tutor of Trinity Hall; Regius professor of civil law, 1847-1854; called to the bar in 1850; reader on jurisprudence, Middle Temple, 1854; law member of the supreme council, government of India, 1862-1869; Corpus professor of jurisprudence, Oxford, 1870-1878; member of council of secretary of state for India, Nov., 1871; elected to the mastership of Trinity Hall, Cambridge, Dec., 1877; a foreign associate of the Institute of France; author of 'Ancient Law: its Connection with the Early History of Society, and its Relation to Modern Ideas,' 1861; 'Village Communities in the East and West,' 1871; 'The Early History of Institutions,' 1875; 'Early Law and Custom,' 1882, and 'Popular Government,' 1885.

Maitland, William J., C.I.E., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and abroad; temporary clerk, 3rd Nov., 1866; junior clerk, July, 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1878; private secretary to the secretary of state (Viscount Cross), August, 1886; C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

Malet, Arthur, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Addiscombe, and finally at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1824; arrived at Bombay, May, 1826; served first as assistant collector and magistrate, Khandeish, and then as assistant to the resident of Baroda; political agent and resident, Kutch, 1842; political agent, Kathiawar, 1843; secretary to government of Bombay, political and secret departments, 1846; chief secretary to government, 1847; legislative council of India, 1854; Bombay council, April, 1855; also chief judge of the court of Sudder Dewanee and Sudder Foujdarre Adawlut, 1857; retired, 1860.

Mallet, Frederick Richard, F.G.S., F.C.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 12th Feb., 1859; was employed in various districts of Bengal, Central India, the Central Provinces, Assam, Sikkim, and Bhutan; keeper of the mineral collections in the museum, Oct., 1875; 1st grade officer, Jan., 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883; designation changed to superintendent of survey; author of contributions to the survey publications.

Mallet, Right Hon. Sir Louis, C.B.—Clerk in the audit office, 1839; transferred to board of trade, 1847; private secretary to president of the board of trade, 1848 to 1852, and again 1855 to 1857; accompanied Mr. Cobden to Paris in April, 1860, as assistant commissioner for the purpose of making a tariff; English member of mixed commission at Vienna for the purpose of examining into an Austrian tariff, 1865; C.B., 1866; knighted, Dec., 1868; retired from the board of trade, and was nominated to the council of the secretary of state for India, 1872; permanent under secretary of state for India, Feb., 1874-1883; privy councillor; author of a treatise on 'Reciprocity,' printed for the Cobden Club in 1879.

Mallet, Robert Trefusis, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1868; executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway, Nov., 1868; superintendent of works, Ravvee section, April, 1873; temporary superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, Jan., 1877; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley railway, April, 1879; director of stores, railway branch, Oct., 1880; engineer-in-chief, Rewari Ferozepur railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Ferozepur bridge, in 1885; transferred to North-Western railway as chief engineer, Jan., 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885.

Mallock, Henry Archibald, Colonel, B.S.C., Indian Telegraph Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1853; joined the telegraph department, Jan., 1861; superintendent, 1st grade, and storekeeper, Dec., 1866; director of construction, April, 1868; deputy director-general, June, 1883; officiating director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887.

Maltby, Edward, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Haileybury; appointed to the Madras civil service in 1828; served in the revenue and judicial departments; appointed civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, 1848; collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, 1849, and in the south division of Arcot, 1851; member of board of revenue, 1854; was temporarily chief secretary to government; provisional member of council of governor of Madras, June, 1858; member of council, 16th Dec., 1859; also president of the board of revenue; acted as governor of the presidency for a few months in 1864; retired in 1864.

Maltby, Edward Pennycuick, Major, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Jan., 1861; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; served in civil employ in the Mysore commission from Jan., 1864; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1877; small cause court judge, and town and cantonment magistrate, Bangalore, March, 1879; district magistrate and collector, and president, municipal commission, in the civil and military station of Bangalore from March, 1881.

Mance, Sir Henry Christopher, C.I.E., late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, July, 1863; superintendent, Kurrachee, Persian Gulf section, Sept., 1866; engineer and electrician, Sept., 1879; C.I.E., Jan., 1883; retired, 1886.

Mancherji Pestanji Khareghat, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Xavier's College, Calcutta, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector, March, 1885.

Mander, Alfred Thomas, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1854; 2nd lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857; served in the Bombay public works department, from March, 1858, as assistant and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Nov., 1886.

Manderson, Thomas Claridge, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Go-
vernment of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, July, 1860, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Punjab, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1872; served in the Rawal Pindi, Meerut, and Lahore commands, and was promoted to superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; officiating inspector-general, military works, April-Nov., 1886.

MANISTY, GEORGE ELDON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ruabon Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1873; served in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Dec., 1884.

MANN, GUSTAV, Forest Department, Assam.—Assistant in government cinchona plantations, Darjeeling, Nov., 1863; assistant conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1864; from Nov., 1868, served in the Assam forest department, and was promoted to conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882.

MANSFIELD, SAMUEL, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts, and was appointed political agent, Rewa Kantha, 1847; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1852; revenue commissioner, northern division, 1859; commissioner, Sind, 1862; member of council, Bombay, 14th May, 1867; retired in 1872.

MANSON, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; also served as second inspector of registration offices, Aug., 1876; officiating commissioner, Chittagong division, Nov., 1885.

MARINDIN, CHARLES RANDAL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Tirhoot, Feb., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1885.

MARKBY, W., late Judge of the High Court, Calcutta.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; doctor of civil law, fellow of All Souls College, fellow of Balliol College; recorder of Buckingham, 1864-66; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1866 to 1878; vice-chancellor of the university of Calcutta, 1877-78; justice of the peace for county of Oxford; author of 'Elements of Law' (Clarendon Press, Oxford).

MARKHAM, ALEXANDER MACAULAY, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Down and Connor Diocesan School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating postmaster-general, officiating cantonment magistrate, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Allahabad, Nov., 1880; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwâris and Kanûngos, Nov., 1880; member of grass supply committee under military department of government of India, Oct., 1881; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli division, March to July, 1882.

MARKHAM, CLEMENTS ROBERT, C.B., F.R.S.—Educated at Westminster School; appointed a naval cadet, 28th July, 1844; midshipman, July, 1846, and passed for lieutenant, R.N., Dec., 1851; served in the Arctic expedition in search of Sir John Franklin, 1850-51; explored Peru and the forests of the Eastern Andes, 1852-54; from July, 1854, served as clerk under the India board of control, and on the transfer of the government of India to the crown, in 1858, was appointed a clerk in the correspondence department of the India office; private secretary to the parliamentary under-secretary of state (Mr. T. G. Baring), 1862 to 1864; assistant secretary in the public works department, 1867-71, and in the judicial, public, and revenue department, from 1871 to 1877, when he retired from the service; appointed C.B. (civil), May, 1871; was employed in introducing cinchona cultivation into India, 1859-66, and visited India and Ceylon; geographer to the Abyssinian expedition, 1866-67, and was present at the storming of Magdala; secretary to the Hakluyt Society, 1858 to 1886; secretary to the Royal Geographical Society, 1863 to 1877; in 1874 was created by the King of Portugal a commendador of the order of Christ; and by the Emperor of Brazil a chevalier of the order of the Rose; author of 'Franklin's Footsteps,' 1853; 'Cuzco and Lima,' 1855; 'Travels in Peru and India,' 1862; 'Quichua Grammar and Dictionary,' 1863; 'Threshold of the Unknown Region,' 1874; 'History of the Abyssinian Expedition,' 1869; 'Life of Lord Fairfax,' 'Life of Admiral Fairfax,' 'A Naval Career in the Olden Time,' 'History of Persia,' 1873; 'History of the War between Peru and Chili,' 'Peru,' 1880; 'The Sea Fathers,' 'Irrigation in Eastern Spain,' 1867; 'Memoir of the Indian Surveys,' 1871; 'Life of the Countess of Chinchon,' 'Peruvian Bark,' and 'Missions to Thibet,' 1877; has also translated and edited various works, including 'Embassy of Clavijo to the Court of Timour,' 'Royal Commentaries of Garcilasgoa de la Vega,' 'Chronicle of Cieza de Leon,' 'Memoir of Alonzo Henriquez de Guzman,' 'Report of Pascual de Andagoza,' editor of 'Early Voyages of the East India Company,' and Voyages of Baffin; wrote the 'Reports on the Moral and Material Progress of India,' for 1871-72 and 1872-73, and edited the 'Geographical Magazine,' 1872 to 1878.

MARRIOTT, CHARLES RICHARDSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

MARRYAT, ERNEST LINDSAY, Major, R.E., late Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1859; probationary assistant engineer, Mhow, Bombay, Nov., 1862; assistant engineer, Central Provinces, Oct., 1864;
executive engineer, Bombay public works department, Jan., 1866; assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, June, 1869; consulting engineer for reclamation, Bombay, April, 1870; acted for various periods as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1874; acting manager, Dhond and Manmad state railway, Dec., 1878; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, March, 1879; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; manager, Punjab northern state railway, in 1st class of the state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1880; retired from the public works department, 1887.

MARSDEN, F. J.—Clerk of the crown, 14th May, 1873; officiating magistrate, Calcutta police, and coroner, Oct., 1874; presidency magistrate and coroner, Dec., 1877; chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1878; also judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and of the court of survey, port of Calcutta.

MARSHALL, CHARLES HENRY TILSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from July, 1865, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1878; superintendent, Chamba state, Oct., 1879; divisional judge 3rd grade, Sept., 1886; from Dec., 1886, served under foreign department, government of India; author of a 'Monograph of the Capitonidæ, or Sconsorial Barbets,' 'The Game Birds of India' (with A. O. Hume), 'The Ornithology of the Hills about Murree,' and 'The Ornithology of Chamba.'

MARSHALL, GEORGE FREDERICK LEYCESTER, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, 28th March, 1864, and served in the irrigation department, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Sept., 1868; special assistant, irrigation branch, N.W. Provinces secretariat, 1876; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil works branch, Oct., 1876, to May, 1877, and again in 1878; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, railway branch, Nov., 1881, to Feb., 1882; under secretary, government of India, civil works branch, June, 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of the public works department, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Dec., 1884; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent, governor-general, Rajputana, April, 1887.

MARSHALL, HERBERT, Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough College; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 19th March, 1869; senior clerk, Jan., 1884.

MARTELLI, NORTON CHARLES, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 15th foot, Oct., 1864; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1870; served in civil employ from 1872 as assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, and political assistant in Rajputana; magistrate of Aboo, and assistant in the thuggee and dacoity department, 1875; guardian and tutor to Maharaj of Alwar, Aug., 1876; served in Beloochistan, 1880-81, as political officer, Jacobabad, Quetta, and the Bolan; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, and superintendent of operations for control of Moghias, Oct., 1881; officiating political agent, Baghelcund, 1882, and in 1886; political agent, Bhopawur, 1885.

MARTIN, C. A., LL.D., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 22nd Nov., 1864; served as professor at the Dacca College, and at the Krishnagur College; inspector of schools, Aug., 1877; 2nd class, educational service, Aug., 1877.

MARTIN, CHARLES WILLIAM WALL, B.A., LL.D., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Nov., 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1883, in Cuddapah, and afterwards in Salem.

MARTIN, EDWARD JAMES, M.I.C.E., and F.R.I.B.A., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, May, 1859; arrived in India, 6th Sept., 1859; served in the Punjab in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer and executive engineer till 1869-70, when he was transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and posted to the Rajputana state railway; officiated as engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, April, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Aug., 1877; also ex-officio manager of the line, April, 1878; transferred to Bengal, railway branch, and appointed engineer-in-chief of the Central Bengal system of state railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal provincial branch, Jan., 1880; on special duty under the chief engineer, Bengal, as government architect, April, 1881; superintending engineer, and 2nd class, Feb., 1882; deputed to Indore on special duty, Jan., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885.

MARTIN, GERALD WARD, Captain, Bo. S.C., Assay Master, Bombay Mint.—Ensign, 88th Foot, 22nd June, 1867; joined Roorkee College, Nov., 1869, and obtained certificate as civil engineer; admitted to the staff corps, March, 1871; from March, 1871, to July, 1878, served as assistant superintendent of survey in Assam, in the Deccan topographical survey, and in the Soane irrigation survey; transferred to the financial department for employment in the assay department, July, 1878, and acted as deputy assay master in the Calcutta and Bombay mints; appointed assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1884; also served with the Afghan expeditionary force as assistant superintendent of survey, 1879-80 (medal and clasp for Cabul), and with the Waziri expeditionary field force.

MARTIN, WILLIAM THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law) Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Regent's Park College, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865; from July, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; judge, 3rd grade, Aligarh, April, 1885.
MARTINDALE, ARTHUR HENRY TEMPLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the foreign department of the government of India from Oct., 1877, to Oct., 1879, and from June, 1881, to May, 1882, as attaché, officiating political agent, 3rd class, and assistant secretary to government, and was placed on special duty Dec., 1881; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, May-Aug., 1882; from Aug., 1882, served again under the foreign department of the government of India as political agent at Kotah, and assistant secretary to government; junior under secretary, Oct., 1884; officiating assistant to resident in Mysore and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg, Feb., 1885; officiating resident and chief commissioner, May-June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, April, 1886; first assistant and secretary for Berar to the resident, Hyderabad, Nov., 1886.

MASSY, CHARLES FRANCIS, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th June, 1868; from Aug., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty to settle boundary disputes in Feb. and Oct., 1874; on a deputation to Kashmir, Aug.-Dec., 1876; political officer with the Punjab native chief contingent, Nov., 1878; on special duty in connection with Viceregal Durbar, at Lahore, Nov., 1880; on special duty to inspect the Punjab Rajputana border, Nov., 1883; officiating divisional judge, Jullundur, April, 1885; superintendent, Kapurthala state, Aug., 1886.

MASSY, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of vaccination; deputy sanitary commissioner (sub pro tem.), Nov., 1880; civil surgeon, 1st class, Rawa Pindi, Oct., 1881.

MASTER, CHARLES GILBERT, C.S.I., (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate from Sept., 1855; deputy secretary to government in revenue department, Dec., 1859; commissioner of income tax, 1860-1865; secretary to the board of examiners, April, 1861, to Jan., 1866; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue for various periods between 1862 and 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Calicut, May, 1869; on special duty in Godavari and Kistna on irrigation works, May to Nov., 1869; from Nov., 1869, to May, 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Nellore, and other districts; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1877; chief secretary to government, June, 1882; additional member of the legislative council, June, 1882; ordinary member of council, Madras, Jan., 1884; president of the committee in connection with the Draft Tenancy Bill, July, 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

MATHEW, GEORGE FELTON, C.I.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1876, as assistant to the manager, Rajputana state railway; officiating traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, June, 1879; and class, traffic department, Jan., 1880; Kandahar Railway, March, 1880; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; officiating manager, Nizam's railway, March, 1882; Rajputana-Malwa railway, Dec., 1884.

MATHEWS, HENRY MONTAGU, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed 4th grade executive engineer, 8th Oct., 1868; arrived in India, Dec., 1868; served in British Burma, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, Oct., 1877; employed in examining, repairing, and reporting on lighthouses, British Burma, Jan.-March, 1878; transferred to railway branch as engineer-in-chief and manager of the Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, public works department, Oct., 1880, and again in 1886; 1st class, 1st grade, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; also chairman, Rangoon port trust; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, 1887.

MATHIAS, HENRY VINCENT, Colonel, B.S.C., Ensign Bengal infantry, Dec., 1849; in command, Nagode divisional military police, Oct., 1862; from 1st July, 1865, to 1886, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent of police, 1st class, April, 1875.

MATTHEW, Ven., HENRY JAMES, M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 16th Feb., 1867, and served in N.W. Provinces and Bengal as chaplain of Allahabad and Fort William, and as domestic chaplain to the Lord Bishop; from Jan., 1877, served in Punjab as senior chaplain, and was appointed archdeacon, Aug., 1878, and bishop's commissary, March, 1883.

MATHEWS, HAROLD FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1871; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam; officiating superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Sept., 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1885; has also served as officiating deputy commissioner, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge.

MAUDE, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov., 1884; under secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1885.

MAUDE, WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1883.

MAUNSELL, JOHN RICHARDSON, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, 1851; 2nd lieutenant, June, 1853; arrived in India, 6th July, 1855; served in the Bombay public works department from March, 1856, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, June, 1858; on special duty investigating irregularities in local fund system, Nov., 1871; superintending engineer (temporary),
May, 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class, May, 1884.

MAXWELL, Henry St. Patrick, Captain, Bengal S.C.—Arrived in India, 26th March, 1869; joined as ensign, 60th Foot, April, 1869; from May, 1873, served in civil employ in the Assam commission; served in the Dafa expedition, 1874-75; acted as political officer, Naga Hills, Feb. to July, 1878; political officer with the Naga Hills expedition, Oct., 1879, to April, 1880 (medal); inspector of immigrants, Jan., 1881; from May, 1881, acted as deputy commissioner in the Garo Hills; political officer with the Aka field force, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1886.

MAYHEW, Alfred Hercules, Major, Bombay S.C.—First commission as ensign, Madras army, June, 1861; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1862; from July, 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Thar and Párkar, head assistant collector, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in the military department, March, 1882; in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Jacobabad, May-Aug., 1883, and March-May, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate and district registrar, Shikarpur, and political agent, Khairpur State, Dec., 1885.

MAYO, John H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; East India House writer, old establishment, 28th Feb., 1855; junior clerk, administrator general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; military department, 1875; assistant secretary in the military department, Dec., 1882.

McANDREW, John, Police Department, Punjab.—From 8th Nov., 1860, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, July, 1880; deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, March, 1885.

McCABE, Robert Blair, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Oct., 1884.

McCALLUM, Edwin, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, May, 1884.

McCarthy, Samuel Trant, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Patrick's College, Carlow; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Oct., 1877; acted as collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Sept., 1879, to March, 1881; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1882, in the district of Vizagapatam, and afterwards in Kistna and Madura.

McCLEVERTY, William Anson, General.—Entered the army from the Royal Military College, Sandhurst, and obtained a commission in the 48th regiment, March, 1824; brigade major to the western auxiliary column, Coorg field force, March-April, 1834; temporarily attached to the engineer department at Gibraltar, 1840-41; deputy quartermaster-general in the Australian Colonies, July, 1846, to April, 1857; commanded the troops in New Zealand during the native disturbances in 1847 (medal); assistant adjutant-general in Scotland, Jan., 1859, to Feb., 1860; in command of the presidency division of the Madras army, April, 1860, to April, 1865; in command of the southeastern district of England at Shorncliffe and Dover, 1866-67; commander-in-chief of the Madras army, with local rank of lieutenant-general, and member of the governor's council, July, 1867, to April, 1871.

McCONAGHEY, Matthew Allen, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1879; commissioner, Rae Bareli, Nov., 1883, and subsequently in the Sitapur and Lucknow divisions.

McCONNELL, James Frederick Parry, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1870; house-surgeon to the Calcutta Medical College Hospital, Oct., 1871; professor of pathology in the medical college, and resident physician to the College Hospital, March, 1872; also officiated as professor of the comparative anatomy section of the college museum, in July, 1873; officiating civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Sept.-Nov., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; superintendent of vaccination, Feb., 1883; officiating professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, and medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1883, and again, July, 1885; civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, medical officer, Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, 1885.

McCORKELL, Gilmour, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Foyle College, Londonderry, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting educational inspector, acting district superintendent of police, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting district judge; 1st grade, assistant judge, Feb., 1886.

McDONELL, William Fraser, V.C., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1849; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, Champaran, April, 1864); on special duty, May, 1858; settlement officer, Shahabad, July, 1859; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1863; civil and sessions judge, 1st grade, Nuddra, March, 1868; commissioner, Bhagulpore division, April, 1874; judge, high court, Calcutta, Aug., 1878; retired, April, 1886.

McDOUGALL, H. R. L., Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.M. (Ed.), late Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1858; civil surgeon, Rajkot, Oct., 1875; acted as superintendent of vaccination, Oct.-Nov.,
1882; brigade-surgeon, May, 1883; superintendent of Matheran, March, 1884; retired, May, 1886.

McKeon, George, Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay ordnance department, Sept., 1831, to May, 1839; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, July, 1860; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877.

McLaughlin, Frederick Hubert, LL.M., B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury grammar school, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1877; from April, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1884.

McLean, John James, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the International College, Ealing, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate, Jhansi; also acted as deputy commissioner, Lalitpur.

McLeod, Kenneth, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, March, 1865; civil surgeon, Jessore, 20th Feb., 1866; on special duty as member, cattle plague commission, Dec., 1869; secretary to inspector-general of hospitals, Jan., 1871; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio 2nd surgeon, College Hospital, April, 1874; also officiating medical inspector of emigrants, Calcutta, and officiating marine surgeon, Jan., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex-officio 1st surgeon at the hospital, Jan., 1880; health officer for town of Calcutta, Feb., 1880; author of several publications on cattle diseases, including the report of the cattle plague commission, 1871, and on medico-legal subjects; also of 'History of the Medical Schools of the Bengal Presidency,' 'The Sanitary Past, Present, and Future of Calcutta,' 'Operative Surgery in the Calcutta Medical College.'

McMinn, Charles William, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1864, to Feb., 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty for completion of Oudh gazetteer, July, 1872, also at Simla, July, 1873; from March, 1879, served in the Central Provinces and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1884.

McNally, Christopher John, Surgeon-Major, M.D., and C.M., L.R.C.S., S.L.C.C., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department till July, 1879, also holding charge of the jail at Secunderabad in 1873 and 1878, and acting as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Mangalore, March-Sept., 1878; from 1879, served as assistant physician at the General Hospital, Madras, and professor of materia medica, pharmacy, and hygiene in the Medical College, and was also in charge of the principal medical storekeeper's office, May, 1880, and acted as professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology, July-August, 1880; on special duty in Egypt in connection with outbreak of cholera, July-Oct., 1883; surgeon-major, March, 1884; from April to July, 1884, acted as fort surgeon, medical inspector of seamen, Madras, and professor of anatomy in the Medical College, also acting as surgeon, General Hospital, and professor of clinical surgery, April, 1884; chemical examiner and professor of chemistry, Medical College, July, 1884; member of committee in connection with the scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

McNeile, Charles, Lieutenant-Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1858; from Dec., 1861, served in the Punjab police department as assistant superintendent and officiating district superintendent; from May, 1865, served in the commission as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and judicial assistant; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886.

McNeile, John Magee, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined at Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; 1st commission, Bengal Engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, 10th April, 1858; from May, 1858, served in the public works department as assistant engineer, and executive engineer in Bengal; also as assistant superintendent, Alguada Reef Lighthouse works, 1860-65; officiating superintendent of works, Ajmere and Mairwara, 1874-1876; re-transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1876; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1879; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, public works department, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1882; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, Jan., 1884; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1885, to Oct., 1886.

McQueen, J. W., Colonel, C.B., B.S.C.—1st commission, Bengal Infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, 15th May, 1854; employed in military department up to 31st Dec., 1882; military secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; brigadier-general, commanding Hyderabad contingent, Sept., 1885; commanding Punjab frontier force, Oct., 1886; aide-de-camp to the Queen.

McRea, John Graham, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C.—Arrived in India, 10th July, 1858, and served in the Bombay Presidency on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department as assistant superintendent; on military duty, Nov., 1867, to July, 1868 (field service in Abyssinia), and again Dec., 1870, to Nov., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Bombay forest department as deputy conservator; conservator of forests in Sind, Aug., 1878.

McWatters, George, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry Col...
legiate School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting under secretary to government of Madras, public department, May-Sept., 1872; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1879; district and sessions judge, Salem, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Salem, Jan., 1884.

McWILLIAM, ORMISTON GALLOWAY REID, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 22nd Nov., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Tipperah, Jan., 1865; from March, 1868, to Dec., 1883, served in district of Cachar, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 4th grade, and political agent, Naga Hills, April, 1871; retired, Sept., 1885.

MEAD, CHARLES CLEMENT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

MEAD, HENRY ROBERT, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857, and served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer (4th grade, Jan., 1866), and was placed on special duty on the Neringipeth Anicut project, March, 1871; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; on special duty in Travancore, Feb., 1882; 1st class superintending engineer, April, 1886.

MEADE, SIR RICHARD JOHN, Lieutenant-General, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Bengal Staff Corps.—Educated at Royal Naval School; appointed a cadet, Bengal Infantry, 1st March, 1838; arrived in India, July, 1838; served with the 65th and 54th regiments, N.I., and also temporarily in the commissariat department; interpreter and quartermaster, 65th regiment, N.I., Jan., 1844; station staff at Nowgong, Oct., 1845; 2nd in command, 6th Infantry, Gwalior Contingent, Dec., 1845; brigade major, Gwalior Contingent, postmaster, Gwalior, and cantonment magistrate, Morar, Nov., 1851; also paymaster and commissariat officer, May, 1853; served with 65th Regiment, N.I., in Burma, 1853-1855, and was appointed assistant adjutant-general, Pegu division, Oct., 1854; on the mutiny of the Gwalior contingent, escaped to Agra, where he raised a body of cavalry, subsequently known as "Meade's Horse;" in June, 1858, escorted Maharaja Sindhia back to Gwalior, and was present at the battle at that place, Sindhia's palace being surrendered to him personally; was afterwards employed as special commissioner in Gwalior to deal with the Gwalior State troops; in 1859 joined brigadier-general Sir R. Napier's force, and received the surrender of Raja Man Sing, and captured the rebel leader, Tantia Topee; in July, 1859, surprised and routed a large body of rebels at Gurroya in the Jhansi district; brevet-major, mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; political agent, Gwalior, April, 1860; governor-general's agent in Central India, and opium agent, Malwa, Nov., 1861; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, Feb., 1870; president of special commission to inquire into charges against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Oct., 1873; member of the commission to investigate the charge preferred against the Gaekwar of attempting to poison the resident Colonel R. Phayre, C.B., Feb., 1875; appointed, to the charge of the Baroda state as agent and special commissioner, April, 1875, and superintended the measures necessary for the reorganisation of the administration, and the selection of a successor to the deposed Gaekwar; resident at Hyderabad, Dec., 1875, to March, 1881; C.S.I., June, 1866; K.C.S.I., May, 1874; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; lieutenant-general in the army, Sept., 1884.

MEADOWS, CHARLES JOHN WALFORD, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; from 26th April, 1872, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in Bengal; surgeon-major, Oct., 1881; civil surgeon, Backergunge, with charge of jail, Feb., 1883.

MEDLICOTT, HENRY BENEDICT, M.A., F.R.S., F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Engaged for service in India from the geological survey of Great Britain; joined appointment in India, March, 1854; professor of geology, Roorkee College, Aug., 1854, to Oct., 1862, when he rejoined the geological survey as deputy superintendent for Bengal; received the Indian mutiny medal for special services in Rohilkund; was variously employed in Bengal, Assam, Central India, Rajputana, Central Provinces, &c.; superintendent of the geological survey (subsequently designated director of the geological survey), April, 1876; fellow of Calcutta University, and member of the faculty of arts and engineering, April, 1876; author of numerous contributions to the survey publications, and of a manual of the geology of India (in part).

MEIKLEJOHN, DAVID OGILVY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, Hoogly, Dec., 1870; from Oct., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Dec., 1882; judge, small cause court, Jubbulpore, April, 1885.

MELITUS, PAUL GREGORY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Marylebone, and All Saints' Grammar School, Marlborough, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1886.

MELLOR, CHARLES WARREN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; 1st grade, Feb., 1882.

MELVILL, SIR PETER MELVILL, Major-General, K.C.B.—Educated at Merchant Taylors'
School; ensign, Bombay army, 1819; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1819; was employed with the revenue survey of Guzerat, 1822 to 1827; fort adjutant of garrison of Bombay, and A.D.C. to the governor, 1828; on special duty in Calcutta as assistant to the Bombay military member of the financial commission, 1829; 1st assistant to resident in Cutch and Sind, 1836; political agent in Cutch, 1838; secretary to government of Bombay in the military and marine departments, Dec., 1840, to April, 1859; appointed K.C.B., 1860; retired with honorary rank of major-general, Dec., 1861; was a member of Lord Hotham's committee on the amalgamation of the Indian with the British army in 1860, and of the royal commission appointed to report on the memorials of the Indian officers in 1863.
