MELVILL, PHILIP SANDYS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1846; arrived in India, 4th Oct., 1846; attached to the Punjab, and served as assistant to the resident at Lahore, and assistant commissioner; settlement officer in the Hoshiarpur and Amballa districts, 1850-54; deputy commissioner, Amballa, Jan., 1854; commissioner, Hissar division, 1860 to 1862, and subsequently of the Delhi and Rawul Pindi divisions; officiated as financial commissioner of the Punjab in 1869, and again in 1873, and as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces, in 1870-71; commissioner, Jullundur division, 1872 to 1875, and officiated as judge of the chief court of the Punjab in 1873 and 1874; member of commission for investigating the charges brought against the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; agent to the governor-general and resident, 1st class, at Baroda, Oct., 1875; retired, Jan., 1882.

MENZIES, HUGH CHRISTIAN, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—Ensign, Dec., 1849; Arrived in India, 7th June, 1850, and served under the military department in Madras, and took part in the operations against the insurgents in the Parla Kindedi District, 1857; served in Burmah from Aug., 1859, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Oct., 1860, served as superintendent of police in Madras, and was engaged in the organisation of the police in the South Malabar districts, and in the Hyderabad assigned districts from Oct., 1862; from Dec., 1864, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, and small cause court judge at Amraoti; inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1871; deputy commissioner, April, 1878.

MENZIES, OSWALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 26th Aug., 1854; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1854; from March, 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, July, 1880; inspector-general of police in the Punjab, and under secretary to government, March, 1885.

MEREDITH, ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; officiating under secretary revenue department, Dec., 1886; officiating deputy commissioner, Jullundur, April, 1887.

MERES, WILLIAM FITZPATRICK, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 29th Nov., 1864; from Sept., 1865, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and in Assam (March-Dec., 1881), and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1883; acting judicial commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1885; president of the educational syndicate, Burma, Feb., 1885.

MERK, WILLIAM RUDOLPH HENRY, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kornthal, Wurttemberg, the Grammar School, Old Aberdeen, and the University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Jhelum, March, 1877, and in the Khyber Pass, 1879, and again as assistant political agent, Sept., 1879; assistant resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1882; on special duty with the Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884; C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

MERRIMAN, CHARLES JAMES, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, June, 1850; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1852; assistant engineer, Sept., 1853; field engineer, Persia, Nov., 1856; executive engineer, Hyderabad, Sept., 1857, and subsequently at Kurrachee and at Aden, 1866; superintending engineer in Sind, May, 1868; in N.W. Provinces to examine irrigation works, Sept.-Nov., 1869; acting chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, 1871, and again in 1873 and 1877-79; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bombay, general, and buildings and roads branches, March, 1880; retired from the public works department in 1885.

MERRIMAN, JOHN HENRY, Salt Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from June, 1868, to Oct., 1880; on special duty in Ganjam for settling boundary disputes, March, 1877; from Nov., 1880, served in the Salt Department as assistant commissioner, and was on special duty in the office of the commissioner of salt and akbari revenue, Jan.-April, 1885; deputy-commissioner, salt revenue, Dec., 1885.

MESTON, JAMES SCORGIE, Bengal C.S. (North West Provinces).—Educated at Grammar School, and University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23 Nov., 1885; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

METCALFE, CHARLES THEOPHILUS, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1857; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; deputy commissioner and civil officer, Bhutan field force, Oct., 1864; senior superintendent of survey, May, 1869; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, June, 1871; additional commissioner, Patna division, March,
MEYER, WILLIAM STEVENSON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Missionary School, University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Oct., 1886.

MICHAEL, JAMES, Major-General, C.S.I., M.S.C.—Educated at the Temple School, Brighton; also studied on the Continent, and at the Military Academy, Edinburgh; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1844; in 1848 was appointed to organise a scheme of forest conservancy, which he superintended till the establishment of a regular forest department in 1856; assistant chief engineer, Hyderabad, March, 1857; executive engineer, Secunderabad, Sept., 1862; superintendent of family payments and pensions, and curator of government books, Madras, 1865 to 1876; commissioner for Madras at the Universal Exhibition, Paris, 1867; acted as deputy secretary to government of Madras, military department, 1869; commissioner for India to the Vienna Exhibition, 1873 (appointed commander of the Order of Francis Joseph of Austria); fellow of the University of Madras, 1874; attached to the staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales during his visit to Madras, 1875; secretary to the government of Madras, military department, Feb., 1876 to 1883; C.S.I., March, 1876; commissioner for India to the Edinburgh Forestry Exhibition, 1884; royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886.

MICHELL, THOMAS BERNARD, Colonel, B.S.C., Assam Commission.—First commission as ensign, Feb., 1858; arrived in India, 29th Jan., 1860; from March, 1866, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, and grade, Jan., 1883; also served temporarily in Bengal as cantonment magistrate, Dum-Dum, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; retired, March, 1886.

MIDDLETON, JAMES RUSSELL, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Aug., 1883; senior collector and magistrate, Bijapur, Nov., 1886.

MIDWINTER, WILLIAM COLPOYS, Burma Commission.—Assistant conservator of forests, June, 1868; from Sept., 1869, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, officiating judge of the small cause court at Rangoon, settlement and boundary officer in the Tharrawaddy district, and cantonment magistrate of Thayetmyo (July, 1883); deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883.

MILES, SAMUEL BARRETT, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1857; from Nov., 1867, served as cantonment magistrate and assistant resident, Aden; assistant political agent, Meikran Coast, 1871; from Oct., 1872, served as political agent and consul, Muscat; officiating political agent, Turkish Arabia, and consul-general Baghdad, 1879-80; political agent, Zanzibar, 1881; returned to agency of Muscat, 1883; graded as political agent, 1st class; acting political resident, Persian Gulf, April, 1886.

MILLER, A., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 11th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, March, 1880; attached to library.

MILLER, JOHN ANDREW ERASMUS, Punjab Administration.—Joined the Punjab commission, Jan., 1863, as extra assistant commissioner; personal assistant to the financial commissioner, Oct., 1865; secretary to the financial commissioner, May, 1866, to 1880; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, 1871-72; officiating inspector-general of registration, and superintendent of stamps, Aug., 1879, and again in 1882; also officiated in the grades of judicial assistant and deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884, Kangra; officiating additional divisional judge, Jan.-May, 1886; commissioner of income-tax, Aug., 1886.

MILLER, JOHN ONTARIO, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1883; under secretary to government, May, 1884; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor of the N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886.

MILLER, LESLIE CREERY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

MILLETT, ARTHUR FENNING, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; served in N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1864, as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and from April, 1866, as assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, June, 1881, but served in the judicial department, from Aug., 1879, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, N.W. Provinces, March, 1883.

MILLETT, H. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Professor of English law, Presidency College, Calcutta, April, 1870; officiating 2nd judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Oct., 1871; receiver, high court, April to Dec., 1873; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, legislative department, Dec., 1873, to April, 1875; first judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1876.

MILLETT, MONTAGUE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857;
from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, June, 1884.

MILNER, J. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 26th April, 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; attached to funds department, estates and administrator-general's branch.

MITCHELL, HORACE, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Paul's School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 27th March, 1885.

MITCHELL, THOMAS CANDY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal; from May, 1876, served in Burma as assistant commissioner and boundary and settlement officer; on special forest demarcation duty, Nov., 1880; on special duty in connection with waste land grants in Arakan division, March, 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886.

MOBERLY, CHARLES MORRIS, Colonel, M.S.C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 2nd European regiment Madras, May, 1855; joined the public works department, May, 1867, as examiner of railway accounts, Madras; controller of accounts, Calcutta, 1873; officiating deputy accountant-general, March, 1876; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1878; Rajputana railway accounts, 1879; acted as manager, Rajputana railway, May-Aug., 1881; on special duty as secretary to railway conference, Jan.-March, 1884; examiner, 1st class, in the accounts establishment, Jan. 1886; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, March, 1887.

MOBERLY, HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradfield, and King's College School, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

MOCKLER, EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1859; served as assistant resident, Aden, Dec., 1866-1873; on civil employ, Mekran coast, from 1873; assistant to the governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, Oct., 1879; assistant agent and consul, Busrch, Turkish Arabia, Nov., 1881; acted as political agent, Muscat, 1883, and again April, 1886; graded as political agent, 2nd class.

MOHENDRO NATH BOSE, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 26th Feb., 1859, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, Sept., 1868; small cause court judge, Midnapore, Feb., 1872; 1st grade subordinate judge, and small cause judge, Hooghly, Serampore, and Howrah, May, 1877; officiating judge, highcourt, Jan., 1882; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, and of the courts of small causes at Krishnagar, Ranaghat, and Bongong, Oct., 1884.

MOIR, WILLIAM, M.A., M.B., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 20th Jan., 1860; arrived in India, 27th April, 1860, and was employed in various military medical charges; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail at Mainpuri, and afterwards at Meerut, and was placed in medical charge of the lock hospital at the latter place; held medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, 1863-64; superintendent, meteorological observatory, Meerut, June, 1868; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1872; surgeon-major, Jan., 1875; officiating chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878 to March, 1879.

MOLESWORTH, GUILDFORD LINDSAY, C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at the College of Civil Engineers, Putney; in 1852 was chief assistant engineer on the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway, which he left in order to superintend the construction of buildings and machinery in the Royal Arsenal at Woolwich, during the Crimean war; afterwards practised as a consulting engineer in London for some years; was awarded the 'Watt' medal and the Manby premium by the Institution of Civil Engineers in 1858, for a paper read before the institution on the 'Conversion of Wood by Machinery;' engineer on the Ceylon railway, 1859; chief engineer, Ceylon government railway, 1862; director-general of the railway 1865; director of public works in 1867; consulting engineer for state railways to the government of India, April, 1871; acted as director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March-June, 1880; fellow of the University of Calcutta; is the author of many publications on engineering, monetary, and other subjects, including a 'Pocket-book of Engineering Formulae,' which has passed through twenty-one editions; of 'Proposals for the Establishment of Decimal Coinage,' in Ceylon, 1865, and in India, 1871; of Reports on the Public Works of Ceylon, 1869, on Light Railways in Ceylon, 1870, on the Festiniog Railway, 1871, on State Railways in India, 1872, and on the Madras Harbour, 1884; 'Iron Manufacture in India,' 1884; 'Suggestions for the Establishment of an Engineer Volunteer Corps for India,' 1865; 'Imperialism for India,' 1885; 'Text-book of Bi-metallism,' 1886, &c., &c.

MONAHAN, FRANCIS JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Oratory School, Birmingham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

MONAHAN, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881.

MONEY, ALONZO, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Backergunge, 1846; superintendent of survey, Monghyr, 1850; magistrate and collector, Behar, 1857, and afterwards of Shahabad and Tirhoot; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Pooree, 1859; controller of government salt-chowkies, 1860; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Bhaugulpore, 1863; commissioner of Patna, and member of council of the lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1869;
member of revenue board, Lower Provinces, 1869; district and sessions judge, Bareilly, and member of revenue board, 1875; retired, 1878.

MONEY, ROBERT COTTON, Major-General, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 20th March, 1855; from 1st March, 1861, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1877; manager of the Durbhunga Raj estate, April, 1876, to Jan., 1878, and again, Jan., 1880; retired, April, 1886.

MONEY, WILLIAM JAMES, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; served in the revenue and survey departments in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent of survey, and was employed as civil officer with the troops in the Sonthal insurrection, 1855-56; private secretary to Sir James Outram, chief commissioner of Oudh, Aug., 1857; during the mutiny was present at several engagements, and was a member of the garrison of Lucknow; mutiny medal; served subsequently in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of revenue survey, 1860, in Jessore, and afterwards in other districts; magistrate and collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1861; officiated as district and sessions judge, Mymensingh, from 1869, and was confirmed in that appointment, Sept., 1873; retired, 1879.

MONTEATH, ALEXANDER M., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Edinburgh University, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; arrived in India, 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Allahabad, 1858; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; under secretary to government of India, financial and home departments, 1861; director-general of the post office of India from 1867 till his retirement in 1881, during which period he was placed for about two years on postal duty in England, including the representation of India at the postal conference at Berne in 1876.

MONTEATH, JAMES, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay in connexion with the Kârâna land assessment case, Nov., 1873; also acted for various periods as under secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, financial, and general departments, under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the Bombay legislative council, and as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1884, and acted as secretary, Sept.-Dec., 1884; acting private secretary to the governor, Oct., 1886.

MONTGOMERY, JAMES ALEXANDER LAWRENCE, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1868; from Nov., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; director of settlement and revenue records in the Punjab, Dec., 1885; author of a report on the settlement of the Hoshiarpur district.

MONTGOMERY, SIR ROBERT, G.C.S.I., K.C.B.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1827; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1828; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector of Allahabad, June, 1839, and subsequently of Mirzapore; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, 1846; commissioner, Punjab, 1849; 3rd member of the board of administration, Punjab, 1852; judicial commissioner, Punjab, 1853; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1858; provisional member of governor-general's council, Sept., 1858; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1859; retired, 1865; member of council of secretary of state, 1868.

MOORE, GEORGE MONTGOMERY J., Major, R.A.—Military secretary on personal staff of the governor of Madras (Rt. Hon. Sir M. E. Grant Duff, G.C.S.I., C.I.E.), 1st April, 1884 to 1886.

MOORE, JOHN GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; served in Sind from Dec., 1862, to Nov., 1870, as assistant commissioner, educational inspector, branch registrar-general, and acting commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, Sattarra, Oct., 1876; senior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1877; on special duty as president of the jail commission, July-Sept., 1878; was subsequently collector and magistrate of Poona, and acted on several occasions as commissioner of the southern and central divisions, Bombay, and as commissioner of customs, salt and opium, Feb., 1885.

MOORE, LEWIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate (Dec., 1884), acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled 'Trichinopoly District Manual.'

MOORE, ROSS ARTHUR LESLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

MOORE, WILLIAM JAMES, Surgeon-General, C.I.E., Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1852; was employed on regimental and other military duty till April, 1862, when he was appointed residency surgeon at Joudpur, and afterwards at Marwar; served from Aug., 1867, in Rajputana as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination; acting deputy surgeon-general, Bombay, 1877; deputy surgeon-general, Oct., 1877; surgeon-general with the government of Bombay, 1st April, 1885; hon. surgeon to the Viceroy.

MORGAN, CHARLES, Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd April, 1857; assistant to registrar, Oct., 1874.

MORGAN, WILLIAM HENRY, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Madras.—Appointed to the Indian medical department, 4th Aug.,
1855; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1856, and served in various military medical charges in Madras, Bengal, and N.W. Provinces; also held the civil surgeoncy of Etawah, June to Nov., 1858; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; from May, 1878, served as civil surgeon, Cochin; brigade-surgeon, Aug., 1882; retired, May, 1886.

MORIARTY, ARTHUR STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

MORISON, WILLIAM THOMSON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; transferred to Burma as assistant-commissioner, 1887.

MORRIESEN, EDWARD CURRIE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, assistant magistrate of Rangoon town, and in charge of Toungoo jail; from Dec., 1881, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; forest settlement officer, Dec., 1885.

MORRIS, SIR JOHN H., K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1847; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1848; served in the Punjab as assistant resident, Lahore, assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer in the Trans-Sutlej division; settlement officer, Mooltan, 1854; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, May, 1862; settlement commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1863; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1868; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, May, 1870; retired, 1883.

MORRIS, ROBERT, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

MORRISON, FRANK, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the telegraph department, Sept., 1863, to Feb., 1864; rejoined government service, and was employed in the accounts establishment (public works) in Bombay, Sindh, the Punjab, and Calcutta; deputy controller, Nov., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, Dec., 1875; examiner, Indus Valley railway, June, 1878; examiner of P.W. accounts, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; Northern Bengal railway accounts, May, 1882; examiner, 3rd class, May, 1886; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1886-87; examiner, southern Mahratta railway company, March, 1887.

MORTON, BOYCE WILLIAM DUNLOP, Colonel, B.S.C., late Non-regulation Commission, Bengal.—First commission, 9th June, 1848; served in Assam from June, 1854, as junior assistant and principal assistant to the commissioner; deputy commissioner, and class, Goalpara, April, 1861; superintendent of Darjeeling, Dec., 1866; on special duty for conducting the prosecution of Captain Playfair, Aug., 1876; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; retired, Aug., 1885.

MOSCARDI, EDWARD HENRY, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Somerseshire College, Bath, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty compiling the general administration report of the Bombay Presidency, Aug., 1881; from Dec., 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed 2nd grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883.

MOSLEY, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bishop's Stortford Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from April, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1884.

MOSS, T., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, July, 1849, and served as assistant and executive engineer and as assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces; officiating controller, central office of account, Rangoon, Oct., 1869; assistant accountant-general in the public works department, government of India, April, 1872; officiating controller, Madras, March, 1873; controller of accounts, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; transferred to Central Provinces as controller, Nagpur, Sept., 1875; examiner of accounts, Rangoon, April, 1878; transferred to Punjab, 1879; examiner, 2nd class, Sept., 1881; retired, 1886.

MOULE, HORACE FREDERICK D'OYLY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty in 1872 to conduct the prosecution of the sub-judge of Mirzapur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, June, 1884; secretary, board of revenue, Jan.-May, 1886.

MOUNSEY, CHARLES HERBERT, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant, Anantapur, May, 1886; compiled and edited the 'Reports of the Meriah Agents (Ganjam)', and wrote a 'History of the Ganjam Mahiaks'.

MOWAT, M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Professor, Presidency College, June, 1876; Dacca College, Jan., 1878; officiating instructor of schools, Nov., 1879; professor, Patna College, Feb., 1880; officiating principal,
Patna College, May, 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1883; officiating principal, Hooghly College, April, 1885.

MUHAMMAD ABBAS MIRZA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, C.S.I., Lieutenant-Colonel, Sirdar, Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed British agent at the court of H.H. the Amir of Kabul, March, 1882.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, Sirdar, Khan Bahadur, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1883.

MUHAMMAD ASLAM KHAN, Kazi, C.M.G., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra-assistant commissioner, 10th Sept., 1881; on special duty in civil secretariat, Dec., 1881; probationer under native civil service rules, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; on special duty with Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884, to Nov., 1886.

MUHAMMAD HYAT KHAN, C.S.I.—Extra assistant commissioner, Punjab, March, 1862; promoted to assistant commissioner, Jan., 1872; C.S.I., May, 1872; served as officiating judicial assistant in the Punjab, and was employed on special duty with the camp of exercise at Hasan Abdal, 1873; also as officiating political assistant with the Kuram field force, 1878; and as political officer with the staff of Sir F. Roberts, Kabul field force, 1879-80; district judge, 2nd grade, Punjab, Dec., 1886.

MUHAMMAD ISHAK KHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1884.

MUHAMMAD RAZA KHAN SAHIB, Madras C.S.—Served from Jan., 1874, in subordinate posts in the Madras revenue and educational departments, and in Hyderabad as attache to the resident; appointed by the government of India to be a member of the Madras civil service, 3rd Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1883, is also a forest settlement officer.

MUIR, JOHN FAIRLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1869, to April, 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting assistant secretary and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; from April, 1874, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector, May, 1880.

MUIR, JULIUS WOOD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dumfries Academy, and Edinburgh University, called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, July, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade in Oudh, Sept., 1885.

MUIR, SIR WILLIAM, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., LL.D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kilmar-nock Grammar School, and Edinburgh and Glasgow Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1837; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1837; settlement officer in Cawnpore and Bundelkund, 1840-1843; officiating collector, Futtehpore, 1844-1845; secretary, Sudder board of revenue, 1847; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; member, board of revenue, 1856; in charge of intelligence department at Agra during mutiny, 1857; secretary with Lord Canning at Allahabad for N.W. Provinces, 1858; reverted to board of revenue, 1859; member of legislative council of governor-general, 1864; foreign secretary, government of India, 1865; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1868-1874; financial member of governor-general's council, 1874-76; member of council of secretary of state, 1876-85; principal, Edinburgh University, 1885; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Glasgow and Edinburgh; author of 'Life of Mahomet and History of Islam to the Era of the Hegira,' 1853; 'Annals of the Early Caliphate,' 1883, and other works on the same subject; pamphlet on indigenous education in Futtehpore, 1845; papers on revenue settlement in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, &c.

MUIR, WILLIAM JAMES WEMYSS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1858; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Sept., 1863; assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakalti, June, 1864; political superintendent, Sirohi, Sept., 1865; officiated for some time as agent of Haroati and Tonk; political agent, Moorsheadabad, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1879; Haroati and Tonk, 1880; graded as political agent, 1st class.

MUIR-MACKENZIE, JOHN WILLIAM PITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877.

MULLALY, CHARLES MYLNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Southampton Grammar School, Hartley Institution, Southampton, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1883.

MULLINS, JOHN, Lieut-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, 8th Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1850; assistant civil engineer, Feb., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in Nellore and Tanjore, 1858-64; consulting engineer for the irrigation and canal company, Madras, May, 1864, to Aug., 1869; under secretary to government, public works department, Feb., 1869; chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Madras, public works department, Nov., 1870; acted as chief engineer and secretary to
government in 1875 and 1877; president, irrigation committee, famine commission, Oct., 1878, to Jan., 1879; on special duty for drawing up the Bangalore water supply scheme, Oct., 1883; services replaced at disposal of military department, in 1884; retired, 1886.

MULOCK, FRANCIS BERRY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty as assistant private secretary to lieutenant-governor on occasion of visit of H.R.H. Prince of Wales, Dec., 1875, to March, 1876; on special duty for arrangements connected with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1886.

MULOCK, HENRY PILKINGTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; from Feb., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred temporarily to Bengal for employment on Behar famine relief works, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885.

MULOCK, WILLIAM BURY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 28th Nov., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar of the high court, and assistant collector and magistrate; from April, 1873, to Nov., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of assurances in Sind, also as inspector of education, May-Nov., 1873, and was on various occasions in charge of the office of the commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Jan., 1880; acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, June, 1884; senior collector and magistrate, Nasik, March, 1885.

MUNRO, W. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1861; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

MURDOCH, DAVID DOIG, Madras C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived, 7th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate in Kistna and Chingleput; acting head assistant collector and magistrate, Salem.

MURRAY, ALAN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1857, as ensign, Bengal Fusiliers; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, and was present at the relief of Lucknow, Nov., 1857; served subsequently with Sir James Outram's force, Nov., 1857 to Feb., 1858, and took part in the pursuit of the rebel Tantia Topee, Jan., 1859 (medal and two clasps); served in the Oudh Police department as assistant superintendent from June, 1866 to April, 1867, and subsequently in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and assistant settlement officer; junior secretary to chief commissioner, 1874-1878, and acted as director of public instruction, Jan.-March, 1874, and as personal assistant to chief commissioner, April-Aug., 1876; attaché in Foreign Office, Nov., 1876 to Jan., 1877; in charge of Oudh Gazetteer, Aug., 1877 to Feb., 1878; officiated as cantonment magistrate and wasika officer Lucknow, in 1879, and in 1881-82; district judge, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, Kheri, April, 1886.

MURRAY, JOHN, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at Peterhead, and Marischal College, and University of Aberdeen; A.M., 1828; M.D., University of Edinburgh, 1831; M.R.C.S., London, 1831; assistant surgeon, Indian medical service, 1832; field surgeon at the battle of Aliwal, 1846; surgeon, 1848; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, 1858; inspector-general of hospitals, 1865; retired Jan., 1871; has written various papers on cholera and its treatment.

MURRAY, Robert, Major-General, C.S.I., R.A.—Educated at Addiscombe; 2nd lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 14th June, 1845; served with the army of the Punjab, 1848-49, and was present at the action of Sadoolapore, and the battles of Chillianwallah and Guzerat, and in the advance to Peshawur (medal and two clasps); served on regimental duty, 1845-1857, including command of a battery in the Gwalior contingent, and in the Oudh irregular force; appointed to the telegraph department in Oct., 1857, as deputy superintendent; superintendent, 1860; major, Bengal staff corps, June, 1865; deputy director-general, Jan., 1866; lieutenant-colonel, Bengal staff corps, June, 1871; director-general of the telegraph department in India, Jan., 1878 to June, 1883; nominated C.S.I., May, 1884; major-general, May, 1886.

MURRAY, THOMAS JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1860; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1860; on famine relief work, Patna, May, 1874; served in Assam from Dec., 1875, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, May, 1876; officiating inspector of schools, March-July, 1877; officiating secretary to the chief commissioner, July-Oct., 1877; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Jan., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; registrar of joint stock companies and inspector of registration offices, July, 1882; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps, inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise, March, 1883.

MUTHUSWAMI AIYAR, TIRUVARUR, B.L., C.I.E., Judicial department, Madras.—Served from 1st May, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the Madras revenue, judicial and educational departments; deputy collector, July, 1859; magistrate of police, Nov., 1868; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1872; on duty at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Jan., 1877; C.I.E., Jan. 1878; judge high court, Madras, Aug., 1883.

MYLNE, RIGHT REV. LOUIS GEORGE, M.A., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Arrived in July, 1876; installed as Bishop of Bombay, 6th July, 1876.

NANABHAI HARIDAS, LL.B. (Madras),
Judicial Department, Bombay.—From May, 1873, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting judge of the high court, and government pleader; also acted as professor of law in the government law school, July to Dec., 1880, and in Feb., 1881; confirmed as judge of the high court, June, 1884.

NANNEY, Lewis Charles, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.F.P.S., L.S.A., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1886; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1886; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; acting presiding surgeon, Madras, 1872-73; superintendent, lunatic asylum, Madras, Oct., 1875; also professor of materia medica, medical college, July, 1876; surgeon-major, March, 1878; medical officer, Coonoor and Kotagiri, 1879-1881, and at Ootacamund, 1881-1883; special sanitary officer, Ootacamund, Aug., 1881, to July, 1883; civil surgeon, Cannanore, July, 1883; civil surgeon, Trichinopoly, June, 1884.

NAPIER AND ETTRICK (BARON), RIGHT HON. FRANCIS NAPIER, K.T.—Attaché to the embassy at Vienna in 1840, and afterwards at Constantinople; served as secretary of legation at Naples and St. Petersburg, and was appointed secretary of embassy at Constantinople in 1834; British minister at Washington, 1857, whence he was transferred to the Hague, 1858, to St. Petersburg in 1860, and to Berlin in 1864; governor of Madras, March, 1865 till Feb., 1872; on the assassination of Lord Mayo, acted temporarily as viceroy; was president of the Social Science Association at Plymouth in 1872; and presided over the education section of the Association at Glasgow, in Oct., 1874; a royal commissioner on the Highland Crofters' question, March, 1883.

NAPIER, HON. GEORGE CAMPBELL, C.I.E., Major, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1861; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; on special duty, March, 1874, in Persia, and again, Feb., 1881, at Kandahar; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882, to Sept., 1883; judicial assistant, Feb., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; superintendent, Kapurthala State, April, 1885.

NARSINGRAO BHOLOATH DIVATIA, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, Jan., 1844, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed in the Bombay civil service, March, 1886.

NASH, A. M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th Jan., 1875; arrived, 31st March, 1875; served as professor, Presidency College; appointed inspector of European schools, and promoted to 2nd class of the education department, April, 1883.

NAYLOR, JAMES RICHARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kaladgi, June, 1875; remembrancer of legal affairs, July, 1876; acting chief secretary to government, judicial, educational, political, secret, and separate departments, Oct., 1879, to March, 1880; additional member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1884; on special duty in connection with the Bombay municipal bill, June, 1885.

NEALP, WALTER ERskine, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from Nov., 1867, to April, 1880, as settlement officer; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1881.

NEATHAM, A. H. J., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Feb., 1879.

NEEL, EDMUND, Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; India office writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, military department, 1860; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1868-1871; military department, 1871; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; funds department, 1874; assistant secretary in the military department, Aug., 1881; assistant secretary in the political and secret department, 1885.

NEILL, JOHN WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1864; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Jan., 1866; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Central Provinces, July, 1866; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, May, 1870, and acted as secretary to the chief commissioner from June, 1870, to March, 1877, when he was confirmed in the appointment; also acted as inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise in 1872, and as inspector-general of education in 1873; commissioner, Nagpur division, June, 1880; acting judicial commissioner, June, 1881, to March, 1882, and again in 1885; fellow of the University of Calcutta, June, 1883; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Oct., 1883.

NEILL, LINDSAY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1867; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector-general of education in 1874, and as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, in 1872-74, and in 1875-6; under secretary to government of India, home department, April, 1877; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, June, 1880; acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, 1877 to 1882, also acting as inspector-general of police and prisons, June-Aug., 1881; acting commissioner, Nagpur division, April, 1882; additional commissioner, Jan., 1883; secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1883; acted as commissioner in the Jubbulpore division in 1883 and 1885.

NELSON, JAMES HENRY, M.A. (Barrister-at-
Law), Madras C.S.—King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1863; acted as small cause court judge of Madura, 1865-67; acting registrar of the high court, Madras, April, 1867; small cause court judge, Kumbakonum, Dec., 1867, to June, 1872; prepared the Madura district manual; from June, 1872, served as civil and sessions judge in Tanjore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, July, 1876, to March, 1880, and afterwards in South Arcot and Chingleput.

NESFIELD, JOHN C., M.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—From 22nd Jan., 1867, to May, 1872, served in Bengal as professor, Krishnagarh College, and at the Presidency College; from May, 1872, served in British Burma as director of public instruction, and inspector of schools; transferred to Oudh, March, 1874, and served in the 2nd grade of education officers as director of public instruction; principal, Benares College, May, 1878; inspector of schools, Oudh division, Nov., 1879; author of 'An Essay on the Kanjar Tribe,' 1882; 'On the Results of Primary Education in N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1883, and 'On the Tharu and Bagsha Tribes,' 1884; 'Brief View of the Caste System of the North-West Provinces and Oudh,' 1885, and 'A Pamphlet on the Project for Establishing a University for North-West Provinces and Oudh,' 1886.

NETHERSOLE, WILLIAM, B.A., LL.M., Barrister-at-law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1878, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate in 1882, and as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1883; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1884; acting director of agriculture, July, 1884; acting junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1884; from Dec., 1884, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer of Sambalpur, March, 1885.

NEWBERY, FRANCIS MONRO, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 38th native infantry, 13th April, 1859; served in the China campaign of 1860, and was present at Simbo, capture of Tongku and the Jaku forts, and final surrender of Pekin (medal and clasps); from February, 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; city magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1874; on special duty in connection with agricultural meeting and exhibition at Lucknow, Dec., 1881; district judge, 3rd grade, sub. pro tem., March, 1883; sub-judge, 1st grade, April, 1883; district judge, 2nd grade, Lucknow, May, 1885.

NEWBERY, HENRY JAMES, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1885; retired, April, 1887.

NEWMAN, JOHN HENRY, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Establishment.—First commission in the Indian medical service, 1867; served in civil employ, in the political agency, Joudpore, from April, 1869; civil surgeon, Ajmere, April, 1879; officiated as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination, and administrative medical officer in Rajputana in 1884; is also superintendent of jail at Ajmere, and medical officer of the Mhairwarra battalion.

NEWMARCH, FRANCIS W., Military Department, India Office.—Matriculated at Balliol College, Oxford, Jan., 1873; scholar of Corpus Christi College, Oxford, 1873-8; 1st class in classics, moderations, May, 1874, and 1st class in classics, final schools, Dec., 1876; B.A., Feb., 1877; junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1877; resident clerk, 1885.

NEWMARCH, OLIVER RICHARDSON, Major-General, B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, March, 1855; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, July, 1857; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, 1871; deputy accountant-general, military department, 1875; accountant-general, military department, April, 1878; also ex-officio deputy secretary to the government of India; secretary to government of India, military department, July, 1886.

NEWTON, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury School, and afterwards at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; judicial assistant to commissioner, Satara, 1854; joint judge and sessions judge, Poona, 1858, and afterwards of the Konkan; acting sub-treasurer, Bombay, July, 1859; acting civil auditor, Aug., 1859; registrar, court of Sudder Dewani, Nov., 1859; acting puisne judge of the Sudder Court, Jan., 1860; member of commission to frame a code of laws for the Parsees, Dec., 1861; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1863; acted as chief justice, Bombay, 1868; retired in 1871.

NEWTON, J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

NICHOLLS, GEORGE JASPER, LL.B. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, May, 1874, to May, 1875; acting secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1877; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; acting inspector-general of police, July, 1880; small cause court judge, Jubbulpur, Sept., 1880; deputy commissioner, 4th class, March, 1883; from July, 1883, served in the N.W. Provinces as officiating magistrate and collector, 1st grade, and was appointed manager of the Awa State, Oct., 1883; judge, 3rd grade, Ghazipur, April, 1885; author
of 'The Law of the Central Provinces,' 'Digest of the Circular and Standing Orders of the Chief Commissioner, Central Provinces, 1862-80,' 'An Economic Gazetteer of the Central Provinces,' and contributions to the 'Central Provinces and Imperial Gazetteer.'

NICHOLSON, FRANCIS COBHAM, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; from March, 1873, served as civil surgeon in Bengal, and also as medical inspector of labourers, and superintendent of labour transport at Goalundo; civil surgeon, Monghyr, Nov., 1876; superintendent of the presidency jail, and resident surgeon of the general hospital, and governor of the workhouse, Jan., 1878; acted as superintendent of the Alipore and Russia jails, 1879 to 1881, and as superintendent of the Campbell medical school and hospital, professor of medical jurisprudence at the medical college, police surgeon, and superintendent of lock hospital, 1879, and again in 1882; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, 1881; surgeon-major, Oct., 1881; civil surgeon, Darjeeling, Feb., 1884; civil surgeon, Chittagong, March, 1886.

NICHOLSON, FREDERICK AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Medical College, Epsom, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty with the selection of forest reserves, Nov., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1883; principal assistant to the collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Sept.-Nov., 1885.

NICHOLSON, WILLIAM GUSTAVUS, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission as lieutenant, March, 1865; arrived in India, Dec., 1871; joined the public works department, Feb., 1872, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad, but was shortly afterwards transferred to the Punjab irrigation branch; transferred to military works branch, 1873; executive engineer, March, 1876; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, and was present at the actions of Shutargardan and Lataband, and march from Kabul to relief of Kandahar (medal and 3 clasps, bronze star, brevet of major); secretary to defence committee, April, 1882; served in Egyptian expedition, 1882, including battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal and clasp, bronze star, 4th class Osmanieh); ex-officio assistant adjutant-general, 1885; superintending engineer, March, 1886.

NILKANTO SIRCAR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed, under the native civil service rules, assistant magistrate and collector on probation, June, 1886.

NISBET, ROBERT PARRY, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1859; from Aug., 1862, served in the Punjab assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, April, 1885, Rawal Pindi; officiated as commissioner and superintendent in the Delhi, Derajat, and Rawal Pindi divisions, 1884-86; commissioner, Rawal Pindi, Nov., 1886.

NOBLE, CHARLES SIMEON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bengal native infantry, 14th Nov., 1858; from April, 1862, to June, 1866, served in the police department, Oudh, as assistant district superintendent, officiating assistant inspector-general, and district superintendent; from June, 1866, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, and officiating deputy commissioner; secretary to committee appointed to conduct the agricultural meeting, Lucknow, Aug., 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1883.

NOLAN, PHILIP, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Stonyhurst School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; on special duty at Darjeeling, Aug., 1875, and again, in the stamp and stationery office, Nov., 1879; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Shahabad, Sept., 1884; officiating secretary, board of revenue, March, 1885; secretary, government of Bengal, general, revenue, and statistical department, March, 1887.

NORMAN, SIR HENRY WYLIE, General, G.C.B., C.I.E., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal Army, March, 1844; deputy assistant adjutant-general, Peshawur, Aug., 1853; assistant adjutant-general of the army, May, 1856; deputy adjutant-general, Dec., 1857; secretary to government of India in the military department, 1862-70; military member of governor-general's council, Jun., 1870-76; member of council of secretary of state for India, Feb., 1878, to Nov., 1883; governor of Jamaica, 1883.

NORMAN, THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886.

NORRIS, J. F.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1882.

NORTHBROOK (EARL OF), RIGHT HON. THOMAS GEORGE BARING, G.C.S.I., D.C.L.—Born 1826; educated at Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated (and class in classics) in 1846; was successively private secretary to Mr. Labouchere at the board of trade, to Sir George Grey at the home office, to Sir Charles Wood at the India board, and at the admiralty till 1857; sat in the House of Commons as member for Penryn and Falmouth, 1857 to 1866; was a lord of the admiralty, May, 1857, to Feb., 1858; under-secretary of state for India, June, 1859, to Jan., 1861; under-secretary for war, Jan., 1861; again under-secretary for India, July, 1861, to April, 1864; under-secretary for home affairs, 1864 to 1866; again under-secretary for war, 1868 to 1872; viceroy and governor-general of India, Feb., 1872, to Feb., 1876; G.C.S.I., May, 1872; created Viscount Baring, and Earl of Northbrook, 1876; first lord of the admiralty, 1880, to June, 1885; high commissioner on a special mission to Egypt, Aug., 1884; a royal commissioner for the London Exhibition of 1886.
NORTON, David, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1886; transferred for service in Burma as deputy commissioner, 1887.

NUGENT, John, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Institution School, Liverpool, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant educational inspector; appointed under secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial, political, and educational departments, and secretary to the legislative council, Feb., 1875; also acted on several occasions as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, as collector of salt revenue, July, 1878, and as secretary in the political, secret, judicial, educational, and Persian departments, Feb.-March, 1879; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Feb., 1881; acting collector of stamps and stationery, April, 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Satara, May-June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as secretary to government in revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Dec., 1882; also acted as chief secretary to government in 1884 and 1885; president of the central committee for vernacular departmental examinations.

NUGENT, John, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Stonyhurst College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872, and served in Bengal, and from Jan., 1880, in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Aug., 1885; senior-assistant commissioner, Kumaon, Jan., 1887.

NUNDA KRISHNA BOSE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Employed in the education department from Aug., 1878; appointed under the native civil service rules, and served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, from Jan., 1880, as assistant magistrate and collector on probation, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Sept., 1881.

NURSEY, J. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 26th July, 1871; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878; attached to financial department.

OAKESHOTT, Jonathan, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at City of London School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

OBbard, Robert, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1873; from 7th Jan., 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; transferred for special famine duty in the Madras presidency, Sept., 1877, to July, 1878; acted as judge of the small cause court, and superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, in 1882.

O'BRIEN, Edward, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Colomba's College, Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, March-Dec., 1871; promoted to deputy commissioner, and grade, Nov., 1884; author of a glossary of the Multani language, and a report on the settlement of the Muzaffargarh district.

O'BRIEN, Peter Henry, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Malvern College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1882.

O'CALLAGHAN, Francis L., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, June, 1862, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to the railway branch, 1870; Nagpur and Raepur railway survey, March, 1871; engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, June, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, Pindi-Peshawur section, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, Jan., 1880; C.I.E., 1883; appointed to superintend assistant engineers on practical training in England, Nov., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind Sagar railway surveys, Dec., 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, June, 1885; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; engineer-in-chief, Kwaja-Amran railway survey, Feb., 1887.

O'CALLAGHAN, I., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1873; traffic superintendent Rajputana state railway, Dec., 1874; 1st class, traffic department, state railways, Jan., 1882; on special duty with railway conference, Calcutta, Jan.-March, 1884; general traffic manager, Rajputana-Malwa railway system.

O'CONNOR, J. E., Financial Department, Government of India.—Registrar, department of agriculture and commerce, June, 1873; assistant secretary in statistical branch of department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary, department of finance and commerce, and in 2nd class of financial department, Dec., 1879; deputed on special duty in connection with the International Exhibition at Melbourne, July, 1880, to Feb., 1881.

O'DONNELL, Charles James, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Ignatius' College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, June, 1874; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1886.

O'Dwyer, Michael Francis, Bengal, C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in
India, Nov. 19, 1885, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab.

O'FARRELL, HORACE HANDLEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting additional sessions judge.

OGILVIE, GEORGE MACARTNEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1883.

O'KINEALY, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Nov., 1862, to Sept., 1874, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of survey, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate, and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; appointed additional sessions judge of Bhagalpore, in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1874, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, May, 1875; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, Dec., 1877; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan., 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, Feb. to Sept., 1880; judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Feb., 1883; president of the board of examiners, April, 1885.

OLDFIELD, RICHARD CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1848; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed in charge of the office of assistant superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1855, and appointed assistant secretary to government, and assistant accountant, N.W. Provinces, March, 1856; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, March, 1864; on special duty at Cawnpore for enquiring into the case of the Dewan of Chirkhari, Feb., 1866; on special duty under the public works department, Feb., 1869; on special duty for investigating the charges brought against Mir Badshah, Munisif of Deoband, March, 1869; from May, 1869, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872, and subsequently at Allahabad; additional judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1874; puisne judge, high court, Nov., 1882.

OLDHAM, FRANCIS GEORGE, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, Dec., 1858; joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as officiating deputy controller of accounts, Calcutta; controller of accounts, Hyderabad, April, 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, March, 1878, and subsequently at Calcutta, 1879; Central India, 1882; examiner of telegraph accounts, 1883; examiner of accounts, Allahabad, Aug., 1885; examiner, 2nd class, in the accounts establishment, Sept., 1886; examiner of accounts, military works, Jan., 1887.

OLDHAM, WILLIAM BENJAMIN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1865; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879, and deputy commissioner, and grade, Nov., 1879; on famine relief duty, Oct., 1866, and again March, 1874, and at Bellary, March, 1877, to Feb., 1879; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, April, 1886.

OLIPHANT, HENRY LAURENCE, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; from July, 1859, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, April, 1877; retired, Oct., 1885.

OLIPHANT, JOHN S., Funds Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd June, 1853; junior clerk, minuting branch, 1855; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1857–58; India office, secretariat department, 1859; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1863 to 1865; senior clerk, funds department, April, 1866; assistant secretary, military department, 1872, but continued doing duty in funds department; also agent to administrators-general of India, 1877; acting judicial and public secretary for four months, 1879; director of funds, 22nd July, 1879.

OLLIVANT, ALFRED, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department (North-Western Provinces).—Arrived in India as ensign, 20th April, 1857; medal for services during mutiny, 1857; appointed to Jhansi military police, July, 1858; from May, 1861, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, July, 1882; deputy inspector-general, June, 1885; senior deputy inspector-general, May, 1886.

OLLIVANT, EDWARD CHARLES KAYLL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant agent in special charge of Sachin state, and was in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Sept.–Oct., 1875; acting junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Surat, April, 1878; on special duty at Baroda in connection with estate of Mir Zulfikar Ali, Jan., 1879; assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration in Sind, and Sindhi translator to government, Sept., 1880; also deputy superintendent of census in Sind, Jan., 1881; municipal commissioner for Bombay, May, 1881; on special duty in England in connection with the municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug-Nov., 1883.

OMMANNEY, EDWARD LACON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 12th June, 1855; assistant to commissioner in charge of ex-king of Delhi and state prisoners, Sept., 1857; took ex-king of Delhi and family to Rangoon, and served in Pegu commission, Oct., 1858, to April, 1859; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, personal as-
sistant to commissioners of Derajat and Pesha-
wur, and deputy commissioner; on special duty in Bengal, March, 1871, and again, April, 1871, at Patna, to give evidence in case of Queen v. Amir Khan; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Derajat, Dec., 1883.

OMMANNAYE, HENRY TRAVERS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, cantonment magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, acting political agent, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Oct., 1882; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial and general departments, April, 1886.

OPPERT, GUSTAV, Ph.D. (Halle), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 14th Nov., 1872, as professor of Sanscrit, Presidency College, and curator of Government Oriental Manuscript Library; fellow of Madras University, April, 1873; Telegu translator to government, Sept., 1878; 3rd class of education department, March, 1882; officiating principal of Presidency College from May, 1885.

ORR, JOHN HENRY, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., C.B., late Madras Medical Service.—Educated at the University of Edinburgh; M.D. of the Royal College of Physicians, and licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh; arrived in India as assistant surgeon on the Madras establishment, May, 1837; was employed in H.H. the Nizam's service, and subsequently with Hyderabad contingent, Jan., 1842, to Oct., 1862; during this period took part in various military operations, including the siege of Darur, 1851, and various engagements with the insurgent Rohillas; served through the campaign in Malwa in 1857, under Brigadier-General Sir C. Stewart, K.C.B., and was present at various actions; was staff surgeon to the Hyderabad contingent during the campaign in Central India in 1858, under General Sir Hugh Rose, G.C.B.; medal and clasp, C.B., and hon. surgeon to the Queen; garrison surgeon of Bangalore, and Fort St. George, Oct., 1862, to Feb., 1863; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, with the Nagpore force, Feb., 1863, to March, 1865, and afterwards in Mysore and the ceded districts; retired, Feb., 1870; was president of the Bangalore cantonment and Pettah municipal boards, April, 1871, to March, 1881.

ORR, J. W., M.A. (Dublin), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 7th May, 1860, as acting deputy clerk of the crown, clerk to the chief justice, acting prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits and sealer of the high court, registrar of joint stock companies, and clerk of insolvent court; confirmed in appointment of prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, from Feb., 1866.

O'SULLIVAN, PATRICK (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in judicial department, Madras, from Oct., 1864, as law reporter to the high court, acting clerk of the crown and crown prosecutor, and also as professor of law, Presidency College, Jan., 1867, to Sept., 1870; assistant secretary to government, legislative department, Feb., 1872; additional member of legislative council, Jan., 1877, and was re-appointed in Sept., 1886; fellow of Madras University, March, 1877; advocate-general, Madras, Jan., 1878; member of forest draft bill committee, May, 1882.
