OTTLEY, JOHN WALTER, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission as lieutenant, Jan., 1864; arrived in India, Nov., 1868; joined the public works department, Feb., 1870, as assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Punjab, April, 1870; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; personal assistant to superintending engineer, Bari Doab Canal, April, 1872; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Bengal, Feb., 1874; re-transferred to Punjab, irrigation branch, June, 1875; assistant secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, July, 1881; superintendent of works, Bari Doab circle, April, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1884.

OWEN, E., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

OWENS, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Aug., 1873.

OXENHAM, ROBERT G., M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1863, and served till Nov., 1874, as professor of English literature at the Deccan College, Poona, and subsequently as principal of the college, and professor of moral philosophy; also held acting appointments for various periods at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, as professor of English literature and history, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy, and as professor of history and political economy.

OZANNE, EDWARD CHARLES, M.R.A.C., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; on famine relief duty in Tirhoot, March-Oct., 1874, in Mysore, Oct., 1877, and in Kâthiâwar, March, 1879; on duty in England at the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester, Sept., 1882; director of agriculture in the Bombay Presidency, July, 1883; acting survey and settlement commissioner, Dec., 1886.

PAGE, WILLIAM HUMPHREY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Nottingham Grammar School, and Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; district and sessions judge, and 2nd grade, Oct., 1885; district and sessions judge, Dacca, April, 1887.

PAKEMAN, THOS. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 16th Oct., 1851; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, July, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

PALLE CHENTSAL RAO PANTULU, C.I.E., superintendent of stamps and stationery, Madras.—Served from Feb., 1851, in various subordinate posts in the judicial and revenue departments, Madras; from July, 1859, to May,
1872; served as deputy collector, and as special assistant to the Inam commissioner, also as deputy collector of salt revenue, and was on special duty under the collector of Godavari, Aug.–Dec., 1870; sheristadar, board of revenue, May, 1872; fellow of the Madras University, Nov., 1873; superintendent of stamps and stationery, July, 1882; member of the draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885, C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

PALMER, ELWIN MITFORD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, Nov., 1871; assistant to accountant-general, British Burma, Dec., 1873; transferred to Bombay, April, 1876; assistant to comptroller-general, Oct., 1878; served under the Egyptian government, Dec., 1878, to April, 1879; from Jan., 1880, served in Madras as officiating assistant accountant-general, and officiating deputy accountant-general; comptroller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1882; 4th class of financial department, Dec., 1882; assistant-accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, Nov., 1884; assistant comptroller-general, Dec., 1884; transferred for service under Egyptian Government, Aug., 1885.

PANAMALA RAMACHANDRA RAO, B.L., Madras, C.S.—Served in the education department, 1864–1867, and from Feb., 1868, in various subordinate posts under the revenue department; assistant to deputy superintendent of census operations, Madras, April, 1881; acting personal assistant to commissioner of salt revenue, 1882–1885; appointed by the government of India to be assistant collector and magistrate in the Madras Presidency, Dec., 1885.

PARGITER, FREDERICK EDEN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at College School, Taunton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1875; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, settlement officer in Chittagong, and commissioner of the Sunderbunds; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Jan., 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1887; author of 'Revenue History of the Sunderbunds from 1765 to 1870.'

PARKER, EDWIN WOODALL, Punjab Administration.—From 20th Oct., 1863, served in the Punjab as extra assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and officiating judicial assistant; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; officiated as district judge, and as divisional judge, Nov., 1885; officiating inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, &c., Jan., 1886; on special duty with the public service commission, Dec., 1886, to April, 1887; author of 'Outlines of the Constitutional Law of India,' and 'Outlines of Jurisprudence.'

PARKER, GEORGE ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Uppingham School, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Madura, March, 1872, and district and sessions judge, April, 1882, in the district of Kurnool, and subsequently in South Tanjore; officiating judge of the high court, Madras, July, 1885.

PARKER, JOSEPH, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; East India House writer, old establishment, 9th July, 1851; junior clerk, marine department, Aug., 1858; store department, 1860; senior clerk, Nov., 1866.

PARKER, WILLIAM HENRY, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed as temporary assistant engineer, 24th Aug., 1860, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, April, 1872; from Nov., 1873, served in the railway branch, and was employed on the Western Rajputana and Indus Valley state railways; transferred to Bengal, June, 1881, and employed temporarily on Central Bengal railway as superintending engineer, and subsequently on Nagpore railway surveys as engineer-in-chief; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, Bengal, railway branch, July–Oct., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Godra-Rutlam railway survey.

PARKER, WILLIAM JACKSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1888; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Raja of Sirmoor, Dec., 1875, at Calcutta, and again, Dec., 1876, at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Nov., 1885.

PARRATT, CHARLES, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Clerk, London office, 1881.

PARROTT, BENJAMIN ALEXANDER NAPIER, Captain, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, H.M. 76th regiment, July, 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1868; served in the Lushai expedition, 1871; from April, 1872, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant town magistrate, and settlement, and boundary officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1886; transferred to Upper Burma, June, 1886.

PARRY, R., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 14th Jan., 1865; served as head-master, Krishnaghur College, and Hooghly College, professor at Hooghly College (March, 1868), and at Presidency College (Sept., 1874), inspector of schools (temporary), and officiating principal, Dacca College; 3rd class, education department, Aug., 1877; professor, Patna College, June, 1884.

PARSONS, HENRY JAMES (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant judge, and judge and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, in 1881–82; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Thana, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge, Dharwar, Sept., 1885.

PARSONS, JAMES EDMUND BACON, Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1849; from Feb., 1856, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 1st class, May, 1876; retired, Nov., 1885.

PARTRIDGE, WILLIAM REGINALD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, Sherborne School, and University College, London; appointed to
the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1883, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

PATÉKI SRINIVASA RAO, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in the judicial department from 16th Dec., 1844, as gumastah, Foujdar translator, district munsi, and principal sudr amin; magistrate of police, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of Madras University, Nov., 1875; small cause court judge, Madras, April, 1880; board of examiners, 11th Jan., 1882.

PATTERSON, ALEXANDER BLEAKLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Belfast Royal Academical Institute, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant magistrate and collector; from June, 1869, to April, 1883, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882; on special duty in the settlement department, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Allahabad, Dec., 1883; acting commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, Agra, June, 1885.

PATTLE, A. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

PAUL, ALFRED WALLIS, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on special settlement and survey duty, Aug., 1878, and again, Nov., 1881; services placed temporarily at the disposal of the public works department, Nov., 1883; officiating inspector-general of registration, June, 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1884; secretary to the central examination committee, Calcutta, Dec., 1884; on special duty under foreign department, government of India, in connection with the Thibet Mission, April, 1886.

PAUL, GREGORY CHARLES, B.A., C.I.E.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1862-78; advocate-general, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1878; additional member, governor-general's council, 1878-82; legislative council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, March, 1885.

PEACOCK, RIGHT HON. SIR BARNES KNIGHT.—Was called to the bar at the Inner Temple, and practised on the Home Circuit; queen's counsel, 1850; legal member of the council of the governor-general of India, June, 1852; was also president of the Indian law commission, 1852-54; chief justice of the Supreme Court, Calcutta, and vice-president of the legislative council of India 1859, and chief justice of the High Court of Judicature, Calcutta, on its establishment in 1862; resigned, 1870, and was sworn a privy councillor; member of the judicial committee of the privy council, June, 1872.

PEACOCK, FREDERICK BARNES (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed registrar, high court, May, 1864; president of a committee to report on the King of Oudh's affairs; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1870; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1873; commissioner, Dacca division, April, 1878; and of the Presidency division, May, 1881; president of a committee on the transport and storage of inflammable oils, July, 1879, and of committees on railway police, in 1881 and 1882; chief secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments, March, 1883; officiating member, board of revenue, Sept., 1883; member of the public service commission, Dec., 1886.

PEACOCK, HENRY PHIPSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal cavalry, Sept., 1856; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Lucknow (medal); served subsequently with the governor-general's body guard; acted as agent to the governor-general with King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, in 1868, and on several occasions subsequently; political agent, Moorsheadabad, 1878; political agent, Ulwar, Rajputana, 1882; graded as political agent, 2nd class; acting resident, W. Rajputana, March, 1886.

PEARSE, HERBERT GEORGE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1886.

PEARSON, CHARLES, M.A., late Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab educational department from March, 1861, as professor and principal, Agra College; inspector of schools, Rawal Pindi circle, Nov., 1865; 2nd grade, educational department, April, 1870; officiating director of public instruction in 1873, 1876, and 1883; on special duty with education commission, 1882; retired, March, 1886.

PEARSON, FRANCIS BOYLE, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; attached to the N.W. Provinces; served in various districts in the grades of assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and civil and sessions judge; also as settlement officer, Jullundur, 1849-50, and as registrar to the court of Sudder Dewani and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1850-53; judge of Sudder Dewani and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1862-66; puisne judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866-81; retired March, 1881.

PEAT, WALTER SCOTT, Lieutenant-Colonel—1st commission, Bombay cavalry, 1859; from Feb., 1883, acted as cantonment magistrate, Mhow; and assistant agent to the governor-general, Baroda, and cantonment magistrate, May, 1885; is also railway magistrate, and small cause court judge.

PEDDER, WILLIAM GEORGE, C.S.I., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Departments, India Office.—B.A. of Exeter College, Oxford, 1854; appointed to Bombay civil service after open competitive examination, 1855; arrived in India, 8th Oct., 1856, and served as assistant magis-
trate and collector; on special duty under the revenue commissioner for alienation, Feb., 1859; assistant settlement officer, March, 1860; on special duty as president, Guzerat Wattan commission, Sept., 1864; superintendent, revenue survey, and assessment, Jan., 1867; on special duty to reorganise the salt department, Dec., 1869; officiating commissioner, Nagpur, Central Provinces, Sept., 1871, to Dec., 1872; municipal commissioner, Bombay, June, 1873; acting secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, general, and financial departments, May, 1875; junior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1877; on special duty to organise the licence tax, April, 1878; commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; retired, 1879; appointed secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India Office, June, 1879; royal commissioner of the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886; C.S.I., 1886.

PEDLER, A., F.I.C., F.C.S. (London and Berlin), Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed to the education department, 22nd Jan., 1873; arrived 8th May, 1873, and served in the 3rd class of the department as professor of agricultural chemistry, Presidency College; on special duty, eclipse expedition, March, 1875; officiating principal, Presidency College, Aug., 1883; also officiating meteorological reporter to government of Bengal, and officiating secretary to the central committee for management of the Economic Museum, 1884.

PEET, HENRY JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1860; arrived in India, and Oct., 1860; was employed under the military department till Oct., 1865, including service in the Bhutan Campaign, 1864-65; from Oct., 1866, served as assistant commissioner in Assam; assistant political officer in the Daffa expedition, 1874-75; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1875; officiating secretary, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1879; acting inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, and commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, June, 1881, to Feb., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1883.

PEILE, JAMES BRAITHWAITE, M.A., C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 8th Oct., 1855, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty, alienation department, Nov., 1858; on special duty for inquiry into claims of Thakurs of Bhavnagar on account of land and sea customs, May, 1859; especially appointed to inquire into condition of Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Jan., 1860; alienation settlement officer, Guzerat, April, 1861; assistant to revenue commissioner, Dec., 1861; under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue department, April, 1862; on special duty for carrying out provisions of bill for relief of the Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Dec., 1862; commissioner for revising subordinate civil establishments, April, 1866; registrar-general of assurances, July, 1866; director of public instruction, April, 1869; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, May-Oct., 1872; acting political agent, Kathiawar, Jan., 1873; on duty at Delhi in connection with Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876; acting commissioner in Sind, June, 1878; on special duty as member of famine commission, Aug., 1878, to March, 1879; acting secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, March, 1879; from April, 1879, served as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and acted as chief secretary; on special duty on famine commission in England, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; on special duty in India, Nov.-Dec., 1880, and in June, 1881, at Simla; member of council, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acted as governor and president in council in March, 1885; temporary member of governor-general's council, October, 1886; member of council of India, 1887.

PELLY, SIR LEWIS, Major-General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., M.P., Bombay Staff Corps.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1840; posted to the 17th N.I.; served as assistant resident, Baroda, and prosecuted the Khutput enquiries before the commission under Sir James Outram in 1851; deputy collector in Scinde, Dec., 1853; 2nd assistant commissioner for jaghirs, in Scinde, June, 1855; personal assistant to the commissioner, 1856; served in the Persian expedition as A.D.C. to General Jacob, and political secretary to Sir Jas. Outram (medal); brigade-major, Scinde frontier force, Dec., 1858; deputy magistrate, Kurrachee, June, 1859; secretary of legation, Persia, 1859; chargé-d'affaires, Persia, 1860; served on a special mission through Persia, Herat, Afghanistan, and Beloochistan, in 1860 and 1861; on special duty at Calcutta, with Lord Canning, 1861; on a mission to the Comoro Islands, 1861; political agent at Zanzibar, 1861-62; political resident in the Persian gulf, with local rank of lieutenant-colonel in Persia, from 1862 to 1873, during which period he was employed on various missions and negotiations with Arab chiefs in Arabia, and on the shores of the Persian Gulf, including a visit to the capital of the Wahabees, in 1865, and was associated with Sir Bartle Frere on an anti-slavery mission to the east coast of Africa and Arabia, in 1872 and 1873; agent to the governor-general, and chief commissioner, Rajputana, 1873 to 1878, and was deputed as special commissioner to Baroda in 1874, when he arrested the Guicowar, and took charge of the state; on special duty with the government of India in 1876; was appointed envoy extraordinary and plenipotentiary for Afghan affairs; K.C.S.I., June, 1874; K.C.B., Aug., 1877; has been a member of the council of the Royal Geographical Society, and of the Asiatic Society; author of a pamphlet on 'Our North-West Frontier,' 1858, 'Views and Opinions of General Jacob,' 'The Miracle Play of Hasan and Husein, collected from Oral Tradition,' 1870; was elected conservative member for North Hackney, Nov., 1885, and was re-elected in 1886.

PELLY, SAVILLE MARRIOTT, Inspector-general of Hospitals, C.B., late Bombay Medical Service.—Educated at Winchester College, and studied at the Bristol Infirmary, and Guy's Hospital, London; M.R.C.S., 1841; F.R.C.S., 1859; entered the Bombay medical service in June, 1841; served with various regiments till 1850, and was present in the Scinde campaigns, 1843-44-45, including capture of Shahpoor, and with Sir C. Napier's force at Bhawalpoor in 1846-47; assistant magistrate in Khandeish, 1850, and held charge of the Dhulia jail; transferred to Nassick, 1854; surgeon, Oct., 1855; served in Rajputana during the mutiny campaign, 1857-58 (medal and clasp for
Central India); deputy medical storekeeper, Kurraachee, 1862-1864; surgeon, 2nd district, Bombay, 1864; president of the municipal commission, Bombay, Sept., 1864, to July, 1865; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Scinde, April, 1867, and afterwards in the Poona division; served in the Abyssinian campaign as principal medical officer, Indian medical department, 1867-68 (medal and C.B.); retired, 1872; author of a paper on 'The Camel,' and a report on the municipality of Bombay, 1865.

PEMBERTON, ROBERT CHARLES BOILEAU, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1853; joined the public works department, May, 1857, and served in the Punjab on the Bari Doab canal; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, and the final capture of Lucknow (medal and two clasps); served subsequently in the road department, Oudh, as executive engineer; assistant secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865; acting under secretary to government of India, 1866-67; officiating superintending engineer, railway branch, Hyderabad, Sept., 1870; director of stores, railway branch, May, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; director-general of railways and deputy secretary, government of India, railway branch, Feb., 1887.

PEMBERTON, WILLIAM WALKER, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, July, 1853; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1853; served in the Burma commission from Dec., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner (May, 1873), small cause court judge, and boundary officer; 1st grade deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882.

PENNINGTON, HENRY FRANCIS DUMARESQ, Bengal C.S. (Oudh).—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, sub-judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, April, 1886.

PENNINGTON, JAMES BURN, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Sedburgh Grammar School, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, sub-secretary and acting secretary to the board of revenue, and acting collector of sea customs at Madras, and protector of emigrants; on special duty at Madras with the public works committee, Feb., 1866; acted as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, and political agent, Puducottah, Aug., 1872, to April, 1875; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, July, 1875; member of commission of special inquiry on emigration matters, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate and political agent, Tanjore, Sept., 1884.

PENNY, JAMES CHAMPION, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857; from Feb., 1863, served in the Punjab at various stations as civil assistant surgeon, and civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; brigade-surgeon, April, 1884.

PENNYCUICK, JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Dec., 1885; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1860; served in the Madras public works department from April, 1862; executive engineer, Dec., 1866; served in the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68 (medal); acting deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, April, 1879; superintending engineer, Oct., 1881; deputy chief engineer, and under secretary to government, Jan., 1883; superintendent of works, tank maintenance scheme, April, 1884; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government of Madras, Sept., 1886.

PERKINS, ÆNEAS, Major-General, C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1851; joined the public works department, March, 1855, and served in the Punjab; during the mutiny, 1857-58, served at the battle of Budleekeeserai and siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); assistant principal and professor, Calcutta Civil Engineering College, 1861; served with the Bhutan field force, 1864-65; served subsequently in Bengal as executive engineer and acting superintending engineer; acting superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1870; from April, 1872, served in the military works branch as superintending engineer, and was posted to the Meerut command in Jan., 1879, and to the Rawal Pindi command in March, 1881; was also on active service, Oct., 1878, as commanding engineer, field force, Kabul, and in Oct., 1879, Kuram division (medal and four clasps and bronze star); C.B., 1879; aide-de-camp to the Queen, March, 1881; acting deputy inspector-general of military works, April-July, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, Central Provinces, public works department, Feb., 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; chief engineer and secretary, Punjab, April, 1886.

PERKINS, HENRY EDMUND, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856, and served in the Punjab, and temporarily in Oudh, as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, Dec., 1864; promoted to deputy commissioner, April, 1866; commissioner and superintendent, Amritsar, April, 1877, and afterwards in the Mooltan and Rawal Pindi divisions; retired, Nov., 1886.

PERROTT, FINCH, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 24th Dec., 1880.

PETERSON, F. W., F.C.S., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Joined the mint department as assistant in the bullion office, Calcutta; between Jan., 1869, and Oct., 1881, acted for various periods as deputy assay master at the Calcutta mint, and at the Bombay mint, and also as assay master at the latter mint; appointed deputy assay master, Calcutta mint, Oct., 1881; acting assay master, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883, and again in 1884.

PETERSON, FREDERICK WILLIAM VOYSEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leicester Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 7th Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 3rd
grade, Dec., 1877; from May, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Sept., 1885.

PETERSON, Herbert Parsons, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Loughborough Grammar School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

PETERSON, Peter, M.A. (Ed.), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, and Jan., 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of oriental languages, Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as professor in the Deccan College, Poona, Oct., 1875-Nov., 1876; university registrar, Bombay, Jan., 1878; promoted to 3rd grade of the educational department, July, 1879; on leave to attend international oriental congress at Leyden, Aug.-Nov., 1883.

PETHERAM, Sir William Comer, Kt., Q.C.—Took his seat as chief justice of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1st Nov., 1884; chief justice, Calcutta, 24th March, 1886.

PETLEY, E. W., Lieutenant, R.N.—Deputy conservator of the port of Calcutta, and river surveyor, Oct., 1881.

PETRE, Francis Loraine (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oscott College, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Bareilly, April-Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Aug. to Nov., 1882; junior secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; from April, 1885, served under the foreign department, Government of India, as assistant agent to government-general in Central India.

PETTY, A. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 16th July, 1883.

PEYTON, William, Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, March, 1851, and served in Madras on military duty till Jan., 1866, and subsequently as deputy conservator of forests; from Oct., 1870, served in the Bombay presidency as conservator of forests (2nd grade, Dec., 1883).

PHAYRE, Sir Robert, Lieutenant-General, K.C.B., B.S.C.—Educated at Shrewsbury; ensign, Bombay army, 26th Jan., 1839; served in the first Afghan War and the Scinde campaign, 1840-1845, and was present at the action of Kotra and the battle of Meance (medal); deputy assistant quartermaster-general in Scinde, 1844-50; assistant quartermaster-general, 1850-1855; deputy quartermaster-general, Bombay army, Dec., 1855; in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867-68, served as quartermaster-general to the pioneer force, and conducted the reconnaissance of the Magdala position, and was present at the action of Aragoe (C.B., medal, and aide-de-camp to the Queen); political superintendent and commandant of the Scinde frontier field force, July, 1868 to 1872; resident at Baroda, March, 1873-74, during which period he brought charges of maladministration against the Gaekwar, which were investigated by a commission of enquiry; returned to military duty after the attempt of the Gaekwar to poison him at the end of 1874; brigadier-general, and in command at Nusseerabad, April, 1875; served in the Afghan War in 1879-80 in command of the reserve division, and the line of communication to Quetta, and took part in the relief of Candahar (thanks of both Houses of Parliament, K.C.B. and medal); major-general, Jan., 1880; in command of Mhow division, March, 1881, to Feb., 1886; lieutenant-general, Nov., 1881; acted as commander-in-chief, Bombay, Nov., 1885, to Feb., 1886; returned to England, March, 1886.

PHEAR, Sir John Budd, Knt.—Educated at Pembroke College, Cambridge; graduated 6th wrangler in 1847, and was elected fellow, and afterwards appointed mathematical lecturer and assistant tutor of Clare College; M.A., 1850; called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1854; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1864 to 1876; knighted in 1877; chief justice of Ceylon, 1877 to 1879; is justice of the peace and a chairman of quarter sessions for the county of Devon; unsuccessfully contested the Honiton division of Devon in 1885, and the Tavistock division in 1886; is fellow of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, and of the Geological Society, and president of the Devon association for the advancement of science, literature, and art; author of 'Elementary Mechanics,' 'Elementary Hydrostatics,' 'Rights of Water,' 'The Aryan Village in India and Ceylon,' 'International Trade,' and a presidential address to the Devonshire association of science, &c., on 'Domesday and the Early English Land System.'

PHELPS, W. E., Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal artillery, 30th Oct., 1869; served in the Bombay ordnance department, from Feb., 1876; served in the Quetta field force, 1878-80; transferred to Bengal ordnance department, May, 1881, and was promoted to sub-conductor, Aug., 1882; assistant in office of inspector-general of ordnance, Bengal, 1880-84; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, 17th June, 1884.

PHILIPPS, Herbert Rees, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Trinity College, Cambridge; Porson (Greek) University prizeman, 1871 and 1872; B.A., 1873; M.A., 1877; junior clerk, General Post Office, 1867; junior clerk, correspondence department, India office, estates and will branch, 1868; transferred to public works department, 1869; statistics and commerce department, 1874; attached in 1876 to select committee on the depreciation of silver, and edited report of committee; transferred to military department, 1883; senior clerk, July, 1883; compiled Parliamentary papers, Nos. 8 to 16 of statistical abstract relating to British India, Nos. 13 to 16 of statement exhibiting the moral and material progress of India.

PHILLIPS, A. (Barrister-at-Law).—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, from 1871; standing counsel, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1880.

PHILLIPS, Augustus Marshall, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, June, 1855; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1855; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); from March, 1863, served as assistant political
superintendent, Sávantvadi; assistant political agent, Mahi Kántha, Sádra, Gujerát, Feb., 1867; special assistant political agent in charge of estate of Gondal, Káthiáwar, July, 1872, to April, 1875; served subsequently as assistant political agent in Káthiáwar, and acted as superintendent of the Gáckwar's contingent, assistant in charge of Amreli Mahals, and superintendent, stud department, Káthiáwar, June, 1883; first assistant political agent, Káthiáwar, Sept., 1883; also acted as political agent in Káthiáwar, in Cutch, and in Mahi Kántha.

PHILLIPS, FRANCIS ANGELO THEODORE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces.)—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1880, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; acted as judge, small cause court, Nagpur, in 1883.

PHILLIPS, HENRY ARTHUR DEUTEROS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1874; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Bellary, Aug., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885; undersecretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1886; author of 'Indian Criminal Law,' 'Manual of Revenue and Collectorate Law,' and 'Our Administration of India.'

PHILLIPS, HENRY DOMINIC, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service in 1829; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge, and was appointed junior deputy secretary, board of revenue, 1837; acted as registrar, Sudder Dewani and Fojdari Adawlut, 1842-43; sub-judge, Madura, 1846; agent to governor of Madras, at Kurnool, 1847; collector and magistrate, Salem, 1850; civil and sessions judge at Mangalore, and at Madura, 1857; collector and magistrate and resident commissioner at Tanjore, 1853; puisne judge, Sudder Dewani and Fojdari Adawlut, 1858; president of the board of examiners; commissioner for the affairs of the late Raja of Tanjore, 1859; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; provisional member of council of governor of Fort St. George, 1864; member of Madras council, 16th Dec., 1864; resigned the service, 12th Nov., 1869.

PÍGOT, J. Q., B.A.—Advocate, high court, Bombay, 1870-82; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Bengal, 1882.

PIKE, HERBERT WATSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Honiton Grammar School, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1885; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

PILCHER, JESSE GRIGGS, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1860; officiating sanitary commissioner for Bengal, 26th April, 1875; officiating health officer for the port of Calcutta, April, 1876, to Feb., 1877; civil surgeon, Burdwan, June, 1876, and at Howrah, from Feb., 1877, with medical charge of the government engineering college, from April, 1880.

PINHEY, ARTHUR FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

PINHEY, ROBERT HILL (Barrister-at-Law), late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, joint judge and sessions judge, and registrar of the high court, Bombay; judge and sessions judge, Thana, Sept., 1863; acting judicial commissioner, and judge of the sadar court in Sind, Nov., 1869, to June, 1871; judge and sessions judge, and agent for Sardárs in the Deccan, Poona, April, 1873; judge of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1875; retired, 1885.

PITCHER, DUNCAN GEORGE, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 3rd Sept., 1859, having previously served in the royal marine light infantry and artillery, 1856-59; served under the military department till Aug., 1868, from which date he was employed in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; small cause court judge, Lucknow, April, 1873, to March, 1882, also serving as registrar, Lucknow, from Sept., 1873; member of commission appointed to inquire into the rights and privileges in Oudh forests, 1876; on special duty at Naini Tal, July, 1878; deputed to inquire into mortality statistics of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1878; deputy director of agriculture and commerce for Oudh, June, 1882, and for N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1886.

PITTAR, CHARLES WILLIAM ERSKINE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dacca, Nov., 1884.

PLACE, GEORGE WILLIAM, B.A., L.L.B., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Jan., 1886, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

PLANCK, CHARLES, F.R.C.S., F.S.S., Deputy Surgeon-General.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Feb., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Fatehgarh, July, 1859; superintendent, central prison, Agra, Feb., 1862; inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, Oct., 1864; sanitary commissioner and compiler of mortuary returns, N.W. Provinces, April, 1868, also in Oudh, April, 1877; also superintendent-general of vaccination, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Aug., 1881; retired, Aug. 1886.

PLANT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Colonel, M.S.C.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 9th June, 1855; served in the Burma commission from March, 1860, as assistant magistrate of Rangoon, assistant commissioner
and deputy commissioner, and officiated at various times as commissioner in the Arakan, Pegu, Tenasserim, and Irrawaddy divisions; appointed commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1883.

PLAYFAIR, ARCHIBALD LEWIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, Aug., 1856; arrived 22nd Nov., 1856; during the mutiny served at the Alam Bagh, and siege and capture of Lucknow (medal and clasp); served with the Hyderabad contingent, 1862-1873; served subsequently in civil employ as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; superintendent of central jail, and penitentiary, Hazareebagh, March, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1875; cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1879-84, and subsequently at Mhow.

PLOWDEN, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Feb., 1854; arrived in India, 28th April, 1854; was employed under the military department till May, 1860, including service in the mutiny, 1858-9; served from May, 1860, in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, in 1867-68, and was appointed commissioner of excise, inspector-general of registration, and superintendent of stamps, Sept., 1880, and deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Saugor, Nov., 1884.

PLOWDEN, GEORGE WARD CHICHELE, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India, as cornet, Bengal light cavalry, 4th April, 1854; was employed under the military department till Sept., 1874, including service in the mutiny campaign; present at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief of Lucknow, Cawnpore, &c. (medal and three clasps); from Sept., 1874, served in the N.W. Provinces as cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, and subsequently of Meerut; promoted to 1st class cantonment magistrate, March, 1876.

PLOWDEN, SIR HENRY M. KT. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab from 17th March, 1871, as government advocate and officiating judge of the chief court; confirmed as judge, chief court, Jan., 1878; knighted, Feb., 1887.

PLOWDEN, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1868; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, March, 1872, and Jan., 1873; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1873; inspector-general of police, Assam, Nov., 1876; on special duty as secretary to the prison conference, Jan., 1877; acted as under secretary, government of India, foreign department, from Jan., 1877, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1878; resident, 2nd class, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, March, 1880; consul-general, Baghdad, June, 1880; made a tour on Turco-Persian frontier, June-Sept., 1881; visited Karbala and Najaf, Nov., 1881, and Samara, Takrit, and the Upper Tigris, in April, 1885; commissioner of Ajmere-Merwara, June, 1885; resident in Meywar, Nov., 1885; resident in Kashmir, April, 1886.

PLOWDEN, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Lieu-
tenant-Colonel, C.I.E., Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1859; from May, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; in attendance upon the Peshawur Darbaris to visit the Prince of Wales at Lahore, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; also district judge; has published translations of the Khalid-i-Afghani and the Ganji-Pakhto, also a collection of Pushto Colloquial Sentences, and 'Adam Khan and Durkhani,' an Afghan novelette.

PLOWDEN, SIR WILLIAM CHICHELE, K.C.S.I., F.S.S., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1852; arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1852; from Nov., 1853, served in the revenue and judicial department in the N.W. Provinces, Oudh, and Punjab, and was appointed deputy commissioner, Aug., 1858, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1863; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, July, 1864; on special duty in connection with the census report, April, 1866, and again, May, 1872; magistrate and collector, March, 1870; civil and sessions judge, March, 1877; on special duty at Calcutta as president of census committee, Jan., 1878; commissioner, Meerut division, Sept., 1879; officiating member, board of revenue, Aug., 1880; census commissioner for India, March, 1881; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881; retired, July, 1885.

POLLEN, ARTHUR DANIEL, B.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting remembrancer of legal affairs; on special duty as joint sessions judge at Surat, Aug., 1878; special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, Jan., 1880; and grade judge and sessions judge, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge, Feb., 1886.

POLLEN, JOHN, B.A., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate; on famine relief duty, Dinagepore, Bengal, March, 1874; on special settlement duty, March, 1879; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, Dec., 1880; assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration and stamps in Sind, April, 1882; also Sindhi translator to government, Nov., 1881.

POLLOCK, SIR FREDERICK RICHARD, Major-General, K.C.S.I.—Educated at King's College School; appointed an Indian cadet of infantry, June, 1844; assistant resident, Lahore, Nov., 1847; on the Sikh outbreak in 1848 accompanied the Ferozepore column to Mooltan as political officer, and served during the double siege of Mooltan, under Sir H. Edwardes (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner in charge of Kohat district, April, 1849, and afterwards at Peshawur and Bannu; employed in the expedition under Sir Charles Napier against the Affreedees in the Kohat Pass, 1850 (medal and clasp); civil and political officer with the expe-
dition against the Omurzye Wuzeerees; deputy commissioner, Dera Ghazi Khan, March, 1854, and afterwards at Rawul Pindi; accompanied Brigadier-General Chamberlain's expedition to the Border Hills as civil officer, 1857; commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, 1867; political commissioner with the Hazara field force, 1868; employed in Afghanistan and Persia with the Seistan Commission, 1871-72; commissioner of Peshawur up to 1878; retired from the army, May, 1879.

POLLOCK, GEORGE D., Store Department, India Office.—Examiner of surgical instruments, store depot, Oct., 1857.

PONNUSWAMI PILLAI, TIRU VENKATA, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from the 15th April, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the public works, military, and judicial departments, and was appointed 1st grade district munsif, April, 1866, principal sudr amin, July, 1872, and sub judge, June, 1874; from May, 1880, acted as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1883; board of examiners, June, 1884; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, March, 1885.

PONTIFEX, CHARLES, Legal Adviser, India Office.—B.A., Trinity College, Cambridge, 1854; called to the bar, May, 1854; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, May, 1872; retired in 1882 on appointment as legal adviser to secretary of state for India.

POPE, J. VAN SOMEREN, M.A. (Cantab.), Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 17th June, 1876, and served as professor at the Patna and Presidency Colleges, and as principal, Dacca College, Oct., 1881, and was promoted to 3rd class, education department, April, 1883; inspector of schools, April, 1884; fellow of the Calcutta University, March, 1886.

POPE, RICHARD RODNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, April, 1885.

PORTEOUS, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1879; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner.

PORTEOUS, CHARLES ARKOLL, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived, 26th Nov., 1856; ensign, 1st regiment of native infantry, Madras, Dec., 1856; was employed in the suppression of the mutiny, and was present at several engagements, 1857-1859 (medal and two clasps); served in the Madras police department from May, 1860, as assistant superintendent, and superintendent; in charge of the Madras police at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; deputy inspector-general, July, 1883.

PORTEOUS, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Jan., 1874, to April, 1878, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner, acting town and cantonment magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner, also acting as deputy inspector-general of police, July-Oct., 1876, and assistant sessions judge, Oct., 1877-March, 1878; from April, 1878, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector of salt revenue, Bombay, July to Nov., 1881, and Feb.-Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Kaira, and political agent, Cambay, Nov., 1886.

PORTER, ALEXANDER, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., M.R.I.A., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1865, and served under the military department in the Central Provinces, also holding the civil surgery of Akola, with charge of the jail, from May, 1866, to April, 1874, and acting as sanitary commissioner, Berar, 1870-71; from April, 1874, served in Madras, and acted as fort surgeon and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, and as chemical examiner to government, and professor of chemistry and hygiene, March, 1876, to Jan., 1877; surgeon-major, March, 1877; from Jan., 1877, served as surgeon, 4th district, Madras, and also as professor of medical jurisprudence in the Medical College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883; principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Dec., 1886; author of 'Notes on the Pathology of Famine Diseases.'

PORTER, FORTESCUE WILLOUGHBY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Felstead Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1869, to 1878, served in the settlement department, and was promoted to settlement officer, 3rd grade, April, 1877; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1885; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1886.

PORTER, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Felstead Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1874; also served as inspector of schools, Feb., 1866, to Nov., 1868, and as deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, May, 1874, to April, 1875; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; and was promoted to 1st grade, Sept., 1884; officiated as judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, from March, 1884, and was confirmed in that appointment, Oct., 1885; officiating judge, high court, Calcutta, Feb., 1886.

PORTER, JOHN SINCLAIR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from June, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputy commissioner,
Lalitpur, Oct., 1874; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Jhansi, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1877; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1879; acted as opium agent, Benares, May-Aug., 1886, and as commissioner of the Allahabad division, Sept.-Oct., 1886.

PORTER, Leslie Alexander Selim, M.A., LL.D., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces.)—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1878, to Jan., 1883; joint magistrate, April, 1886.

PORTMAN, Augustus Berkeley, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1860, and was employed on military duties till May, 1866, and subsequently served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and superintendent of railway police on the Bombay, Baroda and C.I. and Great Indian Peninsula railways; on special duty, Bombay, Feb.-March, 1874; acting inspector-general of registration and stamps, March to June, 1879, and March, 1880, to Sept., 1883; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, Jan., 1885.

POSFORD, Joseph, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1883.

POULTON, Henry D., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 26th Dec., 1873.

POWER, Ambrose William Bushe (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated in Germany, and at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, deputy commissioner and political agent, Hill Tipperah; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, January, 1880; officiating magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Shahabad, March, 1885.

POWER, Guy Francis Thomas, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting principal assistant; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884; additional sessions judge in the agency tracts of Vizagapatam, May, 1885.

POWLETT, Percy William, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 58th native infantry, Bengal, April, 1855; during the mutiny, 1857-58, served at the siege and capture of Lucknow and other operations (medal and clasps); assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1862; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Berar, 1865; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1868; settlement officer, Ulwar, Jan., 1871; political agent, Kota, Jan., 1877; political agent for the Western Rajputana states, 1880; resident, Western Rajputana, Dec., 1881.

PRATT, James, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen, and London Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Oct., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, January, 1883.

PREECE, H. C., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Dec., 1885.

PRENDERGAST, Hew Lindsay, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—1st commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853, and served in Burma on military duty, and as executive engineer, Bassin, till Nov., 1854, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer; on military duty, Feb., 1855, to Nov., 1857; from Nov., 1857, served in the public works department as garrison engineer, Madras, district engineer, and acting deputy consulting engineer for railways, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, July, 1865; acting controller and auditor, public works accounts, Madras, Jan., 1864; acting consulting engineer for railways, April, 1870; on military duty, May, 1874, to May, 1876; supervising engineer, Oct., 1878; superintendent of works, presidency, July to Oct., 1880, and again in 1881; in charge of Buckingham canal, 1880; supervising engineer, 1st class, April, 1884; officiating chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, Sept.-Dec., 1885.

PRENTIS, Charles, Surgeon-Major, M.R.C.S., L.R.C.S., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th Jan., 1858; arrived in India, 25th June, 1858, and served under the military department; from March, 1864, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Mainpuri, June, 1864; officiating superintendent of Central Prison and Lunatic Asylum, Bareilly, 1866; transferred to Gorakhpur, March, 1869; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1870; superintendent of government observatory, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1873.

PRICE, James Cattarall, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; settlement officer, Midnapore, Dec., 1871; also superintendent of survey, March, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; author of 'Notes on the History of Midnapore.'

PRICE, John Frederick, Madras, C.S.—University of Melbourne; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive ex-
amination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent for Pondicherry, April, 1878; collector and magistrate, Chingleput, Sept., 1878; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Madras, April, 1885; acting secretary to government revenue department, Oct., 1885.

PRIDEAUX, WILLIAM FRANCIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1860; assistant political resident, Aden, from April, 1864; attached to mission to King Theodore of Abyssinia, March, 1865, and was in captivity at Magdala, July, 1866, to April, 1868; officiated as political agent, Zanzibar, 1873-75; fellow of Bombay University, Jan., 1874; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1875; officiating political resident, Persian Gulf, 1876-79; political agent, Bhopal, March, 1879; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, Calcutta, Nov., 1880; officiating resident, Eastern Rajputana states, Feb., 1882, to Jan., 1883.

PRIEST, HENRY HALSTED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Real-Schule, Marburg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd December, 1879, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1883, to May, 1884; acted as political agent, Bhowani Patna, in 1884 and 1885, and as deputy commissioner; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1885.

PRIMROSE, ARTHUR JOHN, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1879, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating political agent, Manipur.

PRINGLE, ROBERT KEITH, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1820; arrived in India, 1821, and served in the Bombay revenue department; superintendent of revenue survey and assessment of the Deccan, 1826; first assistant to collector of Ahmednagar, 1831; sub-collector and magistrate, Sholapur, 1837; acting deputy civil auditor and deputy mint-master, 1838; collector and magistrate, and political agent, Khandeish, Dec., 1840; secretary to government, Bombay, general department, June, 1843; revenue commissioner, July, 1843; chief secretary to government, Bombay, revenue and finance departments, government director of the Bank of Bombay, and master of the mint, April, 1846; acting member of council, Bombay, April, 1846; chief commissioner of Sind, July, 1847; resigned, Feb., 1851.

PRINSEP, HENRY THOBY, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Nov., 1856; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1860; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1861; registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, Feb., 1862, and subsequently of the high court, July, 1862; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1866; officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, May, 1866; served in the judicial department from Feb., 1867, as district and sessions judge, and officiated as judicial commissioner of Mysore, March, 1875, to July, 1876; lieutenant-governor's council; 1st grade district judge, Sept., 1875; judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1878.

PITCHARD, CHARLES BRADLEY, C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 24th Jan., 1858, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty at Poona for investigating frauds committed by subordinates in the public works department, Oct., 1870, to Oct., 1871; collector of salt revenue, Bombay presidency, Feb., 1873; on special duty in Madras as president of the salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; on special duty to submit a scheme for the working of the abkari system, May, 1877, to March, 1878; commissioner of customs, opium, abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, April, 1881; 1st grade commissioner and commissioner of salt revenue, Oct., 1882.

PROPERT, WILLIAM HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Feb., 1876, served as collector and magistrate and political agent, Khandaish; senior collector, Sept., 1877; also acted as commissioner, Northern division, April, 1883; was on special duty, Poona, July-Oct., 1883; commissioner, Southern division, April, 1886.

PUCKLE, RICHARD KAYE, C.I.E., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Haileybury College; entered the Madras civil service in 1851, and was appointed deputy director of revenue settlement in 1859; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, 1866; director of revenue settlement, 1874, and member of board of revenue, 1879; was engaged for 22 years in preparing data for the re-assessment of the lands, and for the revision of government establishments in the ryotwari villages of Madras; published a handbook on revenue matters and the duties of village officers; was specially employed in the distressed districts in famine of 1877; C.I.E., 1878; retired in 1881.

PULFER, J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 3rd Aug., 1865; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; India store depot.

PULLAN, AVTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Arrived in India, 29th April, 1856; first commission as ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; was employed under the military department till April, 1862, including service during the mutiny, and was present at the siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); officiating assistant political agent and bazaar master, Morar, April-June, 1862; joined the great trigonometrical survey as 2nd assistant, Jan., 1863; acted as deputy superintendent from Dec., 1871, and was appointed to the charge of the Kathiawar survey, April, 1873; was afterwards employed in the
survey of Cutch; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

PUNNETT, HENRY BEATSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Falmouth Grammar School, and Boston Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Nov., 1886.

PURSER, WILLIAM EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was placed on special duty, May and Dec., 1879; senior settlement officer and deputy commissioner of settlement, Jullundur, Sept., 1880; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of the Montgomery District, and on the Settlements of the Muktars and Mamdot Parganas.'

PURVES, HENRY BLACK, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—1st commission, 1865; from 12th March, 1867, served as civil assistant surgeon, and civil surgeon, in various stations in Bengal; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, Aug., 1885; officiating medical inspector of emigrants, July, 1885; civil surgeon, Patna, and superintendent, Temple Medical School, Oct., 1885.

PUTNAM, P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 28th July, 1881.

PYCROFT, SIR THOMAS, K.C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, and Trinity College, Oxford, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1828; served in various offices in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from 1829 to 1839; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, Madras, 1843-44; secretary to the board of revenue, 1845-50; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue and judicial departments, 1850-55; chief secretary to government of Madras, 1855-62; member of Madras council, 1862 to 1867, in which year he retired from the service.

QUIN, HENRY OSBORNE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1885; assistant collector, Jan., 1886.

QUINLAN, FRANCIS PETER, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the accounts branch, Oct., 1870, and was employed on the accounts of various railways in the grades of accountant, assistant examiner, assistant controller, and deputy examiner; Northern Bengal state railway, Dec., 1879; acting manager, June-Sept., 1881; promoted to examiner, Sept., 1881; Punjab northern state railway, March, 1883; on special duty, Sept.-Oct., 1883, to revise state railway revenue code; examiner and auditor of accounts, Eastern Bengal state railway, July, 1884; also acted as examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Aug.-Oct., 1884; examiner, 3rd class, Dec., 1886.

QUINN, CHARLES CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 8th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and grade, Oct., 1884.

QUINN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was appointed deputy commissioner, Oudh, April, 1877, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Ballia, Dec., 1881; commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1884; officiated as judicial commissioner, Oudh, in 1884.

QUINTON, JAMES WALLACE, B.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces from Oct., 1857, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; served in Oudh from March, 1865, to April, 1875, as deputy commissioner, and officiated as commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1869; officiating judicial commissioner, British Burma, April, 1875, to March, 1877; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, April, 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, April, 1878; on special duty at Naini Tal as member of N.W. Provinces famine commission, July, 1878; commissioner, Jhansi division, April, 1880, and Lucknow division, Feb., 1882; additional member of governor-general's council, Feb., 1883, and again in 1884 and 1886; commissioner, Agra division, April, 1884; junior member, board of revenue, March, 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

RAIKES, FREDERICK DUNCAN, Captain, C.I.E., Bo. S.C., Burma Commission.—Arrived in Bombay, as ensign, H.M.'s 66th regiment, 1st April, 1870; acted as superintendent of bazaars and commissariat officer, Hyderabad, Sind, 1871; Bombay staff corps, Feb., 1873; acting assistant superintendent of police, Panch Mehalas, March, 1873; from May, 1873, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant town magistrate, Rangoon, 1874-75; transferred to Upper Burma, Feb., 1886; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

RAJANINATH RAY, M.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, and was attached to the office of the comptroller-general, Nov., 1872; served in the Central Provinces, May, 1874, to Jan., 1876, and afterwards in Bombay as assistant to the commissioner of paper currency, and assistant to the accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, Nov., 1882; class iv., financial department, April, 1885; has also served as deputy accountant-general, Bombay, Aug.-Nov., 1885, and in Bengal, March, 1886.

RAJENDRA CHANDRA CHANDRA, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; from July, 1863, served as civil assistant surgeon, also officiating as sub-assistant commissioner, Deoghar, from July, 1864; surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; officiating civil surgeon, Midnapore, July, 1874; professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex-officio physician to the College Hospital, Feb., 1875; was also appointed surgeon to the mint and officer of the
customs preventive service, Jan., 1878, and medical inspector of emigrants, May, 1881.

RAMESHAWARASING KUMAR, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules, and served as assistant magistrate and collector on probation in Bengal from March, 1878; confirmed in his appointment in the Bengal civil service, March, 1881; resigned, 1886.

RAPPINI, ROBERT FULTON, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 28th Nov., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1880; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, July, 1880, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1883; also served as officiating inspector of schools, Sept., 1873; district and sessions judge, Burdwan, April 1887; edited Bengal Tenancy Act (VIII.) of 1885.

RAMSAY, HON. SIR HENRY, Lieutenant-General, K.C.S.I., C.B., Bengal S.C.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; from Aug., 1840, served as junior assistant to commissioner in Kumaon; senior assistant to commissioner in Gharwal, Nov., 1845; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49 (medal); commissioner, Kumaon, Feb., 1856 to 1884.

RAMSAY, HENRY LUSHINGTON, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, Feb., 1874; served with the 6th royal regiment at Sialkot, and subsequently with 9th Bengal cavalry; acted as assistant to agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Dec., 1877, to March, 1878; junior attaché, foreign department, March, 1878; political officer on staff of Major-General Sir F. S. Roberts with the Kuram field force, Sept., 1879; present at defence of Sherpur (medal and clasp); senior attaché, foreign department, June, 1880; acted as assistant secretary, foreign department, June-July, 1880; assistant to agent, governor-general, Rajputana, Oct., 1880; magistrate at Abu, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, Nov., 1880; assistant agent, Beloochistan, June, 1882, to May, 1883; consul at Basra, May-Oct., 1883; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Nov., 1883; British joint commissioner of Leh, Sept., 1885.

RAMSAY, HERBERT MAYNARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry.—First commission, 1860; from 2nd July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector general; on special duty to Cachar, March, 1866; 1st grade district superintendent, April, 1886.

RAND, WALTER CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

RANSOM, HENRY EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 12th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

RATTON, JAMES JOSEPH LOUIS, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.R.C.S., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 16th April, 1868; served in the Abyssinian expedition (medal), and in various military medical charges; also as civil surgeon, Central Provinces, 1869-70; on special duty for the board of revenue, Madras, in connection with salt manufacture, from Jan., 1872, to Nov., 1876 (including one month in South of France); in medical charge of East Coast canal, famine relief works, Dec., 1876; Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail, Chittoor, April, 1877; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; acting president, board of medical examiners, Oct., 1884; surgeon, General Hospital, Madras, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery in the Medical College, Feb., 1885; acting principal, Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug.-Sept., 1885; member of salt committee, Feb., 1886; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; besides official reports on salt manufacture, &c., has published a 'Handbook on Common Salt,' a 'Treatise on Tetanus,' and a 'Syllabus of Surgery.'
