WARD, DAVID, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Sept., 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege and assault of Delhi, and Lucknow, and various other operations and engagements (medal and two clasps); joined the public works department, Feb., 1859, as assistant engineer, Oude; Chakrata division, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1868; transferred to military works, 1872; superintending engineer, Lahore, March, 1877, and subsequently at Meerut; superintending engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1882; chief engineer, 3rd class, and secretary, P.W. Department, Central Provinces, April, 1886.

WARD, GEORGE ERNEST, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Jaunpur, July, 1879; on special duty on the education commission under the government of India, 1882; commissioner, Jhansi division, July, 1885.

WARD, HENRY CONSTANTINE EVELYN, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, as ensign, April, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service at the siege and assault of Delhi, 1857 (medal and clasp), and at the battle of Narnoul, Nov., 1857; served also with Eusufye expedition, 1858, and in the campaign against the Mahsood Waziris, 1859-60 (frontier medal); assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; acting inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Nov., 1873; additional commissioner for the administration of affairs in Kalahadi, June, 1882; acting commissioner, Chhattisgarh division, March-Nov., 1883, and again in 1884; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1885; on special duty as special commissioner for the repression of dacoity in Nerbudda division, Feb., 1886; from June, 1886,
served under the government of India, as minister of the Bhopal state.

WARD, WILLIAM ERSKINE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1861, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866, and again in 1867, and in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March, 1873; officiating magistrate of police, Calcutta, April, 1873; from Oct., 1873, served in judicial department as acting district and sessions judge, and was transferred to Assam, March, 1876, and served as judge and commissioner of Assam Valley districts; officiated temporarily as judicial commissioner of Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; fellow of University of Calcutta; officiating chief commissioner of Assam, July-Oct., 1883; president of provincial committee for collecting exhibits of Assam for Calcutta Exhibition, 1883; judicial commissioner, Burma, May, 1886.

WARREN, AUGUSTUS BROOKE, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Kensington Grammar School, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, March, 1856; judge and sessions judge, and agent for governor, Surat, 1861; acting judge of the high court, May, 1863; judge and sessions judge of Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, Sept., 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1865; was also president of the departmental examinations committee for junior civilians for five years; retired, 1871.

WARREN, CHARLES JAMES HISLOP, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1874; from 18th March, 1876, acted as civil surgeon of Bhagulpore, with medical charge of the central jail; on special duty in the excise department, board of revenue, Dec., 1876; officiating principal assistant to the opium agent, Behar, April-Oct., 1878; officiating superintendent, central jail, Bhagulpore, Nov.-Dec., 1879; professor of chemistry, Medical College, and chemical and opium examiner to government, Dec., 1879; member of opium committee, Oct., 1880; surgeon-major, March, 1886.

WARREN, FREDERICK, Captain, Marine Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian navy, 2nd March, 1852; from Dec., 1865, served as port-master of Canning, and, in addition (from Jan., 1867), as assistant collector of customs and ex-officio superintendent of customs; from Dec., 1866, acted as assistant master attendant, and agent for government consignments, Calcutta, and from March, 1870, as agent for transports; also government prosecutor for trial of pilots, May, 1873, to March, 1876; officiating deputy master attendant, Aug., 1875; officiated as port officer, March, 1876, to Aug., 1879, and performed duties of superintendent of dockyard, from March, 1876, to Nov., 1877; assistant port officer, Aug., 1879; examiner in navigation, Nov., 1879; transferred to Rangoon as port officer, March, 1882; also superintendent of lighthouses, superintendent of mercantile marine, and transport agent.

WARREN, JOHN LODWICK, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 8th March, 1852, and served in the Bombay covenanted civil service as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and deputy magistrate in charge of the Adalat, Hyderabad; resigned the covenanted civil service, May, 1858; appointed extra assistant secretary to government of Bombay, in the judicial department, Dec., 1866; assistant judge and sessions judge, April, 1867, to June, 1868; acting magistrate of police, July-Oct., 1868; from Jan., 1869, served as small cause court judge, and was appointed 3rd judge, at Bombay, Dec., 1874.

WARRE, SIR HENRY JAMES, General, K.C.B.,—Obtained commission from Sandhurst, 1836; ensign, 54th foot, 3rd Feb., 1837; from 1839 served as aide-de-camp to commander of the forces in British North America (Sir R. Downes Jackson, K.C.B.); during 1845 and 1846 was employed by colonial office in exploring a route for transport of troops from Canada to the Red River settlement, by Ottawa, and in surveying and reporting on the various settlements in the Oregon Territory, and on various islands on the coast of the Pacific; served in the Crimea from March, 1855, and succeeded to the command of the 57th regiment; present at the siege and fall of Sebastopol, the assaults on the Redan, and the surrender of Kinbourn (medal with clasp, C.B., 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); in 1858 was in command of a mixed force on the Taptee River in co-operation with the Central India field force, and was subsequently appointed brigadier at Mhow; military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (Lieutenant-General Sir Hugh Rose, K.C.B.), June, 1860; served in the Maori war in New Zealand, 1861, and acted for a short time as governor of the province of Auckland; was subsequently in command of the troops on the west coast, and in the province of Taranaki (under martial law), 1862-66 (medal); from 1870-74 was stationed in Ireland as brigadier-general; commander-in-chief, and member of governor's council, Bombay, Nov., 1878 to 1881.

WATERFIELD, HENRY, C.B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; junior clerk, 1st Sept., 1853; India board, financial and railway department, 1853; political and secret department, 1856; private secretary to president of the India board, 1858; India office, financial department, 1858; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1860; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, April, 1863; assistant secretary in the military department, 1867; public works department, 1871; secretary in the statistics and commerce department, 1874; secretary, financial department, 1879; C.B., Dec., 1885; author of the first report on the moral and material progress of India, 1866, and of a memorandum on the census of British India of 1871-72, both of which were presented to Parliament.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal C.S. from Haileybury in 1852; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1852; served in Bengal in the revenue and survey departments till 1859, when he was transferred to the financial department as 1st assistant to the accountant.
general for India; acted as sub-treasurer, Madras, and as civil auditor and superintendent of stamps, Madras, Calcutta, and Bombay; from 1864 to 1877 served successively as civil paymaster, deputy accountant-general, and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; comptroller-general, 1877-80; retired, 1881.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM GARROW, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1852; from Sept., 1857, served in the Punjab as personal assistant to commissioner of Delhi, and assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1863, to Nov., 1865; assistant settlement officer, Gujarat, Nov., 1865; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1867; on special duty for reporting on the Gujarat settlement, July, 1868; commissioner and sessions judge, Peshawur, Feb., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Sept., 1878; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (with the Kurri field force); served under the foreign department of the government of India, 1881-82; author of a report on the settlement of the Gujarat district.

WATERHOUSE, JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1859; assistant revenue surveyor, Lower Provinces, June, 1866; assistant surveyor with superintendence of the photozincographic operations in the office of the surveyor-general of India, July, 1866; assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1870; on special duty with the Indian eclipse expedition, Nov., 1871, to Jan., 1872; and for observing the transit of Venus, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; in charge of Indian eclipse expedition to Nicobar Islands, March, 1875; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Jan., 1884; author of a pamphlet on "The Application of Photography to the Reproduction of Maps and Plans."

WATERS, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st Oct., 1860; arrived in India, 27th May, 1870, and served in the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, Bombay, and civil surgeon at Bushire (1871-75); on special duty under the government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March-April, 1877; surgeon to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; from Oct., 1881, served as third physician and registrar, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, curator of the pathological museum, and professor of pathology, Grant Medical College; also acted as second physician and professor of physiology.

WATKINS, LAWRENCE AUGUSTUS, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1863; served in the Bombay judicial department from Jan., 1865, as deputy registrar of the high court, clerk to the high court judges, and commissioner for taking affidavits; also acted as assistant commissioner for taking accounts, and assistant taxing master, Aug.-Oct., 1878.

WATSON, H. E., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 29th June, 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, June, 1879; in charge of the special duty of the salt department in Sind, July-Oct., 1880; on special duty in the military department, June, 1881; head assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, June, 1885.

WATSON, Sir JOHN, Major-General, K.C.B., V.C., Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1848; from Sept., 1871, served as commandant, Central India Horse and political agent; resident, 2nd class, and agent to the governor-general at Gwalior, April, 1877, also acting as agent for Central India; brigadier-general commanding cavalry brigade, Malta expeditionary force, 1878; commanding Punjab chiefs' contingent in Afghanistan, 1878-79; in political charge of the district of Kuram, Nov., 1879, to Nov., 1880; resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1882; retired from the political department, March, 1886.

WATSON, JOHN WHALEY, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 6th Oct., 1854, and served under the military department till Feb., 1863, and subsequently in the political department as political assistant and acting political agent, Káthiáwár; also acted as assistant resident, Baroda, and superintendent of Gaéckwár's contingent, Oct., 1863; special assistant, Gondal, March, 1872; acting political superintendent of Pálánpur, March, 1873, and political agent, Rewa Kánthá, March, to Nov., 1876; appointed joint administrator of Bávnagar, March, 1877; president of the Rajasthánik court, Káthiáwár, July, 1878; acting political agent, Kolhapúr and Southern Mahratta country, May, 1885; political agent, Káthiáwár, Jan., 1886.

WATT, G., M.D., C.I.E., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th July, 1873; arrived, 4th Nov., 1873; served in the 3rd class of the Bengal education department as professor, Presidency, Hooghly, and Patna Colleges, and as officiating principal, Krishnagur College, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Burma-Munipore boundary expedition, Oct., 1881; services placed at disposal of executive committee of the Calcutta International Exhibition, Feb., 1883; served under government of India, revenue and agricultural department, from May, 1884; C.I.E., June, 1886.

WATTS, CHARLES WILLIAM PAXTON, Bengal C.S. North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1859; served in the Punjab from Jan., 1860, to Nov., 1866, as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and appointed assistant settlement officer, and grade, Nov., 1866; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1867; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, July, 1877; civil and sessions judge, and grade, Saharanpur, June, 1884.

WEBB, W. T., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 6th April, 1875; professor, Dacca College, May, 1875; officiated as inspector of schools, Feb., 1877; professor, Presidency College, from Jan., 1878; officiating principal, Calcutta Madrassa, in addition to other duties, Oct., 1880; 3rd class, education department, Dec., 1880; has published 'Hints on the Study of English,' 'Indian Lyrics,' and translations.

WEBSTER, EDMUND FORSTER (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857;
served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Madura, May, 1867, and afterwards at Cuddalore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, June, 1873, and at Trichinopoly, Aug., 1873; collector and magistrate and agent, Tanjore, April, 1878; on special duty in connection with the famine commission, Oct., 1878, and again, Aug., 1881, as secretary to the famine code committee; member of the forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1882; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, July, 1883, and again, July, 1885, and March, 1886; chief secretary to government of Madras, Jan., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1885.

WEBSTER, HENRY BINNY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 17th June, 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Nov., 1867, and subsequently at Gorakhpur and Meerut; commissioner, Jhansi division, Jan., 1878; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; retired, 1886.

WEDDERBURN, FRANCIS EDWARD KEIR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

WEDDERBURN, SIR WILLIAM, Bart., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 25th Nov., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judicial assistant to the commissioner in Sind, and small cause court judge; acting under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1866; acting registrar-general of assurances, Oct., 1866; acting secretary to government in the judicial, political, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Dec., 1866, and again in 1870 and 1874; under secretary to government, judicial and political departments, May, 1867; acting registrar, high court, Jan., 1869; acting judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the sadar court, May, 1874, to Feb., 1876; and grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1875; on special duty in Bombay, Nov., 1876; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, May, 1882; on special duty under government of India, April-May, 1884; acting judge, high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886.

WEEKES, ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; on famine relief duty at Madras, Feb., 1877.

WEIDEMANN, GEORGE LEVER, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1870, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner (3rd grade, May, 1884); on special duty in Rangoon, July, 1879.

WEIR, CHARLES JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal Belfast Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; from May, 1884, served in Coorg as officiating first assistant commissioner and district magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Oct., 1886.

WEIR, JOHN WILLIAM ALLEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin School, Hammersmith, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

WEIR, PATRICK ALEXANDER, Surgeon, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service 1875; officiating 2nd resident surgeon, presidency general hospital, 22nd Aug., 1876; on special duty with lieutenant-governor on tour in cyclone districts, Nov., 1876; superintendent of vaccination, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, March, 1882; principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1882.

WEIR, THOMAS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1867, and served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate; deputy registrar, high court, Jan., 1870, to June, 1872; acted as registrar, high court, Feb., 1874, to Feb., 1880; Tamil translator to government, Jan., 1879; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Godavari, March, 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; confirmed as registrar, high court, April, 1882; published the law of offences and criminal procedure, and the civil digest of rules and standing orders of the high court; from July, 1883, acted as district and sessions judge in the districts of Coimbatore, North Tanjore, and Madura, and was placed on special duty in connection with the reorganization of the subordinate judicial service, Nov., 1883; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1886.

WEIR, T. S., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1870; health officer, Bombay, from 1874; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

WELD, MATTHEW RICHARD, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dublin University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan.-March, 1885, and as collector and magistrate in the same district from April, 1885.
WELDON, THOMAS, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Joined Addiscombe, Jan., 1852; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 12th April, 1854; from July, 1860, served in the Madras police department as assistant superintendent and superintendent; senior magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1867; on special duty, in connection with the note forgery case, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; chief magistrate of police, Madras, April, 1877, on special duty in Burma in connection with the commissariat case, Nov., 1879; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; commissioner of police for town of Madras, Dec., 1885.

WELLS, WALTER FOX WILLIAMSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, Oct., 1885.

WELLS, WILLIAM, Accounts Department, Burma.—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency in Sind, June, 1865, also editor of Sind portion of 'Gazetteer,' and deputy branch registrar-general in Sind, Nov., 1868; from April, 1871, to Jan., 1882, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general, and assistant commissioner of paper currency (April, 1877), and officiated as deputy accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; from Jan., 1882, served in the Punjab as officiating deputy accountant-general, and officiating accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency; transferred to Burma, March, 1883, and served as comptroller, and commissioner of paper currency for Rangoon; and class, financial department, April, 1885.

WELSH, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, assistant sessions judge, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Jan., 1885.

WEST, RAYMOND, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, F.R.G.S., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1856, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, officiating under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and acting judge and sessions judge; registrar, high court, Bombay, June, 1863; judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, June, 1872; judge of the high court, Bombay, Sept., 1873; on special duty as member of the law commission, Calcutta, April-Nov., 1879; vice-chancellor of the University of Bombay, Oct., 1886.

WESTERN, JAMES HALLIFAX, Major, R.E.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; assistant engineer public works department, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1863; Eastern Jumna canal, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, Ganges canal, June, 1868; superintendent of works, Betwa canal, Nov., 1881; transferred to Punjab as temporary superintending engineer, Sirhind canal, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, Nov., 1884; services lent to Egyptian government; retired, 1887.

WESTLAKE, SIDNEY ST. JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated in Germany, and at Cheltenham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1885; assistant collector in Sind, April, 1886.

WESTLAND, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and Wimbledon School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 10th Oct., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1867, officiating magistrate and collector, Jessore, Aug., 1868, officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1869, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1870; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Dec., 1870; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1873; accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nagpore circle, Dec., 1873; on special duty in the home department, Nov., 1875; inspector of local offices of accounts, Nov., 1877; accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878; acting comptroller-general and head commissioner, department of issue of state paper currency, April, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884, and again Nov., 1886; to England on special duty, April-Sept., 1884; member of finance committee, March, 1886.

WESTMACOTT, EDWARD VESEY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Jan., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was on famine relief duty, Jan., 1874; officiating commissioner Dacca division, Aug., 1882; on special duty for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system, Nov., 1882; magistrate and collector, and grade, March, 1883; services placed temporarily at disposal of financial department, Oct., 1883; officiating inspector-general of jails, March, 1884.

WESTROPP, GEORGE RALPH COLLIER, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1851; was employed under the military department, including service in Khandesh against the rebel leader Tantia Tope, 1858; adjutant, Sávántádi local corps, Feb., 1859; acting assistant magistrate in Ratnagiri, May, 1860; assistant to political superintendent, Sávántádi, Nov., 1862; assistant political agent, Kolhapur, 1865-1869; in charge Southern Mahárrátá Jágír states, 1869-1877; political superintendent, Sávántádi, and commandant of the local corps, Aug., 1877; deputed on special duty in the Savanur state in 1880.

WESTROPP, SIR MICHAEL ROBERT
Knight.—B.A., Trinity College, Dublin, 1838; called to the bar of Ireland, 1840, and to the bar of Bombay, 1854; authorised reporter, court of common pleas, Ireland, 1847-1850, and in the court of chancery, Ireland, 1850-1853; acting advocate-general, Bombay, 1856-57, and again, 1861-1862; remembrancer of legal affairs, Bombay, April, 1860, to Aug., 1862; member of the legislative council, Bombay, 1861-62, and again in 1863; puisne judge of the high court, Bombay, Aug., 1863, to April, 1870; chief justice, Bombay, April, 1870, to April, 1882.

WHALLEY, PAUL, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating junior secretary, and under secretary to government; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Dec., 1871, to Feb., 1872; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, in Oudh, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, Pilibhit, Nov., 1879; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Oct., 1883; author of 'A Collection of the Laws and Rules of the Non-Regulation Provinces.'

WHEELER, PERCY COTTERILL (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Jaunpur, Nov., 1882; author of 'Settlement Report of the Recent Revision of Records (1878 to 1886) in the Jaunpur districts.'

WHISH, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1886.

WHISHAW, JOHN CHARLES, M.D., Surgeon-Major, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 3rd Sept., 1858, and held various military medical charges up to 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, April, 1860; superintendent, central prison and district jail, Lucknow, Nov., 1867; also civil surgeon, Feb., 1868; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Oct., 1870, also ex-officio inspector-general of prisons, March, 1871; civil surgeon, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Lucknow, Oct., 1873, also in charge of meteorological observatory, Lucknow, Dec., 1877; retired, Feb., 1886.

WHITE, EDMUND, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, Feb., 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, April, 1880; also under secretary to government in the census department; on special duty in connection with census, Sept., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1882; director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, June, 1885; author of 'Report on the Census, N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1881.

WHITE, H. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 4th Dec., 1872; graduated B.A., London University, with French honours, in 1882.

WHITE, HERBERT THIRKELL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1878, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; on special duty, Rangoon, April, 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, Thayetmyo, April, 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, April-Sept., 1882, and again in 1883; officiated for various periods between 1880 and 1886 as assistant secretary, junior secretary, and secretary to the chief commissioner; also as director of agriculture, Aug.-Nov., 1884; secretary to the chief commissioner for Upper Burma, March, 1886.

WHITE, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Dec., 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Rajputana under the foreign department of the government of India as officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and acted as superintendent, Rajputana state railway police, and also held charge of the office of political agent, Jaipur; served again under the foreign department of the government of India, May, 1876, to Dec., 1881, in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and political agent, 3rd class, and officiated as resident (3rd class) and commissioner of Ajmere, May-Aug., 1878; also acted as general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity, Nov., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, July, 1883.

WHITE, JOHN HUBBARD, Colonel, R.E., Mint-Master, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, Nov., 1855; from June, 1856, served in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer (for irrigation); from May, 1865, to Feb., 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer and acting consulting engineer for railways, Bombay; acting superintending engineer, Feb., 1874; acting chief engineer, and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, June-Dec., 1874; transferred to financial department of government of India as acting mint-master, Bombay, June, 1876; rejoined the railway department, Feb., 1878; from March, 1879, served as mint-master and mint-engineer, Bombay.

WHITE, PHILIP JAMES, North-Western Provinces.—Signaller in telegraph department, July, 1854; was employed in various capacities in several government offices till outbreak of mutiny, when he served with a body of
volunteer horse and was present at various engagements; mutiny medal; deputy collector and deputy magistrate, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1858; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1859; from March, 1863, served in the Jhansi commission as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, and class, Jalna, Dec., 1879; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1885.

WHITESIDE, WILLIAM SOUTHEY, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy secretary to government, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting civil and sessions judge, small cause court judge of Cuddalore, 1866-67, and acting collector and magistrate; collector and magistrate of North Arcot, Feb., 1873, and subsequently at Tanjore; on special duty as member of the forest draft bill committee in Ootacamund, May, 1882; served on the board of revenue from Aug., 1882, in charge of the Inam department; acting president of the board of examiners, Nov., 1882; acted as director of revenue settlement and agriculture, and Inam commissioner, April-July, 1884; on deputation in the southern districts for reporting on working of Licence Tax Act, Dec., 1884; additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1886.

WHITEWAY, RICHARD STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of London, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting assistant secretary to government, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879; settlement officer, 3rd grade, on special duty at Aligarh, Nov., 1881; settlement officer, Ajmere and Merwara, Jan., 1883.

WHITMORE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, Dec., 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1885; district and sessions judge, Fureedpore, Sept., 1886.

WHITTEN, RICHARD JOHN, Salt Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service in Feb., 1862, as assistant patrol; deputy inspector, internal branch, Jan., 1867; on deputation to inquire into illicit manufacture of salt in Behar, 1869; personal assistant to commissioner of inland customs, Oct., 1869; collector of customs, Sept., 1871; on deputation to report on salt taxation in Sind, July-Aug., 1872; 1st grade collector, July, 1876; on deputation in Rajputana to report on salt sources in connection with proposed abolition of inland customs line, July-Oct., 1877; employed temporarily under government of Bombay in salt inquiries in Kutch and Kathiawar; deputy commissioner of inland customs, Dec., 1879.

WHITWELL, H. W., Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Service.—First Commission, 1886; officiating principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1872; acted as civil surgeon of Bheerbhoom, Julpigoree, and Monghyr, 1884-85; principal assistant to opium agent, Behar, Oct., 1885.

WHITWORTH, GEORGE CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sandicor School, Northwich, and Queen's College, Liverpool; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council, Jan., 1876; (pro tem.) under secretary to government in the public works department for relief purposes, Sept., 1877, to March, 1878; second assistant collector, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1886; author of 'The Theory of Relevancy for the purpose of Judicial Evidence,' and an 'Anglo-Indian Dictionary,' 1885.

WICKES, THOMAS HAINES, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by government of India as special assistant engineer, April, 1861; engineer to the suburban municipality, Calcutta, Jan., 1865; re-appointed as executive engineer, public works department, Bengal, Nov., 1865; on special duty in the famine districts, May, 1874, and in connection with the Eastern Bengal railway, April, 1875, also with the secretary to the government of Bengal, March, 1878; assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886.

WIGHT, JOHN KNOX, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Queen's Collegiate School, Trinidad, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1872, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, April, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; deputy commissioner, Sept. 1885.

WIGNER, JOHN M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's Lynn Grammar School; B.A. and B.Sc., London University; temporary clerk, India office, 17th July, 1862; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, July, 1885.

WILKINS, CECIL ASDELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating registrar, high court, April, 1880, and again from 1881 to 1884; on special duty in the high court, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, and grade, Beerbboom, April, 1886; compiled revised editions of the High Court's Rules and Orders, in 1881 and 1883.

WILKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India,
Jan., 1858; served with the Cawnpur field force, Feb.–March, 1858; studied at Thomason College, Roorkee, March, 1861, to Aug., 1862; served in the revenue survey from April, 1863, as assistant surveyor, and was employed in the Central Provinces, Punjab, Midnapur, Dearah, and British Burma surveys; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1878.

WILKINSON, Alfred Reginald, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal infantry.—First commission, 1860; from 10th July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; attached to the special police levy for service in Bhutan, Oct., 1864; on special duty at the presidency, June, 1866; personal assistant to the inspector-general of police, 1869 to 1881; promoted to 1st grade district superintendent, June, 1886; has also acted as deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and as deputy inspector-general.

WILKINSON, Francis Henry, Madras C.S.—Educated at Milton Abbas School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Feb., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as under secretary to government in the revenue department, Aug.–Nov., 1867; on special duty as arbitrator of boundary disputes, June, 1870; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Salem, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, June, 1882.

WILKINSON, Thomas Ormerod, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Chudleigh Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; officiated as registrar of the chief court in 1878, 1879, and 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Jan., 1887.

WILLIAMS, Albert, Bengal C. S., (Punjab)—Educated at Uppingham, Clifton, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1886, and was appointed assistant-commissioner, Punjab.

WILLIAMS, Edward C. S., Major-General, C.I.E., R.E., India Office.—Commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; arrived in India, 1850; adjutant of engineers, Fort William, and studying machinery in Calcutta mint, 1850; extra assistant secretary, military board, 1851; superintendent, iron bridge yard, Calcutta, 1851–52; served with the Pegu expedition, 1852–53, as adjutant of engineers and in charge of engineer park (medal and clasp); superintendent, Pegu topographical survey, 1854–56; principal, Civil Engineering College, Calcutta, 1856–59; member of senate, Calcutta University; acted as under secretary to government of India, public works department, for one year, during mutiny; principal, Thomason College, Roorkee, 1861–62; under secretary, government of India, public works department, 1863–69; member of Bengal sanitary commission; in charge of office of inspector-general of forests for one year; acting mint-master and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, 1867; deputy secretary, government of India, public works department (railway branch), 1869–74, and again, 1877–78; director of state railways, 1874–77; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; deputy government director of Indian railway companies, India office, March, 1880.

WILLIAMS, Fleetwood, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating political agent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1841; magistrate and collector, Bareilly, 1845; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Meerut division, 1857; retired in 1870.

WILLIAMS, George Robert Carlisle, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, acting deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886; author of 'An Historical and Statistical Memoir of Dehra Dun.'

WILLIAMS, Henry Clissold, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; from Nov., 1878, served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise, Assam, Sept., 1885; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886.

WILLIAMS, John Charles, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London, and Uppingham School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from Jan., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was specially deputed to Lucknow for the purpose of compiling and reporting on census, March, 1866; from May, 1875, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880.

WILLIAMS, Ralph King, Public Works Department, Central Provinces.—From Nov., 1860, to Feb., 1873, served in the office of the consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, as accountant and deputy controller, and was appointed assistant examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in 1872; served in Madras from Feb., 1873, to March, 1878, and was appointed deputy examiner, May, 1876; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in Calcutta, March to May, 1878, and subsequently in Madras, and at Lahore, March, 1880; examiner, 4th class, Indus valley state railway accounts, Aug., 1880; transferred to Nagpur, Central Provinces, March,
1885; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, April, 1885; examiner, North-Western railway accounts, Lahore, Jan., 1886; 2nd class examiner, Dec., 1886.

WILLIS, JOHN, Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 3rd Nov., 1862; junior book-keeper, Nov., 1868; assistant book-keeper, Dec., 1881.

WILLOCK, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th March, 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector; on special duty, Jan., 1876, as member of the salt commission; from March, 1879, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner, and acting commissioner (in 1884 and 1885), and was also employed in suppressing the disturbances in the Gudum Hills, May, 1879; acted as collector, magistrate, and agent in 1886.

WILLOUGHBY, MICHAEL WEEKES, Brigadier-General, C.S.I., Bo. S.C.—First commission, Bombay army, June, 1849; acted as secretary to government of Bombay in the military, marine, and ecclesiastical departments, from 21st May, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881.

WILLSON, J., M.A., Bengal Educational Service (Assam).—Arrived in India, and Jan., 1870; Professor, Cathedral Mission College, Calcutta, Jan., 1870; assistant, geological survey of India, Sept., 1871, to Feb., 1873; professor, Hooghly College, March, 1873; Dacca College, Jan., 1874; Patna College, May, 1875; 3rd class of the education department, Aug., 1878; from Jan., 1879, served in Assam as inspector of schools.

WILSON, ARTHUR.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1878.

WILSON, CHARLES, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and University College, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1886; served in the N.P. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

WILSON, DAVID, M.A., Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Hutcheson's Grammar School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1886; served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

WILSON, GEORGE HERBERT DASHWOOD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 26th Nov., 1863, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1880; senior collector, Broach, May, 1885.

WILSON, JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Perth Academy, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, April, 1879, and again, Oct., 1880, in the civil secretariat; officiating under secretary to government, July, 1881, and again in 1884; on special duty at Simla for the purpose of writing the final report on the Sirsa settlement, Aug., 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, April-May, 1886; author of 'A Code of Tribal Customs in the Gurgaon and Sirsa Districts.'

WILSON, JOHN HATTON, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Probationary assistant engineer, 5th March, 1856; served in the public works department in the Central Provinces, and temporarily in Oudh, 1865-67, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; temporarily transferred to military works branch, July, to Sept., 1879; in charge of the Nagpore and Chattisgarh railway reconnaissance survey division, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, and transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Dec., 1885.

WILSON, ROBERT HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating registrar-general of assurances, Sept., 1870; also officiating marriage registrar, Calcutta; officiating under secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1870; inspector of registration offices, July, 1872; officiating inspector-general of registration, Sept., 1872; officiating secretary, board of revenue, July, 1877, and again in 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, Aug., 1884; employed under the public works department on the commission in connection with the Orissa canals, Nov. 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Feb., 1886; on special duty with the finance committee, 1886.

WILSON, THOMAS CORBY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, Central Provinces; acting district superintendent of police, Hoshangabad, Sept.-Nov., 1884; assistant settlement officer, June, 1886.

WILSON, WILLIAM, M.A., Madras C.S.—Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna, Feb., 1874, and collector and magistrate, June, 1877; on special duty for compiling irrigation accounts, Nov., 1875, and again, Oct., 1879, and Aug., 1881; acting director of revenue settlement, April, 1878, to Sept., 1879; collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Oct., 1879, to Aug., 1881; collector, magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1882; acted as member of the board of revenue in 1882, 1883, 1884; director of revenue settlement, and agriculture, Nov., 1882; in charge of the Inam department, March, 1883; also an additional member, board of revenue, April, 1883; permitted to visit on duty agricultural institutions in N.W. Provinces, and Bombay, Nov., 1883; fellow of Madras Universi-
WILSON, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1857, and was employed on military duties till April, 1864, when he was appointed acting assistant political agent, Sádra; from Nov., 1864, served as assistant superintendent of police, subordinate magistrate, superintendent of railway police on Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway, and district superintendent; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, June, 1883; acted as commissioner of police for city of Bombay, Oct., 1885 to June, 1886.

WILSON, WILLIAM HERBERT, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.G.S. (Heidelberg), Education Department, Madras.—Served from 4th Feb., 1875, as professor of physical science, Presidency College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class, education department, June, 1882; registrar of Madras University, March, 1886.

WILTSHIRE, CHARLES PALMER BLUETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, City of London School, King's College, London University, and Middle Temple; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting port officer at Karwar, and superintendent, timber depot, Canara; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873; on famine duty, Dharwar, in 1876 and 1877; in charge of Huzur treasury in 1880 and 1881; 1st assistant collector, Sept., 1886.

WIMBERLEY, REGINALD JUSTUS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Ensign, 3rd Bengal European regiment, 1859; served in the Punjab police force, Dec., 1861-67; commissariat department, March-Aug., 1867; from Aug., 1867, to 1872, served in Bengal as district superintendent of police; in command of police force to quell insurrection in the tributary Mehals, May, 1868; 1st assistant superintendent, Port Blair and Nicobars, April, 1872; called to the bar, Inner Temple, Nov., 1877; deputy superintendent, Dec., 1884.

WINCHESTER, CHARLES BLAKE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting forest settlement officer, and acting junior collector and political agent; on famine duty, Sept., 1877; and assistant collector, Nov., 1886.

WINCHESTER, E. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 16th Dec., 1872; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

WINGATE, ANDREW, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, Kensington Grammar School, University of London, and University of Heidelberg; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Bombay administration report for 1874-75, and for 1875-76; in political charge of the Jath state, Feb.-Sept., 1876; additional secretary in the famine department under chief commissioner of Mysore, Aug., 1877; assistant secretary to famine commission, Aug., 1878; settlement officer in Oodeypore state, Aug., 1879; officiating resident, Meywar.

WINGFIELD, SIR CHARLES JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.B.—Educated at Westminster School, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1839; arrived in India, March, 1840; served in the revenue and judicial departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; on the annexation of the kingdom of Oudh in 1856, was appointed commissioner of the trans-Gogra division, and was actively engaged in the suppression of the mutiny, 1857-59; chief commissioner of Oudh, March, 1859; C.B., 1860, and K.C.S.I., 1866; retired, 1866; sat in parliament for the borough of Gravesend, 1868 to 1874.

WINNY, THOMAS H.—Appointed assistant to the surveyor and clerk of the works, India Office, Aug., 1885.

WINTER, EDGAR FRANCIS LATIMER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WINTER, HENRY EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and King's School, Canterbury; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement and demarcation officer, Poonah districts, Jan., 1883.

WINTERBOTHAM, HENRY MARTIN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting Malayalam translator to government, March-Dec., 1877; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, June-July, 1883; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate, and as district and sessions judge in various districts.

WISE, FRANCIS JOHN, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd May, 1857; employed on military duties till Oct., 1863, including service in the Deccan against the rebel Bhils in 1857; and in Khandaish and Nimar against the rebel army under Tantia Topee in 1858-59; served subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; also served as boundary commissioner, and assistant political agent, Khandaish; member of committee to report to government on system of rural administration, July, 1873; on special duty on western frontier of Karachi district, Feb., 1875; on special duty in attendance on H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; member of the railway robberies inquiry committee, Bombay, March-Aug., 1878; superintendent of Great Indian Peninsula railway police, June, 1878; on special duty, June, 1879, to June, 1880; 1st grade superintendent, May, 1882; acting inspector-
general of prisons, May-Aug., 1884; inspector-general of police for the Bombay presidency, Jan., 1885.

WODEHOUSE, Charles, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, March, 1857; arrived in India, 6th April, 1857, and was employed under the military department, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857-58 (medal and clasp for Central India); from March, 1867, served as boundary settlement commissioner, Baroda; from Sept., 1868, acted in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, director of public instruction, and small cause court judge; acting assistant resident, Hyderabad, April to Nov., 1870; acting cantonment magistrate and judge, Secunderabad, Dec., 1870; acting assistant resident, Baroda, Jan., 1873; acting political agent, Rewa Kántha, Feb., 1873; from March, 1873, served in Káthiáwar as political assistant, acting judicial assistant, and acting political agent, and was placed on special duty for the settlement of boundary disputes in the Gheer forest, July, 1874; also acted as private secretary to the governor of Bombay from May, 1876, to April, 1877; political agent, Mahi Kántha, Sept., 1881; 2nd grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, April, 1885.

WOODEHOUSE, Sir Philip Edmund, K.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Writer, Ceylon civil service, May, 1828; assistant colonial secretary, and clerk of the executive and legislative councils, Oct., 1833; district judge of Kandy, 1840; government agent for the Western Province, 1843; superintendent of Honduras, 1851; governor of British Guiana, 9th Feb., 1854; employed on a special mission to Venezuela, Feb.-May, 1858; C.B., May, 1860; governor and commander-in-chief of the Cape of Good Hope and its dependencies, and Her Majesty's high commissioner for the settling of the affairs of the territories adjacent to the eastern frontier of that colony, 28th Oct., 1861; K.C.B., July, 1862; governor of Bombay, 6th May, 1872, to 30th April, 1877; G.C.S.I., June, 1876.

WOLFE-MURRAY, Francis D'Arcy Osborne, Madras C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, acting principal assistant collector, assistant sessions judge, forest settlement officer, and sub-collector and joint magistrate.

WOLLASTON, Arthur N., C.I.E., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Stockwell Grammar School; entered the India office by open competition as writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, political and secret department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1873; assistant secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Jan., 1884; in 1877 published a translation of the 'Anvar-i-Suhaili' or Poems of Bidpai; in 1879 edited Sir Lewis Pelly's miracle play of 'Hasan and Husain'; appointed to succeed Sir F. J. Goldsmid as examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, 1880; selected in 1881 by the science and art department to superintend the translation of the oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum; in 1882 published an English-Persian dictionary (the first of its kind); C.I.E., 1st Jan., 1886.

WOMACK, Arthur Shaw, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to the Central Provinces, July, 1885, and served as assistant commissioner, and registrar of the judicial commissioners' court.

WOOD, Edward Septimus, Captain, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland highlanders, 20th Sept., 1857; from Dec., 1859, served in the public works department on irrigation works, N.W. Provinces; officiated as conservator of forests, 1864-66; reverted to his regiment, Feb., 1866; appointed executive engineer, 4th grade, March, 1867; from April, 1867, served in the forest department, Oudh, and was appointed conservator, Oct., 1868; promoted to 2nd grade, Sept., 1882.

WOOD, G. P., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough, and Addiscombe; writer, India office, 25th Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

WOOD, Henry Mackenzie Macdonald, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; also district judge.

WOODBURN, Archibald Francis, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; also acted as forest settlement officer, and as junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, June, 1885.

WOODBURN, John, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Feb., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating personal assistant, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1870; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, in the Oudh revenue department and forest branch, Jan., 1882; also in the Oudh political department, March, 1882; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, judicial department, May, 1884; acted as chief secretary in 1884-86.

WOODCOCK, Elborough Martin, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 9th March, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); appointed to Oudh military police, 27th Nov., 1858; from March, 1860, served in the police department as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

WOODWARD, Hillersden, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Bir...
mingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting railway magistrate; on special duty in connection with the Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, Dec., 1882, and again, Aug., 1883; forest settlement officer, Sholapur, Nov., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1884; second assistant collector, May, 1885.

WOODWARD, WILLOUGHBY, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting magistrate of police at Bombay, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Aug., 1881; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, March, 1886.

WOOTTON, J. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 20th Feb., 1872.

WORDSWORTH, WILLIAM, C.I.E., M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational service, May, 1861; arrived in India, 10th July, 1861, and served as head-master of the Elphinstone Institution, Bombay, acting professor of history in the Elphinstone College, and assistant inspector of schools; from May, 1862, served as principal of the Deccan College, Poona, and also acted as professor of English literature; from June, 1872, acted as principal of the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and was also appointed to select the government records at the secretariat; confirmed as principal of Elphinstone College, and professor of logic and moral philosophy, Nov., 1874; principal, and professor of history and political economy, from June, 1878; also sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

WORGAN, JOHN BERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; from May, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879.

WORSLEY, CHARLES FORTESCUE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; on special duty, Dec., 1873 (famine), and in Nov., 1882, for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system; additional commissioner of Patna, Dec., 1884.

WORSLEY, F., Political Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, savings bank department, general post-office, April-Dec., 1868; writer, marine department, board of trade, July, 1870, to July, 1874; writer, India office, 13th July, 1874; clerk specially attached to political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

WRIGHT, FRANCIS NELSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1864; from Dec., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from May, 1870, to April, 1878, in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1876; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878, and again, 1880-81; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1885; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Meerut, April, 1885; author of a memorandum on the 'Agriculture of Cawnpore,' 'Cawnpore Gazetteer,' 'Cawnpore Settlement Report,' and 'Report on Wheat.'

WRIGHT, FREDERICK, Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, 20th Aug., 1859; served as inspector in the Madras police from Jan., 1860; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1862, and served as assistant superintendent and district superintendent of police (1st grade, April, 1877); officiating inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, July-Oct., 1884, and again in 1885; author of 'Margpradurshuk' (a treatise on the Indian Penal Code, 1878), a police manual of laws in 1883, and a schedule to all the penal acts of the government of India, 1841 to 1883.

WRIGHT, FREDERICK C. B., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 4th July, 1867.

WRIGHT, JAMES McCALLUM, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Educated at Fordyce School, University of Aberdeen, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, and Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces.

WRIGHT, JAMES WALKER, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the public works department in July, 1859; served in the Punjab as assistant and executive engineer; in charge of Madhopur workshops, March, 1868; executive engineer, military works, Chakrata road, and afterwards in the Jullundur division, 1872; transferred to the Punjab provincial list, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, and class, July, 1886.

WRIGHT, WILLIAM H., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Appointed to the education department by secretary of state, 7th Aug., 1867, and served from 7th Dec., 1867, as professor, Benares College; professor of English literature, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1872; 3rd grade of educational officers, July, 1872; principal, Bareilly College, Dec., 1873; officiating inspector of schools, June, 1875, to March, 1876; from Jan., 1877, served as professor at the Muir Central College, and officiated as principal of the Benares College, in 1878; has published a handbook of the education department, an account of the Muir Central College, and various educational works.

WYER, FREDERICK, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiated as commissioner of the Burdwan division in 1883; and of the Dacca division, in 1885.

WYER, THOMAS ROWLAND, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, and in acting appointments as joint magistrate, magistrate and collector, small cause court judge, and district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

WYLIE, HENRY, Major, C.S.I., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Oct., 1861; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1861; served with various regiments, and took part in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1863, the Yusafzai expedition (medal and clasp), the Bhutan Campaign, 1865 (clasp), the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal), and the Hazara campaign, 1868 (clasp); on special duty in Beloochistan, with Major R. Sandeman, Nov., 1875, to Feb., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, 1877; served in the Afghan campaign, 1878-80 (medal); C.S.I., Feb., 1881; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, Feb., 1885; political agent, Jhalawur, April, 1885.

WYLLIE, WILLIAM HUTT CURZON, Captain, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 106th Foot, Oct., 1866; arrived in India, Feb., 1867; served in the Oude commission, 1870-1879, as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment and city magistrate; staff corps, 1868; acted as inspector-general of registration in 1875, and as junior secretary to government, Oude, 1876-77; from Jan., 1879, served under the foreign department, government of India, as cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, assistant commissioner in Merwara and Ajmere, and as assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan; served in Madras, 1880-81, as military secretary to the governor, and acted as private secretary; C.I.E., May, 1883; political agent, 3rd class, in political charge of ex-Gaekwar of Baroda, Mulhar Rao, 1881; assistant resident, Hyderabad, 1882; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Nov., 1883; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1884; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, April, 1885.

WYNCH, LIONEL MALING, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

WYNNE, SYDENHAM HENRY, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Naval School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Oct., 1882.

YELD, HORACE PARR, Surgeon-Major, Mint Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1874; was employed in the military department up to Aug., 1884, when he was appointed probationer in the assay department, Bombay mint; transferred to Calcutta mint, Sept., 1884; surgeon-major, March, 1886; deputy assay-master Bombay mint, May, 1886.

YOUNG, GEORGE GORDON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from June, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1877; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Jan., 1881, and subsequently in the Jullundur division, April, 1883.

YOUNG, WILLIAM, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Basti, March, 1875; was subsequently posted to Mainpuri, Moradabad, and Muzaffarnagar; civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Bareilly, Oct., 1880; and afterwards at Allahabad; judicial commissioner, Oudh, Aug., 1886.

YOUNG, WILLIAM MACKWORTH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating secretary to financial commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; attached on special duty to office of financial commissioner, Oct., 1872; under secretary to government, Punjab, Oct., 1873; settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1875; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1878; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1878; secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ARTHUR DELAVAL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Clifton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, acting talukdari settlement officer, and assistant political agent.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ROMER EDWARD, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1885; acted as junior secretary and as senior secretary to financial commissioner; confirmed as junior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1886.

YULE, HENRY, Colonel, C.B., Council of
India.—Second lieutenant, Bengal Engineers, Dec., 1838; appointed to survey duties in the Cossya Hills, Jan., 1841; assistant superintendent of Delhi canals, 1843; officiating executive engineer, northern division, Ganges canal, June, 1846; served with the army of the Sutlej in 1846, and with the army of the Punjab in 1848-49, and was present at the action of Ramnugar, the passage of the Chenab, and action of Sadoollapore, and the battle of Chilianwallah; deputed to report on protective measures necessary in the mountain passes of Arakan towards Burmese frontier, Jan., 1853; deputed to report on batteries for protection of Singapore harbour, August, 1853; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Feb., 1854; deputy secretary (afterwards changed to under secretary) to government of India, public works department, Feb., 1855; deputed to proceed to Ava as secretary of the mission under Major (afterwards Sir Arthur) Phayre, July, 1855; garrison engineer, Allahabad, July, 1857, and extra superintending engineer in the N.W. Provinces, with charge of construction of defensive works at Allahabad, Benares, and Mirzapore, Aug., 1857; reappointed under secretary, public works department, Sept., 1857; officiating secretary, public works department, Nov., 1857; appointed secretary to government of India, public works department, with official rank as lieutenant-colonel, Jan., 1859; retired with honorary rank of colonel, March, 1862; from Oct., 1875, has served on the council of the Secretary of State for India, of which he is a permanent member; author of various geographical and other works; gold medallist of Royal Geographical Society, 1872, and of the Italian Geographical Society, 1871; president of the Hakluyt Society; president of the Royal Asiatic Society, 1885-86; hon. LL.D. of the University of Edinburgh, 1884; hon. fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and of the Scottish Society of Antiquaries; foreign or hon. member of the Geographical Societies of Paris, Berlin, Italy, &c., and of various other foreign and colonial societies.
HARRISON AND SONS beg to observe that Orders can only be taken conditionally, and subject to the fluctuations of the market.
